1 of 211 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January 21, 1991


House Africa Leader Changes


LENGTH: 214 words


Howard Wolpe (D-MI), who has chaired the subcommittee on Africa in the House of Representatives for the past decade, has stepped down to take over a Science, Space and Technology subcommittee. Mervyn Dymally (D-CA) is slated to replace Wolpe. Aides say Dymally was urged to take the post by fellow members of the Congressional Black Caucus.

Dymally has taken an active interest in various African issues and was an active proponent of the South African sanctions bill adopted in 1986.

Dymally has chosen Stan Smith, staff director of the international operations subcommittee the Congressman chaired, to head the Africa subcommittee staff. He will replace Steve Weissman, who directed the staff during Wolpe's chairmanship. Africa policy groups say the departure of the current staff will leave a void on Capitol Hill, where they earned respect for energetic activity on a range of Africa-related issues.

Somalia On the brink: Efforts by opponents of President Mohammed Siad Barre to oust the aging leader faltered this month, despite heavy fighting in and around the capital Mogadishu.

Although Siad may still be forced to relinquish power, his hold on the reigns has been boosted by deep rifts between opposition groups, which are divided along clan lines.


LOAD-DATE: March 1, 1991


LANGUAGE: English

2 of 211 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January 21, 1991


DIPLOMACY WORKED


LENGTH: 176 words


The Algerian news agency announced this month that the government of Mali and representatives of Touareg nomads have signed an agreement to end the fighting that killed hundreds of people last year.

Many African countries have difficulty dealing with wandering peoples who have little regard for national borders, and Malian Touareg have long complained of unfair treatment by the government in the south. 

Tensions increased last June and July when Touareg who had been in refugee camps in neighboring countries since the severe droughts of the 1970s began to return to Mali. The returnees demanded a larger share of the impoverished country's development aid. Government officials labeled them "Libyan-trained bandits."

In the Algerian-mediated talks, the government reportedly agreed to give two Touareg areas in northern Mali a special status amounting to "internal autonomy." Other details of the accord were not released.

The foreign ministry in Algiers issued a statement saying that "Algeria rejoices in this happy outcome."


LOAD-DATE: March 1, 1991


LANGUAGE: English

3 of 211 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January 21, 1991


THE SECOND TIME AROUND


SECTION: BITS AND PIECES


LENGTH: 353 words


For the second time since its independence from Portugal in 1975, Mozambique has abolished the death penalty.

The abolition took effect on November 30 when a new constitution, which also introduced a multiparty system, came into force.

Capital punishment was disavowed by the Frelimo party when it took power from Portugal. But death sentences were reintroduced in 1979 in response to mounting atrocities and terrorist attacks by Renamo rebels. From 1979 to 1986, 78 people were executed, for violent crimes such as murder and terrorism as well as certain economic offenses. 

Officials said they hoped the existence of the death penalty would act as a deterrent to crime. But the government never became comfortable with capital punishment, and the penalty has not been used for the last four years.

Mozambican officials began to say that there was no evidence that the death penalty had prevented terrorism or other offenses. Some argued that executions tarnished Frelimo's historic belief in the possibility of rehabilitation, even for vicious criminals.

An editorial last June 13 in the Maputo newspaper Noticias welcomed the absence of a death penalty in the draft constitution that was being circulated for public comment. "We have so short a time to live," the paper said, "that we should not shorten it any further. Rather, we should teach each other to live better and accept each other in harmony and tolerance."

Last September, in a speech to an Amnesty International forum in Havana, Judge Abdul Carimo Issa signaled Mozambique's intention to reabolish the death penalty formally. The people of Mozambique, the judge said, believe "that life is an immeasurable good to be preserved in the name of all civilization and the highest values of a society, and that other means can be used to achieve that which capital punishment showed, in practice, that it cannot achieve: peace, harmony, respect for human life and stability."

In October, the National People's Assembly added article 70 to the draft constitution: "In Mozambique," it states, "there will be no death penalty."


LOAD-DATE: March 1, 1991


LANGUAGE: English

4 of 211 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January 21, 1991


SOUTH AFRICA ALL-PARTY MEETING AIRED


LENGTH: 480 words


The balance of forces in South Africa has "shifted irrevocably" in favor of the African National Congress (ANC) and its allies, ANC Deputy President Nelson Mandela said in a major policy statement earlier this month. The white-led government has been "obliged," Mandela said, to accept "the inevitability of a negotiated resolution" of the country's problems.

Speaking for the national executive committee of the ANC, Mandela called for convening an all-party congress, drawn from all segments of society, to undertake the constitution-writing process and to oversee the transition to democratic rule. 

At the ANC national consultative conference in mid-December, delegates endorsed a resolution accusing the government of a "deliberate attempt" to "destabilize the ANC and sow terror and chaos."

Shortly after the conference ended, President F.W. de Klerk responded, saying in a nationally televised speech: "We shall not capitulate to radical pressure and we shall not shrink from using all available resources to ensure stability."

Mandela pledged the ANC to a "program of liaison with all relevant political organizations," in order to seek an end to large-scale fighting in the country. He called on all groups, specifically mentioning the Inkatha Freedom Party, led by Gatsha Buthelezi, to cooperate "in good faith to save the lives and property of the people."

Major General Bantu Holomisa,

who like Buthelezi heads one of the black homelands created by the government's apartheid policy, said in an interview that he fears that Mandela's appeal to Inkatha will not be heeded, since there are forces inside the government's security apparatus promoting division and distrust.

Holomisa leads the ruling military council in Transkei, which was the first of the homelands to be given nominal independence by Pretoria in 1976. Since seizing power in December 1987, he has moved to distance his administration from the government in South Africa and has repealed security laws and other restrictions on free expression. "Transkei has been a catalyst in the change that is taking place in South Africa," Holomisa says. "We introduced dramatic changes even before Mr. de Klerk announced his reform program and released Mr. Mandela in February."

Holomisa says the Transkei is now well-placed to promote unity among competing political movements, particularly the two largest and oldest organizations, the ANC and the Pan-Africanist Congress (PAC). Only in the Transkei have leaders of these two groups come together and jointly addressed mass rallies, he says.

Although he is ready to represent Transkei in any all-party meeting, Holomisa firmly rejects any idea that the territory could or should remain separate from the rest of South Africa. "I see no future for any homeland; they are neither economically nor politically viable," he says.


LOAD-DATE: March 1, 1991


LANGUAGE: English

5 of 211 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January 21, 1991


DEBY TAKEOVER USHERS OUT LIBYAN "CONTRAS'


LENGTH: 1022 words


A sensitive American intelligence operation directed against Libyan leader Muammar Qaddafi was apparently aborted last month by the unexpectedly swift seizure of power in Chad by Idriss Deby. Deby and his Patriotic Salvation Movement (MPS) swept into the capital N'Djamena on December 1, sending President Hissein Habre fleeing for his life.

Situated in the center of northern Africa and bordering seven other nations, Chad has been the focus of an international scramble involving the United States, France, Libya, and several other African nations. But neither France -- with 1,000 troops stationed in Chad, nor Libya -- despite a history of active involvement in Chad's affairs -- took any direct action when Deby assumed control. 

One of the new leader's first actions was to free Libyan prisoners of war captured during the frequent clashes between Habre's army and Libyan forces in the 1980s. Libya sent several aircraft to ferry the freed POWs to Tripoli.

But one group of Libyans -- members of a specially trained unit housed in a secret camp six miles north of N'Djamena -- did not join in the repatriation. Instead, they were hastily airlifted by U.S. military planes first to Nigeria and then on the Zaire.

According to authoritative sources, these evacuees -- thought to number about 700 -- were Libyan defectors belonging to the Libyan National Liberation Army (LNA). This "contra" force is believed to have received instruction in sabotage and guerilla infiltration from U.S. intellengence agents and to have launched attacks inside Libya from Chad territory. The LNA has served as the military wing of the anti-Qaddafi National Front for the Salvation of Libya, created in 1981, many believe by the Central Intelligence Agency (CIA).

Deby denies receiving Libyan backing for his takeover, but Western officials believe he did receive arms and money from Qaddafi. Africa Confidential in London reports that Deby obtained Libyan aid in exchange for information about the CIA operation. As a former Chad armed forces commander-in-chief, Deby was in a position to have inside knowledge of what the "contras" were doing.

Deby fled Chad in early 1989, fearing that Habre was planning to accuse him of fomenting a coup.

When the U.S. Air Force planes began the evacuation, Deby said the Libyans had been offered a choice of remaining in Chad as refugees or leaving, and U.S. officials say that everyone in the group went voluntarily. However, according to the London-based Middle East International, Red Cross officials were not allowed free access to the men before they were flown out.

Libya responded angrily to the U.S. airlift, demanding an emergency session of the United Nations Security Council and even asking Iraq to send some of the American "human shield" hostages to be used to exchange for its nationals' return.

Why the Nigerians agreed to accept the LNA "contras" is unclear. Although Nigeria and Libya have been at odds over Liberia, the two countries have reasonably good relations. General Ike Nwachukwu, the Nigeria minister of external relations, was quoted as saying the Libyans had been accepted on humanitarian grounds.

The decision to re-transport the group to Zaire was less surprising, given the historically close relationship between President Mobutu Sese Seko and the CIA. Zaire could be a logical base of operation if the U.S. intended to keep the force together as a fighting unit to oppose Qaddafi.

But according to UPI, the request for transfer of the "contras" to Zaire was made by Libyan Foreign Minister Mohammad Ibrahim Bishari, on a visit to Kinshasa on December 13. Libya offered Mobutu oil shipments with payment deferred until 1992, the news agency said.

Mobutu then announced that the U.S.-trained Libyans would be free to go home if they wished. Zaire also turned down a request for asylum from Habre, who has remained in Senegal.

Until his ouster became inevitable, Habre had been asking France to come to his aid, as happened on several occasions since he seized control of N'Djamena in 1982.

But French discontent with Habre had been growing, fueled by steady reports of malfeasance and evidence of widespread human rights abuses. As Deby's MPS forces advanced towards N'Djamena, the French limited their military involvement to protection of French citizens.

Washington took its cue from Paris. The American embassy in N'Djamena said that as a result of French assurances that Deby is "a patriot" and not a "Libyan agent," the U.S. is maintaining its $ 15 million aid program in the country.

Deby has stated his intention to establish a multiparty democracy, a challenging task. After 20 years of civil war, Chad is home to many competing factions -- and to an abundance of weapons. Following several outbreaks of shooting in the capital, Deby launched a house-to-house campaign to confiscate guns.

Habre has also taken steps to shore up relations with Chad's powerful neighbors. He has won a pledge of friendship from Nigeria to the west.

Deby has also mended fences to the east with Sudan, a Libyan ally where the new Chad leader enjoyed sanctuary when he fled from Habre two years ago. The office in N'Djamena of the Sudan People's Liberation Movement, which is fighting the Sudanese government, has reportedly been closed. And Sudan has offered landlocked Chad an outlet to the Red Sea.

But the greatest relaxation in tensions has been with Libya to the north. Chad and Libya are going ahead with the agreements to take their dispute over the uranium-rich Aouzou strip to the International Court of Justice at the Hague.

For many Africa observers, the chain of events surrounding Deby's coming to power suggests a possible shift in American priorities towards Africa. For the past decade, a principle tenet of U.S. policy has been opposition to what the Reagan and Bush administrations have termed "Libyan expansionism" on the continent.

Now, the staunchly pro-Western Habre has been replaced by someone with at least modest ties to Tripoli and neither Washington nor Paris seems very upset.


LOAD-DATE: March 1, 1991


LANGUAGE: English

6 of 211 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January 21, 1991


Nigeria's Timetable To Civilian Rule


LENGTH: 699 words


1990

* first quarter: drafting of party constitutions and manifestoes; registration of party members

* second quarter: party conventions at ward and local levels

* third quarter: party conventions at state and national levels; approval of manifestoes and constitutions

* fourth quarter: local government elections

1991

* first quarter: inauguration of local councils; launch of census

* second quarter: census

* third quarter: census

* fourth quarter: state executive and legislative elections; inauguration of state officials

1992

* first and second quarters: election of federal legislators and convening of a national assembly

* second and third quarters: presidential election; swearing in of the president and the end of armed forces control

Source: Newswatch magazine


 
Portuguese-speaking Countries

President Joao Bernardo Vieira of Guinea Bissau announced last month that the former Portuguese colony will hold its first multiparty presidential elections in 1993.

Between January 20 and 25, the African Party for the Independence of Guinea and Cape Verde, which has ruled since independence 15 years ago, will hold a national congress to debate the shift to a multiparty system.

Similar moves are taking place in other former Portuguese colonies. Sao Tome and Principe, a tiny west African island archipelago, scheduled multiparty presidential elections for March 3, following January 20 parliamentary voting. 

Another archipelago, Cape Verde, held parliamentary elections last week that swept the ruling African party for the Independence of Cape Verde from power.

In a process that has been underway since 1988, Prime Minister Pedro Pires conceded defeat after early returns gave the opposition Movement for Democracy (MPD) an estimated 65% of the vote. Presidential elections are set for February 17.

The primary distinction between the parties is their stance on foreign investment. Voters apparently were persuaded by the MPD's charges that the government had mishandled the economy. Cape Verde gets most of its income from foreign aid, and its biggest export is its citizens who go abroad to find employment. There are more Cape Verdeans away from the islands than the 300,000 who remain at home.

"Change" was the theme word for the campaign of MPD leader Carlos Veiga, a lawyer. That sentiment seemed to have more appeal than the government's claim to represent stability and continuity. Now Cape Verdeans face the prospect that Veiga may unseat President Aristides Pereira, a father figure for his role in overthrowing Portuguese colonialism. Pereira has won respect for his party's careful use of resources, its lack of corruption and its protection of human rights. But Veiga's message has been particularly popular among young people who don't remember the long struggle for independence.

The main issue in presidential elections may be the MPD's proposals for development of a tourist industry, which is sees as one of the few prospects for the arid islands to support themselves. Government officials worry about whether the economic policies of equity and fairness can survive unfettered development.


 
Mali

Among the countries still clinging to one-party rule, Mali is coming under increasing public pressure. Police in the capital, Bamako, said an estimated 20,000 demonstrators marched through the streets at the end of December to demand a multiparty system. Earlier this month, Bamako was paralyzed by the first general strike since independence three decades ago. The 48-hour action drew a government promise to meet with the National Union of Malian Workers to discuss demands.

The ruling Malian People's Democratic Union has strong pockets of resistence to sharing power. Nevertheless, many people expect that President Moussa Traore, who has held power since 1968, will agree to allow other parties in the near future.

Many Africans are hotly debating whether the continuing movement towards pluralism will guarantee effective democracy. But there is broad agreement that the move away from authoritarian rule is an essential first step -- and a promising beginning.


LOAD-DATE: March 1, 1991


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1991 AllAfrica, Inc.


7 of 211 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January 21, 1991


AGENDA DEMOCRACY


SECTION: AROUND THE CONTINENT


LENGTH: 1494 words


 

While war broke out in the Persian Gulf and violence flared in the Baltic Republics -- and Africa's regional conflicts either simmered or inched towards resolution -- much of the continent was taking quiet steps to satisfy the demands of pro-democracy movements. Following is a round-up of some of the developments.
 
Benin

The government of President Mathieu Kerekou, who last February was forced to fire his cabinet and replace it with a transitional government until elections could be held, has scheduled parliamentary balloting for February 17. Presidential elections will be held on March 10 and 24.

The nominally Marxist Kerekou has ruled Benin since 1972 when he seized power in a military coup. He is now no more than a caretaker president with little or no power. During the transition, the country is being run by a French-trained former World Bank executive, Nicephore Soglo. 

Last month, a system of multiparty democracy for the country received more than 90% approval in a public referendum. Some 64% of the voters said "yes" to a new constitution, and another 29% approved the document generally, but opposed a clause limiting the age of presidential candidates to between 40 and 70 years.

Many of those who voted "no" to the constitution said they feared it had too few safeguards against governmental abuses of power.

Some Africa watchers say Benin is a model of how autocratic rulers might relinquish power gracefully. Battered by growing opposition, the Kerekou government convened a national conference last February. While nearly 500 representatives from over 50 groups debated the country's future, Benin radio and television carried the nine-day event live.

Although the conference blamed the government for corruption, human rights violations and bringing the country to bankruptcy, it rewarded the president and his army for their cooperation by letting Kerekou retain his office until the elections.

"We don't want to give anyone a lesson, but what happened here is a test," said Soglo, after being named interim prime minister. "It shows you can move towards liberty without shedding blood."
 
Burkina Faso

Officials in Ouagadougou expected to finish by this week a census that began on January 5, designed to compile an electoral list of citizens over 17 years old. The actual age of voting eligibility for elections scheduled for late this year will be set by the end of the month, the government said.

Military leader Blaise Compaore promised to hold the multiparty vote -- the first in Burkina Faso since 1978 -- after public protests last year. A presidential ballot is set for November 3 and popular assembly delegates are to be chosen December 8.

Since Compaore agreed to elections, 15 political parties have emerged to put forth candidates.
 
Zambia

Newstead Zimba, the Secretary-General of the Zambia Congress of Trade Unions, has told President Kenneth Kaunda that Zambians want to see him "correcting the situation in your country first." Zimba was responding to Kaunda's peace mission to Iraq, days before the U.S. attack on Baghdad.

Three weeks ago, the trade union congress severed its ties with Kaunda's party and allied itself with the Movement for Multiparty Democracy (MMD), Zambia's main opposition party and one of six groups formed to contest elections scheduled for October. Zimba issued his challenge to Kaunda last week at an MMD rally attended by an estimated 50,000 supporters.

The party was made legal on January 4, after popular pressure forced Kaunda to agree to recognize competing groups. Kaunda's United National Independence Party (Unip) has ruled Zambia since independence from Britain in 1964 and has been the only legal party for 17 years.

In recent years, Kaunda's government has been buffeted by public discontent with the effects of the structural adjustment program mandated by the International Monetary Fund. Last June, 26 people protesting the economic austerity measures were killed by security forces. Resulting anger prompted an abortive coup, and Kaunda was seriously embarrassed by celebrations in the streets when the coup was initially reported to have succeeded.

The re-emergence of a multiparty system in Zambia has been troubled by accusations of unfairness from all sides. Last month Kaunda accused the MMD of planning a military coup. "Multiparty elements are going around recruiting soldiers to stage a coup if they lose in the 1991 elections," the president said.

Leaders of the MMD and other parties say it is Kaunda who is trying to manipulate the system to his advantage. They point to his arrest of political opponents and the banning of rallies. In December, Kaunda warned workers at the National Broadcasting Corporation that they are part of the "party machinery," and the president fired the editors of Zambia's two main papers, the Times of Zambia and the Zambia Mail. The veteran journalists, whose papers are owned by the ruling party and the government, respectively, were replaced by university lecturers known for their loyalty to the president. Kaunda also instructed government agencies to stop placing advertisements in the Catholic church-sponsored biweekly paper, the National Mirror, which has supported political pluralism.

For the moment, the opposition seems to have gained the momentum. Early this month, ruling party leaders were startled by the defection to the MMD of a Unip founder and former secretary-general, Humphrey Mulemba, who said he was unhappy with the lack of "democratic principles" in the governing party.

But any future leaders of Zambia will have to confront the country's formidable economic problems. Despite its copper reserves, Zambia is one of the continent's poorer countries and its per capita debt is one of the highest in the world. Because over 90% of the country's foreign earnings have come from copper, the decade-long slump in world commodity prices devastated Zambia's economy. Attempts to lessen its economic dependence on South Africa cost an additional $ 7 billion. So debt relief is bound to top the agenda for the winnerof this year's ballot.


 
Nigeria

Since the beginning of this month, Nigeria has been swearing in the 5,575 local council members elected in nationwide polls in December.

The voting process will culminate in presidential elections at the end of next year.

The local votes were a key step in Nigeria's multi-year transition from military to civilian rule. Africa's most populous nation has had military governments for all but a decade of its 30 years of independence. And the civilian governments that presided over Nigeria from 1960-1966 and again from 1979-1983 were popularly regarded as both corrupt and ineffective.

The weekly magazine Newswatch applauded the "wide acceptance of the results" of December's balloting as a watershed in the country's elusive quest for free and fair elections.

But to some observers the proceedings were marred by the low turnout -- as little as 10-15% in some places -- and by the fact that there was no secret ballot. Government officials defended the requirement that voters line up behind symbols of their candidate as necessary to prevent charges of fraud, a serious problem in past elections. Officials pledged that state and national elections would be by secret ballot, although recent government statements on the issue have been ambiguous.

In a further attempt to break with abuses of the past, the government banned all previous parties and decreed the establishment of two new ones -- the Social Democratic Party (SDP) and the National Republican Convention (NRC). The government also wrote manifestoes for the two groups, which are described as slightly to the left and slightly to the right of the political center.

Nigerian President Ibrahim Babangida said the two parties have the responsibility to usher in a "new breed" of politicians, beholden not to special interests but to their constituencies.

In the local polls -- where the issues were about things like schools and roads -- ideology was in little evidence. Nor was there an apparent trend towards a winner. SDP took 232 of 453 council chairs, and won 2,934 of the 5,575 councilorships -- a slight edge in numbers. But the NRC points out that it won a slight majority of all votes cast in the country's 21 states.

The next big challenge facing the Babangida government's transition program, according to journalist Tunde Obadina, will be the population census, scheduled for the second quarter of this year. Because the census dictates the apportionment of representation and resources, past attempts to count Nigeria's people have been plagued by tensions and even violence. The current estimate that the country has a population of 110 million is a projection from a 1963 census -- but that count, like every other in Nigeria's history -- has been fiercely disputed.


LOAD-DATE: March 1, 1991


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1991 AllAfrica, Inc.


8 of 211 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January 21, 1991


BEARING THE BURDEN


LENGTH: 538 words


LUANDA -- A walk down the streets of Angola's capital is a balancing act. The once black-and-white stone mosaic pavements, signature to former Portuguese rule, have broken down into an obstacle course of loose rocks, ditches and strewn debris.

Almost 70 percent of the national budget is funneled into the government's war effort against Unita (the National Union for the Total Independence of Angola), says Finance Minister Arguinaldo Jaime. There are few funds available for long-overdue maintenance of the city's ailing infrastructure. 

War has flooded Luanda with over a million refugees, uprooted from their rural homes by the fighting. An escalation in Unita sabotage late last year has regularly disrupted electricity and water supplies to the city, prompting a health crisis which the authorities have struggled to combat.

Ubiquitous streams of bucket-crowned women file along the streets performing a difficult balancing feat. It is they who must locate and transport the water their families require for normal daily life. One Unicef official here estimates that each of them spends an average of three hours daily on this task alone.

Most shops in the city are empty and locked. In the official lojas do povo (people's stores), where entry is restricted to ration card-holding Angolans who are formally employed, only sacks of dry beans and a few cans of dried milk powder sit on the mostly empty metal shelves.

By contrast, flourishing commerce can be found on the outskirts of the congested city. Roque Santeiro, named for the title character of a popular Brazilian television soap opera, is a prime example of the "parallel" market system that the government has come to accept as a fact of life in Angola's stagnant economy.

"Here at Roque you can get anything," boasts one marketer as she encourages passers-by to try her home-made cigarettes. Walking along the long rows of stalls, over layers of crushed imported beer cans and through partitions of dangling blue jeans, shoppers can find goods from all across the globe: cashews from Germany, chickens from Argentina and enough imported alcohol to flood the Bay of Luanda.

Markets are also the only place to find such otherwise unobtainable items as marriage licenses, airplane tickets, and even newspapers.

But of course all these goods have a price -- a very high price in comparison to official stores. A gallon jug of wine which sells for 200 kwanza ($ 6.50 at the official exchange rate) at the lojas do povo will bring about 8,000 kwanza ($ 266) at Roque. Although the unofficial value of the dollar is much higher than the official rate, a planned devaluation, part of the government's economic reform program, has yet to be implemented.

Only people with access to foreign currency have enough cash to make purchases at the markets. Most Angolans must resort to barter to afford what they need at Roque. Beer has become the unofficial medium of trade. One bottle or can buys a tank full of gasoline. Two crates can purchase a round-trip plane ticket to Rio de Janeiro.

Once again, it is mostly women who are in evidence, transporting up to three beer crates on their heads as they walk into the market to shop.


LOAD-DATE: March 1, 1991


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1991 AllAfrica, Inc.


9 of 211 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January 21, 1991


ANGOLA & MOZAMBIQUE: PEACE ON THE HORIZON?


LENGTH: 1003 words


After nearly three decades of almost continual conflict, hopes for peace in Mozambique and Angola have risen. Major hurdles stand in the way of final accords, but negotiation efforts have produced signs of movement towards a cease-fire in both countries.

Within a few weeks, Portuguese intermediaries hope to convene the sixth round of talks between the government of Angola and the Unita rebel movement headed by Jonas Savimbi. The session will be scheduled when both parties have agreed to terms of a settlement. 

Last month, in an attempt to break the logjam in the negotiations, U.S., Soviet and Portuguese officials met in Washington with representatives of both Angolan parties to draw up a draft accord. The meeting, at the State Department on December 13, followed an unprecedented tete-a-tete between Savimbi and then-Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevarnadze and a separate discussion between U.S. Secretary of State James Baker and Angolan Foreign Minister Pedro de Castro van-Dunem Loy.

Following the Washington meetings, Savimbi announced that Unita's leadership -- which had gathered in Washington -- had accepted the entire draft. The government negotiators returned to Angola to report to President Jose Eduardo dos Santos.

The accord calls for legalization of political activity within a multiparty system in Angola, international monitoring of the cease-fire, an end to all outside arms shipments, free and fair elections monitored by outside observers and an understanding on a firm date for a nation-al election prior to a cessation in hostilities. These points bridge many of the differences which have divided the two sides in months of previous discussions.

The government in Luanda has not issued a formal declaration on the Washington accord. And, with distrust remaining high, Unita and the government have been trading accusations, each blaming the other for delay. Following a high-level meeting at Unita headquarters in southeastern Angola, a Unita communique on January 8 reiterated support for the Washington accord and charged the other side with blocking a settlement.

But Luanda saw in the Unita communique what it regarded as new preconditions for peace. The document said the ruling MPLA should "present its proposed law on political parties at the next round of negotiations" and also asked that the U.S. and the Soviets become direct participants rather than observers in the negotiations. The government rejected both of these steps as infringements on its sovereignty and promised to respond "forcefully" to Unita maneuvers "designed to gain time."

Meanwhile, the intermediaries have been seeking to find a compromise on the election timetable issue, which appears to be the main obstacle to a cease-fire agreement. The government favors a three-year process while Unita wants a vote within 12 months. The formation of a new national army may also still be a sticking point, although compromise language is contained in the Washington accord.

U.S., Soviet and Portuguese officials have been meeting to forge other language, which they hope will be accepted by both parties.

Like the political negotiations, emergency relief operations have suffered from ups and downs which have left most of Angola's neediest people without adequate assistance. A United Nations food program launched late last year with U.S. backing has encountered numerous roadblocks, despite an agreement by both the government and Unita to allow shipments through contested areas. About 110,000 tons of food aid are required to meet the needs of 1.8 million civilians, the UN says.

In Mozambique, a new round of talks between government and the Renamo rebels are expected this month, following last month's agreement on a partial cease-fire. Under the December pact, 7,000 Zimbabwean soldiers, who had been fighting alongside Mozambique government forces, have withdrawn to the Beira and Limpopo corridors -- the narrow strips of land along which run the railways and highways linking land-locked Zimbabwe with the Mozambican ports of Beira and Maputo. The Zimbabwean troops are allowed to guard the corridors, but their movements are restricted to within three kilometers (1.8 miles) of the edge of the strips, and the Zimbab-weans are barred from offensive actions against Renamo units.

On January 10, an international commission established to oversee the partial cease-fire said Renamo rebels had apparently broken the pact. Heavy fighting reportedly took place near the Beira corridor when Renamo forces sought to take over positions evacuated last month by the Zimbabwean troops.

The membership of the 40-member monitoring commission includes the governments of Mozambique and Zimbabwe, Renamo and nine other nations chosen by the two sides -- four permanent UN Security Council members (the U.S., USSR, Britain and France), plus Congo, Italy, Kenya, Portugal and Zambia.

Following the partial cease-fire accord, talks between the government and Renamo resumed in Rome last month without any reported progress. Currently, the Italian government is seeking to identify and narrow the differences that prevent a full cease-fire accord. Already, the government has taken most of the steps Renamo has been demanding. A new pluralist constitution was adopted in November, and the parliament last month approved legislation creating a multiparty electoral system.

Nevertheless, the fighting continues, putting more and more Mozambicans at risk of serious privation. The two million people uprooted by war within the country are in most immediate danger, a report compiled by UN and government experts says. "Massive, direct, emergency assistance is needed now," according to the report, which was completed last month.

More than a million tons of food aid will be required this year, including 354,000 tons for free distribution to the totally destitute. The remaining 687,000 tons would be placed on sale in towns and rural areas, the report says.


LOAD-DATE: March 1, 1991


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1991 AllAfrica, Inc.


10 of 211 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January 21, 1991


SUDAN: A PLEA FOR SANCTIONS


LENGTH: 566 words


CAIRO-- "Everybody is living in fear," says Bishop Taban Paride, whose diocese in southern Sudan includes a large area of territory held by the Sudan People's Liberation Army (SPLA), which is fighting the Sudanese government.

At least once or twice a month, with no warning, bombs from high-flying government aircraft drop on villages and towns. "They just bomb any corrugated sheet building or anything at all -- they don't know," he says. People have become so scared that "everyone runs when any plane passes over," the Roman Catholic cleric says. 

As a result, church and community leaders have been urging people who don't have to live or work in town, especially children and women, to move far enough away to avoid the deadly explosives.

Bishop Taban was interviewed when he attended the African-American Conference here, organized by the African-American Institute in New York and co-hosted by the Egyptian government. The Sudanese bishop appealed for world attention to Sudan's plight and for international action to force a settlement of the conflict.

"We believe the kind of pressures and sanctions which were put on South Africa should also be put on the Sudan government," Taban said. "We need pressure from outside because the government will not listen to the voice of the suffering people."

Five to six million Sudanese are considered at risk of starving this year, according to international aid experts, and widespread deaths of children are already being reported. The UN says 1.3 million tons of food aid will be needed to offset the shortages caused by failing harvests in several parts of the country.

However, political problems have kept much of the food already donated from being distributed to those in need. The government of General Omar Hassan al-Bashir has blocked relief operations mounted by the UN and other agencies, fearing the supplies would help the rebel effort and that relief convoys would provide cover for the transport of military materiel.

On January 16, the United Nations postponed a visit to Khartoum by Under Secretary General James Jonah, who was to have discussed rellief operations with the government. The U.S. and other aid donors have been asking for assurances that supplies wil be distributed to those in need. But the al-Bashir government's ties with Iraq and its record of human rights abuses have complicated relations with Washington and other Western capitals.

According to Bishop Taban, the government's air war is being fought by Libyans. "We know because we have the wreckage of a Libyan plane lying outside the town, and the Libyan pilot was captured by the SPLA," he says.

The sporadic bombing of Taban's own town of Torit, which was captured by the SPLA in 1989, has disrupted almost all forms of normal daily life, he says. "We had established schools and several cooperatives with the women," says the bishop, "and rural projects as well. But this has all been interrupted by the bombing." At night, he says, there is free movement of people and even relief trucks in the area, but by day the overflying planes "harass and terrorize the people." The bombardment has made it impossible for people to cultivate, weed, or harvest their crops -- even in areas where rain has been sufficient for a good harvest. As a result, the food crisis is worsening, he says. "We are facing a disaster."


LOAD-DATE: March 1, 1991


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1991 AllAfrica, Inc.


11 of 211 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January 21, 1991


MILLIONS FACE SUFFERING


SECTION: HUNGER


LENGTH: 419 words


Famine is stalking several African countries where continuous wars have disrupted harvests and relief efforts and created hundreds of thousands of refugees. "About 20 million people in Africa will face starvation this winter unless food aid is provided immediately," six non-governmental international relief agencies said in a joint appeal earlier this month.

Aid is going to the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe, while Africa is being neglected, the agencies said. "Africa has slipped off the priority list because it is a creeping and continuous crisis with no easy solutions," Brian Neldner of Lutheran World Service told Reuters. "Our priorities must still be in Africa," said Paer Stenbaeck, secretary-general of the Red Cross League, who is chairing the steering committee set up by the six agencies. In addition to the Lutheran Federation and the League of Red Cross and Red Crescent Societies, the groups include Caritas, Catholic Relief Services, Oxfam and the World Council of Churches. 

The United Nations Food and Agricultural Organization (FAO) says 15 African countries confront "exceptional food emergencies" this year. The FAO has asked UN member states for an urgent response to the shortages.

The five most critically affected countries, according to the relief agencies, are all consumed by serious, long-lasting war. "Of most concern is the rapidly deteriorating situation in Sudan and the continuing food emergency in northern Ethiopia," the FAO says. Between two and three million people are threatened with starving or dying from thirst as fighting continues in Ethiopia (see Africa News, November 12, 1990). More than twice that many are considered at risk in Sudan.

Half of Mozambique's 16 million people face famine -- two million are threatened with immediate starvation -- as a result of the continuing war between the government and the Renamo rebel movement, according to a recent analysis by the UN and the Mozambican government. And nearly two million Angolans are at risk of starving due to conflict and drought.

In Liberia, year-long strife has forced some 800,000 people out of the country and left at least a million more homeless.

Other countries threatened by famine stemming from drought and other causes include Burkina Faso, Chad, Mali, Mauritania, Niger, Senegal and Tanzania. Zimbabwe, although it produces a food surplus, is dangerously short of vehicles to transport food to drought-stricken areas in five of the country's eight provinces.


LOAD-DATE: March 1, 1991


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1991 AllAfrica, Inc.


12 of 211 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January 21, 1991


EARLY GULF FALLOUT


LENGTH: 559 words


Before the January 16th attack on Iraq, the U.S. State Department issued warnings about possible dangers to Americans in African countries.

Citing security concerns stemming from the Gulf crisis, diplomatic missions in Algeria, Tunisia and Morocco were encouraged to evacuate all "non-essential personnel and dependents." Public opinion in the three countries was judged overwhelmingly sympathetic to Iraq. 

For Mauritania and Sudan, the department took the unusual step of making the departures obligatory.

In Nigeria, a dozen consular staff were evacuated from the northern town of Kaduna, where demonstrators converged on the U.S. mission last September after American troops were dispatched to Saudi Arabia. The State Department also warned U.S. citizens against travel to northern Nigeria, and urged Americans throughout the country to stock several days supply of food and water and to stay off the streets if tensions run high.

Nigeria's inspector-general of police, Alhaji Aliyu Atta, promised earlier this month that his forces will provide special protection against attack for all expatriates, including Americans.

Concerns about safety persisted, however, especially in the north, where the largely Muslim population is strongly pro-Iraq. Those sympathies proved embarrassing to British officials last September, when the British Broadcasting Corporation (BBC) conducted its annual audience polls for "Man of the Year 1990." Listeners to the BBC's Hausa service, broadcasting to northern Nigeria, overwhelmingly chose Iraqi leader Saddam Hussein.

Some analysts suggest that the sentiment is not so much pro-Iraqi as it is anti-American, fanned by the Gulf operation. Across the continent magazines and newspapers in many countries have printed letters from critics of U.S. policy and in some places there have been street demonstrations, apparently fueled by a belief that the U.S. is employing a double standard. Three issues that have prompted particularly bitter comments are:

* American political and military support for Morocco when it invaded neighboring Western Sahara in 1975, using historical arguments similar to those Saddam Hussein used to justify his claims to Kuwait;

* The Bush administration's refusal to intervene to stop the carnage in Liberia's civil war, despite pleas from a broad range of Liberians who argued that it was American aid that had kept the unpopular Doe regime in power after it lost the election of 1985 -- and despite the presence of four U.S. warships and 2,000 marines off the Liberian coast; and

* U.S. resistance to comprehensive sanctions against the South African government.

In the end, though, the dominant sentiment across Africa seems to be the fear that the Gulf war will further divert attention and resources from African crises. The January 14-20 issue of West Africa magazine notes the recent appeal by an international coalition of aid groups on behalf of the 20 million Africans now facing starvation. "We can now shift all attention to one figure -- the 500 million pounds which has been spent by the British government so far in the Gulf," the magazine says. "That amount could feed all those affected by the famine for five months. Add what the U.S. has spent so far, and is willing to spend, and the dimensions of the irony come into view."


LOAD-DATE: March 1, 1991


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1991 AllAfrica, Inc.


13 of 211 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January 21, 1991


GULF COSTS DRAIN AFRICA


LENGTH: 1181 words


The economic costs of the Persian Gulf crisis have been especially high in the non-oil-producing countries of Africa, where escalating petroleum prices have scuttled development plans and threatened lives.

The International Monetary Fund (IMF) estimates that every one dollar rise in the price of a barrel of oil adds an extra $ 100 million to the annual fuel bill of the least developed African nations. By October last year, the average price of a barrel of oil had risen to $ 35, up from an average of $17 inthe first half of the year. Projections for 1991 see even higher averages as a possibility. 

By the end of 1990, the added costs of African oil imports had reached an estimated $ 2.7 billion, putting new strains on energy and transportation systems that are already fragile.

At a time when African economies desperately need to be expanding, says Adebayo Adedeji, head of the United Nations Economic Commission for Africa (ECA), the lack of affordable fuel has restricted economic recovery. In non-oil-exporting countries, output growth rate has actually declined.

Across the continent, fuel costs to consumers have more than doubled. Ghana's Finance Minister, Kwesi Botchwey, told the Ghana News Agency that higher oil prices cost Ghana an additional $ 50-60 million in 1990, despite an aggressive energy conservation policy.

Eastern and southern Africa have been affected most severely. Except for Angola, which exports 80-90% of its oil to the United States, there are no significant oil resources in the region, although Zambia and Zimbabwe both have coal reserves.

In Namibia, the government's Equalization Fund -- used to stabilize imported fuel prices and ease disruptive fluctuations -- has been totally depleted.

Petroleum prices in Zambia have increased 400% since August, and shortages have led to long lines at fuel pumps, as has happened also in Uganda and Mozambique. Unofficial estimates put Zambia's current rate of inflation at 100%. In presenting the 1991 budget to parliament, Finance Minister Gibson Chigaga conceded that Zambia didn't meet most of its 1990 budget targets and has little chance of dealing with its $ 1.3 billion debt payment arrears to the World Bank and the IMF.

Most worrisome to international analysts is Mozambique, where a war waged by Renamo guerrillas against the government has aimed at the infrastructure of rural life. An estimated two million people who have been unable to plant or harvest crops would starve without continued emergency food distribution.

Because guerrilla attacks have destroyed much of the country's roads and rail lines and made remaining links unsafe, plentiful fuel supplies are necessary to supply rural areas with food by air. Peter Simkin, the top United Nations official in Mozambique, told the Reuter news agency that oil price hikes have raised the cost of transporting a ton of corn from $ 580 to over $ 1000.

In addition to the disruptive effect of higher prices, some of the region's development plans have been based on long-term contracts to purchase oil at concessional rates from Kuwait and Iraq -- supplies which are no longer available.

Although the ECA estimates that Africa's oil exporters may earn an extra $ 10.5 billion from higher prices, it warns against seeing "these temporary gains as signifying an end to the extremely difficult economic circumstances prevailing in many of the African oil-exporting countries."

Nigeria, reluctant to count on any oil price windfall, has based its 1991 budget on an average world price of $ 21 a barrel. At the same time, it haspledged to help its African neighbors, partly by providing discounted fuel.

In another attempt to ease the burden of higher prices, the U.S. in September organized 25 industrial countries into a group to aid nations severely affected by the price hikes. But most of the $ 13 million fund established by the group was earmarked for Middle East nations to encourage their compliance with sanctions against Iraq.

There have been other economic effects of the Gulf crisis as well. Across north Africa, governments obtain foreign exchange from citizens who work in the Gulf and send their wages home. Egypt, for example, depends on such remittances to purchase 40% of its imports. Although Egypt has suffered more directly than other African countries from declining traffic in the Suez Canal and a sharp drop-off in tourism, trade and tourism are down throughout the region. In addition, there is the cost of resettling the returning migrant workers. For Egypt, the bill for absorbing some 600,000 workers is expected to top $ 4.7 billion.

Bettino Craxi, a former Italian Prime Minister who is now the special representative on debt for UN Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar, has proposed an international moratorium on debt collection for the countries hit hardest by the crisis. Without substantial alleviation of its effects, Craxi said, the Gulf conflict "is likely to produce increased poverty and environmental degradation." Besides the negative growth rates the crisis will produce in Africa, Craxi predicted, African countries will have to further deplete their forest reserves to compensate for the loss of petroleum.

Although Africa's structural weakness makes substituting alternative energy supplies more difficult than in industrial countries, a conservation mood has gripped the continent. "We must courageously tighten our belts with a high sense of responsibility," Prime Minister Obed Dlamini of Swaziland told a November meeting of 18 east and southern African countries.

Ghana has demonstrated already that conservation measures can yield quick results. Using guidelines established by the Ministry of Fuel and Power and the National Energy Board, Ghanaian industries have seen substantial savings. In its own buildings, the ministry used 50%t less energy between July and November last year than during the same period the previous year.

If there is a silver lining for Africa, it may be that the resources of the continent will attract increased world attention to its problems. Millard Arnold, a senior associate at the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace, argued last month in a column for the Christian Science Monitor that the United States has ignored Africa's potential economic importance to the industrialized world. Arnold points out that the U.S. has been importing more oil from Angola and Nigeria than from Iraq and Kuwait.

Nigeria, America's fourth leading supplier, sells the U.S. nearly 900,000 barrels a day, compared with 698,000 from Iraq. Angola has averaged 264,000 barrels a day, more than twice the 106,000 that came from Kuwait before the invasion.

Arnold pleads for more U.S. support for Africa's struggling pro-democracy movements and for African countries' attempts to achieve economic stability. "Given the enormous stakes, policymakers need to consider most carefully our cavalier approach to Africa," Arnold wrote. "If things heat up in Africa, it may get very cold in New England."


LOAD-DATE: March 1, 1991


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1991 AllAfrica, Inc.


14 of 211 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January 21, 1991


MUBARAK SAYS AFRICA MUST NOT BE MARGINALIZED


LENGTH: 269 words


Calling Africa's economic and political problems "an inherent threat to world peace and stability," Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak says "it is high time" that the international community seek solutions and provide adequate assistance. A "collective" effort must be devised to "spare Africa" from being left out of the changing world order. 

Mubarak's remarks were made in a formal opening statement to the 21st African-American Conference, organized by the New York-based African-American Institute and co-hosted by the Egyptian government. The speech was delivered by Boutros Boutros Ghali, minister of state for foreign affairs, who served as co-chair of the meeting along with Rep. William Gray (D-PA), majority whip of the U.S. House of Representatives.

The four-day gathering of about 100 Americans and Africans was attended by cabinet ministers from a dozen African countries, members of the U.S. Congress and their aides, and business leaders, journalists and political figures from both continents.

During a 70-minute meeting with heads of delegations and other conference delegates at the presidential palace, Mubarak reiterated Egypt's concern about Africa's future and the negative impact the Gulf crisis is having on various countries across the continent. Mubarak, who chaired the 54-member Organization of African Unity in 1989, said Egypt was committed to its historical position as a "bridge" between Africa and the Arab world. The connection could be mutually helpful, he said, with Africa benefiting from Arab investments and Arab businesses profiting from expanded markets.


LOAD-DATE: March 1, 1991


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1991 AllAfrica, Inc.


15 of 211 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January 21, 1991


EGYPT PONDERS FUTURE


LENGTH: 1707 words


 

CAIRO-- Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak faced little public opposition to his decision to join the U.S.-led coalition against Iraq. But the Persian Gulf conflict has many thoughtful Egyptians -- among them senior Mubarak advisors -- concerned about the implications for the country's future.

In his statements and interviews, Mubarak conveys certitude

about his policy. "I am not a defender of the emir ¢of Kuwait/," Mubarak said in a 70-minute session with delegates attending the 21st African-American Conference here. "But we could never accept this aggression against another Arab state." 

After sending "more than 20 private messages" to Iraqi leader Saddam Hussein offering a face-saving way out of the crisis, Mubarak said he became convinced that force might be the only means of "restoring legitimacy" to Kuwait.

But at the same time, Mubarak has also signaled reservations about committing Egypt to actions which would shift the current balance of forces in the region irrevocably. "Mubarak really believes Saddam Hussein must be Tde-fanged'," one senior diplomat familiar with the president's thinking said. "But Egypt's strategists do not want to see Iraq destroyed and left vulnerable to picking apart by vultures from all directions."

In a commentary on the crisis earlier this month, Ibrahim Nafei, editor-in-chief of Al-Ahram, Cairo's largest newspaper, said Egyptian leaders had "serious apprehensions about Israeli intervention in the Gulf crisis."

This ambiguity, as reflected in some of Mubarak's own statements, has caused confusion and consternation in Washington. "We will oppose Israeli involvement in a war, and we would refuse to take part with Israel," Mubarak was reported as saying on January 9 at the opening of Cairo's annual book fair. "We do not agree to any Israeli intervention under any circumstances," he said, according to the newspaper Al-Akhbar. A few days later, he was quoted saying that Egypt would not join in an attack on Baghdad but would only participate in the expulsion of Iraqi forces from Kuwait.

While joining President Bush in rejecting linkage between the Kuwait invasion and the Palestinian issue, Mubarak also emphasized continued backing for the Palestinian cause. "We have to move on the Palestinian problem," he said in his meeting with African-American Conference delegates. But Iraq's actions "can in no way contribute" to a solution of the issue, Mubarak said.

Mubarak says his government's domestic policies "are putting Egypt on the right economic track," and that its commitment to "democracy and free expression" should insure stability and growth in the years to come. However, growing discontent at home could be one outcome of the Gulf war.

In parliamentary elections late last year, the victory by Mubarak's ruling National Democratic Party was diminished by a low voter turnout and a boycott by most of the opposition parties. Islamic fundamentalists have attacked the president for his avowedly pro-Western tilt.

Mubarak's decision to join Washington in confronting Iraq "is the biggest gamble of his reign," says Ahmed Abdalla, an Egyptian political scientist. The liberal right opposition and the Islamic movement have both exhibited rifts within their own ranks on the issue. "If the Gulf crisis takes a longer course, these splits augur for a reconfiguration of political forces in Egypt," Abdalla says in the current issue of the Washington-based Middle East Report.

Mohammed Khalafalla, a leading Islamic theologian, has charged that Mubarak's decision to join the United States in confronting Iraq "not only violates Islamic values but also goes against Arab culture and history." The war with Iraq "will destroy the Arab nation" and seriously damage Egypt, he argued in a column published in early January in Al-Ahram.

Misgivings about war have also been expressed by the Coptic Christian leadership. In a sermon during midnight Mass on January 6 -- Christmas Eve on the Orthodox calendar -- Pope Shenouda III issued a strong appeal for peaceful resolution of the crisis. With a membership that may be as large as five million -- or a tenth of Egypt's population -- the Coptic Church includes not only some of the nation's professional elite but also a significant portion of the poorest strata of society. When tensions erupt, these impoverished Copts are often the targets of discrimination and even violence.

If the current confrontation creates further economic strains for Egypt, the resulting tensions may cause new difficulties not only for Copts but also for Mubarak.

Egyptian officials estimate that the Gulf crisis has already cost the country nearly $ 4.5 billion. Over $1 billion has been lost in remittances from Egyptian workers in Gulf states, notably those in Kuwait and Iraq, where an estimated 1.3 million Egyptians lived and worked prior to Iraq's invasion. "Additional food will be needed to feed returning workers and their families," according to a recent analysis issued by the U.S. Department of Agriculture. The returnees' need for housing, education and jobs will further stretch the demands already being made by Egypt's rapidly growing population.

The country has also suffered from a 20 percent reduction in Suez Canal traffic and a major drop-off in tourism. Even before the January 16 attack on Iraq, Egyptian businesses reported cancellation rates of 60 to 80 percent from Europe and the United States.

"Europeans think we are close to the war zone," says Seoud Zarkani, whose family operates a tour business and Egypt's only private airline. "They don't realize we are hundreds of miles from Kuwait and out of range of Iraq's missiles."

These losses have been offset, however, by significant dividends resulting directly from the crisis. Egypt's oil revenues have risen by about $ 1.5 billion, although the country's limited oil output generates only a small portion of total foreign exchange requirements. A big chunk of Egypt's $ 50 billion-plus foreign debt has been written off -- the U.S. has cancelled $ 7 billion incurred for military purchases, and Saudi Arabia and three other oil-rich Gulf states have agreed to forgive another $ 7 billion in loans Egypt owed them.

In addition, last month Saudi Arabia announced a $ 1.5 billion grant to Egypt to help meet expenses arising from the Gulf crisis.

Egypt's ongoing negotiations with the International Monetary Fund (IMF) over a multi-million dollar stabilization program have accelerated, thanks to the debt reduction and the increased aid which have resulted from Egypt's participation in the anti-Iraq coalition.

All this has led some Egyptians to see the current confrontation principally in economic terms. "The Egyptian government, like the Americans, wants to send its troops to Saudi Arabia to get a lot of money," said Mustaffa Cherif, an accounting clerk from Aswan, during a street corner conversation.

But many others here seemed concerned about the effect war could have on the economic steps that the country has taken in recent years. "The Egyptian people are looking for peace," said Rahman Kattap, a shopkeeper who recently earned his license to practice law. "I want to appeal to Saddam Hussein on behalf of all Arabic people -- you are a Muslim and a brother -- to return back to your home. We are not afraid of you but we are afraid of what you are going to do."

Mubarak, too, said he sought to convince Saddam Hussein to turn back. "I personally tried to tell him that this action he has taken will never be accepted," the Egyptian leader said in his session with the African-American Conference delegates. The president appeared stung both by Saddam's rejection of Egyptian attempts to mediate the crisis and by a feeling that Saddam had lied about his intentions towards Kuwait. Although Saddam is "not a lunatic," Mubarak said, "he is living in another world." The Iraqi leader's belief that he can win a war would make sense "if he was fighting Yemen or Djibouti," but not when he is facing "the most powerful nation on earth."

Egypt has sent about 30,000 troops to Saudi Arabia, including two crack divisions -- the 4th Armoured and 3rd Mechanized Infantry -- along with Special Forces and chemical warfare units.

Asked about long-term security arrangements in the Gulf, Mubarak said he does not believe American troops should remain after resolution of the current crisis. But there should be "a security plan" with American support in readiness.

The prospect of a demolished Iraq is as worrisome to Egypt's strategists is the idea of Saddam left strong enough to resume his aggression. "Egypt wants to be appreciated as the leader and savior of the Arab world," political scientist Abdalla says, "but the prospect that the destruction of Iraq is the price for this to happen would give Egypt's triumph a bitter taste and the regime risks opprobrium as an American accomplice."

What Mubarak's advisors want to avoid is creation of a regional power vacuum, following an eradication of Iraq's military might, which would be filled by Iran and Israel -- two traditional Egyptian adversaries. "Mubarak was the chief proponent of the pro-Iraq tilt the U.S. adopted in the Iran-Iraq war," notes one top-level Western diplomat wryly. "His reasons for that stance have not been altered by the current crisis."

However, many observers believe that the balance of forces as it has existed in recent years has been disrupted unalterably. Beginning with the end of the Cold War and continuing into the current shooting war, the "prevailing structure" among Arab states "has collapsed and cannot be restored," argues Mohammed Sid-Ahmed, an Egyptian political commentator. "The Arab league is no longer operative," he writes in Middle East Report. "Non-Arab states such as Iran, Turkey and Israel are bound to acquire an enhanced role in the regional competition for supremacy."

The challenge facing Egypt, he says, is to emerge as "a model in the Arab world of deepened institutionalization and democratization." The alternative, Sid-Ahmed and others believe, is division and militarization which will seriously drain the resources of Egypt and its neighbors.


LOAD-DATE: March 1, 1991


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1991 AllAfrica, Inc.


16 of 211 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February 11, 1991


ADIEU, MILLA


LENGTH: 235 words


The 39-year-old star of Cameroon's World Cup soccer team, Roger Milla, has come out of retirement for the second time. Last week Milla played a token 30 minutes with the Indomitable Lions of Cameroon in an exhibition match against England at Wembley Stadium. But before the match, Milla announced it would be his last appearance in international competition. Since the World Cup last year in Italy, Milla has made numerous appearances on behalf of his country.

Called out of retirement by presidential decree to play with the World Cup team, Milla scored four goals to lead the Lions to the quarterfinals. Although they lost that match to England 3-2 in extra time, the Cameroon club was the first African team ever to reach the quarterfinals, and the victory was celebrated throughout the continent. Milla has been voted 1990 African Footballer of the Year by journalists from 49 African countries, and the New York-based Village Voice named him their 1990 Male Sports Personality of the Year.

Soccer fans around the world hailed the inventive and offensive play of Milla and his teammates -- reminiscent of high-scoring Brazilian teams of the 1970s -- in an otherwise dreary series of World Cup games. In recognition of Cameroon's performance, Fifa, the international soccer governing body, has granted Africa an additional slot in the 1994 World Cup games, for a total of three berths.


LOAD-DATE: March 1, 1991


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1991 AllAfrica, Inc.


17 of 211 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February 11, 1991


PRETORIA'S BIG GUN


LENGTH: 239 words


The world has become familiar with Scuds and Patriot missiles, but one of the most highly-prized weapons in the Gulf war is a little-known, long-range artillery gun made by South Africa -- and sold to both sides in the conflict.

The G-5 howitzer, produced by the South African government-owned arms manufacturing company known as Armscor, "poses a greater threat to allied troops" in the war region than Iraqi Scuds, London's Independent newspaper reported late last month. 

Military experts say Iraq has at least 100 G-5s, and some estimates run as high as 200. But the South African government denies the Independent's claim that Armscor was still supplying 155 mm ammunition for the guns until late last year. That would have violated the UN arms embargo against Iraq. Saudi Arabia and Israel also made recent purchases, the London-based newsletter Southscan reports.

Armscor obtained the know-how for the G-5 through one of the largest breaches in the long-standing UN arms embargo against South Africa. Between 1976 and 1978, Space Research Corporation, an American and Canadian-owned firm, sold approximately 60,000 155 mm extended-range artillery shells and related technology to Armscor, along with at least four 155 mm guns, including three advanced prototypes. According to a congressional study of the transactions, the sales provided South Africa with the capacity to develop and manufacture the G-5.


LOAD-DATE: March 1, 1991


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1991 AllAfrica, Inc.


18 of 211 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February 11, 1991


DELAYED REACTION


LENGTH: 317 words


A referendum to decide the future of the disputed territory of Western Sahara is moving up on the United Nations agenda, despite complications created by the Persian Gulf war. Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar is completing a report on how the world organization could implement the terms of a Security Council resolution that calls for a vote by the territory's inhabitants to choose between independence or incorporation into Morocco. A UN technical team visited the area last year to gather the information de Cuellar needs to recommend the civilian, military and security arrangements required to carry out the Council mandate. 

Plans for the referendum were slated for completion last fall, but Iraq's invasion of Kuwait diverted UN attention and delayed work on the report. Said Yiba, a representative at the UN for the Saharan independence movement Polisario, says his group hopes the precedent of a firm UN response to Iraq's action will insure that Western Sahara is not overlooked. "Morocco invaded our country in 1975, and we are eager for the UN to enforce its resolution and give the Saharan people a chance to decide the future," he said.

According to UN sources, Morocco has been reluctant to provide all the information de Cuellar's staff has requested about the size of its military presence in Western Sahara. One unknown factor in the situation is whether political fallout from the Gulf war will affect Moroccan King Hassan II's commitment to cooperate with the UN-supervised poll. The monarch committed a token force of 1,200 soldiers to the anti-Iraq coalition, but popular sentiment in his country appears solidly behind Iraq.

The king has refused to allow public criticism of his decision, but the government last week permitted a large pro-Iraqi demonstration to take place in Rabat, sponsored by opposition political parties and major trade unions.


LOAD-DATE: March 1, 1991


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1991 AllAfrica, Inc.


19 of 211 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February 11, 1991


OUT OF PART OF AFRICA


SECTION: BITS AND PIECES


LENGTH: 215 words


The Peace Corps has pulled its volunteers from four African countries as a result of the Gulf crisis. The most recent withdrawal is from Tanzania, where 22 non-essential staff and 59 dependents at the U.S. embassy have also been sent home. The State Department says the move was taken because of "a credible threat of pro-Iraqi terrorist action directed at U.S. government facilities and personnel in Tanzania."

In early January, Peace Corps activities were suspended in three north African countries -- Morocco, Tunisia and Mauritania. Most of the volunteers who left those countries have had to end their terms of service, a Peace Corps spokeswoman said last week. New assignments for some have been found.

About 2,500 volunteers in 30 other African countries have been unaffected by the crisis.

The war also cut short a tour of Africa by two high-ranking American officials. Health and Human Services Secretary Dr. Louis Sullivan and Dr. Ronald Roskens, administrator of the Agency for International Development (AID), were recalled to Washington last month before making scheduled stops in Mali and Senegal. Before returning home, they visited Cote d'Ivoire, Nigeria, Malawi, Uganda, South Africa and Zimbabwe to examine health problems affecting African children.


LOAD-DATE: March 1, 1991


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1991 AllAfrica, Inc.


20 of 211 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February 11, 1991


AFRICAN ORCHESTRA PURSUES DREAM


SECTION: CULTURE: GHANA


LENGTH: 611 words


Accra -- If the term "symphony orchestra" calls to mind violins and cellos and oboes, a group of African musicians wants you to think again.

The Pan African Orchestra, based in Ghana, may be a novel venture, but its members aim to be taken seriously as artists. Musical director Nana Danso Abiam, who also serves as conductor, says the original intent of the group's founders was "to bring the diverse resources of the rich African musical heritage together." 

Established in 1988 and still struggling for survival, the 22-piece orchestra has been buoyed in recent months by critical acclaim for its performances in Ghana and by the opportunity for a European tour.

The orchestra's guiding principle is to perform indigenous African music using only instruments indigenous to the continent. That doesn't mean, says director Nana Danso, that either the music or the way it is presented will be familiar to African audiences. "It is not purely traditional," he says, "because the orchestra fuses different instruments. It is, therefore, neo-traditional."

Nana Danso hopes that the fusion of elements will stimulate experimentation with new forms of musical expression and encourage compositions designed for the unique blending of instruments in the orchestra.

As its name implies, the Pan African Orchestra isn't limiting its scope to Ghana or to west Africa. The ultimate objective is the formation of a 108-piece symphonic orchestra incorporating instruments from across the continent. Among the instruments expected to become a part of the mix are husk-cane and bamboo flutes, hand or finger pianos, wooden xylophones, harp lutes like the Senegalese kora, and drums of assorted sizes and sounds as well as other percussion instruments.

Nana Danso, who says musicians from many parts of Africa are being invited to participate, envisions a mixed repertoire that will include traditional music from different African communities as well as merging blends of many traditions. To insure high standards and the preservation of techniques and expertise that might die out otherwise, the orchestra plans to develop a training program for music teachers. The group's founders hope, eventually, to mass-produce African instruments according to strict quality control standards.

The orchestra's 22 current members consist of twelve players of the atenteben, a bamboo flute; two players of the gonje, a one-stringed violin; three xylophone, or gyile, players; three drummers and the conductor. Although the musicians are from diverse backgrounds, few have more than a secondary school education. But since playing in the orchestra, all the members have learned to read music.

Despite its ambitious schemes, the orchestra has yet to resolve its toughest problem -- finances. Already, the orchestra has collapsed twice for lack of funds. And constant money shortages have led to a turnover of members and made creating a cohesive musical unit difficult. But the current members say they are determined to forge ahead with their plans.

According to Nana Danso, the group needs $ 700 a month to continue functioning at its present level. While the amount is miniscule by the standards of most orchestras, it is a high sum for musicians in Ghana. And much more will be needed to implement any of the group's long-range plans.

The orchestra's concert in Accra last September was the first performance in 15 months. But the standing ovation from an enthusiastic audience, which included large numbers of foreigners as well as Ghanaians, renewed the members' confidence that their efforts can find wide acceptance, both in Africa and abroad.


LOAD-DATE: March 1, 1991


LANGUAGE: English
