Africa News


February 11, 1991


SOMALIA: REBUILDING SNAGGED BY DIVISIONS


LENGTH: 673 words


Ali Mahdi Mohamed, who was named interim president of Somalia late last month by the rebel movement which ousted former President Mohamed Siad Barre, has called for a national conference of all the country's political groupings on February 28.

Mahdi Mohamed issued his call during a BBC interview last week after several opposition figures denounced his selection by the United Somali Congress (USC). The group took control of the capital, Mogadishu, following Siad's flight from the city on January 26.

The deposed leader, who had ruled the country since 1969 when he took power in a military coup, left behind a devastated scene. During the month before Siad left, his troops shelled the capital with artillery fire and rocket-launchers. As he fled, "his troops looted the central bank," UPI's Neil Fleming reported from Mogadishu. "They turned foreign embassies into matchsticks after the diplomats left. They even pillaged the blood bank, throwing away the blood to steal the refrigerators." 

Left behind were the bodies of slain soldiers and civilians, streets covered with rubble, and power and telephone lines downed across roads and buildings.

But for the incoming administration, reconstructing the country may be secondary to the challenge of forging enough of a political consensus to govern. The new president said the purpose of the February 28 conference is "to decide collectively the political future of Somalia."

However, Somali politics are extremely factionalized, reflecting the country's long history of inter-clan rivalry. Each of the main opposition groups is rooted in a different clan, and most suffer from internal fractures along sub-clan lines. The USC itself has at least three identifiable factions, one of which opposed the choice of Mahdi Mohamed.

His selection is also condemned by the Somali National Movement (SNM), which won control over much of the north of the country from Siad's troops prior to the USC's assault on Mogadishu. "If necessary we will fight against him," SNM London representative Ali Hassan Hussein said in a statement.

The USC says representatives of all opposition movements inside Somalia took part in and approved the new interim president and the 10-member cabinet which was named on February 2. The new president said the government would serve only long enough to ensure free elections.

"I don't think that even if some members of the new interim government get a taste for power they would try to hold onto it," Rakiya Omaar, director of the London-based human rights group Africa Watch, told Reuters. "Somali people are too hungry for choice." Somalis now need "goodwill and a lot of support" to rebuild their country, she said.

At a swearing-in ceremony for the new cabinet, Mahdi Mohamed appealed for immediate international emergency assistance and for longer-term development aid to recover from the destruction. He said the country needs food, fuel, medicines and medical equipment, as well as personnel.

Continuing disorder in the capital -- where armed bands have been looting and terrorizing residents -- and the lack of communication links to the outside world have prevented the arrival of emergency assessment teams from donor countries and agencies.

According to the United Nations High Commission for Refugees, recent fighting and the change in government have produced a new wave of refugees. The largest outflow is believed to have occurred in the north, where between 12,000 and 50,000 persons are thought to have crossed into Ethiopia. Several thousand other Somalis have fled to Djibouti and Kenya.

Inside Somalia itself, pockets of displaced people have been created by the conflict. "People are not yet returning to Mogadishu, since the situation there remains chaotic," said Haram Ruiz of the Washington-based U.S. Committee for Refugees. "What we are hearing is that there are great problems in the areas to which people who fled Mogadishu concentrated, particularly in Kismayo where there is no food."


LOAD-DATE: March 1, 1991

Africa News


February 11, 1991


KENYA: NO VOTING IN 1991


LENGTH: 706 words


There will be no election this year, Kenyan President Daniel arap Moi announced last week. "Nobody should go around cheating the people ¢into thinking/ that elections are on," Moi told guests at the opening of an agricultural show in western Kenya.

The next election in the country is scheduled for 1993, and the president said he does not intend to move the voting up. Moi has been under pressure from domestic opponents, as well as from overseas critics, to allow greater democratic participation and restore constitutional safeguards that have been eroded in recent years. The Kenyan leader has repeatedly rejected calls for a return to the multiparty rule that was formally abolished in 1982. 

But late last year the government did take several steps that had been long been sought by its critics. The first move came during a special conference of the ruling Kenya African National Union (Kanu), the country's only legal party, where delegates agreed to abolish the controversial practice of "queue voting." The queue system, introduced in 1986, requires voters to line up behind symbols of their preferred candidate rather than cast a secret ballot. The decision to eliminate the practice, along with several other election procedures which had been widely criticized as undemocratic, followed a lengthy plenary discussion of the findings of a Kanu review committee chaired by Vice President George Saitoti.

During the debate, sentiment seemed strongly opposed to the Saitoti recommendation that queues be scrapped. But after an impassioned speech by Moi in support of the Saitoti report, delegates endorsed the changes overwhelmingly.

The day after the conference ended, Kenya's parliament approved a constitutional amendment restoring the security of tenure to the judiciary, reversing a 1988 amendment which gave the government the authority to remove judges from the bench.

Government officials are hopeful that the reforms will ease criticism at home and abroad. The Nairobi-based Weekly Review expressed the opinion that these actions "are not the last chapter" of the reform process.

Criticisms of government practices continue, however. In a recent report, the New York-based Lawyers Committee for Human Rights complained that attorneys representing unpopular clients suffer regular harassment and said Kenyan authorities are guilty of other constitutional abuses such as "cruel and inhuman treatment" of political prisoners.

In October, the U.S. Congress voted to withhold about $ 15 million in 1991 military aid for Kenya, unless the administration can certify that the Moi government has met four conditions. It must free or charge all political prisoners, end the physical abuse of prisoners, restore the independence of the judiciary and reinstate freedoms of expression. The restrictions were not applied to the $ 38 million Kenya is to receive in economic assistance this year, but the curtailments could extend to other aid if Congress remains unhappy with Moi's actions.

Responding to the congressional action, Kenya's embassy in Washington protested that "it must be left to Kenyans to decide at what pace and in which direction they want change to occur."

Meanwhile, three prominent critics charged with treason will face trial later this year. Koigi wa Wamwere, a former member of Parliament who had been living in exile in Norway, was seized in October and accused of attempting to overthrow the government by force. The government said he was found with an arms cache in Nairobi, but Koigi told the court in December he was kidnapped from neighboring Uganda. His arrest has ruptured relations between Kenya and Norway. Two lawyers arrested with Koigi -- Rumba Kinuthia and Mirugi Kariuki -- also face treason charges.

Last month, Moi promised decisions on the detentions of two other prominent lawyers -- Kenneth Matiba and Charles Rubia, who have not been charged. Their cases have attracted international attention since they were picked up by police in July. But Moi has not commented on the continued jailing of Raila Odinga, son of a former Kenyan vice president, who headed the outlawed opposition Kenya African Peoples Union. -- with files from William Acworth


LOAD-DATE: March 1, 1991


LANGUAGE: English

23 of 211 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February 11, 1991


RWANDA SHOOTING SPARKS PEACE PUSH


LENGTH: 787 words


With fighting again intensifying in Rwanda, renewed efforts are underway to resolve the conflict by negotiation.

Visiting Rwanda last week, Salim Ahmed Salim, Secretary-General of the Organization of African Unity (OAU), called for an end to hostilities and pressed for a regional solution to the thorny problem of Rwandan refugees. Tanzanian President Ali Hassan Mwinyi has announced plans to convene a summit of eastern and central African countries in Arusha, Tanzania later this month, in an effort to mediate the conflict and resolve the refugee question.

Rebels from the Rwanda Patriotic Front (RPF), who launched the insurgency four months ago with an invasion from Uganda, say they are determined to force a complete change in the policies of Rwandan President Juvenal Habyarimana. "There has been a total lack of democracy in our country," Patrick Mazimhaka, the Front's commissioner for foreign affairs, said in an interview last week while visiting Washington. "Our objective is to change the political system, which is based on discrimination against ethnic groups," he charged. 

The RPF's original invasion force of about 3,000 soldiers were members of the Ugandan National Army who had deserted with their uniforms, weapons and vehicles. "We had to put our national interest ahead of Uganda's," Mazimhaka said. "We did apologize for that, but we could not do otherwise." Most of the invaders were members of Rwanda's minority Tutsi group. But Mazimhaka claims that the front has attracted a broad following inside the country and that its fighting force has more than doubled.

The RPF accuses Habyarimana of favoring Hutu people over Tutsi and of reserving most opportunities for a small Hutu clique from the president's home region in the north. The front says the government's political and economic practices have forced thousands of people into exile in neighboring Uganda, Tanzania, and Burundi. In August, Habyarimana appealed to those three countries to grant citizenship to Rwandan exiles, who he said could not be accommodated in their densely populated country -- a move that some observers believe prompted the invasion.

The Rwanda government rejects the RPF discrimination charges and accuses the rebels of seeking restoration of the ancient Tutsi monarchy. "The invasion has nothing to do with refugees," says Aloys Uwimana, the Rwandan ambassador in Washington. "The invasion leaders have made clear their goal is to overthrow President Habyarimana and take over the government."

The latest strife began on January 22, with an assault against Ruhengeri, Rwanda's second largest city and the site of a major military base and prison. "We opened the prison and we overran the base and captured a lot of weapons," Mazimhaka said. RPF forces are "active on many small fronts" in the northwest of the country, he said.

Government troops quickly recaptured Ruhengeri, and a week ago, the government announced an extensive counteroffensive aimed at reversing the rebel's gains. About 100 insurgents were killed, official sources told the Reuter news agency in Kigali, the Rwandan capital.

Earlier this month, the country's state security court sentenced eight people to death for collaborating with the rebels. In December, Justice Minister Theoeneste Mujyanama announced that over 1,500 suspected rebel sympathizers would be prosecuted. The government said its troops had forced most of the rebels to flee, following heavy clashes that left hundreds dead. Both sides have accused the other of causing extensive casualties among civilians.

The latest battles indicate a continuing combat capacity on the part of the RPF, which lost three of its most senior officers in the early days of the fighting. Among the first casualties was the invasion leader, Fred Rwigyema, a former deputy commander of the Ugandan army and advisor to Ugandan President Yoweri Museveni. The losses were all caused on the battlefield, Mazimhaka said. He denied they were the result of internal squabbles and said the deaths reflect the fact that top commanders "are with the troops in the front" and are not issuing orders from the rear.

Since the October invasion, Habyarimana has announced a series of political reforms, including abolition of the system of identity cards which the RPF has likened to South Africa's apartheid passbooks. He has promised to replace one-party rule with a multiparty system and has called for a national referendum on a new democratic constitution by June.

The RPF says these reforms are only window dressing. "We want total abolition of discrimination in the political life of the country and a government of national unity," Mazimhaka said.


LOAD-DATE: March 1, 1991


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1991 AllAfrica, Inc.


24 of 211 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February 11, 1991


ZAIRE: MOBUTU READIES NEW PLOY


SECTION: AROUND THE CONTINENT


LENGTH: 1282 words


Amid continuing domestic and international pressure for a speed-up of democratic reforms, President Mobutu Sese Seko of Zaire may be preparing to invite opposition politicians to join the government. The move is seen as a bid to forestall an opposition push to curtail the president's authority.

Following an unprecedented meeting last month with Mobutu, opposition leaders announced their acceptance of a "coalition" government to pave the way for national elections promised for later this year. The political leaders said they expected the new government to operate independently of Mobutu, who would in effect become a figurehead. 

The call for an interim government seems to be an attempt by the opposition to move the democratic process forward and force Mobutu's hand. The president announced last April his intention to hold the country's first elections sometime this year, and last month the government authorized 19 political parties to take part. But no date for voting has been set.

Mobutu gave no indication that he would implement the opposition leaders' proposal. Instead, diplomatic sources say, he appears to be trying to coax a few of his better-known opponents to join the current government, headed by Prime Minister Lunda Bululu.

But even if that effort succeeds, it is unlikely that other opposition figures would accept the arrangement. A government of national unity is itself a compromise position for the major opposition parties, who had made Mobutu's resignation a precondition to democratization in the country.

"The people of Zaire are demanding that he go," said former cabinet minister Etienne Tshisekedi wa Malumba, the presidential candidate of the Union for Democracy and Social Progress (UDPS), during a visit to the United States last November. "They are so disenchanted with everything he has done, they do not believe we can have democracy as long as he is there," Tshisekedi said in an interview.

In addition to the maneuverings at home, Mobutu is also trying to accommodate international pressure to reform. Last month, the president was dealt a diplomatic setback when the site for next October's summit of French-speaking nations was shifted from Kinshasa to France. Canada and Belgium demanded the change as a protest against human rights abuses and widespread corruption during Mobutu's 25-year rule.

Speaking in Paris after a meeting with French President Francois Mitterand, Mobutu criticized Canada and Belgium for forcing the transfer, but said he would accept Mitterand's new plan, which calls for Zaire to host the meeting in 1993.

As Mobutu juggles his options, the war in the Persian Gulf may have given him a new advantage over his critics.

Last fall, in reaction to the Mobutu government's reported corruption and brutality, Congress cut off military aid to Zaire and required that all development assistance be dispensed through non-governmental organizations. Rep. Stephen Solarz (D-NY) plans to introduce legislation that would endorse an "interim mechanism acceptable to all political forces" to oversee the transition to a democratically elected government. Solarz, a member of the House Foreign Affairs Committee, visited Zaire in December and held talks with Mobutu.

But the Bush administration, like its predecessors, has been reluctant to distance the U.S. from the Zaire ruler, seeing him as a reliable ally in regional and international affairs. Now, Zaire's role in diplomatic negotiations leading up to the outbreak of war has given the U.S. government leverage to press its position.

In December, Zaire was one of three African nations sitting on the 15-member United Nations Security Council. Along with Ethiopia and Cote d'Ivoire, Zaire was courted strongly by Secretary of State James Baker as he sought to round up African support for the U.S. position on Iraq.

The following month, the alphabetical rotation of the United Nations Security Council presidency put Zaire's ambassador to the United Nations, Bagbeni Nzengeya, in the chair during the crucial period of the January 15 deadline for Iraq to withdraw from Kuwait. The Council's near-unanimity on the Kuwait issue was put to the test, with the Zairian presiding.

"They ran it the way we would have wanted it run," one U.S. official said of the Zaire government's performance, "and of course they have voted right all along."

Currently the administration is working on compromise language that it hopes will be incorporated into the Solarz resolution on Zaire's transition to democracy.

With the political situation at an apparent stalemate, Zaire's economic dissolution has escalated. Inflation, which last year exceeded an estimated 240%, is currently running about 35% per month -- an annual rate of 420%.

Last week, public employee unions staged a three-day strike in the capital, Kinshasa, which emptied government offices, Reuters reported. The National Union of Zairean Workers, which called the strike, is demanding both higher pay for its members and the resignation of the government.

Until formation of a government which can command popular support and make economic commitments, agreement with the International Monetary Fund (IMF) and the World Bank over recovery plans for the country are stymied. Delegations from both institutions visited Kinshasa in November, but neither is near an agreement with Zaire that would open the way to outside financial assistance.

The country's relations with the two financial agencies was further complicated by a front-page Wall Street Journal story in December detailing questionable dealings between Zaire and a senior official in both the IMF and World Bank.

The story, by Journal reporter Edward T. Pound, revolved around Jacques de Groote, an executive director at the Bank and the IMF, with responsibility for his native Belgium, several other European nations and Turkey. The story recounts a series of actions and relationships, including a two-decade tie between de Groote and Mobutu, that suggest a conflict of interest between de Groote's professional responsibilities and his personal finances.

De Groote has been both an official and an unofficial advisor to the Zaire leader, during a period when Zaire has been involved in complex negotiations with both the Fund and the Bank. On more than one occasion, according to the Journal, de Groote's links with Zaire and with businesses operating there have enabled him to obtain loans to help finance a lavish lifestyle.

De Groote told Pound that he never used his position for personal gain, but acknowledged that he was sometimes perceived as a Mobutu agent, even among his colleagues at the IMF and the Bank. Reacting to the story, Tshisekedi and other Zaire opposition leaders have called for an inquiry. Neither financial institution has made an official comment.

One of the items on the U.S. Senate's agenda for the upcoming session will be the question of who will represent U.S. interests in Kinshasa during what promises to be a turbulent time. President Bush has named career diplomat Melissa Wells as the next ambassador. No stranger to controversy, Wells is a former ambassador to Mozambique, whose appointment was delayed by lengthy confirmation queries by North Carolina Republican Senator Jesse Helms. The Senator questioned Wells' personal views as well as U.S. policy toward the Mozambique government. Once on the job, Wells proved to be broadly popular, both with the Mozambican government and among the diplomatic community.

Africanists agree that in Zaire, Wells will have ample opportunity to employ the diplomatic skills she exhibited in Maputo.


LOAD-DATE: March 1, 1991


LANGUAGE: English

25 of 211 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February 11, 1991


HOPES AND FEARS FOR CONTINENT'S CHILDREN


LENGTH: 1140 words


In the past decade, deaths of children around the world were decreased by half, according to a report by the United Nation Children's Fund (Unicef). The report, called The State of the World's Children 1991, says a successful international campaign to immunize 80% of the world's children against preventable diseases has saved 12 million lives. At the beginning of the campaign only 15-20% of children in the developing world were being vaccinated.

The outlook for Africa's children, however, is not as hopeful as that for children in other parts of the world. Many of the past decade's programs failed to reach children in Africa, and without massive debt relief and developmental assistance, there will be little improvement in the 1990s, the report says. 

Final figures on the achievement of the 80% goal, set by the World Health Organization (WHO) in 1980, will not be available until March. But it is already clear, Unicef says, that the past decade's immunization programs have prevented 1.5 million children from contracting paralytic polio and millions more from contracting measles, whooping cough and neonatal tetanus. And because disease prevention reduces malnutrition, diarrhea and pneumonia, immunization also saved millions of children from chronic illness, poor growth and possible early death.

While a reduction in child mortality might suggest a rise in the population growth rate, Unicef says the opposite is true. Several developing countries are approaching the threshold where lowered child deaths mean that women can place greater faith in family planning programs, Unicef says. Because mothers no longer have to bear many children to compensate for anticipated deaths, increased child survival encourages women to limit family size, resulting in millions fewer births.

Heartened by the progress of the past decade, the Unicef report outlines ambitious new goals for improving child welfare in the next ten years. Drawing upon resolutions passed at the World Summit for Children last September, the Children's Fund assigns top priority to cutting child deaths by a further one-third, providing basic education for all children and halving child malnutrition and maternal deaths.

But one of the most urgent needs is to extend the immunization campaign to areas which the past decade's programs have failed to reach. Many of those are in Africa. James P. Grant, executive director of Unicef, says that Africa, with the highest average mortality rate of children under five in the world, is the only continent where child deaths are projected to increase during the 1990s.

Although the global vaccination goal has been achieved, the report explains, not all parts of the world have been equally saturated. In addition, the report says, 80% immunization "does not mean an 80% reduction in deaths, because disease is both more common, and more commonly fatal, among the minority who have not yet been reached." Although 2.5 million children were saved by vaccines in 1990, the same number of children still died from diseases preventable by immunization.

A special supplement to the State of the World's Children report, Africa's Children, Africa's Future: Implementing the World Summit Declaration, indicates that Africa has the greatest proportion of threatened children of any continent. Unless downward spirals of debt, war and famine are reversed, the report says, "Africa's share of global and infant deaths will increase to 40% by the end of the century." In 1950, Africa's share of child deaths was 15%, and in 1986 it was 30%.

The supplemental report on African children lists interwoven factors that bind Africa into a particularly difficult situation. Several years of drought and famine during the 1980s aggravated the effects of environmental degradation, faltering economies and persistent wars. Though many African countries acted to meet the agenda for economic recovery laid out by the 1986 United Nations special session on Africa's crisis, international assistance promised by donors arrived slowly, while debt service payments rocketed. African governments saw funds for children's programs erode steadily.

The emergence of the AIDS epidemic adds additional daunting layers to the problems of Africa's children. African women often lack the education to avoid contracting AIDS or are bound by tradition not to take measures against it. In early 1990, WHO estimated that of three million women worldwide -- mostly of childbearing age -- who tested positive for the AIDS antibody HIV, 80% were in sub-Saharan Africa. The virus frequently passes from mother to fetus. In ten seriously affected African countries, Unicef says, between one-quarter and one-half million children will die each year from AIDS by the year 2000, and millions more will be orphaned as their parents die of the disease. AIDS "threatens to slow or even reverse the momentum generated by child survival and development initiatives during the 1980s," the supplemental report on Africa's children says.

Still, numerous African initiatives have improved prospects for many children. Some 25 African countries have immunized an estimated 75% of their children against six main diseases, although the success rate is substantially lower in countries where wars have made rural children inaccessible.

Several African governments have forged links between international donors and local communities aimed at revitalizing national health systems, and some countries have seen an improvement in child and maternal nutrition.

Unicef also hails the signing by 41 African states of the Convention on the Rights of the Child -- a document setting forth universal standards for the survival, protection and development of children -- as an indication that child welfare is now higher on the political agenda in many African countries. The State of the World's Children 1991 report proposes concrete debt relief and aid programs for the future, such as reductions in military spending and aid linked to investments in child development. It also calls for a broad "new ethic for children" in all countries that would carry the momentum of the World Summit into policies that place concern for children first.

"The...child cannot wait until interest rates fall, or until commodity prices recover,...or until a war has ended," Unicef says. "The child has only one chance to grow normally in mind and body, and protecting that one chance should have first call on our resources -- in good times and in bad."

Unicef officials concede that the "new ethic for children" the organization wants to implement is revolutionary. But in Africa, they say, it will take a revolution of world priorities to ensure that the continent's children fare better in the 1990s than they did in the last ten years.


LOAD-DATE: March 1, 1991


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1991 AllAfrica, Inc.


26 of 211 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February 11, 1991


SOUTH AFRICA GRAPPLES WITH LAND ISSUE


LENGTH: 1778 words


How fertile the land is," says South African constitutional scholar Albie Sachs, "in posing problems!"

The belief that the greatest challenges are still ahead dominated discussions of South Africa's future last week, following President F.W. de Klerk's February 1 pledge to scrap the major laws that have become known as the cornerstones of apartheid -- the Land Acts, the Group Areas Act and the Population Registration Act. De Klerk told the opening session of parliament in Cape Town that "South Africa cannot allow or permit the dynamic process of reform to slow down." Parliament is expected to approve de Klerk's proposals by July 1.

Although the inclusion of the population registration laws was a surprise, the removal of the land and group areas legislation was expected, and South Africans have been wrestling with the implications for some time. Amid the proposals and debates about how to structure the political economy of the country, there is widespread recognition that the rising expectations of the impoverished black majority will not be met easily. 

"The fundamental problem of scarcity of resources in relation to the infinity of needs will be the same," economist Simon Brand said in December, "whether it is decided to move towards a more centrally directed or a more market-oriented economy." Brand, who heads the quasi-governmental Development Bank of Southern Africa, said the general public needs to be told "that there are no magic solutions."

Still, the dismantling of the most important vestiges of South Africa's race laws holds a potent symbolism. It was a Friday morning in June 1913, when Africans learned that seven percent of South Africa's land had been reserved for their occupation. The 1913 Land Act was the first absolute legal barrier between areas for black and white residence. Thirty-three years later, the Development Trust and Land Act set aside 13.6% of South Africa's total area for black use and restricted black squatting in areas reserved for whites -- a provision that has allowed evictions and demolitions of black homes to continue. Collectively known as "the Land Acts," the 1913 and 1936 laws and associated regulations created a landless majority and fueled resistance to white rule over the years. The Group Areas Act of 1950, a complex piece of legislation that similarly restricts the rights of "Coloureds" and Indians, completed the division of the country into separate areas for each racial group.

By 1982, an estimated 1.3 million people had lost their rights to land in white areas.

A study for South Africa's Urban Foundation, a business-supported organization, says that the country's race laws systematically undermined black agriculture, resulting in extensive poverty. "By 1990," says the study on rural development, "80% of the households in the rural and dense settlement areas received incomes below the MML," a measure of basic subsistence needs.

The land issue is a central part of the problem of inequity that South Africa now faces, says Max Sisulu, an economic planner for the African National Congress (ANC). "Whites control 95% of the economy," Sisulu says. "The struggle for a democratic South Africa will focus increasingly on the economic sphere."

The question that occupies South African strategists is how to satisfy the land hunger of the country's black population, while maintaining the productivity of the country's farms.

South Africa is one of a handful of African countries that produces enough food for its population and, by current standards of calculation, it became one of the world's six producers of cheapest foods during the 1980s. But many economists say the country has paid a high hidden price for that achievement, both in an underlying structural imbalance that is unsustainable over the long term and in ecological damage that will haunt farmers for decades.

In a paper presented last October to a London conference on land reform, Development Bank manager Nicholas Christodoulou said that a quarter of white farming areas suffer from erosion and that irrigated land is being degraded through salination, while acid rain is a growing concern. Population pressures in the crowded black areas makes land conditions there even worse. Across-the-board improvement in land use policy is needed, Christodoulou told the conference.

The Urban Foundation report concurs. "To continue with present policy," it says, "is to invite demographic distortions, deepening poverty, increasing polarization and inefficient utilization of national resources." But the question of what should replace present practices is a complex one.

The ANC Freedom Charter, a document of principles that has guided the anti-apartheid struggle since 1956, declares that the "land shall be owned by those who work it" -- a statement that raises, for white farmers, the specter of their land being seized and turned over to their farm laborers.

But today's planners see the process of land reform as a balancing act that brings blacks into the farm economy over time, without disrupting smoothly running farms.

Among those looking for formulas are economists at the Development Bank. Christoulou listed seven models for the transfer of land to black ownership, including repossession of heavily indebted farms, negotiating for use of church-owned land, making use of small plots around urban areas, and making available the land held in government trusts.

In one of the more significant indications that Bank thinking may meet land activists halfway, Christodoulou acknowledged that "the history of forced removals in South Africa is inextricably linked with the way in which the agricultural sector has developed." As a result, the Bank official said, the state should return to dispossessed blacks any land still in government hands, and should consider establishing legal procedures to adjudicate conflicting claims to land that is in private hands.

Such statements indicate that government negotiators may be prepared to entertain both the calls for immediate action on certain cases of dispossession and the ANC's proposals for a system of land courts to hear grievances.

Aninka Claassens, a field worker for the Transvaal Rural Action Committee, foresees a land policy that is radical in its break with racial ownership patterns, but gradual in its implementation. The pace of change, Claassens told the journal Work in Progress, should be tied to the ability of people to mobilize and organize to lay claim to parcels of land. Claassens thinks absentee-owned farms might be targets for early transfer from white to black ownership. A process that rests on the ability of farmers and communities to work the land they receive, Claassens says, would be least likely to disrupt food supplies.

All parties share a concern to maintain and increase agricultural productivity. Although there are no hard data on land ownership, there are an estimated 79,000 white commercial farmers and 800,000 black smallholders operating at subsistence levels, according to Christodoulou. Skeptics about land reform say that black farms tend to be poorly run and inefficient, and they warn of economic disaster if land is redistributed.

But a number of groups that have been studying the constraints on black farm production say that there are ways to address those concerns. For the last five years, the Development Bank has been financing agricultural support programs for rural farmers, with what it says are encouraging results. "The perception that blacks can't farm and that people can't make a living on small pieces of land in South Africa is a fallacy," Bank manager Johan Kruger told the Washington Post's Allister Sparks. "Provided they have the necessary support services and infrastructure, black farmers have shown that they can farm as well as whites."

Such support services are the topic of several reports on the future of South African agriculture. A paper presented last March to a rural land workshop, sponsored by the Institute for a Democratic South Africa, surveyed the history of the state role in agriculture. State intervention on behalf of white farmers has produced a high level of efficiency, the report said, but also a low level of equity. If support services were extended to African farmers, it said, they could be productive, too.

The Development Bank's Simon Brand agrees. The government, he says "has played a much more pervasive role in the South African economy than some proponents of the free market view would have one believe."

Given the pressure for redressing economic inequalities, Brand says, it is "unlikely that the share of government in the use of resources in the economy and the extent of its intervention in the economy will decline significantly." It is the direction rather than the size of state intervention that needs adjustment, Brand says.

Among the roles government might assume is that of watchdog over private transactions. Some land rights activists have said that the end of racially reserved land could actually reduce black ownership, by putting land previously reserved for blacks on an open market where only whites could afford to buy. And reformers argue that the mere removal of legal barriers will, in itself, do little to change South Africa's residential and farming patterns.

No one wrestling with these issues argues that they can be resolved quickly or without pain. The debate presupposes the existence of a democratic government that will be forced to balance economic prudence with its accountability to a new, broader constituency. But that, in itself, is a sign that increasing numbers of South Africans of all races now believe that the process of ending apartheid is -- as Anglican Archbishop Desmond Tutu said in response to the de Klerk speech -- "nearly irreversible."

That view is not unanimous, however. White farmers warn that they will defy any plan that gives blacks the franchise in a unitary state or that takes white land for black use. Members of the right-wing Conservative Party stormed out of Parliament when President de Klerk unveiled his legislative proposals, and Conservative leader Andries Treurnicht said that "there is land in South Africa which belongs to whites and we have a claim to that land."

In an apparent attempt to defuse trouble from the white community, President de Klerk took the novel step of placing ads in Sunday newspapers following his speech. The full-page ads showed a dove of peace with the slogan: "Politicians can work out a new South Africa, but they can't make it work -- only you can do that."


LOAD-DATE: March 1, 1991


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1991 AllAfrica, Inc.


27 of 211 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April 1, 1991


PEOPLE


LENGTH: 212 words


A number of new appointments in Washington are important to Africa policy watchers. Several were sparked by the February changing of the guard at the House Africa subcommittee, where Mervyn Dymally (D-CA) replaced Howard Wolpe (D-MI) in the chair. 

Adwoa Dunn has moved from the House subcommittee to the Senate side, where she is the new staff director of the subcommittee on Africa, replacing Nancy Stetson. Former presidential candidate Paul Simon (D-IL) heads the subcommittee.

Dunn's counterpart as staff director of the House panel is former Dymally aide Adonis Hoffman, an attorney who has been a lobbyist for the Angolan rebel movement Unita. Mickey Harmon is the only holdover from the previous subcommittee staff, where she is now joined by Melvenia Gueye, Bernadette Paolo, and Marva Jo Camp, all former Dymally Congressional aides.

Gregory Robeson Smith is the new president of the Congressionally-funded African Development Foundation. He replaces Leonard Robinson, who has returned to the State Department as deputy assistant secretary for African affairs.

Smith, an ordained minister in the AME Zion Church, has worked for Church World Service, where he was in charge of international disaster relief, and five major U.S. corporations.

LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


April 1, 1991


INTERIM BICKERING


SECTION: BITS AND PIECES


LENGTH: 124 words


Rival clan-based armies are arguing over control of the interim government in Somalia, after the government of former President Mohamed Siad Barre was overthrown in January. The United Somali Congress (USC), which nominally controls the government headed by businessman Ali Mahdi Mohamed, is dominated by the Hawiye family, and is reportedly trying to drive the rival Darod clan out of the capital Mogadishu. The Somali Patriotic Movement, made up mostly of Darods, recently formed an umbrella organization called the Somali National Front to bring together several Darod groups. A legacy of the divide-and-rule policies of Siad Barre's regime, the clan conflict has forced up to 600,000 Somalis to flee southwards from the capital.


LOAD-DATE: April 1, 1991


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1991 AllAfrica, Inc.


29 of 211 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April 1, 1991


CEASEFIRE IN PERIL


SECTION: BITS AND PIECES


LENGTH: 232 words


As Renamo rebels stepped up attacks on key government roads and ports last month, the tenuous December 1 ceasefire that had slowed Mozambique's 15-year civil war seems increasingly in danger. Since late February, Renamo has reportedly ambushed a convoy traveling through western Tete province, raided a railway linking Malawi to the Mozambican port of Nacala and attacked Mozambican troops along the Limpopo railway line. 

At the fifth round of Rome peace talks between Renamo and the Mozambique government in January, the rebels rejected the findings of the Joint Verification Commission (JVC), an 11-nation panel monitoring the ceasefire. After investigations, the JVC found Renamo responsible for several early violations of the accord. Renamo claimed the government had broken the accord first, by allowing Zimbabwe to continue stationing troops throughout the country. The ceasefire agreement required that Zimbabwean troops would be limited to the Beira and Limpopo corridors.

Due to disagreement over the JVC report, repre-sentatives at the Rome talks failed to discuss the future political situation. President Joaquim Chissano of the Mozambique ruling party, Frelimo, announced last year that elections would be open to all political parties, including Renamo. Several other groups have said they intend to challenge Frelimo in elections, scheduled for this year.


LOAD-DATE: April 1, 1991


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1991 AllAfrica, Inc.


30 of 211 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April 1, 1991


FINAL OFFENSIVE


SECTION: BITS AND PIECES


LENGTH: 246 words


After a second round of peace talks between the Ethiopian government and the rebel Eritrean People's Liberation Front (EPLF) deadlocked in Washington in late February, the EPLF launched a new assault on the regime of President Mengistu Haile Mariam. An alliance of rebel groups scored major victories throughout March, and now lie poised to strike from Mezezo, a town close to the government's lifeline road to the Red Sea, only1 100 miles north of the capital,Addis Ababa. The offensive has posed the most serious threat yet to Mengistu's embattled government.

The U.S. State Department said non-essential embassy personnel are leaving Addis after being granted "voluntary departure status" last month.

The EPLF, which has been fighting for the independence of Eritrea since 1961, has formed a loose coalition with other rebel groups, operating under the umbrella of the Ethiopian People's Revolutionary Democratic Front (EPRDF), in the common push to oust Mengistu.

The main EPRDF group, the Tigray People's Liberation Front (TPLF), has captured the northern regional capital of Gondar and all of the Gojam province since late February. The group already controls Tigray and parts of Wallaga, Wollo and Shoa provinces.

Mengistu's troops are reportedly outnumbered and low on fuel and supplies. Last month, the president drafted students from the university in Addis Ababa to bolster government forces guarding Ethiopia's last remaining port at Assab.


LOAD-DATE: April 1, 1991


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1991 AllAfrica, Inc.


31 of 211 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April 1, 1991


NEWS ANALYSIS: DEMOCRACY PUSH WIDESPREAD


LENGTH: 649 words


The African drive for greater pluralism and accountability in its political systems was spurred by the democratic revolutions in Eastern Europe, and boosted powerfully by the dramatic release of Nelson Mandela and the legalization of political parties in South Africa.

But the process of enlarging political freedoms in Africa was initiated before these events. In 1989, the United Nations Economic Commission for Africa (ECA) issued the "African Alternative Framework to Structural Adjustment Programs" as a counter to World Bank and International Monetary Fund-sponsored economic reforms. The African proposals for economic recovery explicitly linked the continent's prospects for economic recovery to the introduction of democratic reforms. 

At the urging of African grassroots organizations, the ECA hosted a major international conference on that theme in Arusha, Tanzania a year ago, where delegates adopted a far-reaching "African Charter for Popular Participation in Development."

That and other conferences and meetings acknowledged that African political systems were in crisis, often unable to respond to the variety of urgent economic needs of their people, and that the prospects for external resources to ease this crisis were gloomy. Mobilizing both the energies and resources of the general population came to be seen as an important determinant in reviving economic growth.

Although agitation for greater political freedoms is not new in Africa, most previous movements for change have been contained in one way or another. "What is new," says Olara Otunnu, a former Ugandan foreign minister who heads the New York-based International Peace Academy, "is the sense of confidence and legitimacy with which the democratic demand is being made."

That maturing of political protests, has combined with the economic pressures on most Africa governments, to speed the pace of political reform. Although analysts agree that the single most important factor is popular action, many governments have recognized their inability to meet the twin challenges of domestic economic decline and international geopolitical changes. In country after country, authorities responded to large-scale demonstrations, general strikes, bread riots or violent upheaval by formulating, or agreeing to the need for, multiparty constitutions.

Even before Iraq invaded Kuwait last August, it was clear that the external assistance that has been seen as crucial to Africa's efforts to revive economic and social growth would be in short supply. The much awaited "peace dividend" -- resources freed by the end of the Cold War arms race -- would be directed not towards the world's poorest countries, but back towards Eastern Europe. Even whatever strategic significance Africa was accorded in the super-power rivalry for influence fell away. In addition, Africa's puny -- and still declining -- contribution to international trade has made it seem less and less relevant to the economic interests of richer nations. And the growth of regional economic entities such as the European Economic Community is a further threat to the small, divided economies of Africa.

The awareness of that marginalization has helped to moderate African government responses to demands for increased democracy. But the end of the story is not written yet. Some countries still strongly resist change. And Cameroonian historian Achille Mbembe warns that "there is reason to fear that reforms underway in several countries may be cosmetic."

What is predictable, though, is that there are no quick fixes. While political reforms are vital in the long term for economic revival in Africa, they are unlikely to yield swift results. And economic reforms that are introduced without popular participation or support will lead only to increased turmoil.

Salim Lone is editor-in-chief of Africa Recovery


LOAD-DATE: April 1, 1991


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1991 AllAfrica, Inc.


32 of 211 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April 1, 1991


PACE OF CHANGE QUICKENS


SECTION: DEMOCRACY


LENGTH: 1056 words


ABIDJAN -- Two of Africa's longest serving leaders were ousted last week -- one by efree election, the other by the troops he dispatched to quell pro-democracy demonstrations in the streets.

The Benin elections, which voted out dictator Mathieu Kerekou, and the overthrow of Malian strongman Moussa Traore by his own soldiers, who pledged to meet the protestors and establish "total democracy," were twin signs of the revolutionary changes sweeping West Africa.

Already, protests have forced President Felix Houphouet-Boigny to abandon one-party rule in Cote d'Ivoire and convinced his counterparts in Togo, Gabon, and Cameroon to pledge similar reforms. Popular pressure in Congo spawned a national conference now underway in Brazzaville to reform the country's single-party political system. And last month in the Cape Verde islands, the 16-year rule of the PAIGC -- the African Party for the Independence of Cape Verde, which led the fight against Portuguese colonialism -- was ended by the victory of Carlos Veiga's Movement for Democracy in the country's first multiparty elections. 

In Ghana and Nigeria, where national governments say they are gradually introducing democratic systems that will be strong enough to endure future assaults, pressure for faster, more extensive reforms is strong and growing.

The domino effect is clearly at work, as economically-pressed Africans see their neighbors win political concessions. Benin's election is particularly riveting, since Kerekou represented the generation of aging rulers whose tenures are coming to an end. "He's out," exulted Afiwae Akapko from Togo, as she watched the news from Benin on her employer's television in Abidjan, Cote d'Ivoire's capital, where she came to find work. "Eyadema will be next!" she says, referring to Togolese ruler Gnassingbe Eyadema, who has been under siege in the last two weeks by protests that left at least two people dead.

In the wake of the killings, Eyadema abandoned his long opposition to reforms and agreed to a quick transition to multiparty democracy, a general amnesty for political prisoners and exiled opponents, and a national political conference to chart the country's future.

One factor in Eyadema's new tolerance may be signals from the government of France that it will not intervene to put down the protests, as it often has in past disturbances in former French colonies.

France also has come to the aid of President Mobutu Sese Seko of Zaire during past insurrections in that former Belgian colony. But last April, Mobutu caved in to demands for opposition parties, and more than 60 are now vying for influence amid the country's economic collapse.

Some countries, such as Kenya, have resisted the trend towards multiple parties entirely, arguing that single-party rule has helped discourage political divisions along ethnic lines.

Multiparty advocates counter that ethnic hostilities have festered in single-party states, as in Benin. There, supporters of Kerekou went on a rampage last week after their man won only 32% of the vote in the country's first contested presidential election. The winner, with 68%, was Nicephore Soglo, a 57-year-old former World Bank official who has served as provisional prime minister since Kerekou loosened his hold on power during protests early last year.

Witnesses said thousands of people fled the Benin capital Cotonou and that others sought refuge at police stations and military camps when Kerekou loyalists began attacking people from the south of the country. Kerekou's power base was in the north, and critics have long claimed that his policies exacerbated ethnic tensions by favoring his own area. Dissidents, many from the south, were frequently tortured and killed by Benin's security forces, according to charges by Amnesty International, the London-based Human Rights organization.

Benin, a former French colony that became the independent nation of Dahomey in 1960, experienced six coups in its first 12 years, until Kerekou seized control 21 years ago. In the wake of the post-election violence that killed several people and wounded several dozen, many worried about reports that the army did little to stop the attacks.

But in Mali, where President Moussa Traore's one-man rule ended last week after 22 years, the army did an about-face. Following anti-government protests that left an estimated 200 people dead in four days of demonstrations, the military defied orders to suppress the continuing unrest.

"The army will no longer meddle in politics," said Col. Amadou Toumani in a radio broadcast to the nation after leading a coup against Traore. "The army will return to its barracks," he promised.

Public reaction was jubilant. In an interview on Mali state radio, human rights lawyer Demba Diallo said the "patriotic officers" who overthrew Traore had already consulted opposition leaders from the Committee of Pro-Democracy Associations. The soldiers' intention "is not to take power," Diallo said, but to "insure that Tuniform' no longer usurps the people's power."

But human rights activists cautioned the celebrating crowds against reprisals of their own. Medical personnel who wanted to remain anonymous told the Associated Press that a top Traore official and the president's brother-in-law had been burned to death, apparently by government opponents.

Traore himself is reported to be in the hands of coup leaders.

The march to democratic government in Africa's most populous nation, Nigeria, has been both more raucous and more peaceful, under the military government of President Ibrahim Babangida. With the conduct of a census last month -- a delicate undertaking in a country where both religious and ethnic questions loom large -- Nigeria is entering the final phase of a multi-year transition to civilian rule.

Nigerians have long been accustomed to speaking their minds, and the country's press is among the continent's most contentious. Last week's announcement that forthcoming elections would be by queuing, or lining up, instead of by secret ballot, prompted predictable media outrage. But government officials said that corruption had become so ingrained in the Nigerian political process that only open voting could assure the public that elections were fair as well as free.


LOAD-DATE: April 1, 1991


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1991 AllAfrica, Inc.


33 of 211 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April 1, 1991


BURKINA FASO: FILM FESTIVAL HAS MAGNETIC APPEAL


SECTION: CULTURE


LENGTH: 701 words


OUGADOUGOU -- Every two years, the capital of Burkina Faso becomes the film capital of Africa during the week-long Ouagadougou Pan-African Cinema Festival. Beginning in late February, during the heart of the Sahelian dry season, the brown and dusty landscape of Ouagadougou is transformed by the brilliant blue, green and yellow posters, billboards, and banners displayed on every street corner and available building. "Fespaco is the Environment," proclaims a banner trumpeting the environmental theme of this year's festival -- the twelfth cinema gathering here since the first one in 1969. This year the downtown area was closed to all motorized traffic, including the city's ubiquitous population of mopeds, to make way for a huge open-air crafts market.

The estimated 300,000 people Fespaco attracts are a mixture of international media moguls and local film buffs -- all here to see Africa as viewed by the continent's most talented film and television professionals. Although the commercial opportunities created by the visitors is important to Burkina Faso -- one of the world's poorest countries -- and special care was obviously taken to please the outsiders, Fespaco is a festival for the people of Ouagadougou as much as for the visiting film world. And the widespread public participation generated a sense of excitement during the festival that was felt throughout the city. 

There literally is something for everyone at Fespaco. While famous filmmakers were attending the gala opening with President Blaise Campaore in a modern air conditioned theater, the less affluent but no less cinema-mad general population was watching movies at the many open-air showings across the capital. Movie and television directors sat under palm trees next to the pool at the posh Hotel Independence, discussing the intricacies of various productions, but local inhabitants could be found sitting on street corners discussing the same films with equal enthusiasm. While visiting tourists bought traditional African crafts at the street fairs, Burkinabe were purchasing children's clothes from Pakistan at one of the two non-African craft booths.

Besides films that addressed environmental issues, many of the submissions dealt with a variety of other pressing concerns in present day Africa, such as the role of woman in society. The diversity of films and television programs at this year's festival offered spectators the rare opportunity to glimpse scenes of an entire continent without having to leave Ouagadougou.

Two of the most talked-about films were from the same filmmaker, Idrissa Ouedraogo of Burkina Faso. The festival opened with Karim and Sala, Ouedraogo's most recent work -- so recent that some of the film's scenes shot in Ouagadougou had Fespaco billboards in the background. Shot largely in the country's two urban centers, Ouagadougou and Bobo Dioulasso, the film follows the lives and friendship of two children as they struggle through the seemingly mad adult urban world. A "light" movie by most standards, it depicts Ouedraogo's vision of a world where dreams come true, where families win lotteries, children overcome all hardships, and improbable coincidences restore separated families.

The setting and the message of Ouedraogo's other festival film, Tilai, were vastly different. Filmed entirely in rural Burkina Faso, the story revolves around serious topics such as incest, fratricide, forbidden love, and traditional honor. Already the winner of the special Jury Prize at Cannes in 1990, Tilai captured Fespaco's top prize, the Yennenga Stallion.

The film that many had predicted might win this year's Yennenga, but didn't, turned out to be one of the festival's biggest crowd pleasers: Halfaouine, a Tunisian film directed by Ferid Boughedir. Transporting audiences half a continent away for a tale of an adolescent boy's interaction in the very disparate cultures of male and female Tunisia, Halfaouine had the backing of many critics. But Ouedraogo was a sentimental choice, whose prize seemed to represent both his own well-regarded body of work and the predominant role his impoverished country has played in the promotion of African film.


LOAD-DATE: April 1, 1991


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1991 AllAfrica, Inc.


34 of 211 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April 1, 1991


MOURNING AND MOPPING UP


LENGTH: 1656 words


MONROVIA -- Tejan Cole has big plans for the future. As soon as he can get a calculator, a typewriter, a desk and a chair, he intends to restart the accounting firm he ran before civil war disrupted commerce and drove him from his home last summer.

But with one eye on the future, Cole is preoccupied with unfinished business from the past. He desperately wants to find out whether his wife and 10-year-old daughter are alive or dead.

Like many Liberian families, the Coles were separated in fighting that raged throughout the country when rebel groups took on troops loyal to then-President Samuel K. Doe. During the rebel advance into the capital, Monrovia, in August, Cole was caught on the side controlled by government forces, while his wife and daughter were trapped in an area that was overtaken by rebels. 

Eight months later, Liberia remains a divided country. Monrovia is administered by an interim government under the security umbrella of a 7,000 strong West African peacekeeping force. The rest of this Ohio-size nation, falls behind lines controlled by the National Patriotic Front of Liberia (NPFL), the movement led by Charles Taylor, a former government bureaucrat who launched an insurgency against Doe in late 1989.

Two people have told Cole that his wife and daughter were among the civilians killed by one of the warring factions. But he refuses to accept the news until the roads out of the capital are opened and he can investigate for himself. Cole wants to believe that his family fled to another part of the country during the battle for Monrovia. "I haven't given up hope that I will see them one day," he says.

With Taylors troops allowing few people to cross the dividing lines, Liberia has been unable to tally its dead. A Liberian relief group estimates that 30,000 people have been killed, while other guesses run much higher.

Physical damage caused by the heavy fighting is pervasive. Many homes and buildings have been seriously damaged or destroyed, most are marked with bullet holes, and virtually every structure has been ransacked. Evidence of widespread pillaging endures in the looted goods displayed for sale on every sidewalk.

But in the three months since the West African troops imposed a cease-fire in Monrovia, life has slowly regained a measure of normalcy. Markets are bustling with people, several restaurants are serving meals, and shops and other businesses have begun to reopen.

Alli and Mary Johnson were among the first shopkeepers to start again. Their little stand on the beach was burned down, so in December they rented a stall at the corner of Newport Street and Sekou Toure Avenue and began selling a few goods. They called the stall "Check Point," because it stood beside a guard post that was maintained by one of the armed groups.

The location is near a more affluent area known as Mamba Point -- site of the American embassy, the United Nations relief operation, and several non-governmental assistance groups. But the Johnsons' clientele is almost exclusively from the neighborhood, and the biggest selling item is palm wine -- the alcoholic beverage of choice for those unable to afford the imported products now making their way onto the market.

Heineken beer, selling at Check Point for about $ 3 a can, moves more slowly. A limited selection of food, including flour, sugar, bread, and tea, is also on the shelves. A loaf of bread now sells for about 25 cents, less than a fifth the price of a few weeks ago.

A larger variety of goods has begun appearing on the shelves of the bigger Lebanese-run grocery stores, such as Delbani Supermarket in the center of town. Renovations at the back are in progress, while shelves in the front of the shop display over four dozen items. Store manager Edward Ayub says that when he resumed business at the end of February, he offered less than a quarter of the items he has now, and prices were much higher.

For most residents of the city, food prices are still out of reach. Almost no one is formally employed. The entire interim government is working on a volunteer basis, because no funds were left in the national treasury after the war.

Since late September, food has been reaching the population through a relief effort coordinated by the United Nations and the U.S.-based Catholic Relief Services. Rice, beans, cooking oil, and modest quantities of fish supplied by the United States government and the UN World Food Program are being distributed by a locally led group known as SELF (Special Emergency Life Food Program).

Dorothea Diggs, who co-founded SELF with three other Liberians, says the aim was to create a distribution program that could supply everyone equitably and minimize opportunities for fraud. "We want to show that we can do this without being corrupt," she says.

SELF volunteers conducted a house-by-house survey that numbered over 46,000 dwellings and compiled a computerized registry of their occupants. When a food distribution takes place -- there have been six since late September -- a representative of each household must come to one of 140 neighborhood centers SELF established to collect the household's certified allotment. Everyone in the house is entitled to an equal share.

With the food system in place and working smoothly, SELF is now preparing for the next phase. "We are making plans for productive resettlement of people," says Blamoh Nelson, another co-founder of the group. "We want to move beyond free gifts to encourage people to be productive even under the difficult conditions here."

Working alongside foreign relief groups, SELF is preparing to expand its efforts to Liberia's interior. Several organizations are providing assistance to the concentrations of refugees on the country's borders with Sierra Leone, Guinea, and Cote d'Ivoire. But there is believed to be an urgent need for food and medical care in parts of the country that have been inaccessible to outside help.

The first step towards opening the roads was taken early last month with a series of "confidence visits" organized by the West African peacekeeping force. Members of the armed factions along with journalists and other observers traveled to Charles Taylor's headquarters at Gbarnga and to other towns behind rebel lines, where they were greeted with welcoming shouts of "We want peace," and "No More War."

The roadblocks dividing the two sides went back up as soon as the visits were concluded, but negotiations are underway to expand the security cordon from the capital to other parts of Liberia.

Plans for expanding the relief efforts got a boost with the arrival two weeks ago of the "Harbel Tapper," a large ocean freighter leased by Firestone Rubber Company to bring food, medicines and clothing for war victims, along with vehicles and other materials needed to re-start the firm's rubber plantations at Harbel. The Ohio-based company has been a major presence and a potent symbol of American involvement in Liberia since 1926 .

"We're very happy to have arrived back with 3,000 tons of relief cargo for the needy of this country," said D.A. Ensminger, the American manager of Firestone's Liberia subsidiary, as he watched four big cranes offload the goods. He and the rest of the Firestone management were forced out of the country by fighting last July. This month, the company is sending the ship to bring another 6,000 tons of supplies from Abidjan, Cote d'Ivoire, 500 miles down the Atlantic Coast.

Along with 143,000 bags of rice, beans, and peas, the Harbel Tapper left Baltimore, Maryland with two dozen 20-foot-long wooden crates filled with clothes, medical supplies, and canned wares collected in the U.S. by the Liberian Committee for Relief, Resettlement, and Reconstruction. The committee has joined forces with the United Methodist Church of Liberia to provide the vital supplies to day care facilities, schools and clinics, which have become gathering points for the most needy.

"The whole idea is to involve Liberians directly in disseminating these things," says James Holder, executive director of the relief committee. "As appreciative as we are for what foreigners have come in and done, we have to take initiative ourselves."

Holder, who is serving as interim minister of commerce, believes involvement in relief work can offer local people "hands-on" experience, which he hopes can help spark future development. "Liberians have to take the ball and carry it," he says. "As bad as our situation has become, we now have the opportunity to start from scratch and do things right."

But outside help will be critical to cope with the current emergency. Preliminary assessments suggest that the civil war has brought food production to a halt. "Our farmers, who are 70% of our people, lost their crops, their homes, their tools, and their seeds," says Dr. Nah-do Bropleh, interim agriculture minister. Liberia, which used to be a major seed supplier for the entire region, now urgently needs seeds itself.

The country will be dependent on food aid for at least two years, Bropleh says. "Our priority is to be able to feed ourselves as quickly as possible."

The cost of reconstruction will be huge, but SELF director Diggs sees signs that the rebuilding process has begun. "For all the destruction in Liberia, people are going to their houses and cleaning up the mess in places you would not even want to go. It will take a lot of time to get out of this fix, but we have the courage to do it."

For Tejan Cole, starting over will not be easy. He lost everything he owned when both his accounting office and his home were looted during the fighting. But even as he worries about his wife and daughter, he is looking forward to expanding his firm to include public relations work. "There will be a lot of opportunities," he says. "People will want to set their businesses up right."


LOAD-DATE: April 1, 1991


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1991 AllAfrica, Inc.


35 of 211 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April 1, 1991


LONGING FOR PEACE IN LIBERIA


LENGTH: 1152 words


 

MONROVIA-- "We are here for peace," said Dr. Toga MacIntosh, as he led the delegation from Liberia's main rebel group into the opening of the All-Liberian National Conference. "We will not walk out of this meeting without an agreement on conditions for a lasting peace."

Last week, after 10 days of negotiations, the rebels walked out, taking with them hopes for an early resolution of the civil war that has left Liberia in ruins. Although the MacIntosh delegates promised to return in a week and assured Liberians that the current ceasefire will remain in effect, their departure heightened fears that a peaceful agreement to end the 15-month long conflict may prove impossible. 

Liberia has been wracked by violence and famine since December, 1989, when former civil servant Charles Taylor launched his insurgency with about two dozen men. His National Patriotic Front for the Liberation of Liberia (NPFL) attracted broad popular support that swelled its ranks to thousands of fighters and led to the assassination of dictator Samuel K. Doe. But conflicts between rebels and remnants of Doe's army, and between the NPFL and a breakaway faction led by former Taylor lieutenant Prince Yormi Johnson, reduced much of the capital to rubble, killed tens of thousands of people across the country, and forced more than half the country's 2.6 million people to flee their homes.

The Monrovia meeting was convened by the 16-nation Economic Community of West African States (Ecowas) which intervened to stop the destruction. Three months ago, an army of soldiers from five Ecowas nations managed to enforce a ceasefire. Under protection of the peacekeepers, known as Ecomog -- for Ecowas Monitoring Group, representatives of six political parties and 14 civic, professional and religious organizations joined rival rebel factions in the peace talks, aimed at establishing a framework for democratic government.

The first days of the conference were devoted to lengthy wrangling over accreditation and procedural matters. The NPFL said the conference was dominated by "exiled politicians" with no popular base in the electorate. Other participants accused Taylor's group of stalling and of maneuvering to grab power by force. Last week's walkout came after the NPFL unsuccessfully sought an adjournment to allow consideration of the group's proposal that Charles Taylor be named co-president of an interim government.

Taylor himself stayed away from Monrovia, citing "confirmed intelligence reports" of a plot on his life, but insisting that he has earned the right to leadership by his role in ousting Doe, who came to power in a 1980 military coup. The current interim government is headed by Dr. Amos C. Sawyer, a former university dean who was teaching at the University of Indiana when he was chosen provisional president by a gathering of Liberian groups held in Banjul, Gambia. Taylor boycotted that session, which took place during the height of the fighting in Monrovia last August.

The Monrovia talks are designed to meet Taylor's demand for a national conference inside Liberia. Foreign ministers or other senior officials from seven neighboring countries have participated in the early deliberations. The Ecowas representatives negotiated the selection of three prominent Liberians to chair the sessions: Roman Catholic Archbishop Michael Francis, Muslim Council leader Sheikh Kafumba Konneh, and retired Ambassador Herbert Brewer, a former envoy to Washington and London.

But Taylor's refusal to attend suggested failure from the beginning, and the west African mediators set out to try to win his cooperation. Nigerian Foreign Minister Ike Nwachukwu held an unannounced hour-long session with Taylor on March 16, the day after the conference opened, in Kakata, 45 miles from the capital. Ecowas Secretary General Abbas Bundu and Togolese Foreign Minister Yaovi Adodo also made successive trips to see the NPFL chief.

"Ecomog has done everything to bring him down here in security, but security is very personal," Adodo said after his meeting with Taylor. Special arrangements were made to insure Taylor's safety, the diplomats said -- in addition to the roadblocks in place all around the conference center and the body searches of all participants as they enter the area.

Few here would dispute Taylor's assertion that he could be a target for his rival Prince Johnson. In September, Johnson's group captured Doe when the president ventured out of his heavily fortified Executive Mansion for a visit to Ecomog headquarters. Doe was tortured and killed, and many here are convinced that Johnson would like to eliminate Taylor as well.

For a number of peace talk participants, the first sign that Taylor was ready to enter serious negotiations came at the end of the opening week when his delegation proposed the creation of a three-person ruling council to replace the interim government and lead Liberia towards elections. In a telephone interview with the BBC, Taylor said the council should include himself, a representative of the interim government, and a "neutral" person acceptable to both sides. Previously, Taylor opposed any role for the interim government.

But most conference delegates rejected the NPFL compromise. The Banjul peace plan specifies that no leader of an armed faction can head the interim government and stipulates that neither the interim president nor vice-president can be a presidential candidate in national elections slated for late this year.

Last week, in an attempt to forge a transitional arrangement acceptable to all sides, a nine-person conference committee proposed the creation of two vice presidential posts in the interim government -- one for a representative from each rebel movement. Like the Banjul plan, the committee's blueprint offers Taylor himself the post of speaker of the legislative assembly, the most senior position in the interim government that would leave him eligible to contest the presidential race.

The committee said national elections should be held in October and that the tenure of the interim government should expire in January.

Despite the departure of the NPFL delegation, and the general acknowledgment that no peace scheme can succeed without Taylor's involvement, the conference proceeded to consider the committee report.

But many Liberians remain fearful of Taylor's intentions. "Everybody was supporting Taylor at the beginning," says the Rev. Dixon Kumeh, a delegate representing the Liberia Council of Churches. But Kumeh now believes that "Taylor can never be president" because of the widespread atrocities attributed to his supporters and his refusal to halt the fighting after Doe's death.

"There has been too much bloodletting," says interim president Sawyer. "No one would feel secure with one of the military factions at the head of an interim government."


LOAD-DATE: April 1, 1991


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


May 20, 1991


PEACE REMAINS ELUSIVE


SECTION: CONFLICT: LIBERIA


LENGTH: 522 words


ABIDJAN -- New initiatives are underway to find a solution to Liberia's bloody civil war, which has cost thousands of Liberian lives, crossed the border into Sierra Leone and threatens to widen into a regional conflict.

Diplomats from the 16-nation Economic Community of West Africa (Ecowas), which has a peacekeeping force in the Liberian capital, Monrovia, are exploring possible actions to end the stalement that has divided Liberia into two camps.

Meanwhile, the interim government, operating from Monrovia under the protection of the 7,000-strong west African force, is seeking to gain recognition from its neighbors and from key world powers like the United States. A delegation from the interim government visiting Washington earlier this month to seek closer cooperation and ask U.S. assistance in settling court claims which have frozen all of Liberia's assets in foreign banks. 

U.S. Rep. Mervyn Dymally (D-CA), chairman of the House Africa subcommittee, is trying to break the political deadlock by convening a meeting of the two Liberian sides. He is seeking to bring together the president of the interim government, Amos Sawyer, and rebel leader Charles Taylor, who has refused to cooperate with the Monrovia administration. The Congressman saw both men during a one-day visit to Liberia last month.

Taylor heads a regime heaquartered in Gbanga, 125 miles from Monrovia, which claims control over 90 percent of the country. As the leader of the insurgency launched at the end of 1989 that resulted in the death last September of former President Samuel K. Doe, Taylor says he has earned the right to lead the country until elections are held.

Last month, Taylor's forces clashed with troops from Sierra Leone along the two countries' common border. Sierra Leone has accused Taylor's troops of invading and capturing a number of border towns. Taylor denies his men have attacked Sierra Leone, saying the fighting is caused by opponents of the country's president, Joseph Momoh.

But many of the governments in the area believe Taylor is behind the trouble, including recent clashes in nearby Guinea. Sierra Leonean troops form part of the west African force in Monrovia, which Taylor believes was sent to keep him from seizing the capital. He had earlier vowed to attack the airport in the Sierra Leonean capital, Freetown, the staging base for supplying the west African monitoring force.

Nigeria and Guinea, two other members of the Ecowas Monitoring Group, known as Ecomog, have sent troops to assist Sierra Leone's poorly equipped and lightly trained army. Momoh is also seeking aid from the United States and Great Britain, and both have indicated a willingness to supply materiel.

West African diplomats think Taylor wants to undermine Ecowas willingness to maintain the troops in Monrovia, and they say his armed men include dissidents from several of the surrounding countries. Taylor further alienated Ecowas members when he refused to attend or fully cooperate with an All-Liberia conference convened by the west African governments to work out a peace plan for the country.


LOAD-DATE: May 29, 1991


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1991 AllAfrica, Inc.


37 of 211 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 20, 1991


MOZAMBIQUE: NEGOTIATORS TRY AGAIN


LENGTH: 1166 words
