A sixth round of talks between the Mozambican government and the Renamo rebel movement has begun in Rome, under the sponsorship of the Roman Catholic Church and the Italian government.

With mediators saying last week that the two sides were close to agreement, hopes are rising for an end to the brutal conflict. Fifteen years of Renamo attacks have destroyed much of Mozambique's productive capacity and social infrastructure and caused losses estimated at $ 15 billion in a country ranked as one of the three poorest in the world.

Late last year, the government of President Joaquim Chissano obtained National Assembly approval for sweeping constitutional changes, including all the political reforms demanded by Renamo as conditions for ending the fighting. Mozambique now has a multiparty political system, secret ballot elections, and private property ownership and other personal liberties enshrined in law. 

Several opposition parties have already formed to challenge the ruling Mozambique Liberation Front (Frelimo), which led the independence campaign and has governed since 1975. Among the new groupings are the Mozambique National Union, made up of former Renamo members, the Mozambique National Movement, headed by Maximo Dias, and the Liberal Democratic Party, known as Palmo, now headed by Martin Bilal. Palmo has stirred controversy by advocating job and other preferences for "original Mozambicans" -- a stand sharply at odds with Frelimo's policy of strict equality of treatment for all Mozambicans, including whites and those of mixed-ancestry.

During Palmo's first party congress this month, Casimiro Nhamitambo, a founding member who had been favored as a presidential candidate, reportedly walked out in a dispute with other leaders, promising to set up a new political organization along the same anti-socialist lines as Palmo.

Meanwhile, the war continues. A partial cease-fire agreement late last year broke down in February, with incidents that included attacks on famine relief efforts. A 10-nation verification panel established to monitor the accord blamed Renamo for the violations. The United States government, which serves on the panel, condemned Renamo's refusal to observe the pact.

Details of Renamo's structure and objectives have always been murky. Established in the mid-1970s by the white Rhodesian intelligence service to undermine Mozambique's support for the Zimbabwe independence forces, Renamo became a ward of South African military intelligence when Zimbabwe gained its independence in 1980. In 1984, South Africa signed a non-aggression pact with Mozambique, pledging to end all support for the rebels. But Renamo supply lines remained open.

The ongoing fighting has left a sizeable portion of Mozambique's 15 million people in danger of starvation. As many as six million have been displaced from their homes, many of them forced into exile in neighboring countries, with up to one million concentrated in Malawi.

The task of coordinating assistance for Mozambicans in need -- and the job of day-to-day administration of the government in Maputo -- lies with Prime Minister Mario Machungo. In an interview during this month's African Development Bank meeting in Abidjan, Machungo spoke of the challenges facing his country-at-war.

AN: Are you able to get help to the people left hungry and homeless by the fighting?

Machungo: No, people living in some areas are inaccessible. The war has destroyed much of our transport infrastructure, such as roads and bridges. We don't have planes or money for this effort. That is why the collaboration and aid of the international community is very important.

AN: Have your recent appeals for assistance had an adequate response?

Machungo: Unfortunately, no. We are still talking with donor countries in order to speed up the flow.

AN: Do you have hopes that this round of talks will result in an agreement?

Machungo: Yes, we always keep our hopes for peace. Our delegation has instructions from our president to cooperate with Renamo in order to bring Renamo to reasonable thinking and to find peace. Renamo has said they are committed to the peace process. This has been broadcast and published everywhere in the world. We think the democratization process going on in Mozambique and the trends towards peace and detente in the world may influence Renamo to open their minds, to understand that it is now time for peace in our country.

The environment has been created in Mozambique for Renamo to transform itself into a party, and if they want power that they have to gain power at the polls.

AN: Where does Renamo's outside support come from now?

Machungo: Maybe the same sources.

AN: South Africa?

Machungo: We don't think that the government of South Africa is supporting Renamo, but some forces inside South Africa are.

AN: It is widely reported that Kenya backs Renamo. Has your government discussed this with Kenya?

Machungo: Yes, recently President Chissano made an official visit to Kenya and talked with President Moi to strengthen our mutual understanding. President Moi stressed his commitment to helping Mozambique reach peace and cooperation with all the countries in the region, including Mozambique.

AN: Does the fact that the central committee of Frelimo voted against the new constitution -- and was then overridden by the political bureau -- suggest that there are deep divisions within Frelimo about the changes taking place?

Machungo: We have some divergences, but the discussions we have had have been very positive. There is agreement that Frelimo should continue being a party committed to social justice and democracy.

When we took the constitution to the people for discussion (in a series of nationwide seminars and debates), the majority said they wanted the one-party system. But because there was a strata of our population that believe in the multiparty system, we had to take this into account. The majority is not always right. That's why our politburo proposed a multiparty system, because of the need to accommodate minority feelings.

AN: In the economy, where do you see the best possibilities for revitalization and what are your development priorities?

Machungo: After 27 years of war in our country, I must say that peace is our first priority. Life has been completely disrupted, and we have to resettle people and restore normality. Poverty is devastating our people. This means we have to emphasize rural development -- agriculture, as well as health and education.

The role of the government will be building up the proper environment for the development of private enterprise. This will also provide the important social base for pluralism, for the guarantee of democracy.

We are also focusing attention of the problems of women and children. Historically, women have played an important role socially and economically. We have to take this into account.


LOAD-DATE: May 29, 1991


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1991 AllAfrica, Inc.


38 of 211 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 20, 1991


ANGOLA: PEACE COULD BRING PROSPERITY


LENGTH: 1267 words


Angolan President Jose Eduardo dos Santos and Jonas Savimbi, leader of the Unita movement, are slated to take part in a formal signing ceremony late this month for the peace accord announced at the beginning of May.

Under the agreement, a cease-fire in the 16-year-long war took effect last Wednesday. The accord also calls for the formation of a new national army and for national elections between September and November of next year.

As the deadline for cessation in hostilities approached, Savimbi pledged his forces' compliance. But the Luanda government charged that Unita forces were on the offensive in four provinces, seeking to gain control of at least one town before the fighting stopped. In New York, Angolan Foreign Minister Pedro da Castro van Dunem said he has evidence that South Africa is still supplying Unita in violation of a 1988 agreement. 

The road to settlement in Angola has been long and difficult. The war between Unita rebels and government forces, controlled by dos Santos' ruling MPLA, began prior to the country's independence in 1975. A United Nations estimate says at least 500,000 children died during the 1980s from war and the effects of war.

Angola's impoverished population of nearly 10 million has been uprooted by the fighting. According to the human rights organization Africa Watch, both sides in the conflict have been guilty of "rampant abuse of civilians."

Peace terms call for the cease-fire and election process to be monitored by United Nations observers and overseen by a verification panel composed of the two Angolan warring parties and three foreign governments. The three are Portugal, the former colonial power which mediated the agreement; the Soviet Union, which along with Cuba has been the major source of support for the MPLA; and the United States, which, along with South Africa, has been Unita's largest backer.

An end to the fighting could bring a fairly rapid recovery for Angola's economy, which is potentially one of the strongest in Africa. The country produces about 453,000 barrels of oil a day, making an amount second only to Nigeria in sub-Saharan Africa. Oil accounts for one-third of the Gross Domestic Product, half the government revenue, and over 90% of total export earnings. Chevron and several other American oil companies have major operations in Angola.

Since 1988, the government has committed itself to an economic reform program designed to attract additional foreign investment and stimulate a local private sector. Heading the list of government priorities are agriculture and agro-processing industries. According to Finance Minister Aguinaldo Jaime, Angola's fertile soil "can grow almost anything." The missing ingredient has been peace, he said in an interview during this month's annual meeting of the African Development Bank in Abidjan.

AN: The Programa da Saneamento Economico e Financeiro (SEF) was launched nearly three years ago. Why has there not been more progress?

Jaime: The results have not been all that encouraging because the on-going war takes about 15% of our revenues. And that is reason enough not to achieve any development, any of the objectives we have set up. On the other hand, I am very encouraged by several recent trends. If we manage to bring the war to an end, we will succeed in developing the country, but if the war proceeds, there is no chance for development.

AN: Are you optimistic that the war will end.

Jaime: I think there is still some uncertainty. If we succeed in creating a national army, then I will be optimistic. To let MPLA and Unita maintain their own armed forces would be a disaster. But the United States and the Soviet Union are playing an important role. Fifteen years of conflict have created so many hard feelings, so much distrust that we need this help to bring the conflict to an end.

AN: While the war certainly explains some of the shortcomings of SEF, there are some steps which could have been taken but were not. Why not?

Jaime: There has been a big debate within the government, within the party, and even within the entire society. Many people fear that because we are just about to begin an election process, this is not the right time to implement some of the measures. They are unpopular, because the distortions in the Angolan economy are so huge and some of the measures in the short run will really affect the standard of living of our people.

But some of us believe there is no valid alternative to moving ahead at this time. The more we delay the implementation of the reforms, the more the distortions continue.

AN: Devaluation was one of the steps promised in SEF. But when it finally took place in March, it was a rather modest in scope, since there remains a huge gap between the official rate of 59.2 to a U.S. dollar and the unofficial going rate of about 1000 to a dollar.

Jaime: We have devalued by 100%, and this is very far from the equilibrium rate of exchange, which lies somewhere between the official rate and the rate on the parallel market. We didn't expect impressive results, but we wanted to see the reaction of the economy. With devaluation, we think we could probably create the conditions to increase our domestic production, and this is not something that is going to happen in just three or four months.

We believe further devaluations are needed. But the end of the war is more essential. Since the circulation of people and goods are impossible, we cannot stimulate domestic production while there is fighting.

AN: What other measures are planned to deal with the big price gaps that exist between the official stores and the parallel market? Doesn't the continued existence of the parallel market indicate you have a serious problem with corruption?

Jaime: The prices in the official market are artificial, meaning there is really a temptation to deviate these products from the official circuit and sell them in the parallel market where you can obtain large amounts of profits.

One of our targets for this year is to reform our system of pricing and just subsidize one or two or three products. The government continues to believe that a few primary goods must be sold at an artificial price, subsidized by the state -- sugar, powdered milk, bread, flour, perhaps. Prices for all the other products are going to increase. It is not going to be popular. This is a very sensitive moment.

AN: Will this affect the rest of the country or principally only Luanda?

Jaime: No, mainly Luanda. There we don't have any agriculture. In most of the provinces, they are able to produce some, even with the war. Not enough to distribute to the whole population, but sufficient for people living there. The parallel market is a phenomenon essentially limited to Luanda, where there is a large population of dislocated people -- people have come there because they believe they will be safer. From about 500,000 in colonial times, the capital now has about two million people.

AN: What are your first priorities for economic development?

Jaime: In the past, Angola was self-sufficient in food production. We want to end our dependence on imports and promote agriculture and food-processing industries. We also want to attract foreign investment to our mines, (as in) the oil sector. We have fish and fish-processing, as well as other light industrial capacity. And we must build housing for our people.

If we manage to stabilize the country, Angola can play a major role in the development of southern Africa, of all of Africa.


LOAD-DATE: May 29, 1991


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1991 AllAfrica, Inc.


39 of 211 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 20, 1991


GUINEA-BISSAU: NEW PATHS TO OLD GOALS


LENGTH: 770 words


The African Party for the Independence of Guinea and Cape Verde (PAIGC) has ruled Guinea-Bissau since its leaders declared unilateral independence in late 1973 -- a move that helped spark the coup six months later, which toppled the Portuguese dictatorship and led to independence for all of Portugal's African colonies.

This month, the PAIGC-controlled national assembly voted to end one-party rule and allow the formation of opposition groups to contest elections slated for 1993.

According to President Joao Bernando Viera, who came to power in a 1980 coup, the shift is the continuation of a reform process begun in the early 1980s. The first step was a program of economic liberalization designed to reverse economic decline and make the country eligible for international assistance. 

The constitutional changes approved on May 4 allow a new party to register once it receives 2,000 verifiable signatures. Other changes proposed by a constitutional commission set up by Viera include guarantees of press freedoms and trade union rights.

One opposition party, the Social Democratic Front, led by Rafael Barbosa, has already been established, according to Agence France Presse. Another group, led by former PAIGC official, Aristides Minerves, is expected to apply for registration soon.

Guinea-Bissau has a per capita income of only $ 170, and an average life expectancy among the world's lowest -- less than 47 years. The government believes 40% of children under five suffer from malnutrition.

Viera is campaigning for increased outside aid and investment. Last month, he brought his case for help to the First African-African American Summit in Abidjan where Africa News interviewed him.

AN: As a leader of a country making the transition from single party rule to pluralism, how do you explain the rapid pace of democratization now taking place in this part of the world.

Viera: With regard to Guinea-Bissau, I must emphasize that we are not copying any other examples. We actually started discussing change at our 1984 party congress. Nobody on the outside paid much attention, except that some of our friends in the eastern bloc started giving us some criticism. We began with economic liberalization and have moved from there. We have not acted under pressure. We are taking these steps because we need to go forward.

AN: With all the difficulties you are facing, particularly on the economic front, has the PAIGC lost some of its support?

Viera: Not at all. Everybody remembers the leading role the party played in the liberation of the country. In nearly every family, someone supported the liberation struggle and shared the suffering we went through. We look at the PAIGC as the father, who after providing for the children to grow up, must now allow them the freedom to do whatever they wish. We think it is time for new parties to take part in the political life of our country. If tomorrow the PAIGC is not leading the country politically, it will still be remembered for what it did.

AN: You have changed policies, moving away from a centrally-planned economy. How has this affected the PAIGC's political priorities?

Viera: Our objectives and goals are still the same. We still have to fight poverty and hunger and provide better living conditions and education for our population. To tackle those problems, we need means, and that's what we are seeking from developed countries.

AN: What are your economic priorities?

Viera: We now have a totally free market in Guinea-Bissau. In the past, the state was the major economic factor, but this did not work. That's the reason we decided to liberalize. But because of this and because of colonialism, there are no Guineans with capital to play the role we are looking for. We have to provide loans to our citizens in order for them to become real participants in the economic process.

We want to attract tourists, but we have to get people to know our country better -- they confuse us with Guinea (Conakry), Equatorial Guinea, Papua New Guinea. We also need to develop our tourist infrastructure.

The country has the potential for growth in agriculture, mining, and forestry. Fisheries could also be very important, but we do not have the means to control our waters.

Pirate fishing is a big problem for us. We have introduced new laws to try to protect our fish, especially certain species, and to preserve our other wildlife and the environment. As a measure of the importance we attach to this, I am chairing a national commission on the protection of our wildlife and environment.


LOAD-DATE: May 29, 1991


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1991 AllAfrica, Inc.


40 of 211 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 20, 1991


NEW BEGINNINGS IN LUSOPHONE AFRICA


SECTION: DEMOCRACY


LENGTH: 308 words


The independence of five Portuguese-speaking nations 16 years ago marked the last major wave of African decolonization. Today, Africa's Lusophone countries are in the mainstream of the continent's political and economic changes.

In March, multiparty elections in two island nations off Africa's west coast ousted leaders who had governed since independence. Miguel Trovoada was elected president of Sao Tome and Pr?ncipe, replacing Manuel Pinto da Costa, who dropped out of the race a month before the voting. Trovoada, 54, was one of the leaders of the independence struggle and served as prime minister under Pinto da Costa until 1979, when he was charged with plotting a coup, sent to jail for two years, and then exiled to Paris.

Cape Verdeans selected as their new president Antonio Mascarenhas Monteiro, a 47-year-old former supreme court president. Voted out was 67-year-old Aristides Pereira, leader of the African Party for the Independence of Cape Verde (PAIGV), which have spearheaded the anti-colonial campaign. The years in power had eroded the PAIGV's popularity, and the party also lost the parliamentary elections, winning 23 seats compared with 56 captured by the Movement for Democracy, headed by Carlos Veiga, who has become the country's new prime minister.

The three former Portuguese colonies on the mainland --Guinea-Bissau, Angola, and Mozambique --have shed Marxist-Leninist leanings for more free-market economic policies and pluralist political arrangements. In Angola and Mozambique, the changes parallel new efforts to end devastating civil conflicts that have raged since independence.

Africa News has discussed the latest developments with top leaders from all three mainland states -- the president of Guinea-Bissau, the prime minister of Mozambique, and the finance minister of Angola.


LOAD-DATE: May 29, 1991


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1991 AllAfrica, Inc.


41 of 211 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 20, 1991


COUNTING THE MULTITUDES (BUT NOT THEIR BELIEFS)


LENGTH: 490 words


The national census scheduled for next October in Nigeria will provide the first count of Nigerians since 1973.

To prepare for the massive project and identify weaknesses in the logistical preparations, the Nigerian National Population Commission conducted a trial census during three days in mid-March. Commission officials said the exercise uncovered a number of flaws, including a shortage of census materials, the inability of enumerators to cover their assigned territories, and widespread misunderstanding of the questions on the census forms. 

With its current estimated population of 116 million, Nigeria already counts itself home to one of every four Africans. In addition to trying to pin down a more precise population figure, the census is expected to provide essential social and economic data.

But one statistic the census will not be able to provide is the number of Nigerians who practice various faiths. The October exercise will omit any question about religion -- perhaps the most sensitive and divisive issue the country faces.

The growth of Islamic fundamentalism in the northern region, where large numbers of young people have been joining militant Shi'ite groups, has contributed to the worst religious conflict in Nigeria since the early 1980s.

The latest clashes, in which several hundred people have died and dozens of churches have been burned, have followed months of simmering conflict between Muslims and Christians in the area. Islamic fundamentalist leaders have demanded that the government allow the practice of Sharia, a strict legal code mandating such penalties as stoning and dismemberment, that is rejected by many Muslims as well as other groups.

The Roman Catholic Archbishop of Lagos, Anthony Okogie, says the country risks a religious war unless the government can protect Christians from what he called "fanatical Muslims."

Nigerian President Ibrahim Babangida, himself a Muslim, warned on state radio that the government will deal "very ruthlessly" with religious violence. "Why should people impose their wishes, beliefs or ideologies on others?" Babangida asked, saying that Islam opposes the spread of the faith by force.

Earlier this month the Nigerian Vice President, Admiral Augustus Aikhomu, a Christian, visited Bauchi state, where mosques as well as dozens of churches have been destroyed by rival groups. Aikhomu said extremist Christian evangelicals bear some of the blame for the religious tensions. But in a stern speech, he also said that radical Shi'ites must recognize Nigeria as a multi-ethnic and multi-religious nation, whose government will respond forcefully to intolerence.

Last week an evangelical church leader charged that Christians are still being killed in northern areas, often in quiet raids on people in their homes or fields. People will begin going hungry, he warned, because fear is keeping them away from their farm work.


LOAD-DATE: May 29, 1991


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1991 AllAfrica, Inc.


42 of 211 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 20, 1991


SECRET BALLOT BECOMES ELECTION ISSUE


SECTION: DEMOCRACY: NIGERIA


LENGTH: 1083 words


LAGOS -- As Africa's most populous nation makes its third attempt since independence to establish a durable democracy, the question of how to insure a free and fair voting process has become a central issue for the military government.

Announcing the decision by Nigeria's Armed Forces Ruling Council (AFRC) to conduct elections by what is commonly known as the "open ballot," President Ibrahim Babangida said the AFRC based its choice on Nigeria's "historical experience" and its present level of socio-political development.

Open balloting had a trial run last December during local government elections, when voters lined up in front of posters of competing candidates. At a signal from polling officials, voters would raise their hands in acknowledgment while counting off, "One," "Two," "Three," and so on down each line. Election monitors walked down the lines to confirm the count. 

The result was one of Nigeria's most successful elections, unmarred by the incidents of violence and charges of electoral fraud that were a common feature of past polls. Most politicians as well the country's lively press expressed confidence in the results. The slightly left-of-center Social Democratic Party emerged with a slim lead over the slightly right-of-center National Republican convention by capturing 2,934 local council seats to its rival's 2,558.

But critics of open balloting say it has a major flaw that was apparent in the December elections, when a reluctance to make their choices public kept most voters from the polls.

The Civil Liberties Organization, a leading human rights group, has filed a court action to have the local council elections nullified. Olisa Agbakoba, the group's president, says the low participation prevented the voting from being free and fair. Turn-out is estimated to have been as low as 10%.

Critics also say that the system of lining up is primitive and unwieldy. They say that voters who stay away either out of fear or because the procedures are cumbersome have been effectively disenfranchised. Ray Ekpu, editor of the weekly newsmagazine Newswatch, acknowledges that the secret ballot system must be modified to allow more effective management, but he argues that secret balloting "drastically reduces undue influence on the voter."

Advocates of open voting counter that avoiding the mistakes of past elections requires public scrutiny of the process. The four major elections in the country's history -- in 1959, 1964, 1979 and 1983 -- employed secret ballots, but the results were tarnished by large-scale malpractices. Among the techniques that became commonplace were the printing of fake ballots and the stuffing of ballot boxes by corrupt elections officials.

It was the resulting rancor over disputed results that provided the Nigerian military with excuses to overthrow elected governments in 1966 and 1983.

"Our problems in the past have been with secret ballots and the ballot papers," Babangida said, defending the ruling council decision, "and we want to make sure that this problem does not persist in our national life."

Many Nigerians agree that open balloting is preferable to fraudulent or disputed elections -- and more democratic as well. "Who defines democracy?" says Shola Adedipe, a political science major at the University of Lagos. "We don't have to continue adopting foreign electoral models if those models have proved unworkable here."

Lewis Obi, editor of the news magazine African Concord, says nobody "has handled Nigeria's secret balloting and was not worsted in the enterprise. The open ballot is crude, but it is cash and carry, it is in broad daylight, there are no tricks, no mysteries."

Amid the din generated by the arguments on both sides, the National Electoral Commission, the body charged with overseeing the election process, organized a conference of opinion leaders to examine the ballot question. Virtually all participants, including two former electoral commission chairmen who administered secret ballot elections, favored open voting over the use of ballot papers -- a fact the ruling council must have taken into account when it made its decision.

In a paper presented at the conference, Social Democratic Party head Babagana Kingibe said Nigeria is not politically mature enough for a secret ballot system.

Some political pundits, among them National Republican Convention leader Tom Ikimi, suggested an "open-secret" ballot, in which the marking of ballots could be done in secret, while both the depositing of ballots in boxes and the counting and registering of votes would take place publicly.

Although there was general agreement that fine tuning is needed to increase voter turn-out and reduce other flaws of the open system, there was also acknowledgment that what is called "the Nigerian factor" -- a chronic tendency to rig elections -- makes it easier for the government to win support for any system that seems capable of deterring fraud.

"If ballot papers are introduced," says Dozie Odunze, a Lagos lawyer, "be sure that fake ones will be printed by politicians." Odunze appears to reflect widespread public opinion when he says that secret ballots in Nigeria result in a lack of confidence in the results and a question mark on the elected government's legitimacy. And that, he argues, is a sure recipe for further military coups.

Nigerians don't appear to share the suspicions of voter line-ups that are prevalant in many African countries, such as Kenya, where public voting is widely seen as a government attempt to intimidate its opponents. In Nigeria, even critics of the government credit President Babangida with a bold attempt to forge a genuine democracy.

(For four years, the military government Babangida heads has been orchestrating a gradual return to civilian structures. Among the multifaceted preparations are a national census scheduled for October, and the creation last year of two parties from among more than 60 that competed for recognition. Public reaction then was similar to the current response to open voting: the hope that the measure might free party politics from the corruption of the past appeared to outweigh the unease over the establishment of parties by military fiat.)

The transition to democracy is due to culminate in the election of governors and state legislators for Nigeria's 21 states late this year, followed by voting for federal legislators and a civilian president in 1992.


LOAD-DATE: May 29, 1991


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1991 AllAfrica, Inc.


43 of 211 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 20, 1991


DIPLOMACY: AFRICA


LENGTH: 896 words


LAGOS -- Deft diplomatic footwork, designed to install an African as the next secretary-general of the United Nations is extending from this city to important capitals around the world.

The second five-year term of the incumbent, Javier Perez de Cuellar of Peru, expires at the end of the year, and there is no shortage of African candidates to take his place. Among those who have been considered by ad hoc search committees are Joseph Garba of Nigeria, former president of the UN General Assembly; Ghanaian Kenneth Dadzie, secretary-general of the UN Conference on Trade and Development; Bernard Chidzero, Zimbabwe's finance minister; Senegalese president Abdou Diouf; Tanzania's Salim Ahmed Salim, the current secretary-general of the Organization of African Unity (OAU); James Jonah, the Sierra Leonean undersecretary-general of the UN; and Olara Otunnu, Uganda's former foreign minister who now heads the International Peace Academy in New York.

For now, the top African contender appears to be retired General Olusegun Obasanjo, a former Nigerian head of state who has won the endorsement of Nigeria's government. Although the decision to back Obasanjo has not yet been announced publicly, the government of President Ibrahim Babangida has already begun an international lobbying campaign on his behalf. Nigeria hopes to persuade African heads of state attending the Organization of African Unity summit, due to convene in Abuja, Nigeria in early June, to unanimously accept Obasanjo as "Africa's candidate". 

Although the UN Charter does not require a geographical rotation of the secretary-general's position, many believe Africa is due for a turn at running the world body. The past five UN chiefs have come from Europe, Asia and Latin America. Africa with the largest group of member countries has never produced a secretary-general.

"If we miss this time," says Ibrahim Gambari, Nigeria's ambassador to the UN, "Africa will not have another opportunity this century to fight for the UN post."

Perez de Cuellar has said he would prefer an African to succeed him. If the five permanent members of the Security Council refuse to agree to an African, Perez argues, "Africa must feel excluded."

Why is Africa vying for what Trygve Lie, the first UN secretary-general, called "the most impossible job on earth," when its citizens are struggling daily against poverty and war? The reasons, analysts here say, include a belief that an African secretary-general can make a success of global assignments and, in the process, raise the continent's international profile and help shatter racist myths of black inferiority.

Gabriel Olusanya, former head of Nigeria's Institute of International Affairs, says that although the position has been traditionally administrative and not a strong decision-making one, "an African secretary-general can influence decisions where Africa is unfairly treated."

Others believe that holding such a powerfully symbolic international position will give the continent greater confidence to push its diplomatic and economic interests. Getting greater international cooperation for solutions to Africa's economic crisis is one of those aims.

Another, according to diplomats here, is a permanent seat for Africa on the Security Council. "A continent that accounts for roughly a third of the UN's membership ought to be represented in the most powerful chamber on a permanent basis," Gambari argues. Germany and Japan are also seeking permanent seats in the council.

With the wane of the cold war and with the UN's image enhanced following the Gulf crisis, and after such successes as supervising Namibia's independence process, there is a pervasive feeling that strong leadership could help the UN fulfill its original mission of maintaining world order. Africa's trumpet blowers say the continent has many leaders of international stature on whom that cap would fit.

With these goals heading Africa's agenda, Olusegun Obasanjo is hardly a surprise choice. A military general who voluntarily handed over power to a democratically elected government, the widely admired leader has chalked up an impressive international resume since leaving office in 1979. He has served on numerous international commissions on security and development issues. In 1988 he founded the Africa Leadership Forum, a respected think tank that trains future African leaders and proposes strategies for the continent's development.

Jonathan Power of the Baltimore Sun wrote that Obasanjo "is a civil libertarian, a man of enormous courage and resolve and has no time for people or countries that put principles of international law on one side whenever it becomes convenient."

In the long run, much is riding on the decision of the five permanent members of the UN Security Council. A veto by one of the five will defeat any candidate.

In 1981 Tanzania's Salim, a popular choice of many UN members, was a candidate for the secretary-generalship against the incumbent, Kurt Waldheim of Austria, who was seeking an unprecedented third term. Salim lost, due to a United States veto. China then vetoed Waldheim, leading to the emergence of Perez de Cuellar, a dark horse.

Many diplomats here believe it is unlikely that the Bush White House will follow Ronald Reagan's 1981 example and veto an African front-runner.


LOAD-DATE: May 29, 1991


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1991 AllAfrica, Inc.


44 of 211 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 20, 1991


MILES TO GO


LENGTH: 564 words


As the first woman and the first black to head the 37-year-old African-American Institute (AAI) in New York, Vivian Lowery Derryck would seem to have fulfilled the promise of the generation that rose to prominence in the wake of the civil rights struggle. But she hasn't yet found any laurels upon which to rest.

In a blunt, impassioned speech to the final Summit plenary, Derryck told African Americans that they had not done enough for Africa, and she appealed for a new commitment to building a constituency for Africa in the United States. She described a Ford Foundation-funded project to create a network of advocates for Africa in six U.S. cities as one of AAI's most important programs -- one that should be allied with similar efforts across the country. 

In a catalogue of Africa's needs, Derryck talked about universities without textbooks, about population growth that outstrips food production, and about the loss of an African tree species every day. And she called for new thinking on the continent's debt crisis.

All of those issues deserve more attention, Derryck said, and she had intended to talk about them in her speech. "I was going to emphasize the need to help rebuild one proud institution of higher education like Makerere University in Uganda," she said, "which has never recovered from the (rule of Idi) Amin."

But in the end, Derryck said, she decided to focus her talk on an issue where conference participants could make an immediate and measurable impact -- the war "right next door" in Liberia.

"Liberia is a child of the United States," Derryck said, reminding delegates of Liberia's founding by former slaves, its capital named for U.S. President James Monroe, its legal system codified by Cornell University Law School and its red, white and blue flag.

Liberia's immediate neighbors have been "incredibly generous," Derryck said, providing sanctuary, food and medical care.

But she said Liberia and the region need greater assistance to cope with the highest percentage of refugees of any country in the world, with the possible exception of the Persian Gulf countries where reliable figures are still unavailable. As many as half of Liberia's two million people are thought to be displaced from their homes.

The good news, Derryck said, is that "a special optimism abounds in Liberia" that has prompted ordinary people to organize self-help projects, food brigades and relief efforts. But peace, she said, "is desperately needed."

The United States could help more, Derryck said, both with material aid and with the attempt by the Economic Community of West African States to bring an end to the fighting. She said she is haunted by a question posed to her during the Summit by a Liberian friend: "Why have black Americans let us down?"

"This is a plea to each of you," Derryck told her audience, "to become knowledgeable and politically literate about this issue. The civil rights giants here with us today fought not only so that we could vote, but so that we could influence policy through our informed positions on issues."

When Derryck resumed her seat, it was evident that she had touched a chord in her listeners. With the plenary continuing around them, a parade of delegates knelt by her side, asking for more information or copies of her remarks, and promising their help for future efforts.


LOAD-DATE: May 29, 1991


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1991 AllAfrica, Inc.


45 of 211 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 20, 1991


EXCERPTS FROM SUMMIT DECLARATION


LENGTH: 672 words


Official African and U.S. delegates to the African-African American Summit issued a declaration at the meeting's close, pledging to create an Implementation Committee to act as a follow-up mechanism to the conference. Here are excerpts from the declaration of intent.

* We have assembled: to reestablish the bond of togetherness that has not existed since Africans were uprooted and relocated to the Americas and other parts of the world several centuries ago, and to find ways to accelerate the development process of Africa. 

* African Americans reaffirm their commitment, not only to apply their personal expertise and resources to assist in this development effort, but also to network with others in an effort to acquire significant aid to help accelerate the social and economic growth and development of African countries.

* We have noted with concern, on the one hand the continued plummeting of the export prices of Africa's commodities and the skyrocketing of the prices of imported manufactured goods, and on the other hand the ever-growing burden of external debt and the attendant reverse flow of resources that keep widening the gap between Africa and other parts of the world. In this context, we call for adequately remunerative prices for African raw materials, as well as the total relief and cancellation of all official debt, and we support the expansion of efforts to eliminate all commercial debt.

* We subscribe to the proposition that Africans, African Americans and other friends of Africa shall collaborate in the creation of a climate that shall encourage investment, trade and industrialization, resulting in higher value added (to Africa's primary products) through joint ventures by American corporations and small and medium size African American entrepreneurs.

* In accordance with this concept, African governments shall continue to evaluate their policies and, where necessary, amend them so that American corporations and companies will be encouraged to increase their investments in Africa. The American investors shall make provisions for equality in employment practices for all workers (and) adhere to environmental standards designed to protect natural beauty and resources.

* We consider the strengthening of regional integration to be a priority at both the governmental and non-governmental levels.

* We call for and encourage the participation of African American educators and others in educational and technical programs that will help prepare our populations to be competitive in the twenty-first century.

* We urge better understanding and appreciation of the African heritage and the infusion of the past and present contributions of Africa into all American schools, colleges and universities, and into churches, mosques and other places of worship as well as into the media.

* We recognize that the sufficient production of food and the protection and preservation of the environment are key to the survival of Africa. We pledge to work for the improvement of international trade and exchange policies to encourage farming and strengthen Africa's agricultural infrastructure.

* We commend the American government for increasing its economic assistance to Africa. However, we regret that sub-Saharan Africa is still receiving a disproportionately small amount of assistance in comparison with some other parts of the world. We urge all African Americans and other friends of Africa to use their energy, clout and resources to lobby the American government for a substantial increase in aid to sub-Saharan Africa.

* We have decided that the following commissions should be established:

% Commission on Economic Development

* Commission on History and Culture

* Commission on Education

* Commission on Agriculture

* Commission on Health

Summit organizers said the work of the commissions would be coordinated by a high-level steering committee and promised further conferences at two-year intervals in the future.


LOAD-DATE: May 29, 1991


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1991 AllAfrica, Inc.


46 of 211 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 20, 1991


PROMISES TO KEEP


LENGTH: 970 words


ABIDJAN -- Folks who had hoped to eat local foods were fed champagne and raspberries flown in from France. Wanting to see how ordinary Africans lived, delegates were entertained in the marbled halls of a presidential palace and slept in the plush opulence of a grand hotel that boasts a casino, a bowling alley and an ice skating rink. Speeches and declarations ruled the agenda, rather than the anticipated discussions and interactions.

But in the end, those complaints paled beside the reality of being in Africa and the conviction that, though this might be a first trip for some, it certainly wouldn't be the last. Links were forged, promises were made, and plans were changed, sometimes dramatically. 

Mark Fields, a physician from Rocky Mount, North Carolina, decided to leave his medical practice to spend time working on rural health care somewhere in Africa. Several people pooled their resources to assist Liberian refugees they had met on the street. Representatives of African American women's organizations met with a group of African women, and pledged to work together on specific small-scale development projects in African villages. "This is the sort of thing our chapters are doing already, but we want to do more," said Freddye Prophet, director of international services for the Links. "Our members like to see that their help makes a difference."

A group of students from U.S. colleges spent part of their time conferring with each other, in what they said would be the beginnings of a student network to tackle African issues. "I really wanted to get out of this hotel and meet Africans," said Rahmanda Campbell, president of the student government at Delaware State College. "But I think that what we do after we leave here can really be important."

To those most knowledgeable about current events in the region, there was a sense of irony that the Summit took little note of the political revolutions taking place all around it. In the weeks before the conference, pro-democracy campaigns forced concessions from authoritarian rulers in several nearby countries, and more than one head of state expected to attend the Summit was thrown out of office before he could arrive. "These people are true heroes," mused one journalist, gazing around a room that held Benjamin Hooks of the NAACP, Dorothy Height of the National Council of Negro Women, Joseph Lowery of the Southern Christian Leadership Conference and Coretta Scott King of the Martin Luther King Center. "They've spent their lives fighting for justice. How can they ignore Africans struggling for the same thing?"

Some Summit participants said they were confident that increased awareness would lead to greater support for democratic movements across Africa. "African affairs is the new frontier for African Americans," said Don Anderson, publisher of Emerge magazine. "This is the first step in a process that will develop over the next twenty years." Once African Americans understand the issues they will respond, Anderson said, "whether it's South Africa, West Africa or any other part of Africa."

Entertainer-activist Dick Gregory said he hoped the conference would prompt a reevaluation by African Americans of their own choices. Gregory sees a direct link between the health and well-being of Africans and that of Africa's descendents in the U.S., where a measure of material achievement has led, he believes, to the threat of spiritual poverty.

"We've got to rearrange priorities," he said. "We as black folks that put on a $ 300 suit and $30,000 worth of jewelry and get in a $27,000 car and drive to a black church and give $ 5 -- we've got to change. We've got to breathlife into our black institutions."

The notion that a renewed sense of purpose among black Americans will have beneficial effects on both sides of the Atlantic divide was common at the conference.

It is clear that African Americans can help mobilize resources for African development, said Sheila Walker, director of the Center for African and African American studies at the University of Texas, and a member of the committee that planned the Summit. What Americans can gain from the partnership may be less obvious, she said, but is no less real. The restoration of ruptured ties with Africa, Walker said, can help replace the negative self-image of "a population that sees its origins in defeat and oppression."

Very real differences between Africans and African Americans "impede our mutual understanding," said Moumouni Djermakoye, Niger's ambassador to the United States, who headed the planning committee. But he said many on both continents, especially young people, "are expressing a symbolic identification with each other in a variety of ways." The Summit, he said, had given those symbols more substance and dynamism, and provided a foundation "for combined activities based on our common interests and for our mutual good."

At a cultural evening that went on into the morning hours, two of contemporary America's cultural icons gave a performance that illustrated both the continuing continental divide and the possibilities for bridging it. When Ossie Davis and Ruby Dee approached the microphones, a group of Ivorian women at a table in the back of the room continued to talk among themselves, as they had all night. "I can't understand a word," said one -- a common frustration among French-speaking African participants. Although major speeches at the plenaries were translated, English predominated sessions.

Then the U.S. film stars began reading African poetry in French, and the table suddenly quieted. "Ahhhh," said one of the Ivorians, in a long sigh of satisfaction, as two children of Africa who had made it in the new world showed that they knew how to connect with the old one as well.


LOAD-DATE: May 29, 1991


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1991 AllAfrica, Inc.


47 of 211 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 20, 1991


DEBT INITIATIVE MAY BE LASTING LEGACY


SECTION: U.S. POLICY


LENGTH: 1029 words


ABIDJAN -- The first African-African American Summit was one man's dream, and many people thought, up until the last moment, that he couldn't pull it off. Funding was uncertain, confirmations of participation were slow to come in, and logistical problems threatened to swamp the organizers.

But when the Reverend Leon H. Sullivan stood onstage in the Hotel Ivoire, hands upraised and face streaming with tears, leading a chorus of "The Battle Hymn of the Republic" to the cheers of hundreds of delegates, few doubted that his vision had power. If some of the African participants, raised in more formal cultures than their American cousins, were not wholly at ease with all the fervor, they were ready, nevertheless, to welcome the intent. 

"If black Americans can organize around an issue like debt relief," said Tanzania's deputy foreign minister Abdou Kinana, "it could be of immense benefit to Africa."

The occasion was a late-April meeting in Cote d'Ivoire's cosmopolitan capital that drew over 500 Americans as well as five African presidents, one vice-president, and numerous cabinet officials from around the continent. The Summit was conceived by Sullivan, a 68-year-old Baptist minister and businessman who founded a Philadelphia-based job training program in 1964 and recently established a foundation to encourage corporate and institutional involvement in development projects, primarily in Africa. In Africanist circles, he is perhaps best known for his "Sullivan Principles," a 1977 code of conduct for U.S. companies operating in South Africa.

"Africa is the forgotten continent," Sullivan said in an interview. He said a broad, national campaign by African Americans and other friends of Africa offers the only prospect for putting Africa on the U.S. foreign policy agenda.

C. Payne Lucas, the president of Africare, a Washington, D.C.-based development agency, came to Abidjan because he agrees with that assessment. "Africa's future," he said, "is tied to building a strong African American constituency at home. This conference represents an opportunity to help fashion that new constituency."

Although the focus of the three-day meeting often seemed diffuse, the final sessions offered the prospect that the results could be concrete. A delegation of Congressional representatives, led by House majority whip William H. Gray III (D-PA), pledged to work for an additional $ 200 million in development assistance for Africa in the 1992 budget. In a speech to the conference, Gray also stressed a theme that had been largely absent from the public discussions -- the widespread African movement for greater democracy and human rights. "Human rights must be in the forefront of our relationship," Gray said, "and this principle must apply to all of Africa."

African diplomats at the conference seemed to have a mixture of hope and skepticism about the outcome as they interacted with delegates, many of whom were on their first visit to Africa. Some Africans noted that the attempt to build a voice for Africa in the U.S. is already being pursued by groups like the African American lobby TransAfrica, and that the effort requires a persistent and patient commitment more than an emotional catharsis. But many said any new recruits to the cause of raising Africa's profile are urgently needed, at a time when the continent is feeling increasingly bypassed in world affairs.

"A major goal of this meeting," said Summit planning committee member Sheila Walker, from the University of Texas at Austin, "is to involve African Americans on a much larger and more institutionalized scale than ever before in the economic and social development of Africa."

Sullivan told the conference, in a rousing final speech, that 35 million black Americans pay $ 70 billion a year in taxes, and that their purchasing power gives them further clout. International companies that don't pay fair prices for Africa's commodities, he warned, may find their own products left on the shelves when blacks spend their money.

Promising follow-up through a series of meetings and commissions, including a campaign to be taken to churches across the United States this fall, Sullivan said African Americans possess the power to force the government to help Africa deal with its debt.

Africans attending the meeting seemed in broad agreement that if the push to cancel the debt becomes a reality, the Summit could become the historically important event in African development that Sullivan imagined when he planned it. Even a lively public discussion of the issue in the U.S., said one, could aid Africa's campaign for some form of debt relief that will enable its economies to escape what Sullivan called the "millstone" around African necks.

Although Africa's total debt is smaller than that of Latin America or Asia, and often gets slight attention in international discussions on the third world debt crisis, Africa carries a heavier debt burden in relation to the size of its economies. Latin America's debt, for example, is 60% of its gross domestic product, whereas the percentage for sub-Saharan Africa is over 100%. Only Africa, among all the world's regions, is expected to grow poorer during this decade, a prospect largely attributable to the weight of its debt. African diplomats and economists are united in the view that a lifting of the debt burden could dramatically transform Africa's prospects.

But "unless African Americans are truly organized," says Africare's C. Payne Lucas, "there's little hope that Africa is going to get its share of American foreign policy interest and bilateral aid." On the other hand, he says, African Americans in an alliance with white Americans who care about the continent can create small miracles. The Africare chapter in Chicago alone, he says, has already raised $ 50,000 for child survival in Burkina Faso. And the NAACP, with 600,000 members, is asking every chapter to plant trees in Africa, where deforestation is among the most pressing environmental problems.

"This is a magic moment for Africa," Lucas says, "and Americans can help insure that the magic materializes."


LOAD-DATE: May 29, 1991


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1991 AllAfrica, Inc.


48 of 211 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 20, 1991


THE AFRICA DEVELOPMENT BANK


LENGTH: 475 words


The African Development Bank (ADB), created in 1963, provides loans to its African members to support economic and social development. To keep pace with inflation, the bank's management this year proposed a slight rise in lending but encountered opposition from the major industrial powers, who want to set stricter conditions on the terms of the loans.

The ADB, with assets of nearly $ 9 billion, is the smallest of the four established multilateral lending institutions, which include the Asian and Inter-American Development Banks and the World Bank. 

But the ADB is the most profitable. Financial figures presented at this year's annual meeting in Abidjan show that the bank's net income increased by nearly 25% over the past five years, compared with 15 percent for the Asian Bank, the next most profitable of the group.

And the ADB's net transfer of resources to Africa over the last year -- $ 1.2 billion -- was larger than that of any multilateral financial institution operating on the continent.

With the addition of Namibia this year, the ADB has 51 African, or Tregional' members. Turkey became the 26th Tnon-regional' member. African countries account for 65% of the capital and have two-thirds of the votes.

Management's proposal to increase lending to about 1.6 billion Units of Account (UA), about $ 1.8 billion, was criticized as too ambitious. Management similarly sought a small increase for the African Development Fund, the affiliated institution which makes interest-free loans to the continent's poorer nations.

But the donor countries balked at any increase, citing budgetary pressures and the need for sound financial management. Leading the charge for lower outlays was Walter McClean of Canada, who said the proposed rise "goes beyond the internal prudential guidelines."

After a contentious debate by the board of directors and pointed remarks in many of the formal speeches, Austria put forward a compromise, which limited lending this year to between 1.4 and 1.6 billion UA and avoided a showdown along geographic lines.

Nevertheless, the Africans were clearly disappointed. "The development needs of Africa are so great that we would like to see the bank's loan capacity expand to help meet some of these needs," said Angolan Finance Minister Aguilnaldo Jaime, current chairman of the bank's Board of Governors.

Beyond the drama of the bank's lending size, most members seemed supportive of the policy direction charted by President Babacar N'diaye and his colleagues. Matthew Hennesey, the U.S. governor, spoke of N'diaye's "distinguished record of accomplishment" and specifically endorsed the bank's push for strengthened policies to protect the environment and to increase the role of women, both in formulating development policies and in benefiting from their implementation.


LOAD-DATE: May 29, 1991


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1991 AllAfrica, Inc.


49 of 211 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 20, 1991


A CHANCE FOR AFRICA


LENGTH: 1543 words


ABIDJAN -- Although news out of Africa is dominated by disasters, wars, and human suffering, the head of Africa's preeminent financial institution believes "there is every reason to be positive and optimistic" about the future. Babacar N'diaye, president of the African Development Bank (ADB), says the growing strength of Africa's pro-democracy movement is part of a trend towards accountable, effective government that could reverse the continent's economic decline.

N'diaye's view, expressed in an interview following this month's annual meeting of the bank, is bolstered by news that the world's poorest continent may have begun a fragile economic revival. The bank's newly released African Development Report 1991 says average per capita income rose last year, following a decade in which living standards across Africa dropped by 25%.

Africa experienced a continent-wide growth rate of 3.6% in 1990, outpacing population growth -- three percent for the year -- for the first time since 1985. Only five countries experienced negative growth rates, down from 10 in 1989 and 14 the previous year, the ADB says. 

However, the modest improvement "cannot be considered adequate," N'diaye said in his speech to the annual meeting. The current rate of growth, projected at 3 - 3.5% for 1991, is "insufficient" to restore living standards to the level they were at the beginning of the 1980s, the bank says in its latest annual report. "Significant and sustained efforts still have to be made to regain the income losses of the last decade," the report states.

The World Bank estimates that Africa must maintain a growth rate in excess of four percent to begin sustained economic resurgence.

According to N'Diaye, the continued burden of Africa's $ 255 billion debt is "severely thwarting the prospects for recovery and growth." Payments on principle and interest now take up about 30% of Africa's total export earnings.

N'Diaye said "technical solutions alone" will not take care of the problem. The "unsettled -- and unsettling -- question" is whether the international community will "address the problems of indebtedness in a comprehensive and lasting way," he said.

At least 30 African countries are now in the midst of "structural reform programs." The reforms, usually undertaken under the auspices of the Washington, D.C.-based International Monetary Fund (IMF), are designed to institute sound management techniques and rebuild a country's international credit rating. The measures generally include reductions in government spending, an end to price subsidies on basic consumer goods, and an emphasis on developing the private sector and generating revenues to repay foreign debts.

Financial experts disagree on whether structural reforms have stimulated the slight economic upturn or have only coincided with it in some countries. The importance the IMF and its colleague institution, the World Bank, attach to expanding the output of cash crops and minerals that earn foreign exchange has come to seem like a bad joke to countries like Cote d'Ivoire and its neighbor, Ghana. Urged to expand production of cocoa and coffee, only to find that Asian and Latin American countries were following the same advice and saturating the market, Africa's commodity producers have watched prices plummet to a 14-year low. As long as these prices stay depressed, the African Development Bank's report acknowledges in an understated analysis, "the prospects for robust export-led growth will remain quite limited."

The problems associated with the reform programs are not only economic. In Cote d'Ivoire, where the bank is headquartered, the political impact of adjustment has been visible. A year ago, after three decades of near-tranquil independence, the country erupted as large sectors of the population joined in protest marches demanding changes in economic policies and an end to one-party monopoly on power.

"It is no coincidence that the agitation for multi-party government" has been most vigorous in the richer countries, says a recent Economist Intelligence Unit (EIU) study on West Africa. "The fall in living standards in Cameroon, Cote d'Ivoire and Gabon since the mid-1980s has been meteoric."

While the commodity slump has hit English-speaking countries like Ghana as well, the EIU report says differing governmental structures help explain "why the multiparty time bomb exploded first within the franc zone." Former French colonies have established the kind of large civil services found in Paris, and these are the groups whose salaries and jobs have been most affected by the cutbacks of structural adjustment.

Cote d'Ivoire President Felix Houphouet-Boigny, Africa's longest-serving leader, has managed to diffuse the tensions, though they pose the most serious challenge to his 30 years in power. On the political front, he acceded to the demands for pluralism, and legalized opposition parties and allowed an independent press to flourish. Last November the countrys had its first multiparty elections, which Houphouet-Boigny and the ruling Democratic Party won easily . Today, there are 40 registered parties in the country and nearly two dozen newspapers, where just over a year ago there was a single party and no media diversity.

To tackle the economy, Houphouet-Boigny turned to a respected banker, Allasane Ouattara, who was governor of the Banque Centrale des ?tats de l'Afrique de l'Ouest, the central bank for the franc-zone nations of West Africa. After serving for several months as "economic czar," Ouattara was named prime minister last November. Since then he has sounded almost like an opposition leader himself, declaring war on official waste, corruption, and mismanagement. His slashes in government departments and budgets have proved popular with international financial institutions and have won the release of $ 950 million in funds from foreign donors to help ease the economic crunch.

At a special ruling party congress last month, Ouattara emerged clearly as number two behind the president, even though the heir apparent to the aging leader is the leader of the national assembly, Henri Konan Bedie, who is constitutionally designated to serve out any unfulfilled presidential term.

Encouraged by Houphouet-Boigny's example, a number of beleaguered autocrats in other countries have tapped respected figures with impressive financial resumes to assume prime ministerial responsibilities. Gabonese President Omar Bongo chose Ouattara's former counterpart at central's Africa's franc-zone central bank, Oyeba Cassimir. The leaders of the military coup in Mali, after ousting President Moussa Traore in March, named Souman Sacko, who was a senior official in the United Nations Development Programme.

The presidents of Senegal, the Congo, Cameroon and Zaire have all named internationally-known figures to step in amid domestic difficulties.

"I call these guys "techno-politicians -- I hate the term Ttechnocrat'," says the African Development Bank's N'diaye. "Their first expertise is technical and financial, but they have to be political as well."

One of the group who made the transition into politics is the new president of Benin, Nicephore Soglo, a former World Bank official, who defeated 11-year dictator Mathieu Kerekou. Named prime minister last year by President Kerekou, who yielded to popular demands for an end to single-party control, Soglo based his winning presidential campaign on his success as manager of the government's economic turn-around.

Despite current trends, however, not everyone in Africa has joined the multiparty bandwagon. At the African Development Bank meeting, Kenya's representative, M. B. Keah, credited the "rapid growth of the Kenyan economy" to the leadership of President Daniel arap Moi, who stubbornly clings to a single-party model for his country. "We are not prepared to accept imposed foreign ideologies," Keah said, "particularly the standard textbook prescriptions of a multiparty system."

Other countries are finding that democracy and economic growth do not always co-habit comfortably. According to Angolan Finance Minister, Aguinaldo Jaime, some of his associate in the government, fearing a loss of votes in the country's first multiparty elections next year, are resisting implementation of economic reforms which he himself believes are essential. "These measures are unpopular, and they can be exploited by the opposition," he conceded.

ADB officials believe that the solution lies partially in cushioning the effects of structural adjustment with programs that deliver basic services to the poorest segments of the population. Bank president N'diaye said the budget cuts mandated by reform process shouldn't come primarily from social programs. He called for a reduction in the continent's military expenditures, which average twice the outlay on education and are triple the spending on health, and for an end to the dozens of armed conflicts that affect a third of Africa's 54 countries with "varying degrees of severity."

The bank's development report suggests a ratio of spending to Gross Domestic Product of three percent for education and two percent for primary health care.


LOAD-DATE: May 29, 1991


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1991 AllAfrica, Inc.


50 of 211 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


JUNE 24, 1991


A WAY OUT?


LENGTH: 288 words


Namibia has new hopes of gaining the port of Walvis Bay following recent talks with South Africa, says Namibian Foreign Minister Theo-Ben Gurirab. When Namibia became independent 15 months ago, South Africa retained ownership of Walvis Bay -- the territory's only seaport -- on the grounds that the city was not a part of the old German colony of South West Africa, which South Africa took over after World War I.

According to Gurirab, South Africa's new attitude was demonstrated during last month's discussions when South African Foreign Minister Roelof Pik' Botha unexpectedly announced his government's redrawing of the two countries' boundary along the Orange River from the Namibian side of the waterway to the middle. Botha also indicated that Namibia's claim to Walvis Bay, is getting sympathetic consideration in Pretoria.

Responding to an earlier suggestion that resolution of the issue might have to await the outcome of power-sharing talks in South Africa, Namibia solicited endorsements of its claim from the various South African political groupings. Only Gatsha Buthelezi's Inkatha movement turned down the request.

Originally, Pretoria had signaled that flexibility on Walvis Bay would depend on its next-door neighbor's willingness to distance itself from the African National Congress. But after President F.W. de Klerk unbanned the ANC and opened talks with Nelson Mandela, that issue dropped off the negotiating agenda. Last week, ANC President Oliver Tambo paid an official visit to Namibia -- his first. He was warmly welcomed by Namibian President Sam Nujoma, in recognition of the longstanding close ties between the ANC and Nujoma's South West African People's Organization (Swapo).


LOAD-DATE: June 25, 1991


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1991 AllAfrica, Inc.


51 of 211 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


JUNE 24, 1991


HELTER-SKELTER


LENGTH: 167 words


Eighteen years after the Polisario Front launched its campaign for self-determination in Western Sahara, the United Nations general assembly has adopted a Security Council plan for a referendum in the disputed territory. And after all the years of war, the area's future may be decided in little more than 18 weeks. 

Morocco, which claims the former Spanish colony as a province, has agreed to abide by the results of the proposed ballot. Polisario has long pressed for a UN-supervised vote to determine the territory's future, but the group made concessions to secure Morocco's approval. Most importantly, Polisario dropped its demand that the Moroccan authorities in Western Sahara be replaced by a neutral UN administration to oversee elections. Morocco also won the right to leave 65,000 troops in the territory during the vote, although UN forces will monitor the Moroccan presence.

The referendum is due to take place 20 weeks after a formal cease-fire, which is expected soon.


LOAD-DATE: June 25, 1991


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1991 AllAfrica, Inc.


52 of 211 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


JUNE 24, 1991


WHO GOES THERE?


LENGTH: 192 words


Fifteen years ago this month, the west African nation of Cameroon declared a day of national mourning to mark the vote by the northern section of the former "British Cameroons" to join Nigeria. The southern section opted to join the former "French Cameroons" as part of the independent Cameroon Republic. 

But the matter hasn't ended there. Local Nigerian government officials responsible for islands off the Atlantic Coast have appealed to the Nigerian federal government to deal with what the islanders say is the occupation of nine fishing settlements by Cameroonian gendarmes. The Nigerian News Agency, which sent a team to investigate the story, says its reporters were blocked in their attempts to visit the islands.

There has been public speculation that the matter of a few off-shore villages is not a priority for the Nigerian government, but there are beginning to be calls for authorities in Lagos to respond. "If the federal government has ceded that territory to Cameroon by a gentleman's agreement," says Nigeria's Tribune newspaper, "it should inform the estimated 32,000 persons under Cameroon occupation of that fact."


LOAD-DATE: June 25, 1991


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1991 AllAfrica, Inc.


53 of 211 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


JUNE 24, 1991


HIS, HERS, AND OURS


SECTION: BITS AND PIECES


LENGTH: 206 words


A high court decision in Botswana is being hailed as a sweeping victory for women's equality, but Botswana's attorney general says the case has thrown the country into a constitutional crisis. The suit was brought by an attorney, who challenged the law that prevented her two youngest children from being Botswana citizens, even though they were born in the country. The lawyer is married to an American, and the Citizenship Act says children must have the nationality of their father.

Both sides in the court battle agree that the case has implications far beyond the citizenship issue. The judge determined that the children had a right to Botswana citizenship, saying that "fundamental liberties" in the constitution guarantee nondiscrimination against women. "The day when women were treated as chattels is long past," he said.

Women's organizations, the Botswana Christian Council and the wife of the country's first president all declared support for the decision. But the attorney general said his office had identified numerous statutes that differentiate between men and women. "If we must accept that the ruling applies to all legislation that discriminates against women," he said, "then we have a big problem."


LOAD-DATE: June 25, 1991


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1991 AllAfrica, Inc.


54 of 211 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


JUNE 24, 1991


WHAT NOW FOR SANCTIONS?


LENGTH: 2863 words


ABUJA, NIGERIA -- In their latest resolution on South Africa, African leaders acknowledge that the issue of continued sanctions has been complicated by "positive developments" in the country and the general international reaction to the change.

The Abuja Declaration at the Organization of African Unity Summit reaffirms the need for continued pressure on Pretoria while also authorizing Nigerian President Ibrahim Babangida, the new OAU chairman, to initiate a review of the sanctions policy as soon as South Africa acts to "remove all obstacles to genuine negotiations."

Last week, following repeal of the Population Registration Act by the South African Parliament, Babangida announced that he will convene a meeting of the OAU heads-of-state committee on South Africa to decide whether member countries should move towards lifting sanctions.

African leaders are hopeful that their careful stance, combining continued insistence on majority rule with recognition of forward movement by South African President F.W. de Klerk, will be sufficient to retain key elements of the embargo, particularly the International Monetary Fund ban on lending to Pretoria.

The summit statement, which followed lengthy behind-the-scenes discussions, reflects Babangida's clear intent to break ground on South Africa during his term as chairman. In his major address on opening day, the Nigerian leader promised to "give leadership" on the issue by working for an end to violence and for the "realization of a non-racial society." 

The changes in South Africa, though welcomed and encouraged, fall short of the benchmark for the ending of sanctions that was established three years ago by OAU governments in the Harare Declaration. Notably, the OAU believes, the South African government has not yet released all of its political prisoners, put an end to political trials, extended amnesty to all political exiles, or curtailed "repressive" security force activity against government opponents.

"Should the South African government adopt measures which lead to positive, profound, and irreversible change towards the abolition of apartheid," the statement says, "we commit ourselves to review the question of sanctions with a view towards readmitting South Africa into the international community."

However, sanctions are already eroding, thereby undermining their utility as a bargaining chip. The European Community moved to end its restriction on trade and investment, and already many major African countries are busily building new economic links with their southernmost neighbor.

The African National Congress (ANC) delegation, led by Nelson Mandela, arrived at the summit with a proposal for a phased easing of the embargo as a means of leverage in the negotiations with South African President F.W. de Klerk. But when Mandela presented the idea to a late-night session of southern Africa's frontline states prior to the summit opening, there were strong objections voiced by the Pan Africanist Congress (PAC), a smaller South African political movement which enjoys equal standing in the OAU with the ANC.

"We don't think we should reward de Klerk for doing what should have been done long ago -- eradicate the gross injustices of apartheid," Gora Ebrahim, PAC foreign secretary said in an interview.

Countered the ANC's Thabo Mbeki: "No one is talking about rewarding anybody. What we are saying is that in the light of the erosion that is taking place, what do we do?"

The ANC proposal calls for agreeing to the removal of sanctions in stages, in response to de Klerk's willingness to follow through on the actions he has thus far refused to take. The first restrictions to go would be the ban on air links, the cultural boycott and the bar on sporting ties. Trade and investment bans would follow, with the international arms embargo retained until last.

The significance of the IMF ban on loans goes beyond the amount of financial assistance South Africa may receive. Without IMF imprimatur, Pretoria's access to world capital markets is severely limited.

The Abuja Declaration, redrafted by southern African states following a late-night session of frontline presidents, was adopted by the summit with little discussion. An anticipated floor debate on sanctions failed to materialize, as countries actively pursuing economic ties with South Africa withheld a push to force an immediate change in the organization's historically hardline pro-sanctions approach.

As OAU chairman, Babangida wants to extend his involvement with South Africa beyond the question of sanctions. During the summit, he offered to convene a meeting of "all shades of political interest" in South Africa and called for the formation of a united front of black forces, including the ANC, PAC, and Gatsha Buthelezi's Inkatha Freedom Party, whose members have been warring with ANC loyalists.
