The Nigerian leader dropped a paragraph from his prepared text which said the OAU should send a team of foreign ministers to South Africa to "evaluate developments and assist in the process of change." He also stopped short of offering to meet de Klerk, although his aides acknowledge that a face-to-face session with the South African president has not been ruled out.

One demonstration of the differences that exist within the OAU membership came two days after the summit ended. Kenya President Daniel arap Moi, a conference participant, played host to de Klerk in Nairobi and agreed to a range of new bilateral links. De Klerk has previously visited Cote d'Ivoire, Madagascar and Zaire. On departing Nairobi, he said he would like to meet with Babangida sometime this year.

Kenya granted landing rights to South African Airways late last year, as did Madagascar. In April, the airline initiated weekly service to Abidjan, Cote d'Ivoire. Early this month, the state-owned company was given permission to overfly Mali and Mauritania in west Africa for the first time since 1963, reducing flying time from Johannesburg to London by an hour and saving 10 tons of fuel per plane.

SOUTH AFRICA: LOOKING BEYOND APARTHEID

On July 3, the African National Congress (ANC) is scheduled to convene its first national conference to be held inside South Africa since the organization was banned in 1960. With no resolution in sight to the wave of domestic violence in South Africa, the movement's membership will face a number of pressing problems.

Since being unbanned along with other opposition groups by South African President F.W. de Klerk early last year, the ANC has struggled to make the transition from an underground movement waging a guerilla campaign to a recognized political grouping. It has had overwhelming -- and often conflicting -- pressures thrust upon it, as it simultaneously engaged in difficult negotiations with the government while trying to reconstitute above-ground structures.

Last week's repeal of the final major piece of overtly segregationist legislation in South Africa, the Population Registration Act of 1950, shifts the focus of South Africa's mass movement from protesting apartheid to the establishment of a multi-party democracy with full political and economic rights for blacks.

By doing away with race-based classification of citizens, Parliament opened the way for adoption of a new constitution. Questions of how such a document will be developed and what its provisions should be are already central features of political debate. But the path to a new constitutional structure that will find broad acceptance has been blocked by the continuation of violence and by differences over security issues and political prisoners.

The ANC is circulating constitutional proposals that it calls "a working draft for consultation." The draft contains an extensive bill of rights guaranteeing freedom of religion, language, speech and assembly, including trade union liberties and the right to a free press. Further provisions would enshrine environmental rights, universal suffrage, private property, the protection of disabled persons, equal rights for men and women and the abolition of the death penalty.

Already there has been much public and private discussion of several of the proposed articles, such as the stipulation that natural resources not previously owned will be the property of the state, for the purposes of "reducing inequality, promoting growth and providing goods and services for the whole population." But perhaps the most controversial element is an article that reserves for the state the right "to enact legislation regulating the manner in which fundamental rights and freedoms shall be exercised or limiting such rights ... as might be deemed necessary in an open and democratic society."

Several activist groups and coalitions who support the ANC have said they will retain their own independence in order to ensure responsive government. "When the ANC comes to power, we will not disband," says Kgabisi Mosunkutu, vice-president of the Civic Association of Transvaal -- one of a growing nationwide network of local administrative bodies. "We will become watchdogs to make sure leaders remain accountable to the people and deal with local issues such as housing, water and electricity." Trade unions, too, have promised their memberships that the groups will not become party organs of the ANC.

However, all the constitutional debates have been overshadowed by the continuing violence, which may have killed as many as 10,000 people in the past six years. While the conflict is generally reported as clashes between the ANC and followers of Chief Gatsha Buthelezi of the Inkatha Freedom Party, anti-apartheid critics have long talked about a "third force" that deliberately provokes trouble, with the backing of at least some elements within the South African government. This month that theory was bolstered by the surfacing of retired army major, Nico Basson, who told journalists that he had been part of a "dirty tricks" campaign run by South African military intelligence to undermine opposition. Basson says he personally conducted such activities against Swapo, the party that now governs Namibia, and that current operations against the ANC are supplying weapons and training to Inkatha and encouraging attacks on ANC sympathizers.

The South African defense forces called the charges ridiculous, and Buthelezi angrily denied "any implication that Inkatha would approve of or be a party to deliberately fomenting violence and creating ethnic divisions."

In the wake of the allegations, the South African Council of Churches renewed its campaign to bring together all parties to forge a plan for ending the fighting. Although the ANC withdrew from negotiations with the government, partly over what it said was the government's failure to end the violence, ANC leaders would like to see some improvement in the situation before the July 3 national conference, so that the group's membership can turn its attention to other urgent concerns.

The following news analysis is by Anton Harber, co-editor of the Johannesburg Weekly Mail.

The African National Congress faces its moment of reckoning in July.

When thousands of delegates from around the country gather in Durban for the organization's first proper congress since its unbanning 18 months ago, they will face the formidable challenge of transforming the organization into a coherent, well-structured and tightly run political machine capable of dealing with the massive demands and pressures of the negotiating process.

At the moment, the organization is weighed down enormously by a great deal of historical baggage. Since its unbanning on February 2 last year, it has postponed dealing with many of these issues.

It can delay no longer. The organization's honeymoon period is over and it is under considerable pressure from its alliance partners, the media, local and international political observers, its international supporters and, most important of all, its membership, to sort out lingering problems.

Most media anticipation of the congress has concentrated on personalities, suggesting that the key issues facing the congress will be who gets what job. This will undoubtedly be relevant, but of more fundamental importance will be whether these people inherit a modernized and workable political structure and whether the gap between them and ANC members is closed.

If the ANC does not deal with these issues in July, it faces little prospect of stemming the slow deterioration in its political and organizational position. It will enter the critical period of negotiations still carrying the burden of many historical problems.

Some of these are:

* A leadership that has been inherited from a period of covert struggle rather than elected to deal with the pressures of a political party. This means that it carries an overload of incompetence people who hold their position due to long and honorable service rather than merit. It also means that the leadership is not always accountable to the membership, and this has been a source of frustration to many members.

This was clearly expressed at last December's consultative conference, at which members demanded an end to secret meetings with the government, an injunction that was ignored.

* An anachronistic structure in which many key ANC departments and regions are not even represented in the body making most crucial decisions, the National Executive Committee (NEC). Thus, for example, the organization's biggest region, the Pretoria/Johannesburg area, can form a view on a critical issue, but since it does not have automatic representation at a national level, it cannot be assured of having its view heard. Similarly, there is no representative of a department as crucial as the economics department on the NEC.

This had led to gaps between the views of membership and leadership which become dangerous because there is no structured way of mediating such differences.

* A lack of coherent strategic and tactical direction. ANC policy has often seemed erratic in the last 18 months, motivated as often by the chance proximity of certain individuals to Nelson Mandela and their desire to hold on to their jobs, rather than careful strategic planning.

* An inability to draw on the enormous resources available to it. The ANC carries enormous goodwill among a wide range of South Africa's best experts (lawyers, economists, educationists...) as well as long-standing activists from ANC-aligned bodies such as the United Democratic Front and Cosatu. So far, the organization has failed to draw on these resources.

The main reason is that returning exiles have often felt threatened, and have tended to exclude such experts rather than expose their own vulnerability. The result has been that during negotiations, for example, the team of advisors behind Mandela has not been as strong as it should. Faced with a government team that has all the state resources and expertise as its command, Mandela has failed to bolster his team with the formidable expertise of lawyers and other professionals available to him.

ANC leaders acknowledge many of these problems and express optimism that they will be sorted out at the conference.

The first signs, however, are troubling. The congress is to consider a new constitution that improves representation on the NEC and the accountability of leadership, but opts for an unworkably large executive of 120 people rather than a tight and more coherent leadership.

Coupled with the outgoing NEC being given extraordinary powers (such as being recognized as a region in itself, giving it the power to nominate some of the delegates and electoral candidates), this has led to a growing suspicion that there is a covert attempt to protect the positions of leaders under threat from dissatisfied members.

ANC leaders deny this, but there is little doubt that some of those holding key positions such as general secretary and treasurer general are fighting a rearguard action to avoid being cast out into the cold.

There is little chance of this working, since dissatisfactions with these individuals is widespread. However, their personal battles to make sure there are jobs for themselves risks making the ANC's structure top-heavy and ponderous.

More than anything else, the organization needs to develop a sophisticated leadership core that is able to run a tight organization during a difficult period of political uncertainty. Mandela needs to know that he is surrounded by the best advisers who have the ability and resources to be planning long term strategy, rather than letting the ANC continue to stumble unpredictably from issue to issue.

To achieve this requires toughness. The ANC will have to show that it will not allow itself to be slowed by an inability to deal with incompetence and weakness. If it is to present itself as an alternative government, its leaderhsip will have to demonstrate an ability to deal resolutely with these issues.

If this does not happen at the July conference, it probably never will.


LOAD-DATE: June 25, 1991


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1991 AllAfrica, Inc.


55 of 211 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


JUNE 24, 1991


THE AFRICAN ECONOMIC COMMUNITY -- EXCERPTS FROM THE TREATY


LENGTH: 459 words


Objectives

1. To promote economic, social and cultural development and the integration of African economies in order to increase economic self-reliance and promote an endogenous and self-sustained development;

2. To establish, on a continental scale, a framework for the development, mobilization and utilization of the human and material resources of Africa in order to achieve a self-reliant development;

3. To promote cooperation in all fields of human endeavor in order to raise the standard of living of African peoples, and maintain and enhance economic stability, foster close and peaceful relations among member states and contribute to the progress, development and economic integration of the continent; and 

4. To coodinate and harmonize policies among existing and future economic communities in order to foster the gradual establishment of the Community... .

The Community shall be established gradually in six stages of variable duration over a transitional period not exceeding 34 years.

First Stage (not to exceed five years):

Strengthening of the existing regional structures (such as the Economic Community of West Africa (Ecowas) and the Southern African Development Coordinating Conference (SADCC)) and establishing them in regions where they do not exist.

Second Stage (not more than eight years):

Standardization of tariffs, customs, duties and internal taxes within regional communities; strengthening of regional and continental trade, agriculture, industry, transport and communication; and the harmonization of activities among the regional groupings.

Third Stage (not greater than 10 years):

At the level of the regional communities, establishing a Free Trade Area for intra-regional trade and a customs union for external trade.

Fourth Stage (within two years):

Harmonization of tariffs among the various regional groupings with a view towards adopting a common external tariff.

Fifth Stage (not greater than four years)

Adoption of common policies for agriculture, transport and communications, industry, energy and scientific research; harmonization of monetary, financial and fiscal policies; the application of free movement of persons; and the establishment of budget procedures for the community.

Sixth Stage (within five years):

Consolidation of an African Common Market entailing free movement of people, goods, capital and services; establishment of a single market and a Pan-African Economic and Monetary Union, including a single African currency; creation of a Pan-African Parliament and election of its members by universal suffrage; establishment of African multinational enterprises in all sectors; and the creation of executive organs for the Community.


LOAD-DATE: June 25, 1991


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1991 AllAfrica, Inc.


56 of 211 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


JUNE 24, 1991


AMID CONTINENT'S DRAMA, SUMMIT PONDERS FUTURE


SECTION: SUMMIT: AFRICA


LENGTH: 1604 words


ABUJA, NIGERIA -- When Zambian President Kenneth Kaunda was campaigning for his southern African nation's independence from Britain during the early 1960s, Soumana Sacko was the top student at Mopti Elementary School in the west African nation of Mali.

The presence of both men at this month's annual summit of the Organization of African Unity (OAU) was a metaphor for the dramatic changes sweeping the continent. At the age of 66, after 26 years in office, Kaunda is a remnant of the post-colonial generation whose largely autocratic style has dominated African politics until recently. The 40-year-old Sacko, a University of Pittsburgh-trained economist who became Mali's prime minister two months ago, represents the new technocrats whose ascendancy parallels the spread of pro-democracy movements in Africa.

Since the continent's leaders last assembled a year ago, nine of their number have been removed from office by elections or by coups stemming from pro-democracy uprisings. More than a dozen others have been forced to loosen their once-firm grip on power to accommodate demands for pluralism and accountability, and several more stand on the brink of ouster. 

The stunning pace of change was evident in last-minute shuffles at the summit. Ethiopia's representatives were hurriedly switched, following the rapid collapse of the Ethiopian government as the four-day conference convened. And Algerian Foreign Minister Sid Ahmed Ghozali was summoned home by President Chadli Bendjedid, to become prime minister and take charge of his government's escalating confrontation with Islamic fundamentalists.

Against that backdrop, this year's OAU summit, meeting in the new Nigerian federal capital of Abuja, drew the largest turnout in a decade. Nigerian President Ibrahim Babangida, the incoming OAU chairman, sat the tone when he called for "a sincere embrace" of democracy in his opening address. He said African leaders should dismantle "all apparatus of unrepresentative power" by the end of the century.

Three dozen heads of state and government attended the Abuja meeting personally, and all but three of the 51 member states sent delegations. The old guard, like Zambia's Kaunda and Mobutu Sese Seko of Zaire, both under fire at home from advocates of greater pluralism, sat alongside Mali's Sacko and the newly-elected Carlos Viega of Cape Verde.

Some leaders attended despite their slipping hold on the reins of power. Cameroon's Paul Biya and Gnassingbe Eyadema of Togo calmly took their seats, even as protest strikes and demonstrations, demanding their resignations, brought normal life to a halt in both countries.

The same concerns that are fueling the push for more accountable government across the continent also dominated the agenda of the summit -- how to attack Africa's crippling economic crisis and end the wars that plague every region.

The main order of business was the approval of a treaty establishing an African Economic Market, similar to the European Community. The treaty calls for the removal of barriers to inter-African trade and travel and the promotion of development through economic integration. The goal is to establish an Africa-wide economic union with a single currency, leading to a Pan-African Parliament with members elected by "continental universal suffrage."

But the creation of a fully-functioning structure is slated to take over three decades. After the treaty-signing ceremony, World Bank President Barber Conable urged Africa's leaders to take the necessary next steps to make the far-reaching design a reality.

Ugandan President Yoweri Museveni, the outgoing OAU chairman who oversaw the drafting process, told his counterparts that integration offers the surest means for reversing what he called "Africa's dismal economic performance in the 1980s." Small markets created by inherited national borders present a major obstacle to growth and development, he said.

For the treaty to take effect, ratification is required by two-thirds of OAU member states, a goal Nigeria's Babangida said he will seek to achieve during his one-year term as organization chair.

But as the leaders moved towards union, they found themselves confronted by countervailing pressures towards greater divisions. Much of an eight-hour closed session on the third day of the summit was taken up with consideration of the regional conflicts that are responsible for so much of Africa's suffering and devastation.

The OAU, from its founding in 1963, has recognized the often irrational colonial boundaries and has upheld the "territorial integrity" of member states so the leaders were quick to condemn the recent secessionist move in northern Somalia. A summit resolution calls upon the Somali National Movement to rescind its secession declaration and work for the unity of the country. The African leaders endorsed efforts by Egypt, Djibouti, Sudan and Uganda to convene a national reconciliation conference of all Somali parties to find a democratic solution to the conflict.

The summit also established a five-nation committee, headed by Babangida, to work for the speedy establishment of a broad-based transitional administration in Ethiopia. A three-person delegation representing the interim Ethiopian government, which took power following seizure of the capital by rebels, assured the OAU that the new coalition is committed to the creation of a democratic Ethiopia.

Fighting in the east African nation of Rwanda sparked some of the sharpest exchanges of the conference, participants reported. Rwandan President Juvenal Habyarimana harshly accused Uganda's Museveni of backing last October's invasion of Rwanda by exiled government opponents, most of them members of the Ugandan National Army who helped bring Museveni to power. But Museveni denied the charge and pledged his cooperation for the five-nation mediation effort led by Zaire's Mobutu, which won summit endorsement as well.

The summit also took decisive action aimed at resolving another conflict, the civil war in Liberia. That action came not in the form of a resolution or debate but from the decision to seat Acting President Amos Sawyer, leader of the interim government in Monrovia. A two-man delegation representing rebel leader Charles Taylor, which arrived in Lagos during the summit, was not allowed to come to Abuja to take part in the deliberations.

Sawyer was welcomed with full honors, including a 21-gun salute and a police-escorted motorcade, and seated along with other government chiefs at the conference. It was a diplomatic breakthrough for Sawyer's administration, which controls the capital Monrovia while Taylor holds much of the rest of the country. Several other African governments are expected to follow Nigeria's lead and reopen their diplomatic missions in the country.

On the question of South Africa, the leaders chose to reiterate previous declarations linking the removal of sanctions to greater progress towards majority rule. However, in recognition of the erosion in sanctions now taking place and the changes already underway in South Africa, the summit authorized Babangida, as OAU chairman, to initiate a review of this position when conditions warrant "readmitting South Africa into the international community" (see page 13).

The summit also agreed to endorse Babangida's call for a study of reparations to repay Africa for damages incurred from colonialism and slavery. The OAU is to establish a panel of "eminent" persons from Africa and the African diaspora to examine the issue. "We need to carefully collect and record the evidence so that even the most unsympathetic judge will have to rule in favor of Africa," Babangida said.

Looking ahead to the election of a new United Nations secretary general later this fall, the leaders agreed it is time to have one of their own in the post. Addressing the assembly on opening day, Javier Perez de Cuellar, the current UN chief who is leaving the job at the end of the year, said Africa "deserves to be given a chance" when the selection is made.

The leaders failed to agree on a single candidate, despite speculation that Babangida was seeking to win endorsement for his old commanding officer, former head of state Olusegun Obasanjo. Summit participants said consensus was ruled out in advance by fierce resistance to any Nigeria-led effort from countries like Zimbabwe, who has a candidate of its own (see Africa News, May 20, 1991). Instead, the leaders established a five-member committee of African United Nations ambassadors to screen potential candidates and coordinate the election effort.

The leading contenders, in addition to Obasanjo, are Ghana's Kenneth Dadzie, a veteran United Nations official who heads the UN Conference on Trade and Development (UNCTAD), Sierra Leone's James Jonah, the UN undersecretary-general for political affairs, and Zimbabwean Finance Minister Bernard Chidzero. Other well-known figures who have received mention are Olara Otunnu, a former Ugandan foreign minister who heads the International Peace Academy in New York, Senegalese President Abdou Diouf, and former foreign minister of Nigeria Joseph Garba, who was president of the last session of the United Nations General Assembly.

Pledging to wage "a vigorous campaign" for Africa's candidature, Babangida said that by fielding several strong candidates the continent could enhance the chances that one would emerge with sufficient support from the permanent members of the Security Council, particularly the U.S., which dominate the selection process.


LOAD-DATE: June 25, 1991


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1991 AllAfrica, Inc.


57 of 211 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


JUNE 24, 1991


Conflict in Liberia: Nine More Months


LENGTH: 1240 words


Last September, Africa News (Volume 34, Number 1) presented a chronology of the first nine months of civil war in Liberia. The following sequel was prepared with the help of Scott Stern, an American reporter who has covered the subsequent nine months from the Liberian capital, Monrovia.

September 1990 10: Despite the death of President Samuel K. Doe, fighting intensifies throughout the week. Remnants of Doe's former army -- the Armed Forces of Liberia (AFL) and a rebel group led by Prince Johnson continue efforts to keep Charles Taylor's National Patriotic Front of Liberia (NPFL) from gaining control of the capital. 

15: With Monrovia virtually inaccessible to outside assistance, Catholic Relief Services opens an office in the port city of Buchanan to reach Liberians throughout the countryside.

30: The first distribution of international relief items begins in Monrovia, where a dwindling population has been cut off from all food sources. About 80,000 people are supplied with rice, cooking oil and fish provided by the United Nations World Food Program.

October 20: To combat severe malnutrition among Monrovian children, a local volunteer self-help group known as SELF (Special Emergency Life Food Program) begins supplying concentrated porridge to about 70,000 children under the age of 10.

28: The west African peacekeeping force sent by six members of the Economic Community of West African States (Ecowas) steps up efforts to end the fighting. The force, known as Ecomog (for Ecowas Monitoring Group), provides artillery support for an assault by Johnson's troops, to push Taylor's soldiers to the north and away from Monrovia.

November 2: For the first time since June, a newspaper is published in Monrovia. The Torchlight, edited by Stanley Peabody, appears with sponsorship by Ecomog, which blocks publication on the back page of a photo of Doe's body after his torture and death at the hands of Johnson and his men.

5: Brig. Gen. David Nimley, the AFL commander and former close associate of Doe, flees the country. His replacement, Gen. J. Hezekiah Bowen assumes command and pledges cooperation with Johnson and the Ecomog forces, led by Lt. Gen. Arnold Quainoo of Ghana and Nigerian Gen. Joshua Dogonyaro.

9: With fighting continuing in several areas of Monrovia, Taylor's troops retake the university campus.

21: Amos Sawyer arrives in Monrovia to head an interim government 11 weeks after his selection by representatives of Liberian political, civic and professional groups, meeting in neighboring Gambia under Ecowas auspices. The inauguration takes place the following day. Under the Ecowas plan, Sawyer is barred from running for the presidency in the elections scheduled for October.

30: Meeting in Bamako, Mali in an extraordinary summit, Ecowas heads of state give unanimous endorsement to the Ecowas peace plan and the interim government. Leaders of all the warring factions, along with Sawyer, also endorse the plan and sign a cease-fire declaration. But Taylor immediately expresses doubts about the fairness of the Ecowas approach.

December 3: After an unsuccessful attack on AFL barracks by Taylor's forces, Ecomog assumes control of downtown Monrovia and nearby Bushrod Island.

20: The Ecowas Standing Mediation Committee convenes a meeting of all sides in Bangul, Gambia. Sawyer, Johnson, and Bowen take part, but Taylor stays home and sends his defense secretary, Tom Woewiyu. The following day, the parties agree to open sea and air ports in the country and call for an All Liberia Conference to find a political settlement for the conflict.

January 1991 10: The United States suspends military evacuations, which have airlifted over 500 Americans and other foreign nationals from Monrovia since August.

23: A technical team drawn from the three warring factions fails to agree on a disarmament plan after Taylor's group insists that a new interim government be put into place first.

February 13: Another meeting of the warring parties is organized by Ecowas in Lome, Togo, and after lengthy discussions ends with a comprehensive cease-fire accord.

March 1: After informal talks mediated by Togolese President Gnassingbe Eyadema in Lome, Sawyer and Taylor announce agreement on arrangements for an All Liberia peace conference, to be convened by Ecowas in Monrovia.

10: Ecowas launches a series of "confidence visits" to areas under Taylor's control, as well as to Johnson's bases and AFL-held positions. The visits are seen as a prelude to opening all the country's roads and ports, as stipulated in the Banjul agreement.

15: The All Liberia Conference opens, but Taylor fails to appear. A delegation from Taylor's NPFL objects to participation of delegations from civic, professional and religious groups and demands that representatives from each of Liberia's counties be seated.

27: The NPFL delegation walks out of the peace conference complaining that the meeting was ignoring Taylor's call for a three-person ruling council to run the country until elections are held. Taylor said that he, Sawyer and a third neutral figure should form the council.

29: The NPFL delegates return but refuse to take part in conference deliberations. The delegation chairman, Toga MacIntosh, resigns, saying Taylor is blocking peace efforts.

31: NPFL forces clash with Sierra Leone troops along the Liberian-Sierra Leonean border. As the fighting escalates, Sierra Leone President Joseph Momoh accuses Taylor of seeking to destabilize the country in retaliation for its involvement in Ecomog.

April 5: NPFL denies invading Sierra Leone, blaming the trouble on domestic opponents of President Momoh. Guinea and Nigeria agree to send troops to assist Sierra Leone's poorly equipped army.

13: Sierra Leone cuts off sea and air traffic with Liberia, and Liberian refugees report harassment and intimidation by Sierra Leonean security forces.

19: The All Liberia Conference concludes by re-electing Sawyer as president. The conference approves the creation of two vice president positions, one for each rebel group. Prince Johnson names former minister of labor, Peter Naigow, but Taylor refuses to cooperate, insisting on his troika proposal as the only workable plan.

27: The new Ecomog commander, Gen. Ruphus Kupolati of Nigeria, visits Taylor at his headquarters in Gbarnga, 125 miles from Monrovia. Kupolati restates Ecowas neutrality in Liberia, and Taylor denies involvement in the Sierra Leone fighting.

29: Sawyer swears in a new interim legislative assembly and gives Taylor 30 days to fill the seats reserved for the NPFL in the assembly and government.

May 8: Over 2,500 Liberian refugees arrive in Monrovia by ship from Freetown, Sierra Leone in the first large-scale repatriation since fighting began. With several thousand people crossing from Taylor-held areas into Monrovia each week, the city's population swells to an estimated 800,000 -- about one-third of the country's 2.3 million people.

27: Taylor swears in the second National Patriotic Reconstruction Assembly in Gbarnga, pledging to fight until "final victory" against what he calls an Ecowas aggression.

30: Commercial banks reopen in Monrovia.

June 3: Sawyer takes Liberia's seat at the annual summit of the Organization of African Unity in Abuja, Nigeria. Taylor's delegation is turned back at Lagos.


LOAD-DATE: June 25, 1991


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1991 AllAfrica, Inc.


58 of 211 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


JUNE 24, 1991


LIBERIA: WEST AFRICAN GROUP PURSUES PEACE -- AGAIN


LENGTH: 1189 words


ABIDJAN--A quiet initiative by west African governments appears to offer a fragile new hope for ending the civil war in Liberia that has killed thousands of people, made half the population refugees, and spilled across borders into neighboring countries.

Although west Africans have been divided over the 17-month-long Liberian conflict, rebel incursions into Sierra Leone and Guinea have spurred the renewed effort to forge a common approach by the 16-nation Economic Community of West African States (Ecowas). Already, an Ecowas peacekeeping force with Sierra Leonean and Guinean participation patrols the Liberian capital, Monrovia, where an interim government operates under west African auspices.

The interim government scored an important breakthrough this month at the annual Organization of African Unity summit in Nigeria. Acting President Amos Sawyer, leading a delegation from Monrovia, was received with full honors and seated alongside over 30 other African heads of state. 

Efforts to find a solution in Liberia were given fresh impetus earlier this month by the spread of fighting into new areas of Sierra Leone and by reports from fleeing refugees of continued killings by rebel forces in southeastern Liberia.

West African governments are seeking to increase diplomatic and economic pressure on Charles Taylor, leader of the main Liberian rebel group, who pulled his delegation out of an Ecowas-sponsored "All Liberian Conference" in April designed to lead to free elections later this year. A two-person delegation sent by Taylor to Nigeria was not allowed to travel to Abuja to take part in summit deliberations.

Sawyer's participation in the OAU sessions followed a flurry of diplomacy within the region as well as stepped-up activity in Liberia by the Ecowas peacekeeping force. Last month, after Sawyer visited several area capitals to bolster support for the west African initiative, Ecowas forces in Liberia took the first steps to blockade the port of Buchanan, 65 miles southeast of Monrovia, which Taylor has been using to export timber and rubber to finance his rival administration. At least one ship carrying raw materials has been diverted to Monrovia, where the cargo was seized.

The behind-the-scenes maneuvering points up the importance of two figures -- President Felix Houphouet-Boigny of Cote d'Ivoire, Africa's longest-serving head of state, and President Ibrahim Babangida of Nigeria, the region's dominant economic and political power.

Nigerians supply half of the 7,000 Ecowas forces and are central to any widened action by the peacekeeping troops. Cote d'Ivoire shares a 350-mile border with Liberia and was initially seen as sympathetic to Taylor's efforts to oust former Liberian dictator Samuel Doe, who was killed by another rebel group last September. But more recently, after the Taylor delegation left the peace conference and the fighting began in Sierra Leone, Ivoirian leaders have appeared to share a growing concern in the region about Taylor's intentions.

The Ivoirian view will assume even more importance if the Ecowas blockade is extended, because this country could then become Taylor's only potential outlet for exports.

Currently, Taylor controls most of Liberia's territory, although much of the population has fled to neighboring countries or to Monrovia, which now harbors about one third of the country's 2.3 million people. Taylor, who views the Ecowas plan to sponsor elections as a Nigerian-directed ploy to bar him from power, insists that he either head the interim government or share leadership with Sawyer.

Sawyer, who is barred by the peace plan from running for the presidency, has challenged Taylor to test his popularity at the polls.

Meanwhile, the Bush administration has provided a boost for the west African efforts. Late last month, the U.S. Justice Department asked a Federal court to "confer standing" on the interim Liberian government that would allow it to "present claims and defenses for the Republic of Liberia." The action means that the Sawyer government can move to contest a lawsuit filed by an international bank for non-payment of the country's debts and thereby seek to free some of Liberian's internationally-held assets that have been frozen by previous legal actions.

Success of those attempts would be a crucial victory for the Sawyer administration. The Doe regime left the Liberian treasury bankrupt, and the interim government has been operating with virtually no resources.

"This is not official, formal recognition," said Leonard Robinson, deputy assistant secretary of state for Africa, in a telephone interview from Washington. "But it does indicate our support for the efforts Ecowas is making." Robinson said the U. S. "will follow suit" as west African states establish diplomatic relations with the government in Monrovia.

Liberia, which was founded in 1822 by freed American slaves, has had close cultural, political and economic ties with the United States.

A meeting between Sawyer and Taylor, called by Congressman Mervyn Dymally, a California Democrat who chairs the House Africa subcommittee, was planned last month. But after west African leaders objected that Dymally's public involvement could sidetrack the Ecowas initiative, Sawyer was reluctant to attend and Dymally cancelled the session.

"We are saddened that this meeting did not take place," said Ernest Eastman, a seasoned Liberian diplomat now serving as Taylor's foreign minister. "We believed this offered the possibility for finding a solution acceptable to both sides."

However, Taylor's critics believe he is trying to stall the peace process for economic reasons. "He is shipping timber, iron ore, diamonds and rubber out of the country and depositing the proceeds in a private Swiss bank account," says Paul Reichler, a Washington, D.C. attorney representing the interim government. "The longer it takes to settle, the more he can accumulate."

Meanwhile, Nigeria is taking steps to push the Ecowas process forward. President Ibrahim Babangida has dispatched over a thousand troops to Sierra Leone, where they could be used in a pincer action against Taylor's forces, if Ecowas decides to move against Taylor from Monrovia. And the Nigerian embassy in Monrovia has been reopened.

The next phase of the Ecowas peace plan calls for opening the country's roads, enabling relief supplies to reach areas desperately in need of food and medicines, and beginning the process of reuniting the many divided families. The Women's Committee for Refugee Women and Children, a New York-based group that recently sent a mission to Liberia and the border areas, reported this month that five to ten thousand people a week are returning to Monrovia from refugee camps or slipping across Taylor lines to seek the resources available in Monrovia and the protection of Ecowas troops.

With pressures on the city's services growing, Monrovia's lively, resurgent press is becoming increasingly critical of the west African force for "foot dragging" in implementing the peace plan.


LOAD-DATE: June 25, 1991


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1991 AllAfrica, Inc.


59 of 211 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


JUNE 24, 1991


THE HORN: HUNGER STALKS WAR-WEARY ETHIOPIA


LENGTH: 982 words


An immense human tragedy unfolding in the Horn of Africa has made northeast Africa the "most serious global crisis" according to James Ingram, executive director of the World Food Program. During a tour of the region this month, the head of the United Nations agency appealed to area governments as well as to donor nations to take immediate and decisive action to save the lives of millions of people.

The impact of collapsing governments in Ethiopia and Somalia and a continuing civil war in Sudan, combined with severe drought, has put more than 20 million people at risk.

Ingram warned that the world has been numbed by the prevalence of disasters this year. "We've got to bring home to people that the situation (in the Horn) is so grave that we must act with as much resolution as we have acted in some of the other crises of 1991," he said. 

In southern Ethiopia, over seven million people living in remote, hard-to-reach areas face imminent starvation. Several hundred thousand Sudanese refugees in eastern Ethiopia who have been cut off from food supplies have fled back into Sudan. Somali refugees in the same area are flooding into Somalia.

Ingram said he had been "encouraged" by his contacts with the interim government that took control of the Ethiopian capital of Addis Ababa in early June. But the new authorities face a massive task of food distribution, and they have neither money nor fuel to do the job, he said.

When the rebel army marched into Addis Ababa late last month, after the flight of military dictator Mengistu Haile Mariam, many Ethiopians were uncertain whether to cheer or run for cover.

The 44-year reign of Emperor Haile Selassie, who ran the country like a feudal fiefdom, plus 17 years of harsh military administration, has intensified regional rivalries and left the northeastern African nation bereft of resources.

The rebels came mainly from the north, and there were fears in the capital that their arrival would introduce new tensions.

To combat those worries, the rebel coalition made a pledge to press forward with the task of establishing a broad-based government. It promised to convene a conference of all former opposition forces in Ethiopia by the beginning of July. That meeting will be charged with establishing a transitional government to run the country for the period required to organize national elections.

"Anyone who wants to participate in a peaceful and democratic transition in our country is welcome," says Acting President Meles Zenawi. Zenawi heads the Tigrean People's Liberation Front, the Ethiopian movement with the largest guerrilla army. In the interim administration, the Tigrayans are allied with two other groups under the banner of a coalition known as the Ethiopian People's Revolutionary Democratic Front (EPRDF).

The new authorities in Addis have set as first priorities the establishment of law and order and the provision of food to those most desperately in need. "We have already undertaken the gigantic task of dismantling the largest army in Africa," said Dawit Yohannes, a senior interim government official, interviewed at the Organization of African Unity summit in Nigeria earlier this month. "But the government is bankrupt," he said. "The last regime literally evacuated every coin we had."

The major long-term task ahead is national unification. "Our goal is a democratic Ethiopia in which no group will face discrimination," said Dawit, a member of the Ethiopian Peoples Democratic Movement -- composed mainly of Amharas, the country's largest ethnic group -- who are concentrated in the center of the country around Addis Ababa. The coalition also includes an organization of Oromos, another large population group.

"We have over 70 different kinds of people, with their own languages and cultures and strong sense of national identity," Dawit said. "We have to find a way to build a multinational entity within our borders." But he said the EPRDF recognizes "the right of self-determination up to and including secession."

Already, the EPRDF has agreed to political autonomy for Eritrea, a former Italian colony which Emperor Selassie annexed in 1962, sparking a thirty-year independence war which ended only with Mengistu's downfall. It was the military campaign by the Eritrean People's Liberation Front (EPLF) that inspired other guerrilla movements and finally undermined the military regime.

Three decades of war claimed 1.5 million casualties in Ethiopia, plus untold numbers on the Eritrean side, Dawit said. "We not only lost these human resources; we have been drained as a society." The result is that the area, once highly productive, has become excessively vulnerable to starvation.

"So we say this Eritrean problem has to be resolved democratically," Dawit said.

An agreement on Eritrea's future was worked out in London during peace talks chaired by Herman Cohen, the U.S. assistant secretary of State for Africa. While a transitional government is running Ethiopia for up to two years -- drafting a new constitution and conducting national elections -- the EPLF will administer Eritrea. Once a democratically-elected administration assumes power in Addis Ababa, it will organize a referendum in Eritrea to determine whether the people there want an independent state, unification with Ethiopia, or some sort of federation.

Dawit said the two-year transition period envisioned by the London conference is needed to repair the damage previous regimes have done to the nation. "The level of neglect, particularly of the Ogaden, is incredible," he said, referring to the southern region of the country along the border with Somalia, where the most severe starvation is concentrated. "You will not find a clinic there, you will not find any urban center of government, even though it is nearly as big as Texas," he said.


LOAD-DATE: June 25, 1991


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1991 AllAfrica, Inc.


60 of 211 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


JUNE 24, 1991


ZAMBIA: CAMPAIGN FEVER


LENGTH: 1000 words


LUSAKA -- The crowd at the rally for the United National Independence Party (Unip), which has ruled Zambia for 27 years, was sparse and bored. Most of those attending were market women, afraid of losing their retail licenses if they failed to show up for Unip events. During the speeches, they swatted at flies and nodded off to sleep.

One of the rally's few rousing moments offered a dramatic illustration of the extent to which popular support for the government of President Kenneth Kaunda has eroded. When a local party official attempted to lead a chant of the familiar Unip slogan, "One Zambia, one nation!," he found himself facing a unified chorus of "Sugar!," a reference to persistent shortages of key commodities. 

Dissent isn't new to Zambia, where economic difficulties have spawned several violent protests in recent years. Last week, amid opposition calls for international monitoring of the balloting, Kaunda announced that he had invited former U. S. presidents Jimmy Carter and Gerald Ford to observe the election.

Relations between Unip and the main opposition group, the Movement for Multiparty Democracy (MMD), are marked by growing antagonism. In the daily newspapers, rival party officials exchange accusations of corruption and lying. Unip usually wins the battle of the newsprint, if only because it owns one of the two major papers, the Zambia Daily Mail, and has claimed in a lawsuit to own the other paper, the Times of Zambia, as well.

Both papers are unabashedly pro-Unip. Typical of the tone is a two-inch front-page headline that screams, "Unip Buries Opposition." The story is about a few local officials who buried a coffin labeled MMD at a small political rally. Coverage of ministerial speeches extolling the virtues of Unip is common fare.

Despite its belief that the media has shut it out, the MMD, led by Frederick Chiluba, former head of the Zambian Congress of Trade Unions, appears to be gathering grassroots support. Party rallies attract thousands of enthusiastic people. The gatherings are part politics, part social event, and part religious ceremony, where exuberant chants of the party's slogan -- "The hour has come" -- refer both to the ascension of Jesus and the MMD's quest for political power. Tunes once routinely sung at Unip events now sport MMD lyrics. Charges from critics that MMD leaders have a tarnished past, including drug smuggling and corrupt business deals, don't appear to have dampened what has become almost a passion among Zambians for change.

Fueling the fervor are the deteriorating economic conditions, which years of reform efforts by both the Zambian government and international financial institutions have failed to correct. The economic crisis followed a period of growth and prosperity that ended in 1975, when international copper prices dropped by nearly half. Zambia is the world's fifth largest copper producer, and until recently, the Zambian economy earned 95% of its foreign exchange from the mining of metals, including lead and zinc as well as copper.

Encouraged by the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank, the Zambian government decided to borrow heavily to offset losses from the fall in commodity prices, which were expected to be temporary. But low world prices have continued, and the combination of decreasing earnings and mounting debt has sent Zambia's economy -- along with those of most African countries -- into a tailspin.

Almost the only good news on the economic front is Zambia's success in significantly boosting per capita food production since 1980, to the point where the country is now self-sufficient in maize. In previous years, according to Canadian economist John Loxley, Zambia was importing over 300,000 tons of maize at a cost of nearly $ 70 million.

But that gain has done little to counter the general economic decline. Between 1981 and 1986, the real wages of low, middle and top grade Zambian miners fell by 56%, 77% and 84% respectively. The amount of money the country now needs, just to service its debt and arrears, is the equivalent of 150% of its annual export earnings. Urban dwellers must cope with unemployment and a 100% inflation rate over the last two years. Decaying government services have spawned a dilapidated transport system and crumbling schools. Poor sanitary conditions helped fuel an outbreak of cholera this year that has claimed hundreds of lives.

The resulting tensions have emboldened government opponents and discomfited ruling party officials. Last month the University of Zambia was closed suddenly for undisclosed reason, amid rumors that students planned to demonstrate in favor of an interim government to supervise elections -- an option Kaunda has rejected. Paramilitary troops and police in riot gear staged a dawn raid on the Lusaka campus, trundling the entire student body onto buses for home.

The heavy-handed action and the government's sensitivity to criticism has raised public concern about the fairness of the coming vote. Some highly-placed government officials privately predict that if Kaunda loses at the polls, he may use force to remain in power.

In apparent moves to improve his chance of winning, Kaunda has promoted several people who were political fence-sitters and has appointed seven other waverers to district governorships. Government measures to stem popular discontent include a scheme to get extra taxis and buses on the roads to relieve the transportation shortage.

But Unip's main strategy seems to be to split the opposition. Unip alleges that the MMD appeals to "tribalism" and that only the ruling party can ensure a united, non-ethnic-based government. Rumors are also circulating that Unip has helped finance smaller political parties to try to weaken the MMD.

On its side, the MMD hopes to pin the blame for Zambia's bankruptcy on Unip mismanagement, a charge that, at the moment, does not seem to be falling on deaf ears.


LOAD-DATE: June 25, 1991


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1991 AllAfrica, Inc.


61 of 211 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


JUNE 24, 1991


DEMANDS FOR NATIONAL CONFERENCES MOUNT


SECTION: DEMOCRACY: AFRICA


LENGTH: 1498 words


Two weeks ago, the Foreign Minister of Madagascar told reporters in Togo that he had delivered a message of support to that country's beleaguered president, Gnassingbe Eyadema. The message, from Malagasy President Didier Ratsiraka, encouraged Eyadema to stand firm against anti-government demonstrators, whose strikes had paralyzed the Togolese capital for several weeks.

Hours later, the foreign minister received news that over 100,000 people were in the streets of his own capital city, making the same demand as the Togolese protestors -- a national conference to chart a course towards democratic elections.

Togo's Atlantic coast capital, Lome, is over 3,500 miles from Antananarivo, the Malagasy capital on the Indian Ocean. But in the last year, it has become commonplace for events in one part of the vast African continent to reverberate in another. Largely unnoticed by a world preoccupied with developments elsewhere, Africans are moving with astonishing similarity and persistence to demand responsive, accountable governments. 

Three decades after African countries began to gain formal independence from their colonial powers, they are -- in the view of a growing number of political analysts -- beginning to find their own voice. "We have had less than 30 years of independence," says Siaka Coulibaly, a senior economic advisor to the government of Cote d'Ivoire. "Where was America 30 years after its independence?"

And, Africans say, they are trying to chart their futures in a world that is far more complex, interdependent and dangerous than the one confronted by most young nations in the past.

Every African government faces a host of problems, and most are gripped by economic crises whose causes are deeply rooted and impervious to easy solutions. At the same time, however, it is impossible to travel in Africa today without encountering an atmosphere of hopeful excitement, particularly in places where popular movements are spreading at either the local or national level.

Some western diplomats express concern that the continent's democracy fervor will sour, when newly elected governments prove unable to deliver the economic miracles that many protestors seem to expect. But that prospect appears unlikely to mute the demands for rapid change.

Among the campaigns which are pressing for national political conferences or have already won the battle to hold them are the following:

* In Togo, following weeks of strikes and demonstrations that included violent clashes between protestors and police, President Eyadema agreed to opposition demands for a national conference on the country's political future. Delegates gathering in Lome this week are expected to select a prime minister, who will head a transitional government to rule until multi-party elections take place.

The decision to hold the conference was hammered out in a June 12 session between a coalition of 11 opposition parties and the president, who has kept a virtually unchallenged grip on power since a 1967 coup. Although street protests had mounted for several months, Eyadema bowed to the demand for a conference after an opposition-sponsored general strike brought transportation in Lome to a halt and shut down most offices, banks and schools in the capital. To secure the president's cooperation, the opposition agreed to allow Eyadema to remain as head-of-state until a new government is elected and to stand for election himself if he chooses.

* In nearby Cameroon, President Paul Biya has continued to rebuff similar demands for a national conference from an opposition coalition. Last week, after the government announced a ban on political meetings, the coalition said it would begin an economic blockade of the capital, Yaounde, which is 150 miles inland and dependent on supplies from the coastal city of Douala.

Yondo Black, a lawyer who heads the opposition's coordinating committee, said the ban on meetings is illegal and will be ignored. The opposition also announced a general strike for this week and said that if Biya has not agreed to a conference before July 5, there will be a march on the presidential palace.

The growing militancy of the opposition has caused several smaller opposition parties to withdraw from the coalition, but the bulk of the protest movement appears to be united behind the pressure tactics. Dr. Moses Tesi, a Cameroonian political analyst who directs the Institute of African Affairs, said in an interview that the breakaway parties pose little threat to the opposition campaign, as many of their leaders have served in former regimes. "These people were part of the government during the period when there was no democracy," he said. "How do we know that they will not return to their old ways?"

Biya has held power since 1982. More than 30 people have died in the last two months of protest against his rule.

* In Burkina Faso, a landlocked west African country north of Cote d'Ivoire, President Blaise Campaore, who seized power in a 1987 coup, faces stiff criticism, despite recent reforms that permitted opposition parties and presented a new constitution to voters. After the constitution was approved in a June 2 ballot, Campaore named a new cabinet that included opposition politicians, although 21 out of 34 members are from the ruling party.

At least 11 of 25 opposition parties -- who say they want a greater role in shaping the evolving government structures -- are boycotting consultations between the new parties and the government.

Last week, Campaore was forced to appoint three new Cabinet members, after three opposition leaders resigned amid mounting public pressure to reduce the president's term from seven years to five. Presidential elections are now slated for November 3, with parliamentary balloting to follow on December 8.

* In the Congo, the continent's longest-running national conference ended June 10 after three months of sometimes stormy debate about the country's past political failures and its future. The proceedings were broadcast live on national television.

At the conference closing, President Denis Sassou-Nguesso took part in a hand-washing ceremony symbolizing forgiveness, along with former President Joachim Yhombi Opango, whom Sassou-Nguesso ousted in 1979 and imprisoned without trial for eleven years.

The conference took away from the president most of his powers and named a prime minister, Andre Milongo, to head the government and take command of the army during the one-year transition to democratic rule. A constitutional referendum will be held in November, legislative elections next March, and a presidential vote in June.

The conference participants voiced harsh criticism of Sassou-Nguesso's 12 years in power, alleging corruption, mismanagement, and physical intimidation of opponents. The meeting established a tribunal to probe the assets of the president and his colleagues and to seek repatriation of any funds illegally deposited in foreign banks.

* Next door in Zaire, President Mobutu Sese Seko has set July 10 as the opening day for his country's national conference. A previous effort to convene a meeting on April 29 failed when leading opposition groups accused the president of trying to dominate the proceedings.

An upsurge in discontent forced concessions from Mobutu, who has ruled the country since a 1965 takeover. Last year, he legalized opposition parties but their activities are still curtailed. A rally planned a week ago in Kinshasa by several major opposition groups, including the Union pour la Democratie and le Progress Social (UPDS) led by Etienne Tshisikedi, was blocked by the arrest of Tshisikedi and three other UPDS leaders, who were held for several hours before being released. According to UPDS officials, several hundred party supporters were wounded when police fired on a crowd which gathered for the planned protest.

* The march towards pluralism in Niger took an unusual path last month when thousands of women marched to demand inclusion in the committee to plan that country's national conference. Their demand was accepted, and women are now among the dozens of planners representing political parties, students, workers and civic associations who have been laboring for over a month to lay the groundwork for the meeting. Originally scheduled to begin at the end of May, the conference is now expected to start sometime next month. Delegates are to choose a prime minister to take over administrative powers from Colonel Ali Saibou, who assumed power four years ago.

* Protests that brought out 100,000 people in Madagascar on June 11 were the beginning of a series of demonstrations against the regime of President Didier Ratsiraka that have continued to mount. The protesters in Antananarivo, capital of the Indian Ocean island nation, have been calling for an end to Ratsiraka's 16-year rule and for a national conference to draft a new constitution.


LOAD-DATE: June 25, 1991


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1991 AllAfrica, Inc.


62 of 211 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


JUNE 24, 1991


OPPOSITION SEEKS GOVERNMENT'S RESIGNATION


LENGTH: 228 words


Laurent Gbagbo, leader of the Ivoirian Popular Front (FPI), one of the major opposition parties, is calling for the resignation of the government of Prime Minister Allasane Ouattara. Gbagbo, who ran against Houphouet-Boigny in last year's presidential elections -- the first multiparty contest in Cote d'Ivoire's history -- said the dispatch of the army to university residence halls at 1:00 am raises serious doubts about the government's competence to handle the affairs of state. 

Here are excerpts from Gbagbo's response to the president's speech, from an interview last week with La Voie, a new daily newspaper which supports Gbagbo's FPI:

If the president's declaration had been made the 18th of May, the affair would have been quickly circumscribed. There would certainly have been neither the strikes nor the demonstrations. But coming one month after the beginning of the problem, the speech is incomplete.

Since the 18th of May, the government has made four pronouncements. They were all designed to subdue the emotions of the people of Cote d'Ivoire and to portray the affair as a normal police action.

But essential questions remain. Who gave the order to the military to enter the university? Why was the army used and not just the police?

Come demonstrate with us to show the government that it must learn to respect Ivoirians.


LOAD-DATE: June 25, 1991


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1991 AllAfrica, Inc.


63 of 211 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


JUNE 24, 1991


PRESIDENT PROMISES AN INVESTIGATIVE COMMISSION


LENGTH: 455 words


In a June 16 speech to the nation, President Felix Houphouet-Boigny spoke about the May 17 security force raid on a university residence hall in the suburb of Yopougon where students claim four people were killed -- a charge the government denies -- and about opposition demands for an international commission of inquiry into the incident. Here are excerpts from the address:

What happened that night at Yopougon is a sad event that we regret, that we deplore, and about which immediate action will be taken. But before announcing the measure that I'm taking today, I first want to remind you of some realities. 

It is clear that the commission we are going to create today is going to shed total light on what happened at Yopougon. But the commission will only be composed of our citizens.

I spent 15 years in the French parliament and I participated in six governments. But we would think it odd if the French were to appeal to their friends to come to solve the problems that occur in France. So let's stop this talk of having foreigners intervene in our affairs. We are adult enough, whatever it costs us, to solve our own problems ourselves.

The commission will be composed of 32 members -- and I underline this -- who will be freely chosen by the groups of which they are members. The commission will choose its own president and staff. Commission members will operate with complete independence to clarify for us what happened at Yopougon. They will need to obey nothing but their own consciences.

I have often said to you that I have three judges: God, my conscience and the people. Therefore, the commissioners must obey their consciences. And I appeal to Ivoirians who have any complaints to put them freely before the commission, without hesitation. No one will have anything to fear from telling the truth.

My dear brothers and sisters, since 1943 I have enjoyed the confidence of the valiant and generous people of Cote d'Ivoire. Confidence, as you all know, is very difficult to acquire but, unfortunately, very easy to lose. I don't want to lose the confidence of Cote d'Ivoire.

When I was very young, I pledged before God never to shed, or cause to be shed, a single drop of human blood. You know that Cote d'Ivoire has not abolished the death penalty -- and it falls to your humble servant to decide the fate of those who are condemned to death. Up to this day, I have never allowed the execution of a single condemned person. So how could I dream -- for a single instant -- of snuffing out the life of one of our students, our dear children, our reason for being? Besides their families, our dear children can find no one who loves them more than I do.

God is love. I thank you.


LOAD-DATE: June 25, 1991


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1991 AllAfrica, Inc.


64 of 211 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


JUNE 24, 1991


IVOIRIAN PROTESTS SPREAD


LENGTH: 887 words


ABIDJAN-- Cote d'Ivoire, one of the first countries to respond to pro-democracy movements by allowing opposition parties, unfettering the press and holding presidential elections, is in the midst of a second round of political protests that have claimed at least one life in recent weeks.

A year ago, the country was jolted out of 30 years of relative political tranquility by waves of demonstrations that came to be known as the "strike of the day." Everyone from taxi drivers to bankers to soldiers took to the streets in protests that were fueled as much by economic complaints as by political goals.

Today, this former French colony of 12 million people has dozens of feisty newspapers, a spirited opposition, and an 86-year-old president who handily won re-election last October. But the political reforms have been unable to stop the slide of an economy dependent on earnings from coffee and cocoa, whose prices have remained at a ten-year low. 

After a month of mounting tension following a late-night raid on university dormitories, Prime Minister Alassane Ouattara went on television Thursday night to announce the government's decision to dissolve the national student organization and to order teachers back to their classrooms.

The current conflicts began last month with a public campaign by students and teachers to protest poor conditions and lack of resources in the education system. Sporadic strikes broke out, despite stern government warnings to protesters. The dispute became a crisis on the night of May 17, when more than a dozen students were injured and several women students reportedly were raped as troops swept through student residence halls to round-up suspected ring-leaders.

Student and opposition groups claimed that four students were killed, but the government has maintained that there were no deaths. The bureau chief of the Agence France-Press news agency was promptly expelled from the country for reporting the student allegations without first checking the story with the authorities.

The campus incidents sparked the first street demonstrations seen in this administrative capital since last fall's elections. Amid calls for an investigation and demands for the government to resign, authorities issued a series of statements suggesting the action was taken in response to a plot by students and teachers to disrupt the country.

With protests continuing, President Felix Houphouet-Boigny made a nationally-televised appeal for students and teachers to return to their classrooms. The June 15 speech announced the creation of a 32-member panel of inquiry, composed of judges, members of parliament, parents of students, religious leaders and attorneys.

But the announcement failed to defuse campus tensions, and last Monday a confrontation erupted be-tween members of the striking stu-dent federation and a student accused by the others of leading a group of government-paid thugs. The accused, Thierry Zebie, was killed with sticks and iron bars, and pictures of his bloody body were displayed on newscasts of the government-controlled television network and the front page of the official newspaper. Students and some teachers told journalists that the attack on Zebie came in response to his firing on student activists, but no gun has been produced.

As a result of the raid and the government's handling of the ensuing troubles, opposition leaders have called for the resignation of Ouattara's seven-month-old government. The prime minister, a central banker and former International Monetary Fund official widely respected for his competence, was appointed after last year's protests, with the assignment of getting the Ivoirian economy back on track -- a task that has required a series of painful reforms.

The political and economic reforms have left opposition leaders split over the issue of a national conference to chart Cote d'Ivoire's immediate future. Laurent Gbagbo, the leader of the Ivoirian Popular Front (FPI) who ran against Houphouet-Boigny in last October's presidential elections, has backed away from the demand for a conference that was issued by all the leading opposition groups.

In the November parliamentary vote, the FPI won nine seats in the 175-member National Assembly and is expected to have at least one representative on the panel of inquiry into the university events. Even so, the front has taken its demand for the gov-ernment's resignation into the streets, mobilizing tens of thousands of marchers in demonstrations that con-tinued through the weekend.

The economic reform package, developed in coordination with the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank, is contributing to the government's political difficulties. "We have to reduce employment in the public sector drastically, and that is surely not popular," said one finance ministry official. The cuts in expenditures on education are a major cause for the unrest in the schools and at the university, which has more than 20,000 enrolled on a campus designed for 7,000.

"All this trouble is a result of our poverty," said Foreign Minister Amara Essy in an interview last week. "People think our government is not doing a good job, but the drop in the price of cocoa has reduced our budget by 70%," he said. "What can we do?"


LOAD-DATE: June 25, 1991


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1991 AllAfrica, Inc.


65 of 211 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July 15, 1991


THINKING AGAIN


LENGTH: 139 words


Last week the World Bank released its World Development Report for 1991, called The Challenge of Development. The book's 180-page analysis of the status and prospects for economic development around the world reflects the debate of recent years between the international financial institutions and their critics, who have questioned some of the policies and strategies of the organizations. The report says that "in a spirit of pragmatism and open-mindedness, it is right to conclude that income growth has been overemphasized as a measure of welfare," and that equities of income distribution and other indicators of human welfare should be taken into account. The Bank also stresses the importance of women's role in development, protection of the environment, and preventive as well as curative health care programs.

LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1991 AllAfrica, Inc.
