Africa News


July 15, 1991


SHUT DOWN


LENGTH: 122 words


The general strike in Cameroon -- designed to force the government of President Paul Biya to hold a national constitutional conference -- spread last week to the country's northern province. The eastern and western regions had already joined the protests, which began in the economic capital, Douala. The editor of Le Messenger, an independent newspaper, said Douala remained paralyzed two weeks into the campaign, nicknamed "Ghost Town." Late last week police dispersed demonstrators with tear gas and rounded up as many as a thousand suspected government opponents. In the areas observing the strike, virtually all shops and offices are closed and taxis and buses have stopped running. Only food markets are open.


LOAD-DATE: July 12, 1991


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1991 AllAfrica, Inc.


67 of 211 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July 15, 1991


TRY, TRY AGAIN


LENGTH: 345 words


Frustrated by the continuing stalemate in Liberia, West African leaders have proposed a new election timetable for their war-ravaged neighbor. During a summit in Nigeria early this month, heads of state from the 16-nation Economic Community of West African States (Ecowas) announced plans to hold a presidential vote in Liberia within six months. They asked for assistance in monitoring the poll from former President Jimmy Carter's International Negotiations Network. 

The summit statement followed a meeting in Cote d'Ivoire on June 30 between five West African presidents and the two principal Liberian leaders -- Amos Sawyer, who heads the interim government based in the capital Monrovia, and Charles Taylor, whose forces control most of the country's territory outside the capital. Meeting for the first time since the fighting started at the end of 1989, Sawyer and Taylor agreed to hold elections under Ecowas auspices. Ecowas currently has a peacekeeping force of 7,000 troops stationed in Monrovia.

To oversee the election process, Ecowas established a five-member committee headed by Ivorian President Felix Houphouet-Boigny. Senegalese President Abdul Diouf, the new Ecowas chairman, is also on the panel, along with Gambian President Dawda Jawara, Togolese President Gnassingbe Eyadema, and President Joao Bernardo Vieira of Guinea-Bissau.

The Ecowas communique says each side will be responsible for maintaining security in its territory until the election process begins, but many other details of the transition remain to be resolved. Richard Joseph, a Carter Center representative, was present for the Ecowas summit, where he met with Sawyer and several other leaders. Joseph also had talks with Taylor at his headquarters in Gbarnga, 125 northeast of Monrovia.

Interviewed in Abidjan, Joseph said the current separation of Liberia into two totally separate zones stands in the way of fair elections. "Ways must be found to overcome these divisions and allow free movement of people and goods throughout the country," he said.


LOAD-DATE: July 12, 1991


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1991 AllAfrica, Inc.


68 of 211 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July 15, 1991


CHURCH AND STATE:


SECTION: BITS AND PIECES


LENGTH: 377 words


The Indian Ocean island nation of Madagascar has joined the parade of countries that are convening national conferences to pursue democratic reforms. The decision was made during lengthy negotiations between the opposition coalition known as Force Vive and the four parties that constitute the government. The deal was brokered by the Council of Churches. 

President Didier Ratsiraka, who has ruled for 15 years, had refused all demands for a national conference. But weeks of demonstrations, which brought hundreds of thousands of people into the streets of the capital and other cities, forced him to yield. Despite last week's agreement, a general strike continued in many parts of the country, with protesters saying that pressure on the government must be maintained. The president has continued to insist that he will remain head of state, even if the conference chooses a transitional administration to guide the country toward elections.

A preparatory committee to plan the conference will have 12 members from the government, 12 members from the opposition and seven from the Council of Churches. Asked about the swing votes the Council will possess, a church leader said that religious organizations have a duty to help the country develop a new constitution and to work to improve the nation's economic situation.

Madagascar isn't the only place where the church is playing a central role in political reforms. Last month the national conference in Congo elected Bishop Ernest Nkombo, who has been presiding at the sessions, to head the newly-established Supreme Council of the Republic. The 153-member Council will govern as a legislative body for the next 12 months and will organize elections projected for May of next year. Earlier, conference delegates had reduced Congolese President Dennis Sassou-Nguesso's role to representing the nation at ceremonial occasions and to signing international treaties.

In Ethiopia, the new custodians of state power -- the Ethiopian Peoples' Revolutionary Democratic Front -- delighted the church community by ordering the demolition of a fence that had walled off Trinity Cathedral in the capital Addis Ababa. The church filled with worshippers on Friday after the barrier came down.


LOAD-DATE: July 12, 1991


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1991 AllAfrica, Inc.


69 of 211 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July 15, 1991


DEBT: CLOSING THE GAP


LENGTH: 584 words


Abidjan -- Parliamentarians from Africa, North America, Europe and Australia, meeting in Cote d'Ivoire for a north-south roundtable on African debt, declared last week that the promotion of democracy is the most important goal for achieving economic development.

Dismissing the notion that economic reforms, including painful cutbacks in government programs and spending, require strong-arm governments to impose the tough measures on reluctant publics, the conference statement said that "economic reforms must be fully transparent, answering to the interests and will of the African peoples." Only a government that is accountable to its people, the document says, can pursue a sustainable development program. 

The debt roundtable took place as the leaders of the world's seven most powerful industrialized nations prepared to gather in London for their annual meeting. The parliamentarians said that the so-called G-7 countries, who will "decide the economic future of the world for the next year," should put Africa's economic crisis high on their agenda.

Although debt is one serious problem among many, the roundtable statement said that "debt relief is a necessary precondition for solving these problems."

The roundtable was held against a background of African debt that has increased faster than anywhere else in the developing world. In the last 12 years, the continent's external debt has grown from $ 48.3 billion to $277.7 billion. And as the debt burden and the payments to support it mushroomed, African countries have slipped down the ladder of world economic rankings.

The Organization of African Trade Union Unity points out that during the decade of the 1980s, "the number of African least-developed countries rose from 17 to 29 and several middle-income African countries tripped into low-income countries, but significantly, not one African country rose to the ranks of a high-income country".

Earlier this year, former Italian Prime Minister Bettino Craxi, who is the United Nations Secretary- General's Special Advisor on the debt crisis, told the UN General Assembly that the economic problems of sub-Saharan African nations appear "insolvable without drastically reducing their debt." Craxi called for "exceptional concessionary measures" by the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank.

The United Nations Children's Fund (Unicef) is also campaigning for debt relief. It argues that although Africa's debt problem is not large in world terms -- which means that the continent tends to be overlooked in discussions about the international debt crisis -- easing the debt burden could reverse Africa's economic decline.

Just cancelling interest on the debt would be a significant step, Unicef says, noting that sub-Saharan Africa's combined 1989 interest bill for long-term and IMF debt was $ 7.2 billion, while "all Unicef child-oriented goalsfor sub-Saharan Africa in the 1990s could be achieved with an additional $ 7 billion a year."

One of the calls made by the roundtable is for member governments of the IMF to adopt a policy of "zero net transfers" to Africa for at least the next six years. Between 1986 and 1990, the parliamentarians said, "the IMF has extracted over $ 3 billion" more in debt payments from low-income African countries that it has put into those countries as loans. The legislators called on the IMF to consider selling a small fraction of its gold reserves and using the proceeds to reduce African debt. n


LOAD-DATE: July 12, 1991


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1991 AllAfrica, Inc.


70 of 211 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July 15, 1991


MAURITANIA: QUESTIONS ON HUMAN RIGHTS PERSIST


LENGTH: 419 words


Mauritania was scheduled to join the swelling ranks of African countries voting on new constitutions over the weekend, with a referendum on a document that would re-install multiparty politics in the northwest African nation.

The proposed constitution provides for a president elected for a renewable six-year term and includes guarantees of equality, freedom of expression, association and conscience, the right to political opposition and a free press. But protestors, who took to the streets last month, say that a constitution drafted by military rulers, while opposition leaders are detained, is no recipe for democracy. 

Meanwhile, concerns continue to be raised about Mauritania's record on human rights. Six weeks ago Africa Watch issued a report on the executions or deaths under torture of more than 200 black Mauritanians. The Mauritanian government is dominated by persons of Moorish descent, and discrimination against blacks has been a common feature of Mauritanian life.

Actual slavery was abolished a decade ago, but an Amnesty International report last year called the practice "alive and well." In its annual report released last week, Amnesty cited Mauritania as still a sad case on a continent where human rights have seen some improvement with the growth of pro-democracy movements in the last year. In a move that observers found significant, the Mauritanian Workers Union issued a call in April for an investigation into the treatment of black detainees.

The plight of black and dissident Mauritanians has also received some recent attention in the U.S Congress. In joint hearings on June 19 by Mervyn Dymally (D-CA) of the House Subcommittee of Africa and Gus Yatron (D--PA) of the House Subcommittee on Human Rights and International Organizations, witnesses testified that despite its moves towards political pluralism, Mauritania has not halted its practice of gross human rights violations.

The Congressional Human Rights Caucus has drafted a letter to Mauritanian ruler Maawiy Ould Sidi Ahmed Taya, urging him "to put an end to slavery and the persecution of individuals on the basis of race."

The Mauritanian government has argued that the new constitution, which calls Mauritania an "Arab and African Islamic Republic," and adds there are three languages spoken by black ethnic groups as national languages -- although Arabic remains the official language -- is a giant step towards integrating blacks into the political and economic life of the country.


LOAD-DATE: July 12, 1991


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1991 AllAfrica, Inc.


71 of 211 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July 15, 1991


MOZAMBIQUE: RECOVERY FROM WAR'S TRAUMA


LENGTH: 1839 words


Although Africa has only 11% of the world's population, two-thirds of the victims of wars over the past decade have been African. At the height of the conflicts, 25 African children died every hour from the effects of the fighting, according to estimates by the United Nations Children's Fund (Unicef). An additional 5 million are continuing to struggle for survival amid war-related famine and economic dislocation.

Children are always the foremost victims of wars and natural disasters, and in Africa, where children are nearly half the population, the impact is particularly heavy.

Mozambique is perhaps the worst-affected country. Besides the millions of children who have been displaced, orphaned or separated from their families, tens of thousands have been kidnapped by rebels who forced them to witness and participate in acts of brutality. 

With the help of international organizations like Save the Children Fund and Unicef, the Mozambique government has established programs to train counselors to help children cope with their experiences, to trace family members and to place orphans with relatives or other families in their home communities.

In 1989, Duke University psychologist Neil Boothby and colleagues began a survey of children directly affected by war in Mozambique. In the following excerpts from a presentation in March, he recounts some of the findings.

Six-year-old Franisse was kidnapped by Renamo, the Mozambique rebel movement while he was down by the river. Hands grabbed him, and he was shoved up the path to his village, where a man gave him matches and made him set his family's hut ablaze. His mother ran out first, then his father. Franisse was made to watch as the bandits, as they are called by many in Mozambique, cut his parents heads off with machetes. Their bodies were dismembered, and the heads impaled on stakes. "This is what Frelimo (the government party) buys you," he said, as Franisse was marched along with other survivors, back to Renamo's armed stronghold.

There are tens of thousands of children like Franisse in Mozambique. Child survivors can be seen staggering into government-run refugee centers physically malnourished and psychologically numbed, sometimes speechless, seemingly incapable of showing any emotion other than a kind of unnerving wait-and-see stoicism. Sometimes they awake from nightmares with somatic complications: headaches, stiff necks, respiratory ailments, or occasionally, the temporary loss of eyesight or hearing. Yet given time and stability, many of these child survivors have been able to make substantial recoveries from the almost unimaginable tragedies they witnessed and experienced.

Among the children we have worked with in Mozambique is a group of 42 former soldiers between six and 16 years old who were being cared for at the Lhanguene Center. Nearly all the boy soldiers had been abducted by Renamo, trained as combatants, and in many instances, encouraged to kill other human beings. The indoctrination process is a brutal and systematic attempt to transform children into abusers with formal rituals performed following a child's first act of murder.

Clinical observations of the consequences of various kinds of war-associated stresses and traumas indicates that there is a difference between the effects on children exposed to acute trauma and those faced with chronic stress and violence. An acute reaction generally lasts only a few days and is marked by features of severe anxiety. If the trauma is intense enough, it may lead to permanent psychological scarring, especially when children lose their parents, extended family or other familiar community members. The fear and anxiety that most children do manifest appears to subside fairly rapidly.

Chronic reactions, on the other hand, are those which endure beyond this brief time span. It is marked by features of Post Traumatic Stress Disorder (PTSD), including a persistent re-experiencing of the trauma, reduced responsiveness and involvement with the environment, and diminished expectations for the future. Profound alterations in personality, behavior and moral development have also been noted among child victims of chronic political violence. Many children learn to cope or survive in these dangerous circumstances, but their survival is not without cost.

In our initial experimental treatment for the 42 boys at the Lhanguene Center, we found that the length of time spent in the Renamo base camp, more than direct involvement in violence per se, was associated with their varied abilities to later act upon traditional concepts of right and wrong.

In general, the 35 boys who had spent less than six months in Renamo camps appeared to emerge from these experiences with their sense of basic trust in the traditional tribal values of their communities intact. Even though some had committed acts of violence, they continued to define themselves as victims, rather than as members, of Renamo. After liberation, the majority of these boys did display aggressive behaviors and feelings that were indeed distrustful of adults. However, these behaviors and attitudes subsided quickly, and their early recovery efforts were marked more by symptoms of PTSD -- including appropriate feelings of remorse -- than by antisocial behavior.

But the seven boys who had spent between one and two years in Renamo camps appeared to have crossed a kind of identity threshold in which their own self-concepts had become more solidly entwined with their captors. These boys had come to view themselves as members of Renamo. As one 15-year-old boy put it: "I was reborn in that base camp. Even if I could have escaped, I could never have gone home again. Not after what I had seen and done."

Only after three months at the Lhanguene Center did we begin to observe signs of remorse over previous acts of violence among these boys, as well as anxiety connected to reminders of other traumatic events. These symptoms began to occur at about the same time the boys started to show increased attachment behavior and more positive feelings toward their new adult caretakers, a "softening" that was also accompanied by an increased interest in social activities outside the center. This led us to suspect that these symptoms were prompted by their struggle to leave behind a world in which killing was sanctioned, and to re-enter a world in which killing is, once again, condemned.

Rehabilitation efforts at the center tried to establish daily routines and safe codes of behavior. Oral storytelling, dance, theater or sociodrama and art also emerged as traditional activities most readily adaptable for therapeutic purposes. But the boys' efforts to re-enter civilian life after dehumanizing experiences in Renamo camps were facilitated less through psychological intervention than through members of the Mozambique Women's Organization (OMM) who were the caretakers at the Lhanguene Center. One 52-year-old volunteer told us that the attitudes and behaviors of both boys and caretakers gradually changed over time, from mutual fear to mother/child relationships.

The patience and dedication of OMM caretakers enabled most of these boys to reorient various aspects of their mental, emotional, social and moral development. By the end of the first year at the center, all had made substantial progress in school, bearing witness to their basically unharmed capacity for cognitive learning and had learned to control their aggressive behavior towards outsiders. All showed at least the beginnings of more normal relationships with adults and other children.

When the boys were reunited with their families or returned to their communities, we continued to follow their progress during the first 18 months of their readjustment. The results revealed a continuation of the same high potential for readaptation. Even those who have been cursed with the worst possible circumstances have been able to manage moments and longer periods of competent behavior, good humor and optimism.

What also needs to be stressed is that in Mozambique survival is a collective act, rooted in community compassion and care. In endangered zones, extended families and neighbors employ a number of measures to try to protect their children from Renamo, ranging from hiding children together in forests or caves at night, to caring for one another's children while primary caretakers are away working in potentially dangerous fields, to fleeing together to safer districts, provincial capitals or even to neighboring countries. One of the results of this collective act is that despite the widespread destruction of villages and massive displacements of people, the vast majority of the estimated 200,000 orphaned and unaccompanied children have been absorbed by extended families and members of former communities or ethnic groups.

An awareness of children's potential adaptability under stress and of protective factors within children's ecologies has important programmatic implications in countries like Mozambique. First it suggests that the major thrust of primary mental health initiatives needs to be oriented towards the source of children's resilience, rather than to the individual child. Broader aid efforts must try to help children re-establish their primary relationships with parents, families and communities. The timely provision of food, material or other cash assistance can help vulnerable families to maintain a regular income and to continue supporting themselves and their children. Parents, teachers and other community members also require assistance in understanding that the child's initial aggressive behavior is often an effort to re-establish limits or boundaries as well as trust in others. In this way the community may be better able to tolerate what can be constructive use of aggression.

Finally, we found that former boy soldiers require more than psychological treatment in order to re-enter community life. They need to be forgiven by society, sometimes by the very people who have been victimized by their past actions. Many of our initial efforts on behalf of boy soldiers in Mozambique focused on helping community members -- political leaders, soldiers, police, teachers, and other students -- to understand that these boys themselves were victims as well.

We also worked with the Mozambique government on a national level to establish policy and concrete procedures so that children who were forced to participate with Renamo would be provided appropriate care and psychological treatment rather than be sent to military prisons. Community cohesion, family care and psychocultural support services are all playing a role in children's recoveries. But is has been Mozambique's policy of amnesty -- a policy which institutionalizes forgiveness rather than institutionalizing children -- that has provided at least some of these boy soldiers the opportunity to return home to their families and friends.


LOAD-DATE: July 12, 1991


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1991 AllAfrica, Inc.


72 of 211 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July 15, 1991


FEARS AND HOPES FOR AFRICA'S YOUTH


SECTION: CHILDREN


LENGTH: 882 words


Six out of every ten Africans are children -- a fact that has prompted African countries to take particular notice of children's issues.

African governments were among the first to give their collective backing to the 1990 World Summit for Children sponsored by the United Nations Children's Fund (Unicef). The Organization of African Unity responded to the summit's call for action by drawing up an African Charter on the Rights and Welfare of the Child and declaring the 1990s the "African Decade for Child Survival, Protection and Development." On June 16, countries across the continent observed the "Day of the African Child" by hanging banners, producing media programs and organizing special events to highlight children's needs. 

Spurring all the attention is the grim reality that 29 of the world's 42 least developed countries are in Africa. Of the 30 countries in the world with an infant mortality rate greater than 100 for each 1,000 live births, 23 are in sub-Saharan Africa. The life expectancy of Africa's children is 20 years less than that of children in industrialized countries. During 1991, 4.7 million African children will die, mostly from preventable diseases. The spread of AIDS poses a further threat: already, one of every 10 AIDS patients in east and central Africa is a child under five years old.

Yet the prospects for Africa's children are not unremittingly bleak. In the last decade, North African countries have achieved nearly 80% vaccination rates against the six main child killer diseases, while the rate for sub-Saharan Africa has risen from 20% to almost 60%.

James Grant, Executive Director of Unicef, argues that Africa's gains are impressive, when measured against the starting point at independence. "It has taken Africa just three decades," he says, "to raise health, literacy and other standards to levels which industrialized civilizations took more than a century to achieve." Since the 1960s, the mortality rate for African children under five has dropped by 42%, while average life expectancy has risen from 41 to 53 years. Five out of every six children born in Africa in 1991 will survive their first five, most vulnerable years.

Paradoxically, the lives saved through immunization programs and other advances in health and nutrition will diminish the population pressures that have contributed to the continent's declining per capita income in recent years. Around the world, population growth rates begin to fall only after survival rates rise, when parents have more assurances that the children they bear will live.

The various recent conferences and declarations devoted to children have sparked a number of responses in industrialized countries, including a fact-finding trip to Africa earlier this year by the administrator of the U.S. Agency for International Development, Ronald W. Roskens and Health and Human Services Secretary Louis Sullivan. The trip fulfilled a pledge made by President George Bush in a September 30 address to the U.N. children's summit, when he said he would dispatch a presidential mission to Africa "to see what else America and the world can do to advance child survival across that continent and around the world."

Among the policy recommendations arising from the team's visit to eight countries are: a commitment to broad-based economic growth; an emphasis on support for primary and preventive health care; backing for programs that encourage behavioral change to fight the transmission of AIDS; intensified assistance for family planning; the sharing of information technology with African professionals; the building of stronger institutional links between Africans and Americans; and increased attention to malaria, which the trip report calls "the forgotten killer."

Currently, malaria accounts for 20-30% of Africa's under-five childhood deaths. But there is new hope for curbing the disease's devastating impact. Recently published results of research trials in West Africa show that low-cost bed nets, permeated with insecticides, could dramatically reduce the incidence of malaria.

There are many efforts underway to provide better health care and educational opportunities, to limit population growth, and to increase family incomes. But there is widespread agreement among child welfare workers that two major factors hinder the ability of those efforts to improve the lot of Africa's children. One is the number of armed conflicts across the continent (see story, pages 6 and 7); the other is the debt burden that continues to retard economic recovery.

Despite those harsh realities, there appears to be a growing sense among African researchers and social scientists that hard lessons have been learned over the last three decades and that the 1990s will see the fruits of more informed development policies. "You may have to come and spend some time in the countries of Africa to see some of the positive changes," says Ivorian political economist Dr. Joseph Yao Yao. Statistics may be discouraging, he says--and they are important--but they hide the strength of Africa's human resources. The importance of "investing in human capital," especially in the welfare of children, is one of the lessons that must be heeded, he says.


LOAD-DATE: July 12, 1991


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1991 AllAfrica, Inc.


73 of 211 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July 15, 1991


SUDAN: STARVING WHILE POLITICIANS STALL


SECTION: CONFLICT


LENGTH: 1404 words


Both the Sudanese government of Omar Hassan al-Bashir and the insurgent Sudan People's Liberation Movement (SPLM) have accepted Nigerian President Ibrahim Babangida -- who currently chairs the Organization of African Unity -- as mediator in the civil war that has wracked Sudan since 1983. An early cease-fire agreement would not only suspend the fighting, but would improve the prospects of getting emergency aid to an estimated 8 million people facing starvation in Sudan's isolated southern region.

But the potential benefits of peace have failed to spark any visible progress towards negotiations. Nor have the two sides been able to stir much international interest in a conflict that remains murky to most outsiders.

The ruling military junta seized power in a 1989 coup, from a government that Los Angeles Times reporter Michael Hiltzik called "a democracy -- if a wretched one -- so blind to the needs of its people that it fell entirely unlamented." The new regime of Islamic fundamentalists imposed Sharia, or Islamic law, in the predominantly-Moslem northern region, including the capital, Khartoum. Hundreds of potential dissidents were arrested, including teachers, doctors, lawyers and trade unionists. The human rights group Africa Watch said that in Sudanese detention centers "torture is practiced on a systematic basis." 

The rebel SPLM, led by John Garang, celebrated the eighth anniversary of its military wing two months ago, and the group says it now controls 300,000 square miles of southern Sudan, an area with a predominantly Christian population. But the SPLM suffered a setback with the fall of the Mengistu regime in neighboring Ethiopia, which had backed the rebels. As many as 400,000 Sudanese, who had gone to Ethiopia to escape the fighting, fled back across the border where their new refugee camps have been bombed by Sudan's air force.

Garang, interviewed while visiting Washington late last month, says the SPLM is "eager to negotiate a just resolution to the conflict" and is "prepared to sit down any time." But he says his group remains wary because "there have been many peace initiatives before."

And Garang doubts the government's commitment to end the fighting. The present government in Khartoum, he says, is the fourth one that the SPLM has confronted, and "it is getting more fundamentalist and more intransigent."

A state department official who doesn't want to speak on the record says he doubts the SPLM's own commitment to finding an end to the conflict. "Neither side has shown any willingness to give," says the official.

John Garang says that the SPLM would attend talks "with an open mind and no preconditions." However, Garang's contention that the al-Bashir government "has no legitimacy to give us" is a thinly veiled challenge to the government's own legitimacy. So is Garang's reference to al-Bashir's junta, the Revolutionary Command Council (RCC), as "junior rebels."

Garang's concept of talks, at which the "senior rebels" of the SPLM would "brainstorm" with the RCC and a number of northern groupings that oppose it, is likely to be rejected by the government. And the RCC, for its part, draws its main support from radical Islamic forces and is unlikely to yield on the key question of Sharia.

Although the issues that divide the two sides concern the identity and administration of the state, Sharia has been a touchstone of the war. Its introduction in 1983 by then-President Jaafar Nimeiry weighed heavily among the factors that caused the non-Islamic southerners to take up arms, and Sharia was suspended after Nimeiry's ouster in 1985.

Talks mediated by former U.S. President Jimmy Carter in December 1989 broke down when the al-Bashir government and the SPLM were unable to resolve the issue. The RCC's exemption of the south when it formally imposed Sharia early this year did not appease the SPLM.

In addition, the SPLM raises questions about Sudan's identity as an Arab-African state. Dominated by the Arab-identified north since its independence in 1955, Sudan is a member of the Arab League and the Islamic Conference Organization. The people of the south, where the SPLM draws its main support, are Christians and followers of traditional African faiths.

"These are all questions which must be included in negotiations," says John Garang. He vehemently rejects the suggestion that Sudan might fare better as two nations, saying the SPLM "will fight for the unity of the country."

The unified Sudan envisioned by Garang is one in which the south enjoys some autonomy, and where economic power is not a monopoly.

A fundamental element of the power equation has been control of natural resources. The SPLM now appears eager to sidestep this issue by luring back the foreign investors who fled the fighting between its own army and government forces.

"We are ready now to cooperate with international business," Garang says. The development of the south's oil, gold, tea and coffee sectors "all can start now," he promises. "Whatever scenario we end up with, Sudan is so big that it cannot be administered from the center and there will need to be a devolution of power."

Garang termed his group's opening to investors "parallel development," much like the "parallel aid programs" that have sometimes been a necessity for delivering food aid to famine victims in areas controlled by the SPLM.

When asked what guarantees of security foreign investors might expect when relief workers in the area have complained of harassment by the SPLM -- as well as by the RCC in the areas the government controls, Garang replied that corporations should use as a barometer the "freedom movement" that non-governmental organizations experience in SPLM territory.

"That's crazy," says the state department official, of the appeal to investors. The most attractive oil deposits are all in contested territory, he says.

And the contest, which has cost at least 300,000 lives, seems likely to continue in the immediate future. Although the fall of the Ethiopian government has deprived the SPLM of a valuable base for operations and lines of resupply, Garang claims that the change has had no military impact, since the rebels already control most of the south's territory. However, the government remains firmly ensconced in the major garrison towns of the area.

Kenya is the most logical supply channel currently available to the SPLM, although Garang insists that it would be impossible to bring anything but humanitarian aid through that "open society." Garang also categorically denies persistent reports that Israel is providing military aid to the SPLM.

While there has been speculation that the U.S. has quietly supported the SPLM, the state department denies backing either side. John Garang refuses to divulge details about his discussions with Assistant Secretary of State for Africa Herman Cohen, except to say that it concerned relief for the south and Cohen's ideas for pursuing a peaceful settlement of the conflict.

The RCC is in an equally tight squeeze. Its support of Iraq during the Gulf crisis alienated the Gulf states -- which cut off shipments of free and cheap oil -- as well as angered Egypt and western governments. Already exasperated by the junta's refusal to admit that Sudan faced a famine of epic proportions and by its human rights abuses, the U.S. and Britain withdrew most of their embassy personnel shortly before beginning the war against Iraq in January.

U.S. personnel returned in April, but the Bush administration suspended Sudan's trading privileges under the Generalized System of Preferences. Since then the administration has focused on the delivery of famine relief -- which is of little direct benefit to the government whose economic problems have become catastrophic. Demonstrators underlined the crisis by taking to the streets in May, when the government attempted a quick-fix currency exchange.

Libya has helped with oil shipments and is trying to repair Khartoum's rift with Egypt. The Libyan government has also signed a political unity agreement with Sudan. But the state department official dismisses the pact as rhetoric, arguing that even Libyan leader Muammar Qaddafi, whose foreign policy has consistently called for Arab integration, is not terribly interested in the deteriorating, seemingly hopeless nation that Sudan has become.


LOAD-DATE: July 12, 1991


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1991 AllAfrica, Inc.


74 of 211 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July 15, 1991


TOGO SEEKS NEW FUTURE


LENGTH: 1049 words


 

Lome -- A quarter century of dictatorship in Togo is coming to a methodical end, after months of strikes and demonstrations that forced the government of President Gnassingbe Eyadema to agree to democratic reforms.

In a process that parallels the march towards political pluralism in more than a dozen African countries during recent months, representatives of political parties and civic and professional organizations are meeting in Lome, the Togolese capital, to choose a transitional government. Topping the agenda for the nearly 900 delegates to the national conference is the selection of a prime minister and the adoption of a multi-party constitution and a timetable for free elections.

Opening the conference on July 8, Eyadema said Togo is entering "a new era" that will usher in fundamental change. "We must prepare ourselves to manage this democratic opening with wisdom, tolerance, and especially calm and peace," he said. 

Last week's rousing opening session, where the singing of Togo's national anthem seemed to shake the conference hall, was a victory for the sustained campaign of defiance that had brought normal life in Lome and several other cities to a standstill and left several dozen people dead in clashes with security forces.

Conference proceedings are being broadcast nationally on radio and television -- an opposition demand that the government eventually accepted.

As the meeting got underway, deep divisions quickly surfaced with delegates debating organizational details and accreditation. On Wednesday, proceedings were temporarily suspended after one opposition figure, Andoch Bonin, a former Eyadema aide recently returned from exile, was detained by troops. He was released two hours later following a protest march on the conference center.

The Togolese military, which has been allocated 16 seats at the conference but has not sent any representatives, is reacting warily to the wave of change. Late last month, soldiers staged a one-day protest which included occupation of the national radio stations to underline grievances over pay. And there are signs that lower-ranking troops are more sympathetic to the opposition than senior officers, who enjoy Eyadema's patronage.

Although the president agreed to the conference in principle more than a month ago, the meeting was postponed several times when disagreements arose between government and opposition negotiators. Most serious was Eyadema's initial insistence that national conference decisions be advisory rather than binding and that he stay on as president. After a renewed series of street protests, Eyadema agreed to a compromise that will allow him to serve out his term in office during the transition period but will vest executive power in the hands of the new prime minister.

Another important concession won by the opposition was the democratic election of conference participants from around the country. "We really insisted that the government's idea of appointing the delegates was not acceptable," said Messan Gnininvi, head of the coalition of political parties which worked out logistics for the meeting with the government.

Eyadema has ruled since a 1967 coup that was his second intervention in the affairs of state. In 1964 as an army sergeant, he staged post-independent Africa's first military takeover, in which then-President Sylvanus Olympio was killed -- reportedly by Eyadema himself. The coup leaders handed over the government to opposition leader Nicolas Grunitzky, who served until Eyadema seized control four years later.

Some opposition figures are not reconciled to the agreement that Eyadema could stay on as president. "This government has no legitimacy," said Gilchrist Olympio, son of the slain president who returned to Togo last week after 25 years in exile.

However, Gnininvi says the opposition's acceptance of Eyadema's continuation in office was a necessary compromise. "It was not easy to get him to agree to the conference and we had to offer something to convince him to cooperate," Gnininvi says.

Most Togolese do want Eyadema to resign now, says Nicholas M. Lawson, a newspaper publisher who is spokesman for the opposition coalition. "It is difficult for us to defend the compromise we made, but it is the responsible thing to do," he says. "We have to start learning that in a democracy when you don't like a president you don't just oust him by demonstrations or coups d'etat, you wait for elections."

But the mood in Lome, the seaside capital, is not one of waiting. Dusty during dry spells, Lome's dirt streets have become clogged with mud in the heavy downpours of this rainy season. As residents wade through the often ankle-deep water in downtown thoroughfares, they complain that Eyadema has stolen what wealth the country has produced during his rule. "After 25 years of a government that has done nothing for the people, the situation is catastrophic," says Josepha Afa Pocanam-Dosseh, a national conference delegate and secretary-general of the Togolese Women's Association for Democracy and Development.

The group, only three months old, is one of four organizations formed after women political activists were told that only formal organizations could participate in planning the national conference. "Women were excluded from the preparations," Pocanam-Dosseh says. "If we hadn't created these associations, women wouldn't be represented at all." The Women's Association's chief goal is a reformed educational system, including free and compulsory primary schools. "A generation of our children has been sacrificed," says Poconam-Dosseh. But she is optimistic about the future. "Our true independence begins now," she says. "We will educate our children, our mothers and our sisters and we will make our fathers and our brothers understand that education for everyone is fundamental to democracy."

Attorney Diyanama Ywassa agrees that "profound change" is coming to Togo and she welcomes it. But at the same time, she worries about the high expectations the national conference has generated. "I fear that many people think democracy is a magic word, that with democracy everything is going to change," she says. "The long march to democracy is punctuated with difficulties."


LOAD-DATE: July 12, 1991


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1991 AllAfrica, Inc.


75 of 211 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


JULY 29, 1991


IF YOU CAN'T BEAT THEM


LENGTH: 98 words


The delegation representing the Togolese government last week returned to its seats at the national conference underway in Lome, the capital. On July 16, the government announced its withdrawal after the conference voted to assume executive authority for itself, leaving President Gnassingbe Eyadema only ceremonial duties. The chief government representative, Barry Moussa Barke, minister of mines and planning, said the government's decision to take part in "the fundamental debate on the future of our nation" did not signify acceptance of the conference's claim of sovereignty.

LANGUAGE: English

76 of 211 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


JULY 29, 1991


TOO SOON TO CELEBRATE


LENGTH: 157 words


Liberians marked the 144th anniversary of their nation's independence on July 26 amid new hopes for an end to civil war. But continuing partition of the country meant that there were two separate official ceremonies, one in the capital Monrovia and the other in Gbarnga, headquarters of the National Patriotic Front headed by Charles Taylor. A West African peacekeeping force based in Monrovia maintains a cease-fire, and last month an agreement was reached for the holding of elections under West African supervision.

With the ceasefire holding, many of the nearly one million Liberians forced to flee the country are seeking to return home. The interim government in Monrovia has recently arranged repatriation for over 40,000 refugees from Sierre Leone. Last week, an interim government official, James Holder, visited Cote d'Ivoire -- home to an estimated 320,000 Liberians -- to discuss repatriation with refugees there.


LOAD-DATE: July 26, 1991


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1991 AllAfrica, Inc.


77 of 211 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


JULY 29, 1991


DANCING IN THE STREETS


LENGTH: 243 words


Democracy movements may have sprouted all over the African continent, but few can rival the inventiveness of Madagascar's opposition coalition, Force Vive (Living Force). Last Tuesday, when the government announced a 15-day curfew and state of emergency that banned all meetings and rallies, 300,000 Force Vive supporters gathered in the main square of the capital, Antananarivo, for what they called "an all-night street ball." 

Despite heavy security at government buildings, the opposition was able to install its own leaders in seven government ministries. The shadow ministers were part of a 12-person cabinet named by Force Vive as a transition government, in defiance of President Didier Ratsiraka's refusal to step down or to call a national conference. At least two members of the opposition shadow cabinet were arrested.

The daily public protests, which began on June 10, have been largely peaceful and marked by restraint on both sides. Last week, troops outside the finance ministry stood at attention as opposition leader Jean Rakotoharison arrived at the head of a Force Vive delegation. The Reuter news agency quoted witnesses saying that when Rakotoharison, a popular retired general, ordered armored vehicles guarding the ministry to withdraw, they obeyed.

But there were also violent clashes last week that raised fears of more trouble ahead for the Indian Ocean island, unless the president agrees to opposition demands.


LOAD-DATE: July 26, 1991


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1991 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


JULY 29, 1991


EXPERIENCE COUNTS


LENGTH: 107 words


As Angola shifts from a war footing to peace, President Jose Eduardo dos Santos has named a seasoned administrator to head the government during the lead-up to national elections. The new prime minister, Fernando Franca Van-Dunem, a former justice minister and deputy foreign minister, has been given responsibility for directing the country's war recovery effort and the preparations for elections. A peace accord sign in May by the government and the opposition movement Unita, which brought 15 years of civil war to an end, calls for the country's first multiparty elections to be held between September and November of next year.


LOAD-DATE: July 26, 1991


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1991 AllAfrica, Inc.


79 of 211 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


JULY 29, 1991


WHO'S AT BAT?


LENGTH: 231 words


During his 26 years in power, President Mobutu Sese Seko of Zaire has often outflanked his opponents by appointing his harshest critics to high government positions. Last week he tried to do it again. But his naming of a leading opposition figure as prime minister seems to have backfired.

The announcement of the appointment of Etienne Tshisekedi wa Mulumba, leader of the Union for Democracy and Social Progress (UDPS), brought thousands of protestors to the streets in front of Tshisekedi's house shouting, "We refuse, we refuse!" After meeting with the opposition coalition, the UDPS chief said he was turning down the prime ministership. "We will not be lured by the charm of power," he said. Justine Kasavubu, spokesperson for the UDPS in Brussels, told the BBC that the appointment had been "a maneuver by Mobutu to split the opposition." And in the face of obvious public anger at the announcement of his appointment, Tshisekedi was careful to distance himself from the president's decision. "I was surprised," he told 2,000 people who gathered outside his party headquarters. "I never listen to Mobutu's radio or watch his television."

Mobutu has been under increasing pressure from a pro-democracy movement, and on July 19 he agreed to give limited powers to a national conference on Zaire's political future, scheduled to convene at the end of the month.

LANGUAGE: English

JULY 29, 1991


OUT TO AFRICA?


SECTION: BITS AND PIECES


LENGTH: 66 words


Planning is once again underway for a visit to Africa by Vice President Dan Quayle. Administration officials have slated the trip for late October but have not developed a firm itinerary. The vice president had been scheduled to represent the United States at Namibia's independence celebrations 16 months ago. But he was replaced at the last minute by Secretary of State James Baker.

Africa News


JULY 29, 1991


NIGER: NATIONAL MEETING SET AGAIN


LENGTH: 695 words


West Africa's largest nation, Niger, is scheduled to begin its national conference this week after months of wrangling between government and opposition forces over the shape of the meeting.

While Niger has not experienced the violent upheaval that has occurred in Togo, Cameroon, and next-door-neighbor Mali, the process of change has been no less dramatic. The government has faced steadily mounting pressure to democratize, including several major marches by women, a rarity in the Moslem world. Chris McCarus reports on the mood in the Niger capital during the period leading up to the conference. 

Niamey -- When President Ali Saibou announced last November that a national conference would take place in May, prospects seemed good for a smooth transition to multiparty democracy after 17 years of military-led rule. But progress towards a workable design has proved difficult.

In the weeks that followed, opposition parties sprouted, unions flexed their muscles, and women took to the street demanding a greater role in the planning process and equitable representation at the meeting. The starting date was repeatedly postponed while a 75-member preparatory committee struggled to reach agreement on arrangements.

For the heavily-Muslim country, the public appearance of women in large numbers was particularly astonishing. The first women's march, several thousand-strong, took place on May 13 -- two weeks before the then-scheduled opening of the conference. Carrying banners reading "Stop Injustice" and "Equal Rights," the protesters paraded from the national assembly to the prime minister's office in the center of the capital. Early this month, women marched again, after the conference starting date was postponed once more.

Until the rains arrived a few weeks ago, Niamey was hot and dusty. The Niger River flowing through the capital provides humidity, even in the dry season, and offers a hospitable home for mosquitoes and flies. Amid the brown that dominates the landscape, signs of modernity are sprinkled -- hotels, bank buildings, and the large Kennedy Bridge -- financed by revenues from the country's leading export earner, uranium.

But uranium has been unable to lift Niger from the ranks of the poorest nations on earth. With a population of seven million and an average income of only $ 290 a year, the country's economy has stagnated. Recurring drought and a decade of depressed uranium prices have caused a net decline in living standards in the past 25 years.

The promise of democracy has raised hopes for better things to come. But the work of the conference preparatory committee has been hampered by distrust between the government officials on one side and the representatives of labor unions, student associations and 18 political parties on the other. As the negotiations dragged on and the conference opening was postponed again and again, suspicions deepened that Saibou was maneuvering to retain power.

Chiek Diop, publisher of Haske, Niger's only independent newspaper, said he feared that the delays and the contention could provide an excuse for the army to intervene "and thus scrap the whole conference on grounds of national security."

The conference agenda also remains a delicate issue. Opposition representatives have made clear their intention to raise questions that could embarrass Ali Saibou, an army chief who became head of state in 1987, after the death of Niger's former ruler, Major-General Seyni Kountche.

One preparatory committee document refers to "the political, social, economic and cultural crimes" that will be discussed at the conference. Professor Ali Salifou, a member of one opposition group, said he expects conference delegates to remove all but ceremonial authority from the head of state. "We are going to attend a national conference that is nothing less than a civilian coup d'etat," he said.

That may be just what the government is trying to avoid with its many procedural objections to conference plans. "What right does this preparatory committee have," asked Communications Minister Khamed Abdoullayehave, "to remove the president from power?"


LOAD-DATE: July 26, 1991


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1991 AllAfrica, Inc.


82 of 211 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


JULY 29, 1991


NIGERIA: PINNING ECONOMIC HOPES TO NEW DEMOCRACY


LENGTH: 1059 words


Abuja, Nigeria -- Sam Bede knew what he wanted when he made the 400-mile journey early this year north from Owerri, capital of Imo state in southern Nigeria. Having heard from his older sister that there were job opportunities in this newly built federal capital, the 22-year-old high school graduate came searching for work to enable him to pursue his ambition of an accountant's degree.

Bede says the collapse of a once-thriving oil economy has dealt a "big blow" to Nigerians. "It is very difficult to afford schooling," he says, "unless you are quite wealthy." 

His father, a farmer, has no money for his children's higher education. Although from an oil producing area, Bede believes Nigeria's leaders have pursued unsound development policies. "Agriculture, our major product, has been forgotten, and that has led to our economic downfall," he says.

Food costs have skyrocketed, as have most other prices, following a ten-fold devaluation of the Nigerian currency, the naira. Housing is expensive and in short supply in most areas, including Abuja. "We have money in this country, but it is in a few people's hands," Bede says.

Average income in Nigeria plummeted in the past decade, along with the price of oil. From a peak in 1980, oil revenue fell from $ 25 billion to $6.6 billion in just six years. Last year saw the first increase, as a result of the petroleum price rises sparked by the Gulf war. But income levels remain 30% lower than they were 10 years ago.

At the beginning of this year, President Ibrahim Babangida warned Nigerians against believing that a "windfall" from oil price hikes would stimulate "a second generation oil boom." Much of the extra income from rising prices has been gobbled up to service the country's foreign debt, which now totals about $ 35 billion.

Nevertheless, government officials say they are optimistic that the nose-dive of the past decade has been reversed. A debt-rescheduling agreement with creditors has been worked out, and the International Monetary Fund has agreed to a $ 620 million loan. "There is now widespread confidence in our economy and in the process of political stabilization and democratization that is underway," says Dr. Tunji Olagunju, minister of state for special duties and a Babangida confidant. "We expect to experience an economic boom in the early 1990s," he says.

Already, Sam Bede's prospects have improved. Although unemployment among young job-seekers is said to be running at 60%, Bede now has a steady job at the Sheraton Hotel in Abuja, earning the minimum wage of about $ 25 a month. By living with his sister's family, he thinks he can save enough money to enter university next year.

Unless there are major meetings in Abuja like the recent summits of the Organization of African Unity and the Economic Community of West Africa States (Ecowas), the Sheraton and the two other major hotels are rarely filled. Still, Bede believes his job is secure. He hopes to get a spot on the night shift, so he can work and go to school at the same time when classes begin this fall at the new university here.

Abuja is still a capital-in-the-making -- a project Babangida has committed himself to completing, along with the transition to civilian rule and the economic recovery program, during what he has called "the twilight" of his tenure. A large mosque nearing completion in the center of town dominates the landscape. Four-lane highways connect the large hotels to a huge conference center complex, while shops are spread among several housing areas.

Although some government ministries have moved their operations from Lagos, many buildings remain unfinished, and few embassies have even started construction. Local officials say the pace will quicken later this year, if Babangida transfers the presidency to Abuja, as he has pledged to do.

"We weren't sure the president would ever really move here," says Theophilus Okodo, an odd-jobs man who was attracted to the city two years ago by the prospect of work. "But now it seems he is coming."

The 49-year-old president, who came to power in 1985, also has surprised skeptics with his intention to keep to a timetable for handing over power. After banning all the old political parties and establishing two new ones -- the National Republicans and the Social Democrats -- the government conducted local elections last December which generally won high marks for fairness, though turnout was light.

"We have succeeded in creating national political parties for the first time," says Dr. Jerry Gana, chairman of the directorate for social mobilization, an agency set up by the government to coordinate the transition and educate the public about the process. "They are not ethnic, they are not religiously based, they are not regionally based," he says.

In an effort to avoid the failures of past civilian governments, which became notorious for their extreme corruption and levels of incompetence, the government has banned all former politicians from standing for office in the round of voting that includes state elections later this year and a presidential poll in 1992.

Ray Ekpu, editor of Newswatch, the country's largest-circulation news weekly, says the success to date of the electoral scheme has proved skeptics wrong. But he is concerned about the government's "excessive intervention" in the process. "I think the politicians should be given more leeway," he says.

Gana argues that the effort to break with the past is proving successful. "In every rural area, people now know what is happening, they know the power relations in their community, they know the power of their vote," he says. "We've never had that before in Nigeria."

But the real yardstick by which the military government is likely to be measured is economic. Spiraling population growth, high inflation, and the persistence of rampant corruption threaten to tarnish whatever stability is gained from an orderly election process. "Democracy is very expensive, so we need a solid and growing economy if democracy is to be sustained," Gana concedes.

Still, like many Nigerians, Sam Bede maintains a firm faith that political change will affect his own and the nation's pocketbook. "If we have a democratic system of government it will improve our economic standard," he says.


LOAD-DATE: July 26, 1991


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1991 AllAfrica, Inc.


83 of 211 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


JULY 29, 1991


SACKO: STEPPING INTO THE BREACH


LENGTH: 400 words


Soumana Sacko said he was "surprised" when he got a call late last March from Mali's new ruling military and civilian council asking him to head a transitional government during the changeover to elected rule.

"We have plenty of very able men and women who could have done this job," the 40-year-old prime minister said in an interview with Africa News. The summons reached him in Bangui, Central African Republic, where Sacko was principal economist in the regional office of the United Nations Development Program (UNDP). He thinks he was chosen because he was a known entity, both internationally and at home. 

A former journalist who received a masters degree in public management and a Ph.D in economics from the University of Pittsburgh, Sacko has spent most of his career in government service. He made a name for himself in 1987, during a brief tenure as Mali's finance minister. After only six months in office, he was forced to resign when his anti-corruption campaign veered too close to dealings by President Moussa Traore and his wife Mariam.

Sacko said he enjoys good relations with head-of-state Amadou Toiumani Toure, the army lieutenant colonel who staged the March 26 coup that ousted Traore from office. The prime minister works closely with the 10 soldiers as well as the 15 civilians on the transitional committee that governs the country.

Sacko said his preoccupation is the economy. He defends the austerity measures his government has adopted as essential to "correct past mistakes" and reverse the country's decline. "These are not imposed from outside," he insisted, but are homemade prescriptions for a country on the economic brink.

Sacko sees economic integration in Africa -- and the plans recently endorsed by the Organization of African Unity for an African common market -- as an important step towards growth and development, although he thinks "more backward" countries like Mali stand to gain less at the outset than their wealthier neighbors. "We have to move beyond micro-states which have small markets where production cannot be economic," he said.

The prime minister is enthusiastic about the political dialogue that followed the Traore ouster and culminates this week in the national conference. "We have the whole spectrum of political ideas represented," he said. "So much the better for democracy, so much the better for Mali."


LOAD-DATE: July 26, 1991


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1991 AllAfrica, Inc.


84 of 211 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


JULY 29, 1991


PLANNING THE FIRST FREE VOTE


SECTION: DEMOCRACY: MALI


LENGTH: 1322 words


Four months after a coup that ended 22 years of military dictatorship, Mali is holding a national conference to hammer out a program for a democratic future.

As in more than a dozen African countries experiencing dramatic political changes, accountable government has become the slogan for the landlocked nation that is nearly twice the size of Texas. But events in Mali took a different turn from those in the other countries where national conferences have become the mechanism for a transfer from totalitarianism to multiparty rule.

In most cases, the calls for national conferences have been voiced by government opponents, buttressed by street demonstrations and strikes, and opposed -- often violently -- by troops and security forces.

Mali decisively broke that pattern on March 26, when soldiers ordered to crush the protests turned their guns on the man who gave the orders. A group of army officers -- who said they had sickened of the attacks on demonstrators that had killed more than 200 people -- led the ouster of long-serving dictator Moussa Traore and replaced him with a transitional administration of military men and respected civilian leaders. 

Soumana Sacko, a University of Pittsburgh-trained economist, was appointed interim prime minister, and coup leader Lt.-Col. Amadou Toiumani Toure promised national elections by January. Unlike the regimes that have opposed or stalled national conferences until forced to yield by widespread protests, the Sacko administration has fully supported the preparations for this week's meeting and is expected to establish a precise timetable for municipal, parliamentary and presidential elections. Economic issues will also be discussed, since the country's financial difficulties pose the major hurdle to success for both the current administration and its elected successor.

In an interview, Prime Minister Sacko called the economic legacy of the Traore regime "disastrous." He said university graduates are unable to find work and the government is being forced "to lay off workers in the public enterprises that are running losses."

Last week, Sacko visited Washington and New York, seeking support for his economic reform program from the U.S. government, the United Nations, and the World Bank and International Monetary Fund.

With a per capita income of about $ 270 per year, Mali has long been among the world's poorest nations. Nearly all of the country's eight million people are peasant farmers or cattle herders. Over 80% are illiterate.

Two weeks ago, the new government survived a potential fiasco when an alleged coup attempt was thwarted and the accused leaders arrested. In a radio broadcast, Lt.-Col. Toure said the overthrow effort had been led by Major Lamine Diabira, a senior military officer and minister in the transitional government, who was arrested along with eight other officers.

As news of the attempted takeover was announced on July 15, thousands of people flooded the streets of Bamako, the capital, to show support for the transitional administration, according to reports by Reuters and Agence France Press.

Denying rumors that deposed-president Traore had fled the country, Toure announced that the former leader, his wife and key functionaries of the old regime are still being held in detention. The government has launched an investigation into their handling of the economy, their private finances and their responsibility for the killings that took place during the street demonstrations in January and March. The interim leaders have promised a fair trial for anyone indicted for the alleged offenses, as well as release for those not charged.

As democracy fervor has gripped Africa, there has been some worry among international and financial circles that new governments will abandon unpopular austerity programs. During his visit to Washington last week, Sacko buttressed his appeal for new assistance by repeating assurances that Mali is committed to the painful economic reforms.

Launched in 1985, the Mali reform program was designed to dismantle the highly centralized economic structure the country has had since independence in 1960 and to improve the climate for private sector investment. Regulatory requirements have been eased, price controls removed, and taxes and duties reduced.

"The reforms have produced modest, but not inconsequential benefits," says an evaluation report by the U.S. Agency for International Development (AID), which provided $ 18 million in aid to get the effort underway while negotiations with the World Bank and IMF were stalled.

American assistance helped make "the bitter pill sweeter," says the report, which was written before the recent political changes. Mali's "real challenge," the report says, is to evaluate realistically the resources available -- both domestically and from donors -- and to "allocate them in a way that will best improve the well-being of the people of Mali."

During the strikes and protests early this year, across-the-board pay hikes of 50% were demanded by the National Union of Malian Workers, the country's large central labor group, which played a key role in the opposition movement. The transitional government postponed action on that demand until this month. But hours after the July 15 coup attempt was foiled, Sacko announced a pay hike for members of the armed forces and security services and for civil servants. The government said the increase would boost earnings more than 50% for lower-paid ranks, without overspending the current budget's allotment for public sector salaries through 1991.

Nevertheless, Sacko said in the interview, all segments of Malian society accept that financial sacrifices are "just a necessity of life," and that the economic crisis demands belt-tightening. He said the entire transitional leadership, including trade union officials, reiterated their support for the reform program to World Bank and IMF delegations who visited Mali soon after the government changed hands.

The interim government's economic program aims to "concentrate scarce public resources on the social sector," Sacko said. "The country must 'rely heavily' on the private sector -- local and foreign -- to manage productive areas of the economy and to fuel growth," the prime minister said. "We have good potential for both mining and agriculture, and we hope private investors will be interested in playing a big role."

With outside help, Mali is also trying to resolve another troubling problem -- the continuing conflict between security forces and the nomadic Touareg people in the north of the country. Earlier this month, Lt. Col. Toure broadcast an appeal to "brother nomads" for a cessation of attacks against inhabited encampments, development projects, and transportation links.

The conflict is rooted in a long-simmering animosity between Mali's government and the nomads, who complained that they had been excluded from economic benefits enjoyed by other groups in society, while being subjected to government regulations that threatened their traditional way of life as well as their ability to roam across national frontiers. They accused the Traore regime of widespread violence and discrimination against nomadic peoples.

The new government has endorsed a cease-fire accord, brokered by Algeria, that was signed by the Traore regime and Touareg leaders last January. But one group of nomads has continued fighting.

Sacko's administration is exploring a regional solution to the hostilities. "The same Touareg are launching armed attacks against Niger, Algeria and Mauritania," the prime minister said. "We want to put into place some development activities along our common borders." Sacko said a peace plan that is essentially economic could appeal to people "who may feel that they have been forgotten and left out of the development process."


LOAD-DATE: July 26, 1991


LANGUAGE: English

JULY 29, 1991


NEW ANC LEADERSHIP


LENGTH: 221 words


African National Congress members had their first opportunity this month to elect new leaders since the organization was unbanned by South Africa President F.W. de Klerk early last year.

Here is a complete list of the new officers and members of the group's national executive committee. 

Nelson Mandela (president), Walter Sisulu (deputy president), Oliver Tambo (chairman, a newly created position), Cyril Ramaphosa (secretary-general), Jacob Zuma (deputy secretary-general) and Thomas Nkobi (treasurer-general).

Chris Hani, Thabo Mbeki, Joe Slovo, Patrick "Terror" Lekota, Pallo Jordan, Ahmed Kathrada, Ronnie Kasrila, Harry Gwala, Steve Tanweta, Arnold Stofile, Popo Molefe, Joe Modise, Raymond Mhlaba, Mac Maharaj, Alfred Nzo, Ruth Mompati, Albertina Sisulu, Raymond Suttner, Trevor Manuel, Ebrahim Ismail Ebrahim, Agiz Pahad, Cheryl Carolus, Albie Sachs, Joel Netshitendze, Wilton Mkwayi, Winnie Mandela, Joe Nhlanhia, John Nkadimeng, Dullah Omar, Mohammed Valli Moosa, Gertrude Shope, Andrew Miangeni, Siphiwe Nkanda, Sidney Mafurnadi, Elias Motsoaledi, Mendi Msimang, Reginald September, Barbara Masekele, Billy Nair, Mewayizani Zulu, Sister Bernard Ncube, Gill Marcus, Jeremy Cronin, Rocky Malebare-Metsing, Kadar Asmal, Saki Macozoma, Peter Mokaba, Zola Skweyiya, Thozamile Botha, Marion Sparg.


LOAD-DATE: July 26, 1991


LANGUAGE: English
