86 of 211 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


JULY 29, 1991


POLICE PAID INKATHA TO BLOCK ANC


SECTION: NEGOTIATIONS: SOUTH AFRICA


LENGTH: 1532 words


Johannesburg's feisty independent newspaper, the Weekly Mail, was the journal that dropped a bombshell on the South Africa government when it revealed the results of an investigation into secret government support for the Inkatha Freedom Party -- a party rival of Nelson Mandela's African National Congress (ANC). Clashes between supporters of the groups have killed thousands of people, and the ANC has long charged government complicity in the violence. Here we reprint the story by Eddie Koch and Weekly Mail co-editor Anton Harber that ignited the furor.

The South African Police have paid large amounts of money to help Inkatha oppose the African National Congress.

The Weekly Mail has also obtained copies of internal security police documents showing extensive discussions between Inkatha president Chief Mangosuthu Buthelezi and a senior Durban security policeman about ways of preventing the ANC from eroding Inkatha's support in Natal. 

At least R250,000 ($ 87,000) was paid into an Inkatha bank account by the security police for the purpose of organizing rallies and other anti-ANC activities shortly after the release from prison of ANC president Nelson Mandela. One rally paid for by the SAP, at King's Park, Durban on March 25, 1990, was the spark for an upsurge in civic violence that has been known as the Maritzburg War.

According to a top-secret security police memorandum, Buthelezi was very emotional and expressed extreme gratitude for the financial assistance provided.

The documents reveal that Buthelezi was concerned about declining membership figures in Natal at the time of Mandela's release from prison and had serious misgivings about the support of some of Inkatha's key leaders, including Inkatha chairman Frank Mdlalose and former secretary general Oscar Dhlomo.

The Weekly Mail has receipts, First National Bank deposit slips, and internal security police memoranda marked "Top Secret/Uiters Geheim", which confirm the police payments to Inkatha as well as face-to face meetings between Buthelezi, some of his cabinet ministers, and Major Louis Botha, senior officer in the Durban regional security police, to discuss how to deal with the ANC.

In a 10-page memorandum to the chief of security police in Pretoria, dated February 13, 1990 (number S7/28/3/8/4n), Botha asks for R120,000 ($ 42,000) because it was of "cardinal importance" that arrangements were made for a massive turnout at an Inkatha rally "to show everyone that he (Buthelezi) has a strong base".

"It is recommended that a clandestine grant of at least R120,000 ($ 42,000) be made available for this purpose," Botha wrote to his superiors. "It should also be accepted that Inkatha does not have the financial means to arrange such a gathering on its own. The consequences of this rally failing will have far-reaching implications for Buthelezi and the RSA."

Further letters and receipts show that this payment was made in hard cash into an account in the name of Inkatha/Kgare (Kgare is the organization's Sotho name) at First National Bank in Durban on March 15, 10 days before the rally. The account number was 221426-8006961533.

The security branch of the police has since been disbanded but it is widely believed that its officers are still deployed for covert political operations.

The Weekly Mail also has confirmation of a payment of R100,000 ($ 35,000) to Inkatha to organize another rally on November 5, 1989. The rally was in fact held on November 19 and was addressed by King Goodwill Zwelithini.

This document, a letter from Brigadier J.A. Steyn, deputy regional chief of the security police in Natal, to the commanding officer of the security police in Pretoria, says that Buthelezi and his justice minister, Jeffrey Mtetwa, asked that their "thanks and great appreciation be passed on to those responsible for passing on the funds."

"Chief Minister Buthelezi was very emotional when a copy of the receipt was given to him. He could not say thank you enough and said that he had not expected it."

The Weekly Mail, working in conjunction with The Guardian of London, has run extensive checks on the documents. It has confirmed the Inkatha bank account numbers, the identities, addresses and telephone numbers of all those named in them, and the details of the Durban rallies.

There is no conclusive evidence that Buthelezi or members of Inkatha knew that the money deposited into their account came directly from the security police.

Botha is well-known in Durban as a security policeman with close links to Inkatha and at the time of the documentation was often seen in Buthelezi's company. In the words of one source, "wherever Buthelezi was, Botha was."

It is believed that he was for some time involved with Buthelezi's personal security.

The question of police support for Inkatha was raised in parliament earlier this year by the Democratic Party's Kobus Jordan. He asked whether any section of the intelligence service or the SAP had given financial or organizational support to groups such as Inkatha.

President F. W. de Klerk and Law and Order Minister Adriaan Vlok refused to answer as this would "defeat the legal protection of security information."

Botha's 10-page memorandum motivating the payment to Inkatha gives a rare insight into how the security police see Inkatha as the only organization capable of countering the influence of the ANC. He refers to discussions with Buthelezi over a two-to-three week period and previous security police reports on "Conflict within Inkatha following peace talks" and "Strategic perspectives: Chief Minister Buthelezi and Inkatha: Implications for current negotiations politics."

Botha argues that the police should support Inkatha because Buthelezi, under pressure from some of his ministers because of falling support, would otherwise be forced to join forces with the ANC.

"During our discussion it became very clear that the actions and political maneuvers of the ANC were a matter of concern to the chief minister, especially if one considers the shrinking Inkatha membership figures," Botha said.

He added that Buthelezi had hoped that he would win support after arranging the return to the country of Pan Africanist Congress veteran Prince Velekhaya Shange (described only as "Prins Shange") and ANC veteran Dr. Wilson Chonco.

"It is also clear that he is very suspicious of overtures from the ANC which according to him would make it easy for the ANC hierarchy to destroy him if he and Inkatha joined the ANC. . .."

"He is also worried about the possible role of his supporters and cabinet members, namely Dr. O. Dlomo (sic), minister of education, Dr. F. Mdlalose, minister of health, Chief Gumede, minister of public works and Minister S. Sithebe, minister of home affairs," Botha said, also referring to another memo on "Internal conflict in Inkatha as a result of peace talks."

Dhlomo, then also Inkatha secretary-general, resigned from the organization and the kwaZulu cabinet two months later.

Botha added: "If he (Buthelezi) seeks reconciliation with the ANC, there is the possibility he will be accepted and then removed from the scene... . If he stands on the political sidelines, then he won't be able to take part in the game later on, which will also lead to political humiliation."

"It is the fear of this division (of the police) that, bearing the above in mind, the minister (Buthelezi) will seriously consider throwing in his lot with the ANC with far-reaching implications for Natal and the ANC. With the release of Nelson Mandela, this becomes a serious possibility," Botha reported.

Botha went on to say that Buthelezi was worried that, with the release of Mandela, the ANC would be seen as commanding the support of most blacks, and many whites, Indians and coloureds, and that this would be used overseas to put pressure on Pretoria during the negotiation period.

As a counter, he says, Buthelezi planned a mass rally at King's Park on March 25, 1990 where he would speak against armed struggle and sanctions. Botha recommended that police help pay for the rally.

The rally was a failure. It poured with rain on the day and only about 10,000 people attended, though Inkatha contested these figures. Clashes between busloads of Inkatha supporters and residents of Pietermaritzburg townships broke out before and after the rally.

The next few days saw some of the bloodiest conflicts in the area, including a planned invasion of Edendale by Inkatha-supporting "impis" (military regiments).

These revelations are supported by recent disclosures that there is a sophisticated plan by the government to use Inkatha as a conservative counterweight to the ANC during negotiations.

Earlier this year Sipho Madlala, a self-confessed security police agent, told reporters in Natal that he had been recruited by officers in the security police and military intelligence to assassinate pro-ANC Zulu chief Mhlabunzima Maphumulo.

Other evidence is now emerging about clandestine support from military intelligence and the police for Inkatha so that the Zulu movement can be used to undermine the ANC.


LOAD-DATE: July 26, 1991


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1991 AllAfrica, Inc.


87 of 211 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


JULY 29, 1991


WEANING ITSELF FROM COCOA


SECTION: ECONOMY: GHANA


LENGTH: 1533 words


Accra -- Since the colonial era, most African countries have been dependent on a limited number of agricultural or mineral exports. During the last decade, plummeting prices for those commodities, coupled with rising debt burdens, have sent the continent's economies into tailspins. Ghana, where cocoa has traditionally accounted for over half of all exports, was one of the hardest hit.

Although talk of economic diversification has become increasingly prevalent in discussions about Africa's prospects, most of the action so far has been confined to conference tables and seminars.

Now, after two decades of unsuccessful attempts to expand the export base, Ghana is seeing non-traditional products gaining ground as a source of foreign exchange. 

According to estimates by the Ghana Export Promotion Council (GEPC), non-traditional exports will have grown from five percent of total exports three years ago to 15% of the total by the end of this year. Figures from the first three quarters of 1990 showed that the value of non-traditional exports had already surpassed -- by 11% -- the value for all of 1989. In addition, processed and semi-processed products are accounting for an increased share of the sector, lessening the dependency on primary commodities.

The upturn began in 1987, when the GEPC launched a phased program to promote selected products in agriculture, handicrafts and manufacturing. Using a variety of mechanisms, including flexible exchange rates, trade exhibitions and seminars for potential exporters, the GEPC tries to stimulate interest in the export trade. Ghana's government is offering packages of incentives for more efficient production, as well as establishing marketing infrastructures and working to insure that credit requirements of producers and exporters are adequate.

Within each of the three sectors targeted for growth, certain products get special attention. The primary agricultural items are pineapples, palm oil, yams, fish and other marine products. Dominating the handicrafts are handwoven kente cloth -- perhaps Ghana's most-recognized product, plus artisan works of batik and straw. In manufacturing, the primary areas marked for growth include wood products, aluminum sheets and processed rubber.

Selection of the items was based on the fact that the chosen products already contributed some 70-80% of export earnings in the non-traditional sector. The goal now is to boost the proportion of non-traditional products to overall exports. The campaign to revamp the non-traditional sector has given a substantial boost to both earnings and productivity. The GEPC reports that revenues from non-traditional exports nearly doubled in the first two years of the project, from $ 23.7 million in 1986 to $42.89 million in 1988.

GEPC figures also indicate "significant increases in the number of people engaged in non-traditional exports and products exported." In the first quarter of 1990, the number of exporters rose to 473, up from 458 in the same period the previous year. Earnings for the period rose 38.2%, to $ 10.20 millionfor first quarter 1990.

Although handicrafts have registered the highest growth rate -- doubling earnings in one year -- agriculture has continued to dominate the export field, contributing about 65% of non-traditional product earnings over the last three years. But Ghana's agriculture has been plagued by fluctuating output caused by the vagaries of weather. After a season of severe drought, non-traditional agricultural earnings declined 45% in the first quarter of 1990 over the same period a year earlier. Nevertheless, earnings from pineapples grew 55% during the period, accounting for 86% of the sector.

Manufacturing appears to be overtaking the other two non-traditional export sectors. Last year, for the first time, exports of processed and semi-processed goods exceeded those of non-traditional agricultural exports, increasing by more than 91% over 1989 levels. For the period January through September of 1990, 65.7% of non-traditional exports were goods that had been processed. In addition to aluminum sheets and coils, they included rubber, metal scrap, matches and agricultural processing machinery.

Ghanaian economists say the trend towards greater processing of exports is important, because Ghana retains the value added by processing, rather than losing it to the countries that purchase its raw materials.

One of the goals of the GEPC program is to expand existing markets and to develop new ones. In the past, European Community members have been the largest customers for non-traditional Ghanaian exports, accounting for 36.4% of total value in first three quarters of 1990.

In what may be one of the most significant developments for the future, exports to other countries within West Africa are providing a gradually increasing percentage of the total. Sales to the Economic Community of West African States (Ecowas) grew by an official six percent in the first quarter of last year. Niger, Cote d'Ivoire and Togo were the leading purchasers, with salt being the major product. But West African economists believe the actual amount of inter-regional trade is much higher because official statistics are compromised by malpractices such as smuggling. A major challenge for the future, they say, is to devise multi-national policies that deal effectively with the factors that encourage illegal activities, such as prohibitive tariffs among trading partners in the region.

Experts in the non-traditional area say that despite the sector's growth, its potential as a revenue earner has only begun to be tapped. But to become an important factor in Ghana's economic development, non-traditional producers and exporters will have to overcome numerous problems.

Chief among them, according to GEPC analysts, are financial constraints. Entrants into the export business seldom have adequate funds of their own, and their access to credit is limited. Banks have been particularly reluctant to make loans for agricultural ventures, both because of the lengthy gestation of most projects and the attendant risks. One recent GEPC report says that "delays in processing loan applications in the traditional banking operation" is another major difficulty for producers and exporters.

Economists at GEPC are working to identify the ways that capital shortages hamper export growth. With support from donors, including the United Nations Development Program and the Norwegian and Swedish governments, the council has developed a multifaceted program to address the capital problem, as well as to cut through other bureaucratic and policy constraints to export growth.

* An educational campaign, aimed both at producers and at government entities, is employing advertisements, special publications and training sessions. The campaign is designed to increase awareness about the quality, consistency and packaging needed to make Ghana's products more competitive in a sophisticated international marketplace. GEPC stresses the importance of monitoring consumer tastes and preferences, and it conducts or supports research to determine which potential export products show the most promise.

* In 1988, GEPC established an Export School "to raise the overall standard of performance of export-oriented companies in the non-traditional sector."

* Also in 1988, the council introduced what it called the Export Production Village concept. Although the program is still in its infancy, it aims to develop support facilities for rural areas and to encourage coordination of village-based production and marketing.

* The Bank of Ghana has supported the establishment of an Export Finance Company (EFC) to streamline the flow of funds to the non-traditional export sector. The company, which began operations last August, is a private, non-bank financial institution. By the end of the year it had financed 161 operators in 220 transactions, using its own resources as well as borrowing from the financial markets. Among the EFC's services are a refinancing scheme for banks that lend to exporters of non-traditional products and credit guarantees and insurance for export financing.

Approximately 60% of the credit the company made available went to rural producers. According to a World Bank report, the access to EFC credit stimulated activities in packing and packaging materials, inland production, transportation, insurance and cargo handling. In the hope of providing more services to more exporters, the company is seeking to expand its capital base by increased shareholder commitments and government seed money and is exploring the possibility of help from foreign institutions.

GEPC administrators believe that public participation and support is crucial if non-traditional exports are to approach their earning potential. In an attempt to broaden awareness about the export field and the role it is expected to play in economic recovery, GEPC has established two awards -- the National Award for Export Achievement and the Best National Farmer's Award. Both are widely publicized and offer attractive prizes to the winners.


LOAD-DATE: July 26, 1991


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1991 AllAfrica, Inc.


88 of 211 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


JULY 29, 1991


GHANA ECONOMY GAINS GROUND


LENGTH: 1597 words


 

ACCRA -- After seven years of economic reforms, Ghana has laid the foundation for a dramatic acceleration in growth rates, according to government officials in the West African nation.

"We think Ghana is now poised to achieve rates of growth that the people in Korea and Taiwan are familiar with -- double digit growth rates," says deputy finance secretary K.B. Amissah-Arthur. If the effort is successful, Ghana would be the first African country to achieve sustained growth rates of 10 percent or better.

If there is a country in Africa that can do it, Ghana is certainly among them," says Ajay Chhibber, a senior World Bank economist based in Washington, D.C. "We're very optimistic about Ghana."

Since 1983, the World Bank and other international donors have supported a series of policy reforms designed to reverse the downhill slide that had left the country's economy in ruins. In 1980, a visitor to Ghana could find no food or clothes in the shops, no gasoline or spare parts for cars, and few working telephones. Roads connecting several major cities were impassable except with four-wheel-drive vehicles. Restaurants in major hotels served only rice and tea. The decline was a product of government mismanagement, corruption and, more recently, plummeting prices for cocoa, the country's major export. 

Today, a decade after Flight Lieutenant Jerry Rawlings took power from an elected civilian government, stores are full of goods, new hotels have few vacancies, and the streets of the capital are jammed with too many cars. Outside Accra, from one side of the country to the other, roads have been resurfaced, telephone lines are being strung, and markets are full of produce.

The situation looks good on paper as well. Between 1986 and 1990, Ghana's economy grew at an annual rate of nearly five percent, on a continent where rates of more than two percent are above the norm. Government budget deficits have been turned to surpluses. In 1988, Ghana's debt service obligations -- the amount of the country's payments on its foreign debt, including arrears -- consumed nearly 70% of its 1988 earnings. This year, after steady annual declines, the debt service ratio is projected to fall below 30% (see chart), leaving far greater revenues to be invested in economic recovery and growth.

Even inflation, which is subject to variables that are difficult to predict, appears to be under control. After rising last year to 37%, the inflation rate during 1991 has been falling sharply, and is now substantially below the 1989 level. "By the end of the year," says Amissah-Arthur, "the average rate could well be about 10%, which is a rate we have not experienced since 1985."

Both the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund see Ghana as an example of how their policies of structural adjustment and monetary reforms can rescue failing African economies. The key elements of the reforms have been massive currency devaluations, the scrapping of import licensing and price controls, import liberalization, and the removal of government subsidies.

But not all Ghanaians are convinced that the policies are working. "The impressive statististical glitter," says a professor at the University of Ghana, "blurs realities which undermine Ghana's potential as a long-term sustainable model."

More than half the country's local manufacturing capacity remains idle, the professor says, with domestic enterprises "smarting under foreign competition and exchange rate constraints."

Johnny Hansen, a founder of the opposition Movement for Multiparty Democracy (MMD) agrees. "We used to produce textiles and clothes in this country," he says. "Now most of the things we wear are from Asia. And secondhand clothing imports are beating down local seamstresses."

Amissah-Arthur says the finance ministry is aware of the plight of local businesses and is discussing the need for some measure of tariff protection with the World Bank. "A lot of the industrial development in southeast Asia took place with government support," he says. "You can't remove all tariff protection and expect infant industries to compete from day one. We told the World Bank that they need to have an open mind about this."

Organized labor is among the sternest critics of the government. In a letter to head-of-state Rawlings, the Trade Union Council said that the brunt of Ghana's economic difficulties have been borne by working people, whose minimum wages have remained below the 1974 level.

"There are no clear indications," the letter "that these conditions are going to improve within the context of present policies."

The World Bank's Chhibber, who visited Ghana this month, concedes that structurement adjustment has hurt urban workers and civil servants, but counters that there appear to have been "income shifts to rural areas where the bulk of the poverty is." He says the World Bank's now analyzing data from a living standards survey that may document that trend.

The persistence of poverty is the major reason to pursue double digit growth, says Amissah-Arthur. The finance ministry believes that only a rapidly expanding economy can raise Ghanaians' standard of living and provide jobs to reduce unemployment.

Johnny Hansen wonders who would benefit from rapid growth if it is supervised by the Rawlings government, and he questions the management of $ 2.4 billion in foreign grants and loans the country has received in the last three years. "We want to know what has happened to all the capital," he says, "whether it has been justifiably utilized or found its way into some pockets."

Chhibber says his organization is confident that its money has not been misused. "This is not a government that doesn't know where its money is going," he says. Chhibber says that in addition to "a very impressive" government system of fiscal accountability, Ghana has spent World Bank aid money in highly public ways. "Our money is in power," he says. "Our money is in roads, telecommunications, ports. You can look at the education and health programs and the rehabilitation of the gold mining industry -- that's all very visible."

The scope of that spending is visible on Kwamena Ahwoi's office walls. As Secretary for Local Government and Rural Development, Ahwoi is responsible for ensuring that development reaches the grassroots. Tacked to the wall behind his desk are maps of electricity plants, feeder roads and schools. "By the end of next year," he says "each of the 110 district capitals should be connected to the national electricity grid. Every district capital, no matter how small, should be served by at least a second class access road. Every district is to have a minimum of two high schools. By the end of 1995, every district capital must be served by a telecommunications facility."

The ministry of local government is also responsible for assisting the work of the country's 110 district assemblies. Assembly delegates were elected over the past two years in a process that officials say is building a durable democracy from the bottom up. A distinguished committee of experts is meeting down the hall from Ahwoi's office to craft a proposed constitution, and a national consultative assembly is to meet next month to consider the document.

The secretary dismisses charges by the MMD that the Rawlings government can't be trusted to relinquish power. Already, he says, decentralization has given district assemblies substantial authority for planning and budgeting that is limiting central government authority. Ideally, Ahwoi says, all planning should spring from the village level, and future national development plans should be a synthesis of needs expressed by local people.

Amissah-Arthur says that the growing political involvement of ordinary Ghanaians has led to rising expectations for economic progress, and he sees that as a hopeful sign. He says confidence in the economy is a prerequisite for the investments needed to fuel future growth. "Once people's expectations are that the economy is on the upswing, we begin to fulfill that prophecy," he says. "We are seeing investments that just a few years ago would have been unimaginable."

Both government officials and international donors agree that the sluggish pace of privatization needs to be accelerated. "There are many difficulties," says Amissah-Arthur. "We have state organizations and corporations that have not had audited accounts for 10 years." Selling such businesses is a difficult, time-consuming process, he says.

Ajay Chhibber says that while the World Bank would like to see a faster rate of divestiture, it is sympathetic to the problems. The government timetable was "very ambitious to start with," he says. "These things do take time. And the pace has accelerated a lot in recent months."

Nor is Chhibber concerned about last year's drop in the growth rate to 2.7%, a reversal that he calls "a hiccup." A recent World Bank confidential report on Ghana says that the economic problems of 1990 were due primarily to "temporary factors" -- the severe drought that depressed agricultural output and the more than tripling of retail prices for petroleum products prior to the Gulf war.

But both Chhibber and the report say that Ghana should give clearer signals to international businesses that their investment in the country's economy is welcome. Building an industrial base is important, they say, because without it, Ghana's economy will continue to be vulnerable to factors that are largely beyond anyone's control.


LOAD-DATE: July 26, 1991


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1991 AllAfrica, Inc.


89 of 211 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


AUGUST 26, 1991


ALGERIAN DIALOGUE RESUMES


LENGTH: 138 words


There is new talk of national elections in Algeria, following the reopening of talks last week between the government and over 40 opposition groups. The large fundamentalist Islamic Salvation Front is refusing to take part in the sessions, expected to last a month, to protest the arrest of its two tops leaders for instigating violence that left at least 55 dead and more than 300 injured. Prime Minister Sid Ahmed Ghozali presided at the first meeting, broadcast live on national radio and television. The parties are demanding changes in district lines and other regulations they say favor the ruling National Liberation Front, headed by President Chadli Benjedid. The country's first scheduled multiparty elections were postponed in June after the fundamentalists launched an intense anti-government campaign.

LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


AUGUST 26, 1991


NEEDS IN COMMON


LENGTH: 161 words


Ethiopian President Meles Zenawi, who took power after the ouster of former dictator Mengistu Haile Mariam in May, says economic cooperation is essential to both Ethiopia and the breakaway territory of Eritrea. Since Mengistu's departure, Eritrea has been governed by the Eritrean People's Liberation Front, which waged a 30-year campaign for Eritrean independence. Meles, whose Eritrean People's Revolutionary Democratic Front leads the transitional coalition government now administering Ethiopia, called for an end to "attempts to sow discord" to enable the two sides "to forge strong ties." Eritrea's leaders have been criticized for expelling 50,000 former Ethiopian soldiers and their dependents from the territory.

Meles said the agreement between the two governments involving the port of Aseb is "being observed to the letter." Aseb, which is located in Eritrea but is Ethiopia's only major outlet to the sea, is operating as a free port.


LOAD-DATE: August 23, 1991


LANGUAGE: English

91 of 211 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


AUGUST 26, 1991


NEW ABUSE CHARGES


LENGTH: 150 words


The government of Mauritania is facing new accusations of human rights abuses against blacks. Amnesty International last week released a list of 339 political prisoners reported killed in the country's prisons, military barracks or police stations between November 1990 and March 1991. All those on the list are men who are said to have been detained in a round-up late last year, allegedly aimed at coup plotters. "But in reality it appears that they were picked up simply because of their ethnic origin," says Amnesty, which attributes their deaths to torture or ill-treatment. In May, another human rights group, Africa Watch, said over 200 black prisoners had been executed or tortured to death. The government of Col. Maaowia Ould Sid'Ahmed Taya, who is of Moorish descent like most of his government, responded to earlier protests by Mauritanians by releasing about 100 detainees.


LOAD-DATE: August 23, 1991


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1991 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


AUGUST 26, 1991


SANCTIONS ALIVE


LENGTH: 103 words


Although President George Bush lifted most U.S. economic sanctions against South Africa on July 10, anti-apartheid measures adopted by many American states and cities remain in force. Last month, Los Angeles Mayor Thomas Bradley, along with officials from Pasadena and West Hollywood, pledged to retain the restrictions prohibiting dealings with firms investing or conducting business in South Africa. A resolution adopted by the Los Angeles City Council vowed to maintain what it called "one of the toughest prohibitions in the country" until "true justice and equal access to the law exists in South Africa."

Africa News


AUGUST 26, 1991


IVORIAN DOUBTS


SECTION: BITS AND PIECES


LENGTH: 205 words


A two-month strike by university teachers in Cote d'Ivoire ended in mid-August, but uncertainties over the country's political future still linger. Late last month, the country -- long one of the most tranquil and prosperous nations in Africa -- was shaken by reports of an attempted bid for power by a group of disaffected soldiers. Brig. Gen. Robert Guei, the armed forces chief of staff, who announced the plot in an interview with the government-supporting daily, Fraternite Matin, denied that it was a coup attempt. "This was purely a military matter," he said, indicating that the takeover was aimed at unseating him.

In the interview, Guei suggested that the plotters were manipulated by opposition politicians, who he accused of "sowing confusion in the army." The army chief has been a target of criticism by opposition leaders and the teachers union for a raid on a university dormitory in May that reportedly resulted in a number of student injuries and the rape of women dormitory residents. Announcing the end of the teachers' strike, union leader Marcel Ette said the government had agreed to meet its demand for the withdrawal of troops from campuses and the removal of a ban on political meetings.

AUGUST 26, 1991


BULLETIN BOARD


LENGTH: 918 words


* "South Africa -- What Does Justice Require?" is the theme for a National Council of Churches consultation on South Africa. The October 26-27 meeting at the Newark Airport Vista Hotel in Elizabeth, NJ will focus on political, economic and social strategies for South Africa's future. Contact the Africa Office, National Council of the Churches of Christ, USA, 475 Riverside Drive, New York, NY 10115. Telephone: (212) 870-2645.

* The 34th annual meeting of the African Studies Association will be held November 23-26 in Saint Louis, MO. This year's theme is "African Renewal." Prior to the meeting, on November 22-23, there will be a mini-conference on "The Status of Women's Studies in Africa." Contact the African Studies Association, Credit Union Building, Emory University, Atlanta, GA 30322. Telephone: (404) 329-6410. 

* October 16 is World Food Day. This year's topic for the international World Food Day teleconference is "The Hunger Puzzle: Adding the International and Macroeconomic Pieces." Carried via four earth satellites in English, French and Portuguese, the teleconference will explore how national and international policies and agreements affect farmers, food production and hunger. A study/action packet is available from the U.S. National Committee for World Food Day, 1001 22nd Street, NW, Washington, DC 20437. Telephone: (202) 653-2404.

* The African Business Round Table (ABR), the U.S. Overseas Private Investment Corporation and the U.S. Agency for International Development are sponsoring a conference on "Investment Opportunities in West Africa," in Dakar, Senegal. The November 19-21 conference will bring together American investors and business leaders from more than 20 African countries. The ABR works to attract foreign investments to Africa, to promote intra-African trade and investment and to strengthen Africa's private sector. Conference information is available from the African Business Round Table, c/o African Development Bank, 01 BP 1387, Abidjan 01, Cote d'Ivoire. Telephone: (225) 20-42-88.

* The Executive Committee of the Association for the Advancement of Policy, Research and Development in the Third World is inviting proposals for papers for its November 15-20, 1992 conference on "The TNew World Order': A Challenge to International Leader-ship." Topics are UN issues, geographical issues and applied policy studies. The deadline for submissions is November 15. Contact Mekki Mtewa, Executive Director, Association for the Advancement of Policy, Research and Development in the Third World, PO Box 70257, Washington, DC 20024-0257. Telephone: (202) 723-7010.

* An environmental symposium for non-governmental organizations, called "Growing Our Future: Food Security and the Environment," will be held November 21-22 at Arizona State University (ASU) in Tempe, AZ. The gathering is sponsored by Food for the Hungry International and the ASU School of Agribusiness and Environmental Resources in cooperation with InterAction and the National Audubon Society. The session is a prelude to "Earth Summit", the UN Conference on Environment and Development to be held in Brazil in June, 1992. Write to Kristen Wedan, Food for the Hungry/ASU Symposium, 7729 East Greenway Road, Scottsdale, AZ 85260. Telephone: (602) 951-5090 or (800) 248-6437 (US and Canada only, between 8:00 a.m.-5:00 p.m. PCT).

* The Annual Awards Dinner of the African-American Institute is scheduled for November 7 at the United Nations General Assembly Building. Honorees are Nicephore Soglo, the president of Benin, Adebayo Adedeji, former executive secretary of the Economic Commission for Africa, Dorothy Height, president of the National Council of Negro Women and Frank E. Ferrari, Senior Vice President of the African-American Institute. Contact the African-American Institute, 833 UN Plaza, New York, NY 10017. Telephone: (212) 949-5666, Ext. 893.

* An international water well symposium will be held during the National Water Well Exposition in Washington, DC October 21-23. The meeting will be devoted to water well activities of private voluntary organizations in developing countries, including presentations describing village level projects in Africa, India and the western hemis-phere. Contact J. R. Babson, 1627 K Street, NW, Suite 900, Washington, DC 20006. Telephone: (202) 955-1467.

* The second annual conference of Africa, Inc., an organization of Africans in America, will take place in Cambridge, MA at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology on September 20-21. The conference is one of six activities of Africa. Inc.'s Africa Awareness Week, scheduled this year for September 21-28. Former Tanzanian president Julius Nyere is to deliver the keynote address. Among the topics for workshops and seminars are development, private entreprenuership, and structural adjustment. Contact Africa, Inc., 35 Fremont Street, Suite B4, Arlington, MA 02174. Telephone: (617) 648-2535.

* A UN-sponsored conference to assess the implementation of the UN Program of Action for African Economic Re-covery and Development (UNPAAERD), adopted by the UN General Assembly in 1986, will be held at UN headquarters from September 3-13. The conference also will provide a forum for governments and multilateral agencies to present and explain their policies and programs for future development and economic recovery. Contact the UN Non-Governmental Liaison Service, 2 UN Plaza, Room 1103, New York, NY 10017. Telephone: (212) 963-3125.

95 of 211 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


AUGUST 26, 1991


NIGERIA: RULING ANGERS WOMEN


LENGTH: 268 words


Lagos-- The National Republican Convention, one of Nigeria's two recognized political parties, has protested a ruling by the National Electoral Commission (NEC) that bans the party's Women's Advisory Committee. The election commission, which is charged with organizing, monitoring and supervising elections, says the women's group contravenes a regulation that forbids women and youth, among others, from setting up political groupings outside the main party structures. 

Alhaja Suliat Adedeji, leader of the women's group, says it is not a separate entity from the party, but "part and parcel" of it, and that the commission and the Nigerian police are acting as enemies of the party. The advisory committee was formed to advise the party on issues affecting women.

David Iornem, a university professor and publicity secretary of the other Nigerian party, the Social Democrats, says his group will not flaunt the electoral officials ruling. "We are not going to disobey the NEC by setting up an advisory committee for women," he said, "but we shall put in place a women's counseling section to perform functions similar to those of the Women's Advisory Committee."

The regulations forbidding extra-party organizations was designed to keep a tight rein on political organizing during Nigeria's transition to democratic rule. In the past, the country's elections have been plagued by corruption and fraud that discredited both winners and losers in the public's eyes. But critics of the NEC say it is wielding too big a stick in its attempt to control the process.

Olugbenga Ayeni


LOAD-DATE: August 23, 1991


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1991 AllAfrica, Inc.


96 of 211 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


AUGUST 26, 1991


ANTI-HUNGER WORK RECOGNIZED


SECTION: WOMEN


LENGTH: 364 words


 

This year's $ 100,000 Africa Prize from the Hunger Project will be awarded on September 19 in London to two prominent women, Maryam Babangida, Nigeria's First Lady, and Wangari Maathai, a Kenyan environmentalist and anatomy professor.

The award, formally known as the Africa Prize for Leadership for the Sustainable End of Hunger, is conferred annually by the New York-based international non-profit organization. The 1991 recipients were announced at a July 18 ceremony broadcast worldwide and chaired by Charlayne Hunter-Gault, national correspondent for public television's MacNeil/Lehrer NewsHour. 

Babangida is being honored for founding the Better Life for Rural Women Program, which promotes women's social, economic and political advancement in Nigeria. The group has established over 7,600 cooperatives, 1,700 new farms and nearly a thousand cottage industries, as well as shops, markets and women's centers. Babangiba also has raised funds to construct an international women's center in Abuja, Nigeria's new federal capital, and she is active in an informal grouping of African first ladies, who say their purpose is to improve the quality of life for the people of their countries.

Maathai is being recognized for her work as founder of Kenya's Green Belt Movement, which the Hunger Project calls "one of the world's most successful programs " in community development and environmental protection. The movement has mobilized 50,000 women in the planting of 10 million trees throughout the country and has set up 1,500 nurseries.

Maathai led a successful campaign last year against the construction of a planned skyscraper complex in Uhuru Park in downtown Nairobi, the Kenyan capital. Her efforts attracted heated attacks from many top Kenyan leaders and resulted in the Green Belt Movement's being evicted from its office headquarters. Maathai moved the work to her home and continued her campaign.

Earlier this month, Kenyan President Daniel arap Moi announced cancellation of a proposed shopping mall and underground parking garage in another city park, a project which also had been opposed by Maathai and other environmental activists.


LOAD-DATE: August 23, 1991


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1991 AllAfrica, Inc.


97 of 211 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


AUGUST 26, 1991


NEW CONSTITUTION FEATURES BILL OF RIGHTS


LENGTH: 403 words


The constitution adopted on June 19 by the eighth congress of the Polisario Front says that economic and social development is a continuous process and that the people of an independent Western Sahara will need to ratify a "new, definitive constitution." The current document is intended to serve as the "fundamental source" for that constitution. Polisario envisions an Islamic, democratic state with extensive protection of individual liberties -- economic as well as political. A free-enterprise, market economy is to parallel a public sector that is entrusted with "the exploitation of those natural resources of vital importance to the economic development of the country." Among the provisions of the bill of rights are these:

* No one may be detained for more than 72 hours. Once this term expires, the person either will be freed or brought before the competent legal authorities. In any case, the accused is presumed innocent until proven guilty. 

* The death penalty is prohibited.

* No one may be subjected to torture, inhuman practices or acts contraryto the dignity of the human person.

* A citizen's residence is inviolable. Residential searches always require written search warrants issued by an appropriate legal authority.

* The right to private property is a fundamental, recognized right that will be regulated by law.

* All citizens have the right to education and health care.

* The state will aim to defend the political, economic and social rightsof Sahrawi women and will guarantee their participation in the improvement of society and in the development of the country.

* The state will draft the necessary laws to adopt a policy of social security aimed at protecting senior citizens and persons with disabilities.

The constitution also provides for an independent parliament and judiciary. Legislators are to be elected by direct universal suffrage. Judges may not be detained, replaced or retired, except as preordained by law, and the Supreme Court will have six justices -- two chosen by the court itself, two by parliamentary election and two by presidential appointment.

During this transition period, the constitution says, the secretary general of the Polisario Front will serve as president and the Saharan National Council will function as a provisional parliament.

English translation by Ahmed A. Cherif and Teresa K. Smith de Cherif


LOAD-DATE: August 23, 1991


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1991 AllAfrica, Inc.


98 of 211 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


AUGUST 26, 1991


MOROCCO PRESSES DEMAND FOR POSTPONEMENT OF SAHARAN INDEPENDENCE VOTE


SECTION: CONFLICT


LENGTH: 1009 words


Paris -- Amid intense international negotiations to keep the peace plan for Western Sahara on track, Morocco has appealed to the permanent members of the United Nations Security Council to delay a scheduled vote on the future of the disputed territory.

Last Wednesday, the Moroccan foreign ministry announced that Foreign Minister Abdellatif Filali would meet with representatives of the five permanent members to present Morocco's case. The statement followed a televised speech by Morocco's King Hassan II, who said the vote should be postponed because the United Nations has failed to keep to a timetable for pre-vote preparations.

United Nations officials say it is unlikely that there will be a response to the Moroccan request until UN Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar returns this week from informal consultations in Geneva with the Polisario Front independence movement. 

Since 1973, Polisario has been fighting for the independence of the former Spanish colony, which Morocco annexed after Spain pulled out three years later. Baba Sayed, a Polisario representative in the French capital, says the group believes that King Hassan fears the results of the planned referendum, designed to allow Saharans to choose between independence or incorporation into Morocco. The Polisario spokesperson says he expects the king "to do what he can to make it difficult for the Saharan people to exercise their democratic rights."

At the end of April, the UN Security Council formally established the United Nations Mission for the Referendum in Western Sahara, known as "Minurso," to oversee preparations for a vote. A cease-fire is scheduled to begin on September 6.

In practice, there has been little contact between the rival armies for the last two years, since Polisario declared a unilateral cease-fire. On the ground, Morocco has stayed largely within the confines of a defensive barricade it erected to enclose Western Sahara's main towns and its phosphate deposits. Polisario has roamed the territory outside the wall freely, occasionally taking journalists and other visitors to the base of the heavily-fortified barrier that bristles with electronic sensing devices.

But on August 5, intense fighting broke out. Morocco said Polisario was "infiltrating" military units into Western Sahara from refugee camps in Algeria, to gain an advantage before the cease-fire. The official Moroccan news agency quoted the government as saying that "the Royal Armed Forces have conducted and are conducting sweeps and clean-up operations" in the area between the wall and the territory's boundaries with Mauritania and Algeria.

Polisario accused Morocco of attacking and bombing the group's positions in the town of Tifariti near the Mauritanian border, but it said it hoped the incident was "an isolated act" that would not disrupt the peace process. Later in the week, however, Polisario said air force planes were again on the attack "outside the Moroccan defense line" -- which it called a deliberate attempt to alter the status quo on the ground. Polisario Secretary-General Mohamed Abdelaziz appealed to Perez de Cuellar to intervene, saying that the attacks jeopardized the chances for peace.

Both the secretary-general and the Organization of African Unity issued statements of concern, and UN officials stepped up their diplomatic efforts to secure international backing for the referendum. The French government said it fully supports the UN process and appealed to all parties to refrain from acts that might derail it.

Last Thursday Polisario reported massive Moroccan troop movements in the territory and said it feared a resumption of serious clashes. No independent confirmation of the fighting was available. Interviewed by telephone at his Washington, DC office, Polisario representative Moulud Said said he believes the initial attacks were a provocation, designed to force Polisario to withdraw from the peace plan, but "we didn't fall into that trap." The latest fighting, he said, is a sign of Morocco's desperation. He pledged Polisario's continuing commitment to the referendum.

Questioned by telephone about Morocco's charges that the United Nations has not completed preparations for a cease-fire, Minurso spokesperson Jamel Ben Yahmed said that the plan "is still valid," until the Security Council decides differently. "I don't think the Security Council would take any action without discussing it with the secretary-general," he said.

Ben Yahmed refused to comment on the Moroccan king's statement that the UN is responsible for the delays. "We think that it doesn't serve any purpose to indulge in blame fixing," he said. "But we have always said that the implementation of the peace plan is dependent on the cooperation of the parties." He confirmed reports that Morocco had refused to allow a United Nations ship of logistics personnel and supplies to off-load in Western Sahara. The group was charged with paving the way for the rest of a 1,695-person peacekeeping force that was to have been in place by the cease-fire date of September 6.

Ben Yahmed says the United Nations remains actively committed to the plan and is proceeding with various aspects of its implementation. Resolving longstanding conflicts is never without difficulties he said. But he said it should be remembered that, "from the beginning, the secretary-general said that the time-table in a plan of this type is an estimate. Some things may take longer than projected, but our job is to see that the process is completed."

Meanwhile, Polisario has been engaged in an internal struggle to open up its political processes. For the last two years, forces within the group have argued for movement away from the centralized decision-making of a war footing to a more democratic style of operation. That campaign achieved major successes at a Polisario congress in June, with the adoption of a new constitution and the replacement of the 23-person political bureau with a 53-member council of delegates.


LOAD-DATE: August 23, 1991


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1991 AllAfrica, Inc.


99 of 211 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


AUGUST 26, 1991


NATIONAL CONFERENCES FORGE CHANGES


SECTION: AROUND THE CONTINENT: DEMOCRACY


LENGTH: 1977 words


 

Using national conferences as a kind of modern-day bludgeon for deposing dictators, Africa's democracy movement has scored several new breakthroughs this month.

In West Africa, Niger's national conference assumed control of the government and left military ruler Ali Saibou as provisional president with only ceremonial duties. Next door in Mali, that country's conference adopted a new constitution and set a timetable for elections in six months. And in Togo, long-serving President Gnassingbe Eyadema has seen his powers erode as a national conference there debates the transition to pluralist democracy amid calls that Eyadema be ousted or placed on trial for mismanagement and more serious crimes.

The national conference phenomenon began 17 months ago in Benin, when widespread protests forced dictator Mathieu Kerekou to agree to a meeting between government officials and a broad range of opposition, civic and religious groups. Gabon's conference a few months later served as a prelude to multiparty elections in October, the country's first since President Omar Bongo instituted one-party rule in 1968. 

Since then, national conferences have come to be seen as so synonymous with the idea of democracy, particularly in French-speaking Africa, that demands for them have become the focus of opposition protests in many other countries.

The meetings have not been smoke-filled-room affairs. Delegates are drawn from all parts of the country, representing a range of interest organizations and numbering from about a thousand in Mali to as many as 4,000 attending the conference which began this month in Zaire. In most countries, the proceedings are broadcast on radio and television and are avidly followed by citizens from all walks of life.

President Mobutu Sese Seko is the latest of Africa's long-ruling leaders to give in to the pressure for political reforms. Mobutu, whose 26-year grip on power has been severely weakened by a broad coalition of opposition groups, announced an end to one-party rule early last year. But he has continued to resist change by ordering troops to disperse demonstrators and by arresting opposition leaders.

Last month, as pressures against him mounted, Mobutu relented and agreed to allow a national conference to take place. But since the meeting opened on August 7, disagreements between the president and his opponents have persisted. Charging that Mobutu violated an agreement on accrediting delegates by padding the meeting with government loyalists, the 200-party opposition coalition staged a boycott that has effectively brought the proceedings to a halt.

Mali's national conference was the shortest and smoothest to date. In just two weeks of deliberations, delegates managed to agree on a new constitution establishing a multiparty democracy, a five-year presidential term with a limit of two terms in office, and a new lower voting age of 18. The constitution will be submitted for approval to a national referendum next month.

But Mali's newfound success came at a price. More than 200 people died in pro-democracy demonstrations early this year before soldiers decided to refuse orders to crush the protests and, instead, ousted then-president Moussa Traore, who had governed the country since a 1968 coup. Lt.-Col. Amadou Toumani Toure, who lead the soldiers in their March takeover, established a transitional government made up of civilians and soldiers and promised to transfer power to an elected government by January 20.

Like many of his authoritarian colleagues, Zaire's Mobutu has rejected the notion that a national conference can claim sovereignty over the country's affairs.

The conference in Benin set the pace on the sovereignty issue when it stripped Kerekou of decision-making power and gave executive authority to Nicephore Soglo, an economist at the World Bank who was summoned home to become interim prime minister. A year later, Soglo defeated Kerekou in the country's first free presidential elections.

Earlier this year, a three-month-long conference in Congo chose a 153-member Supreme Council to govern the country until a new government is elected next May. After heated discussions of past government malfeasance, delegates reduced President Denis Sassou-Nguesso to a ceremonial role and initiated probes into corruption and misuse of power.

As the latest assemblage to take charge, Niger's conference appears to have ended 17 years of military rule in the country. Saibou is a former army chief of staff who became president in 1987, on the death of Lt. Col. Seyni Kountche, leader of the 1974 coup which ousted the country's first president, Hamani Diori. Command of the army and the police has been transferred to the conference chairman, Andre Salifou, who is dean of education at the University of Niamey. The conference has also restricted foreign travel for government ministers and ambassadors and has initiated investigations into government abuses and transfers of capital abroad.

The sovereignty issue remains unresolved in Togo, where a national conference is now in its seventh week. When the meeting voted itself full governmental authority last month, the government delegation walked out, only to return a few days later. Since then, President Eyadema's representatives have remained in place while the delegates, numbering about 1,200, have concentrated on airing grievances against his 24-year rule.

But with the scheduled selection of a prime minister and interim government this week, the sovereignty issue will likely come to the forefront again.

Meanwhile, Cameroon's President Paul Biya continues to resist calls for his resignation and the convening of a conference, despite a national 10-week strike staged by opposition forces. The protest has halted normal commerce in most major cities outside the capital.

Opposition to Biya is strongest in the English-speaking part of the country, which includes Douala, the economic capital and major port. The country is officially bilingual, having been colonized by both France and the United Kingdom, but the former British-administered south has felt excluded from power by Biya and his predecessors.

In Douala and other strike-affected cities, routine business is conducted only on weekends, when banks and shops open for long hours before closing again on Modays in observance of the anti-government campaign. Early this month, one wing of Biya's ruling People's Democratic Movement urged the government to agree to "the people's demand" for a national conference. Several government ministers also have endorsed the idea of a "non-sovereign" conference.

But Biya has scuttled previous attempts to bridge the differences, including a church-led negotiation effort last month, by refusing the opposition's demand that he meet with their leaders as a group.

Although only francophone countries have held national conferences to date, pro-democracy stirrings are being felt in English-speaking countries as well.

While Nigeria, the continent's most populous nation, is establishing one pattern by its current two-party election campaign, ending in a presidential poll next year, Ghana is trying a variation on the national meeting idea as a prelude to voting.

Ghana's National Consultative Assembly, scheduled to open this week, shares many characteristics with the conferences that have been held in several French-speaking states in the region. Delegates to the Ghanaian assembly will represent all areas of the country and a cross-section of organizations. Their mandate is to debate constitutional proposals drafted by a committee of legal experts and to prepare a document that will be submitted to voters in a referendum. In addition, the assembly is expected to establish a timetable for elections to return the country to civilian rule. The extensive deliberations are expected to last into December.

The country's government, headed by Flt.-Lt. Jerry Rawlings, who took power in a 1981 coup, says the assembly will be representative because the bulk of delegates are elected by district assemblies which were themselves chosen during the past two years. Other delegates will be chosen by some 60 groups, including civic, religious, trade and professional organizations.

However, Rawlings' plan has come under heavy fire from opponents. At a recent press conference in the capital Accra, an alliance of 11 opposition groups denounced the consultative assembly as "fraudulent" and called for a sovereign national conference to be held instead.

Last month, Ghana's Roman Catholic bishops also criticized aspects of the government's transition plan and called for a specific timetable to be established for elections and a handover to an elected administration. The bishops said the ban on political party activity and restrictions on the press should be lifted.

In Sierra Leone, another English-speaking West African nation, parliament voted last month to end 13 years of one-party rule. During debate in which long-stifled accusations of government misconduct were openly swapped, legislators also adopted a new constitution that is scheduled to be submitted to voters by the end of this month.

However, critics have assailed the government's announced intent to proceed with the referendum despite ongoing fighting in a large section of eastern Sierra Leone. Although government troops have reportedly recaptured several important towns in recent weeks, rebels continue to hold some areas and pose a threat to others.

President Joseph Momoh blames the fighting on Liberian rebel leader Charles Taylor and the government of Libya, which it says is supplying the insurgents with arms. Taylor denies playing a role, saying the fighting is an internal matter led by opponents of Momoh, a former army chief who was the hand-picked successor to President Siaka Stephens when the latter leader retired in 1985.

While some opposition figures have called for a national conference to manage the transition to multiparty rule, others have formed parties and launched attacks on the government's performance, in anticipation of a lively electoral campaign as soon as an end to the fighting permits.

Another spirited campaign is well underway in Zambia, where President Kenneth Kaunda is facing his first real test at the polls since independence in 1964. Early this month, the Zambian parliament adopted constitutional changes that guarantee multiparty elections and deny the president the power to declare martial law.

Kaunda recently announced that elections will be held on October 31 and will be monitored by an outside observer team headed by former American president Jimmy Carter.

Many observers believe that the largest opposition party, the Movement for Multiparty Democracy, can defeat Kaunda. But the 67-year old leader has signaled his intention to campaign hard to keep his job.

Meanwhile, in East Africa, President Daniel arap Moi of Kenya continues to resist demands for ending one-party rule.

The country's only legal party, the ruling Kenya African National Union, this month rejected the latest attempt to promote multiparty government. Leading opposition figures recently announced the formation of the Forum for the Restoration of Democracy, led by a former vice president, Oginga Odinga, and several other former prominent politicians.

Odinga's formation in January of an opposition party, the National Democratic Party, was declared illegal by the government. The Kenyan High Court this month upheld the government's stance.

However, Moi has taken several steps to placate his domestic and international critics. All leading dissidents have been released from jail, the party has halted summary expulsions of suspected rebels, and tenure for judges has been reinstated.


LOAD-DATE: August 23, 1991


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1991 AllAfrica, Inc.


100 of 211 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


AUGUST 26, 1991


MADAGASCAR MULTITUDES PRESS DEMOCRACY CAMPAIGN


LENGTH: 661 words


 

While the world watched thousands of people celebrate in the streets of Moscow last Thursday, 200,000 protestors flooded the main square of Antananarivo, capital of the Indian Ocean island nation of Madagascar. Nearly every day for the last 12 weeks, the country's pro-democracy movement has rallied massive crowds -- sometimes as many as half a million strong.

But Madagascar's demonstrators have been having as difficult a time bringing down the 16-year regime of President Didier Ratsiraka as they have of attracting international attention.

Last Monday, the opposition said Ratsiraka had been "deposed" and would be replaced by an interim government to oversee the transition to free elections. But the 54-year-old leader remained holed up in the presidential palace, appearing only once on national television to sign a decree extending the country's state of emergency. 

The opposition coalition known as Forces Vives (Living Forces) has for the last 12 weeks staged some of the biggest ongoing protests anywhere in the world. Despite the huge numbers, violence has been a rarity. But on August 10, during one of the largest marches, estimated at 500,000, presidential guards fired at a crowd heading for the palace. At least 31 people died, according to a Madagascar Red Cross statement reported by the Associated Press. Another 20 people died in protests the same day in the northeastern port town of Mahajanga.

The violence brought a swift condemnation from France, Madagascar's former colonial power and principal aid donor, which issued a statement calling for internationally supervised elections to break the impasse between the government and the opposition. France also suspended cooperation between 50 French military advisors and the presidential guard.

It was a swift fall from favor for Ratsiraka, who only two months ago received what the Reuters news agency termed "a rare display of favor" from French President Francois Mitterrand, who took the Madagascar leader on a personally guided tour of the Paris air show.

Mitterrand signalled a shift in France's approach to Africa in June 1990, at the Franco-African summit in La Boule, France. Instead of the unqualified support Paris has traditionally extended for leaders of its former colonies, he said future aid would be tied to democratic reform.

With Ratsiraka apparently weakened but holding on, talks began last week between government and opposition figures. Albert Zafy, who has been designated prime minister in the opposition shadow cabinet, told the Thursday rally he had been meeting with Premier Guy Razanamasy and Brig. Gen. Georges Randrianasoavina, a senior military officer who signed an army statement early last week calling for formation of an interim government. No details were released of the talks, which were sponsored by the Christian Council of Churches.

Meanwhile, the six-party opposition coalition met to draft a political program and a new government acceptable to all groups. Three more shadow ministers -- for education, health and agriculture -- were added to the cabinet named by Forces Vives last month. All three are from provinces outside Antananarivo, a move designed to counter government charges that the opposition lacks support beyond the capital, the Associated Press reported.

Some diplomats speculated that the coalition was straining to maintain unity, pointing to the fact that the only statements issued in the name of the entire opposition were limited to attacks on Ratsiraka. One shadow minister resigned to protest the decision to stage the August 10 march which resulted in the deaths.

It is clear, however, that even a divided opposition would continue to pose a formidable threat to the Ratsiraka presidency. The continuation of large rallies, despite mounting public fears and tension following the killings of protestors, appeared to convince most observers that the government's days are numbered.


LOAD-DATE: August 23, 1991


LANGUAGE: English
