101 of 211 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September 9, 1991


"ECONOMIC CRISIS IN AFRICA": EXCERPTS FROM THE SECRETARY-GENERAL'S REPORT


LENGTH: 1007 words


UNPAARED (UN Program of Action for African Economic Recovery and Development 1986 - 1990) was a unique compact between Africa and the international community. African countries committed themselves to necessary economic reforms as a basis for broad-based, sustained economic development. For its part, the international community recognized the need for intensified cooperation and substantially increased support for Africa.

Nevertheless, five years after the adoption of the program, the current socio-economic state of the majority of African countries continues to give cause for concern. The goals set in UNPAAERD are far from being realized. 

The great majority of African countries carried out a broad range of initiatives and reforms, as envisaged in 1986. The framework for reform in most countries was provided by structural adjustment programs (SAPs), since vitally needed external financing became increasingly difficult to obtain without the adoption of these programs. When they were first designed, these SAPs focused on short-term objectives of stabilization. It is now widely acknowledged that these programs must give more emphasis to the longer-term structural transformation needed in Africa.

African countries estimated that the full implementation (of the recovery program) would require total financial resources of $ 128.1 billion, ofwhich African countries intended to provide $ 82.5 billion through the mobilization of domestic resources. The remainder, just over $ 9 billion per annum, was to be met through additional external resources.

Africa's efforts fell short of projections because the continent's main source of external resources, earnings from commodity exports, plummeted in the face of weak prices on the world markets. In 1986 alone, Africa lost $ 19billion as a direct result of falling commodity prices.

While some of Africa's partners substantially increased their support to the continent, the expectation of additional net resource flows to Africa, in real terms, actually declined. Official development assistance stagnated, in real terms, while private flows fell sharply.

Africa's debt and commodity problems were not dealt with adequately, resulting in Africa becoming more indebted by the end of the program than at its inception - and earning a much-diminished income from an increased volume of commodity exports.

In light of the above, it is not surprising that the performance of the African economy remains highly unsatisfactory. GDP per capita fell by an average of .7% per year during the second half of the 1980s. Social conditions worsened considerably, with deterioration in the areas of education, health, nutrition, employment and incomes, with especially serious effects on children, youth and women.

The recurrence of drought in many parts of Africa, political instability, civil strife, military conflicts, weak institutions and, often, less than effective policies to mobilize and utilize domestic resources continued to be both cause and consequence of the poor economic performance of most countries.

There remains an urgent need for a major drive by African countries to reverse the socio-economic deterioration and put the continent on the path to sustained growth and development. This growth must be environmentally sustainable and development must be human oriented, with the effective participation of the African people in the development and the democratization of policy and society.

A majority of African countries have carried out policy reforms aimed at improving efficiency and the allocation of resources. These measures continued to be pursued despite their often high political, social and economic costs, and have shown positive results. But in 1990, declines in economic output and in the delivery of social services had been slowed in many countries and even partially reversed in some. But the continuation of these reforms is being jeopardized by the lack of even minimally adequate resources. Neither socially or politically can this reform effort be sustained without improvements in public services and a gradual rise in real income soon becoming apparent to African consumers and voters.

It is clear that even the fullest possible restructuring of African economies could not generate the resources required for sustained economic recovery for the 1990s. A new compact for African development in the 1990s must be forged by Africa and the international community to support Africa's development strategies.

The renewed global compact for the 1990s should contain specific operational measures to attain clearly identified goals. Three essential goals should be: 1) economic transformation and diversification (from commodity dependence); 2) an acceleration of the rate of growth of GDP (from an average of 2.3%) to at least 6% per annum; and 3) rapid progress towards human-oriented goals by the year 2000.

African countries have to continue adjustment efforts within a long-term framework with the objective of achieving structural transformation. The international elements of the compact must include enhanced financial flows. Even more important than aid flows is the need for a bold attempt to tackle Africa's debt problem.

There is a need for renewed efforts at international cooperation among consumers and producers, especially regarding coffee and cocoa. Diversification provides a major way out of commodity export dependence and its related problems. Additional resources will be required to support diversification programs, through increased contributions by the international community, as well as more efficient domestic resource mobilization.

While there may be room for further debate on the ways by which some of these items are pursued, this consensus achieved during UNPAAERD can be the basis for future international collaboration. A renewed compact between Africa and the international community must be one that is fully observed and implemented by all parties.


LOAD-DATE: September 13, 1991


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1991 AllAfrica, Inc.


102 of 211 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September 9, 1991


UN EVALUATES AFRICAN RECOVERY PROGRAM: FIVE-YEAR EFFORT SEES FRAGILE GAINS


SECTION: ECONOMY


LENGTH: 1352 words


Much like Americans contemplating the steady slide in student test scores despite several years of educational reforms, Africans have endured belt-tightening austerity programs, only to see a continuing decline in per capita incomes and social conditions.

But like the education problems in the United States, the African economic crisis is generating attention, debate and ideas. And the continent's spreading democracy movement, plus a slight improvement in economic growth rates, are seen by some as evidence of a silver lining behind the generally gloomy statistics.

Beginning September 3 and continuing through this week, the United Nations General Assembly is assessing the results - or lack of them - of a bold program adopted in 1986 to reverse Africa's economic decline.

On June 1 of that year, a Special Session of the General Assembly unanimously endorsed the United Nations Program of Action for African Economic Recovery and Development, 1986 - 1990. Despite its formidable name - even the program's acronym, UNPAAERD, is unwieldy - proponents say that the pact offered thoughtful guidelines for meeting achievable goals. The problem, they say, is that it wasn't implemented. 

Last month, UN Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar issued a report on UNPAAERD prepared for the General Assembly session. "Economic and social conditions actually worsened over the five years of the UNPAAERD period," the report notes. "This occurred," it says, "despite the many far-reaching actions and reforms undertaken by African countries, including notable progress towards democratization."

In an unusually stern forward to the report, Perez de Cuellar says that "the situation of Africa raises important questions about solidarity among member States of the United Nations and about their will and capacity to act in concert to address the wide spectrum of inextricably linked development issues, both within and beyond the continent."

As the report sees it, there was a measure of lip service to the compact on all sides. Many African countries, for example, have not gone far enough with economic reforms designed to streamline government performance, to remove bureaucratic impediments to private initiative and to curtail the privileges of special interest groups. But the Secretary-General devotes his harshest critique to industrial nations and what he sees as their failure to remove the international obstacles to Africa's recovery - factors over which, the report says, African countries have little or no control.

The Secretary-General identifies three key areas where a hostile external environment has blunted Africa's ability to overcome its problems: commodities, financial flows and debt.

Africa's earnings from international trade are far more important as a source of investment for development than foreign aid. But dramatic falls in the world prices for Africa's main exports sharply reduced the continent's revenues during the UNPAAERD period. In the five years of the program, African countries lost more than $ 50 billion in earnings from the drop in commodity prices.

The losses are especially serious because Africa is more dependent than any other region of the world on raw material production. Nine out of 10 African countries depend on primary commodities for at least 70% of their exports.

The sharpest decline in prices during the 1980s has been in coffee and cocoa, major exports of 15 or more African countries. By 1980, cocoa prices were at a 15-year low, and by early last year, coffee prices were down to a similar degree. Despite reforms that allowed a 26% jump in production from 1985 to 1989, African cocoa farmers lost over $ 3 billion, due to prices that, in real terms, have reached their lowest level ever.

The continent's dependence on primary commodities for export earnings packs a double whammy to the continent's economic health. Because it produces such a limited number of products and has a small manufacturing base, Africa depends heavily on imports to meet its own needs, including food. And while the prices of its exports have been dropping, depressing the continent's purchasing power, the cost of its imports have risen.

The UN advocates "mutually beneficial agreements between producers and consumers" of major commodities to stabilize prices and prevent wild fluctuations. In the absence of international agreements, individual producing nations are likely to take unilateral steps to try to drive prices higher, as Cote d'Ivoire did when it held its entire crop off the market. Although that effort was an economic disaster for Cote d'Ivoire, Brazil and Colombia announced a plan to withhold 10% of their production in an effort to force prices up.

Rather than individual country action, the UN encourages greater producer cooperation to regulate supplies in order to avoid gluts and to pursue joint research and promotion.

But the most promising effort, UN economists say, would be to reduce Africa's dependence on a narrow range of raw materials by diversifying in two directions - into new commodities, such as tropical fruits and flowers, and into processing or manufacturing that will add value to Africa's traditional exports.

At the same time, the UN report says that "a priority for Africa is to increase intra-regional trade in food products, in both primary and processes forms. The elimination of tariff barriers and the improvement of transportation and communication systems within Africa are seen as necessary steps towards the establishment of an African Economic Community - a plan adopted in May at the last meeting of the Organization of African Unity.

The UNPAAERD called for increased foreign assistance to Africa to support the economic reform efforts undertaken by most of the continent's countries. The pact called for external sources to provide approximately $ 46 billion in aid during the five-year duration of the program. Instead, transfers of funds to Africa declined in real terms, with net resource flows down from $ 24.6 billion in 1986 to $23.3 billion last year.

Although it hails many developments and reforms in Africa - in particular "the enhanced role played by non-governmental organizations in promoting grassroots development - the Secretary-General's report chides African countries for continuing weaknesses in domestic policies and calls on governments to deal more effectively with taxation, the utilization of resources and capital flight. But it says that even the most complete reform program cannot generate the resources needed for sustained economic recovery. In 1992, the report says, Africa requires "a minimum of $ 30 billion in net official development assistance" and a further increase of 4% a year until the end of the decade.

Even more important, though, according to the report, is the reduction of Africa's $ 270 billion debt burden, payments for which consume over 30% of earnings. In addition, the UN says, debt reschedulings that have rolled forward some 40% of the continent's debt service obligations will provide a continuing drag on Africa's attempts to lift itself from its economic morass.

The Secretary-General calls for a cancellation of official debt owed to governments as well as of semi-official/export credit debts. Private and commercial debt, he says, should be reduced, with remaining obligations handled by creative programs that exchange debt for promises to invest in such beneficial projects as environmental protection and poverty alleviation.

The report's conclusion calls for a new compact between Africa and the rest of the world to ensure the fruition of economic recovery efforts. But, substantively, the conclusion is in Perez de Cuellar's forward to the document, when he warns that in the effort to wrench Africa out of "an unrelenting economic crisis of tragic proportions," the international community's credibility is at stake. Failure on this issue, he says, threatens the world's "ability to deal effectively with questions affecting its collective well-being and security." n


LOAD-DATE: September 13, 1991


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1991 AllAfrica, Inc.


103 of 211 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September 9, 1991


GHANA AND NIGERIA MOVING TOWARD '92 VOTES


LENGTH: 400 words


Ghana's first national elections in more than a decade are to take place late next year, according to Flight Lt. Jerry Rawlings, the country's head of state. Rawlings announced the timetable at the consultative assembly, which is meeting in the capital Accra to consider a new constitution for the return to elected civilian rule.

Rawlings has been accused by his detractors of delaying the election process and of buying time in an attempt to perpetuate the ruling council's tenure. Lawyers and students associations are boycotting the assembly, which has representation from other trade and interest groups and from district assemblies around the country. 

The assem bringing the total to 30.

The drawing of state boundaries touches on the two most explosive issues in the Nigerian polity - ethnic and religious affiliations. Babangida's announcement was met with both celebration and protest. Many of those incorporated into new states welcomed the move, while some protested because their area was not party to the changes.

Babangida said that in deciding which boundaries to redraw, the government placed the "utmost premium on political stability and social integration." He also assured Nigerians that the action would not delay the election process.

Although the changes have necessitated a postponement of primaries for gubernatorial and state assembly seats from this month until October, the government says the timetable for general elections at the state and national level will be maintained.

Babangida made the long-anticipated declaration on new states during an August 27 speech on the sixth anniversary of the Armed Forces Ruling Council's tenure in office. He told Nigerians that the council's policies "are yielding encouraging results despite leakages in the system," an apparent reference to corruption. He reiterated the government is commitment to "public accountability" and promised audited accounts of all federal agencies and state governments before the handover to elected successors next year.

He also defended the government's controversial austerity measures which were "necessary to save our economy from collapse," he said. And he pledged to hand the next government "a much-improved economy" and "a stable, peaceful, united country."

- with files from Ebow Godwin in Lome, Kwame Karikari in Accra, and the Newswatch staff in Lagos


LOAD-DATE: September 13, 1991


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1991 AllAfrica, Inc.


104 of 211 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September 9, 1991


CONFERENCES CONTINUE REFORM PUSH


SECTION: AROUND THE CONTINENT


LENGTH: 785 words


Zaire's unsteady movement toward political reform jammed again last week when a dozen people were reported killed by government forces who fired on a demonstration last Monday and raided an opposition party office later in the week.

Before the violence, the national conference, which has been stalled by disagreements over accrediting delegates, had been expected to resume in mid-week. A coalition of major opposition groups, known as the Sacred Union, has refused to take part in the sessions as long as it was excluded from participation in the accreditation committee. The coalition says President Mobutu Sese Seko, who has ruled the country since 1965, is trying to pack the meeting with his own supporters. An announcement late last week said the conference could reconvene within a few days. 

The opposition has vowed to force Mobutu from office as a prelude to the holding of free elections in the country, which has a population of 37 million. The president's opponents hope to copy the successes of democratic forces in several other African countries, including next-door Congo, where President Denis Sassou-Nguesso was stripped of his power and left with a ceremonial position by a national conference earlier this year.

Now events in Togo have taken a similar course. Following an often tumultuous seven-week national conference, President Gnassingbe Eyadma has ceded most of his power to a new prime minister, Kokou Koffigoh, a human rights lawyer and leading opposition figure. For a time, it appeared that Eyadma was going to resist this latest in a series of developments that has steadily transformed the 53-year-old leader from a strongman into a near figurehead.

As the conference moved towards conclusion on August 19, Eyadma suddenly appeared on national television and radio, pre-empting conference coverage to announce a suspension of the proceedings. He also reportedly ordered the dispatch of soldiers to surround the hotel where the meeting was taking place, but the troops never arrived, and it was unclear whether a formal order was never given or the military disobeyed. For 24 hours, the West African nation's communication links with the outside world were cut.

Conference delegates - numbering about 900 and drawn from all over the country and from a range of groups - ignored the president's command to disperse and proceeded to elect Koffigoh and vest him with authority to name a new cabinet. They agreed, however, to allow Eyadma to serve as president until elections take place next year.

After several rounds of intense negotiations between national conference leaders and the government, Eyadma yielded. Opposition leaders helped by agreeing to reconsider elements of the new constitutional draft which Eyadma opposes. And diplomats from the U.S., France, and Germany - Togo's largest donors and trade partners - weighed in with quiet advice to Eyadma to accept what most Togolese saw as inevitable.

The 43-year-old new prime minister, who is president of both the League for Human Rights and the Togolese bar association, is expected to announce the formation of a broad-based government that will likely include some of the president's own supporters.

Events in Niger, to Togo's north, have moved in a similar, if less definitive direction. The national conference meeting in Niamey, the capital, has placed some limits on President Ali Saibou's activities. He was not allowed to make a scheduled visit to Libya last month, for example. But agreement on a new prime minister and several other key decisions has proven difficult.

Late last week, a group of young army officers said they had assumed control of the army after removing the chief of staff from his post. The officers pledged to support the national conference's program of democratic reform in the country, the Reuters news agency reported.

In neighboring Mali, a government shake-up was announced in the run-up to national elections scheduled to take place by January. Five of the ten military members of the ruling transitional administration were removed, following accusations that they took part in the killings of an estimated 200 demonstrators during the anti-government protests that brought down the regime of President Moussa Traore earlier this year.

The transitional council, comprised of both soldiers and civilians, took control in the March 26 military coup against Traore, who had ordered the crackdown on protestors. Another council member, Demba Diallo, a human rights activist, resigned to run for president. Mali's national conference, which met last month, decided that candidates should not hold government positions during the campaign.


LOAD-DATE: September 13, 1991


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1991 AllAfrica, Inc.


105 of 211 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September 9, 1991


REPORT SAYS REBUILDING CRUCIAL TO STABILITY


LENGTH: 715 words


The end of hostilities in Angola will not abolish large-scale suffering - and may not bring lasting peace - unless the international community whose weapons fueled the fighting helps to repair the damages, according to a report published by the Washington, D.C.-based U.S. Committee for Refugees (USCR). "Angola's Post-War Inheritance: The Long Road Home" was prepared by J. Stephen Morrison, a USCR consultant who served on the staff of the House Foreign Affairs Subcommittee on Africa from 1987 to early 1991.

Leading the list of pressing needs, the report says, is resettling the population dislocated by war. About two million people - a fifth of Angola's population - have been displaced, and their "expeditious and effective reintegration" will be central to "any post-war renewal of Angola's rural society and economy," says the report. 

Morrison identifies the continuing presence of huge numbers of land mines throughout the country as "one of the war's most formidable legacies." The widespread use of these weapons has already created in Angola what many experts believe is the largest population of amputees in the world. Even though danger to civilians remains high in post-war Angola, Morrison warns that there is "no broad plan of action for their removal, no existing capacity to carry out such a plan, and no serious discussion yet underway of how such a capacity could be introduced from without."

Until they are removed, the report says, the mines stand in the way of resettlement and the recovery of Angola's once-thriving family agricultural sector and promises a continuation of the hunger and malnutrition of wartime. Morrison says the United States and the Soviet Union, which helped broker the peace accord along with Portugal, should provide the funding and technical assistance needed for the task.

The report is highly critical of what the USCR sees as the "chronic institutional weakness" of the United Nations relief program in Angola and of the U.S. government's "political and humanitarian bias in favor of Unita."

The UN's Angola relief effort, launched in late 1990, came "nowhere near" the goal of delivering nearly 20,000 tons of food to 1.9 million people in nine provinces. According to Morrison, it was the "maneuvering for optimal military strength" by both Angolan parties that is largely to blame for the failure. Unita's refusal to agree to a cease-fire prior to conclusion of a formal peace agreement delayed the dispatch of food to those in need, as did the government's decision last December to suspend the program for nearly three months.

The report charges that the U.S. also contributed to undermining the UN's effectiveness by sending "sizeable shipments of relief" which Morrison says were "disproportionately" allocated to Unita-controlled areas. The U.S. Office of Foreign Disaster Assistance, which made the assessments on which the distribution decisions were based, counters that the deliveries were sent to the areas of greatest need and were not politically directed.

The actions of the rival factions and the role of the U.S. cannot account completely for the shortcomings of the UN relief program, the USCR report says, pointing to what it sees as the UN's failure to make credible evaluations of relief requirements. The report attributes much of the difficulty to inadequate staffing and inexperienced UN personnel.

Morrison believes the same problem threatens the effectiveness of the UN Angolan Verification Mission (Unavem), the peacekeeping force assigned to maintain the cease-fire during the transition to elections. The mission, which is to include 350 military observers, 90 police observers and 250 support personnel, is a "risky experiment in UN minimalism," the report says.

With so much at stake for Angola, Morrison is troubled by the prospect that lingering distrust and bitterness and "fierce competition" in the upcoming election will block progress towards improving the lives of the population. The report concludes with an appeal to the Angolan parties for "greater equanimity, compassion and competence" in handling the country's difficulties and a plea to the U.S. and the UN for "even-handedness" and increased support for efforts to end long years of suffering.


LOAD-DATE: September 13, 1991


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1991 AllAfrica, Inc.


106 of 211 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September 9, 1991


AIDS THREAT STALKS PEACETIME ANGOLA


SECTION: HEALTH


LENGTH: 961 words


Luanda - The peace accord signed May 31 by President Jose Eduardo Dos Santos and Jonas Savimbi, head of the Unita rebel movement, has ended three decades of civil war in Angola. But health professionals in the former Portuguese colony say the country needs to gear up for battle against a different scourge. Peace, they say, will create conditions for the rapid spread of HIV, the virus that causes Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndrome.

There are no reliable figures on how many Angolans already have AIDS. According to the ministry of health, 211 AIDS cases had been reported by the end of 1990. But the ministry acknowledges that this count includes only the people who have been diagnosed with AIDS in public hospitals. 

"In Luanda alone, we should have a number of cases five times greater than that registered by the ministry for the entire country," says Maria Olivia Fortunato Torres, secretary general of the Angolan Association for the Fight Against AIDS.

Torres launched the low-budget organization five months ago in an effort to counteract public skepticism and promote awareness about the disease's existence. She says many people in Angola believe that AIDS is "a foreigner's disease," spread only by "women who have come from outside the country." Her group's fledgling campaign to persuade Angolans otherwise is supported by donor organizations including the World Health Organization, the Angolan Red Cross, Medicines Sans Frontiers, and the Catholic aid group Caritas.

"I think people here have been shutting their eyes to the AIDS problem," she says. "People say they don't believe AIDS exists because they haven't seen anyone die of AIDS."

That is likely to change, according to medical workers. The long, gruelling war destroyed Angola's roads, bridges and communication systems, isolating villages from one another and from the outside world. But the opening of highways is gradually ending the wartime restrictions on movement and, in the process, demolishing the last fragile barrier to dissemination of HIV.

"With peace, people in the country will be able to move around more freely, and we feel we must be even more concerned with educating people about AIDS," says Elsa Montez, director of the National Program for the Fight Against AIDS. "It is a fact that in the next few years, the problem of AIDS will be much worse in Angola."

Montez bases her prediction on experiences in other parts of the continent. An estimated 6 million people in sub-Saharan Africa are carriers of the HIV virus, according to World Health Organization statistics. And among the highest-risk groups for AIDS are long-distance truck drivers and prostitutes.

In Angola, which is about triple the size of California, trucks are able to travel across the country without risking attack for the first time in three decades. With the increase of trucks and their drivers on the roads - plus the demobilization of an estimated 150,000 soldiers as the armies of Unita and the government are combined into a unified force - health professionals predict that prostitution will flourish. AIDS will flourish along with it, the medical workers believe, unless the disease can be headed off by a massive national education campaign.

"Although there have been no official studies, I don't think there is any reason to believe that the situation with prostitutes here is different from that of other countries like Uganda and Zaire, where it's been proven that a very high percentage of prostitutes are infected with the AIDS virus," says Montez.

Another worry of the AIDS-fighting groups is the impact of the return to Angola of approximately half a million war refugees from neighboring countries, such as Zaire and Zambia where the infection rate is high. A further concern is that an increasing incidence of HIV will contaminate the country's blood supply. Hospitals now test blood for the presence of the virus in only 10 of Angola's 18 provinces. By next year, the number is expected to rise to fourteen.

Although the prevalence of AIDS inside Angola is believed to be considerably lower than in many African countries, the disruption of war has made the collection of accurate numbers impossible. And the military demands on both sides has meant that AIDS awareness campaigns have had a low priority in the allocation of scarce funds and personnel.

Montez's program will take advantage of peacetime by beginning a number of studies of high risk groups and their behaviors. In addition, in a venture sponsored by the country's health ministry, the organization has planned two large education campaigns to be carried out before the end of the year.

Montez points out that while war may have slowed the spread of AIDS, it has fostered the growth of other maladies that will make Angolans more vulnerable to the disease when they do encounter it. Only about 30 percent of the population has any access to health facilities. Clean water and sanitation are rare in the war-ravaged provinces.

"In large numbers, people here suffer from hunger and sicknesses," says Maria Torres. "In these conditions, the ability to fight diseases like AIDS is greatly reduced."

Torres' association has no single recipe to fight AIDS in Angola. Convincing men to change their behaviors and have only one sexual partner in a largely polygamous society, where a man's value is often measured by the number of children he has fathered, often appears an impossible task. But the Association, along with other AIDS campaigners, is aggressively promoting the use of condoms.

"Condoms have to be circulated like bread here," says Torres. "But unfortunately, in Angola, it is very difficult to get bread - and it is difficult to get condoms."


LOAD-DATE: September 13, 1991


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1991 AllAfrica, Inc.


107 of 211 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September 9, 1991


SUDAN DISSIDENTS SPARK SECESSION TALK


LENGTH: 653 words


New question marks loom over the future of Sudan following an apparently unsuccessful effort to oust John Garang, leader of the Sudan People's Liberation Movement (SPLM), the insurgent group which has been engaged in a bitter eight-year battle with the Sudanese government. Already the crisis in the Horn of Africa is seen by many experts to be the

world's most serious humanitarian disaster. Relief officials believe as many as 15 million people in Sudan, Ethiopia, and Somalia face starvation this year unless emergency food supplies can reach them. The situation in Sudan, where 9 million people are considered at risk, is the worst. 

The effort to remove Garang from the leadership of the SPLM and its military wing, the Sudan People's Liberation Army (SPLA), was headed by three military officers, who issued a three-page statement from their operational base in Nasir, accusing Garang of "warlordism" and a "dictatorial and autocratic manner." The dissidents include Lam Akol, a top-ranking SPLM official, and two field commanders, Riek Mashar Teny-Dhurgon, another member of the high command, and Gordon Koang Chol.

Garang responded by releasing a communique signed by himself and eight other members of the 13-member SPLM high command and calling the dissidents actions "meaningless."

The SPLM, which controls most of the largely Christian and animist south, except the major town of Juba, opposes domination of the country by Islamic northerners. The Sudanese regime, led by Lt. General Omar Hassan al-Bashir, who overthrow a civilian government in Khartoum in 1989, is heavily supported by Islamic fundamentalists.

However, a mediation effort begun by the Organization of African Unity (OAU) has showed some promise. Last month, Col. Mohammed Al-Amin Khalifa, a leading member of the military junta, visited Nigeria for talks with President Ibrahim Babangida, the OAU chairman. Nigerian officials said they expect to host peace talks between the warring parties soon, and Babangida appointed an experienced Nigerian diploma, to oversee the mediation effort.

The dissidents' statement criticized Garang for failing to press for peace and for giving priority to military goals over civilian relief efforts. They pledged to democratize the movement, respect human rights, and "relentlessly strive to attain a peaceful settlement."

Garang countered with a memo from his headquarters in Kapoeta to supporters promising to continue "all efforts" to achieve a "just, honorable peace."

While the dissidents may have lacked broad support, some analysts believe their action may indicate growing sentiment in favor of secession of the south. Next door in Ethiopia, Eritrea has effectively gained its independence, and on the other side, northern Somalis have seceded from the rest of the country. "It's no longer so unspeakable an idea," says one senior State Department official. "We would like to see Sudan remain a viable united entity, but we can't deny that these feelings may be gaining support within the area Garang controls."

The U.S. government has pledged about 330,000 metric tons of food for the relief effort- about half total worldwide commitments. The latest situation report on Sudan issued by the U.S. Office of Foreign Disaster Assistance cites as a major impediment "a nationwide lack of adequate trucking capacity." Andrew Natsios, the director of the U.S. disaster office, returned from an assessment visit to the area last week, has taken a leading role in trying to persuade the Sudanese government to cooperate with the United Nations-directed relief program.

Roger Winter, director of the U.S. Committee for Refugees, which is actively involved in Sudan, has called for a " tough U.S.-led international position" to put additional pressure on Khartoum. This could be the "only hope" for saving many of the people at risk in the country, Winter says. n


LOAD-DATE: September 13, 1991


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1991 AllAfrica, Inc.


108 of 211 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


OCTOBER 21, 1991


SKIN OF HIS TEETH


LENGTH: 268 words


Togo's President Gnassingbe Eyadema received another blow to his rule last week when an interim civilian government formally retired the general.

The transitional government headed by Prime Minister Kokou Koffigoh is trying to break Eyadema's 24-year stranglehold on power. 

Koffigoh, who was appointed by a national conference in August to head the temporary government, himself has been in a precarious position in recent weeks. On October 8, Eyadema loyalists in the army tried to kidnap the prime minister from his hotel but he eluded capture. The incident marked the third attempt by pro-Eyadema troops to topple Koffigoh, and set off violent street protests which left at least four people dead.

The retirement of Eyadema from the army October 11 capped 10 days of disturbances which have left a total of least seven people dead, by one official count.

Fears are growing among Togolese that the danger of ethnic rivalry will increase the longer the country's political future remains uncertain. The Eyadema government heavily favored the army's Kabyes, who are from Eyadema's region in the north, while southern Ewes grew increasingly isolated. The cabinet has banned all street demonstrations until further notice.

Eyadema has called for the mutinous soldiers to be punished and ordered troops to remain in barracks. But those moves have failed to quiet opposition charges that he instigated the unrest and is sabotaging the transition to democracy.

Elections are to be held next June; both Eyadema and Koffigoh are barred by the transition plan from contesting the polls.


LOAD-DATE: October 18, 1991


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1991 AllAfrica, Inc.


109 of 211 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


OCTOBER 21, 1991


SURPRISE OPPONENT


LENGTH: 350 words


Pro-democracy demonstrators in Burkina Faso are encountering an unusual roadbock in West Africa. Instead of clashing with security forces, the opposition is butting heads with pro-government demonstrators.

Last week, about 15,000 supporters of President Blaise Compaore marched peacefully through the streets of Ouagadougou urging him to reject opposition calls for a national conference. 

The march reflected rare civilian support for one of Africa's military rulers, a succession of whom have ruled Burkina Faso for the past decade.

On September 30, club-wielding pro-government demonstrators confronted opposition protestors while security forces did little but appeal for calm. At least a dozen people were injured in the melee. A day later, civilians wrecked the offices of two opposition parties.

The opposition is demanding a national conference on the country's political future, but the president's ruling party has rejected the call. Twenty-seven pro-government parties have warned Compaore that if he submits to a conference they might boycott the parley.

Such conferences in several other French-speaking African countries have replaced authoritarian regimes with transitional governments leading to free elections.

The people of Burkina Faso approved a new multiparty constitution in a referendum last June, and Compaore formed a transitional government September 10. Shortly afterwards, seven opposition members quit, protesting the government's refusal to hold a national conference.

The president says he quit the army September 29 because the new constitution bars the military from office, and he intends to run for president. He wants the elections to take place in December.

The opposition charges that Compaore will have an unfair advantage at presidential elections and that only a national conference can ensure a fair democratic transition.

Compaore has appointed a 15-member panel, drawn from both sides, to try to reach agreement on the conference issue. Failing an accord, he says, he will put the question to a national referendum.


LOAD-DATE: October 18, 1991


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1991 AllAfrica, Inc.


110 of 211 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


OCTOBER 21, 1991


FRIENDS TO THE END


LENGTH: 393 words


Amid growing fears that continued foreign backing for Zaire President Mobutu Sese Seko could lead the country closer to civil war, the Bush administration still sees an important role for him. "Mobutu says he won't leave, so we think he has to be included in any coalition arrangement," said one State Department official last week, as a transitional administration was being formed.

Successive U.S. administrations have maintained close links with the Zaire leader, even when financial mismanagement and human rights abuses have proved an embarrassment. 

American assistance for Zaire has exceeded $ 1 billion since Mobutu took control of the country in a 1965 coup, but most U.S. aid programs have been suspended this year due to mounting arrears in loan repayments and escalating civil strife. The U.S. embassy in Kinshasa recently donated about $ 25,000 for emergency relief, and a $10 million aid shipment is currently en route to the country.

For normal assistance to resume after the establishment of a democratic government, Congress will have to agree to exempt Zaire from the provision of the 'Brooke Amendment,' which bars aid to countries which fall behind in repaying debts to the United States. Liberia and Ethiopia have been granted such waivers this year.

The same may not prove true for Zaire. Suppport for Mobutu, even from his traditional friends, appears to be eroding. A new memorandum from the conservative Heritage Foundation, which has backed American aid to Mobutu in the past, says there should be "no further aid" until Zaire "demonstrates a commitment to economic growth" and introduces "free market reforms."

But the administration appears reluctant to cut ties completely. Throughout the Cold War era, Mobutu has been viewed as a valuable anti-Soviet ally and a reliable partner for covert activities in neighboring Angola and many other African nations. And despite the changing international scene, some of these old links continue to work in Mobutu's favor.

Last week, the president succeeded in retaining control of key ministries in the new government headed by a chief opposition figure, Etienne Tshisekedi. While 18 portfolios are now in opposition hands, Mobutu managed to hold onto the ministries of defense, foreign affairs, and mines, the source of the country's vast potential wealth.


LOAD-DATE: October 18, 1991


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1991 AllAfrica, Inc.


111 of 211 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


OCTOBER 21, 1991


BIYA: "NOT OPPOSED TO CHANGE"


LENGTH: 315 words


Cameroon's President Paul Biya has returned from a tour of the country's 10 provinces, saying the momentum towards democracy is irreversible.

However, reform can only occur through elections and dialogue, Biya said in a nationally-broadcast speech October 11. He announced that general elections would be held February 16.

Biya also said he had asked the prime minister to organize a meeting among government and opposition parties and independent observers to discuss the country's future. But the president stopped short of calling a national conference, as the opposition has demanded, before any elections are held.

"The democratization of national political life is irreversible, but it is threatened by acts of violence, intimidation and force," said Biya, referring to four months of general strikes and protests which have alternately paralyzed and shaken this relatively peaceful central African country.

Biya's trip was largely seen as a show of strength in the face of mounting opposition. He returned to the capital Yaounde asserting that he was not "opposed to change."

"All the necessary changes will be made, but we must not mistake the will for change expressed by the majority of citizens for a strategy of illegal seizure of power adopted by certain people," he said.

"Reforms must be made through dialogue and consultation," said Biya, adding that a meeting among government and opposition parties and independent groups would be aimed at revising the electoral code and defining modalities for freedom of the press.

Following elections, he said, a prime minister would be appointed from the majority group in the National Assembly and that person would be in charge of forming a government.

Biya called on all political parties to begin campaigning and to use the opportunity to enter history "through the front door."

BITS AND PIECES


LOAD-DATE: October 18, 1991


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1991 AllAfrica, Inc.


112 of 211 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


OCTOBER 21, 1991


DEMOCRACY: CAMEROON SEEKS WAY OUT OF POLITICAL 'HOT HOUSE'


LENGTH: 1102 words


Washington, D.C. - Cameroon's government and opposition leaders are reaching out to the United States to help give their democratic transition a boost.

And in an apparent move to quiet the country's sometimes violent cries for democracy, President Paul Biya has moved parliamentary elections up from 1993 to next February, telling Cameroonians in a national address that he is "not opposed to change."

But political polarization appears to be threatening the country's chances for a democratic future. The opposition coalition showed signs of strain in recent weeks, when it banished from the group three parties that had pursued contacts with the government. And a four-month-old general strike called by the coalition has failed to strong-arm Biya into accepting a national conference, although it has crippled the country economically. 

There is "very much of a hot house political atmosphere" in Cameroon, says Ned McMahon, senior program coordinator for the Washington-based National Democratic Institute for International Affairs (NDI), a non-profit group which seeks to promote democracy abroad.

Last month, at the invitation of the government and with the opposition's approval, NDI sent a team to Cameroon to review a draft electoral code and draft legislation on press freedom. NDI, modeling its work in Cameroon on an earlier successful effort to unblock a stalemate between the government and the opposition in Senegal last year, is to release a report on its findings by November.

Meanwhile, civil strife has continued in Cameroon. On October 14, two schools were sacked in the port city Douala following a police ban of an opposition march. Scores of protesters, including two key opposition leaders, were arrested last month during demonstrations in the city. There have been several deaths and injuries this year as a result of the ongoing clashes between protesters and security forces.

The strikers are demanding the convening of a national conference to look at a new multiparty constitution and an electoral system for Cameroon. As a vehicle to forge new democracies, national conferences have become commonplace in West Africa. After strikes and protests, national conferences in Benin, Congo, Niger and Togo have stripped presidents of all but formal authority and installed transitional administrations in their place.

Cameroon's Biya, who came to power in November 1982, has rejected these demands but made some concessions, reviving the post of prime minister and granting amnesty to political prisoners. The National Assembly in April limited presidential service to two five-year terms.

Political opposition became legal in Cameroon only last December. Since then, the process there has drawn attention from other groups in addition to the NDI.

The National Republican Institute for International Affairs (NRI) plans a November visit to Cameroon, where it wants to set up a "networking" program for democratic activists in French-speaking Africa. NRI hopes to establish similar programs in Angola and Nigeria to serve Portuguese and English-speaking Africa, says program officer Edward Stewart.

In addition, the Agency for International Development (AID) is developing a democracy and governance program for Africa and has been asked to talk to the Cameroon government and opposition, says Anne Williams, a senior AID advisor.

"Our main emphasis from an AID perspective is, 'How do you sustain what is happening in Africa now -- what is the sustainability of the democracy movement?'" she said. That answer hinges on whether the government and opposition can converge and unblock their lines of communication, according to McMahon.

"We found (the political atmosphere) to be relatively more polarized than in other countries" NDI has visited, such as Benin, the Cote d'Ivoire and Congo, said McMahon.

Indeed, one of the two parties excluded from the opposition coalition for having had contacts with the government was the country's oldest opposition party, the Union of Cameroonian People. To justify its action, the coalition expressed fears that the government is trying to infiltrate it and weaken its power.

Additionally, two opposition leaders, Samuel Eboua and Jean-Jacques Ekindi, were arrested following a demonstration in Douala last month. An editor of the independent newspaper, Le Messager, was also arrested. All have been released.

McMahon attributes the political polarization to a lack of neutral domestic groups that could soften political dialogue. In other African countries making the transition to democracy, there are organizations of human rights activists, attorneys or journalists that can screen and mediate political conflicts, he says.

The lack of such groups in Cameroon is due partly to a history of authoritarian rule -- including more than two decades under Biya's predecessor, Ahmadou Ahidjo -- and to the country's cultural diversity, says McMahon. Cameroon has an estimated 200 ethnic groups and is divided into the French-speaking east and English-speaking west. It was colonized by the Portuguese, Germans, French and British.

Foreign Minister Jacques-Roger Booh Booh, who was in Washington this month to meet with U.S. officials and the press, says the government is willing to discuss the country's problems. However, it continues to oppose a national conference, says Booh Booh. "The national conference is not an institution provided for in the constitution," he says.

Booh Booh says the democratic process will unfold in Cameroon through seeking advice from experienced democracies, reviewing electoral law and media access and holding elections.

"Attempts by the opposition parties to go against this normal process, this legitimate process, will not be tolerated for a long time," says Booh Booh. The government has already threatened to declare a state of emergency if the violence escalates.

A Washington-based representative for the Cameroon Democratic Party, whose leader met with officials here in August, says his party is not demanding a national conference, but it would not reject one. "I think we need a new electoral code before talking about elections," says Fabien Assigana. He says the opposition is awaiting funding for elections from the government.

McMahon thinks parliamentary elections will be boycotted unless changes are made to the constitution. "I think the government is prepared to look at making changes in this regard," he said, noting that the government invited NDI to Cameroon. "But again, how far they'll go remains to be seen."


LOAD-DATE: October 18, 1991


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1991 AllAfrica, Inc.


113 of 211 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


OCTOBER 21, 1991


HORN NEEDS HELP


LENGTH: 432 words


The United Nations last week appealed to the international community to refocus attention on the Horn of Africa and help meet a $ 300 million shortfall in pledges to the drought and war-stricken region.

"Donor distraction" to needs elsewhere in the world is endangering the lives of some 22.5 million people in Sudan, Ethiopia, Somalia, Djibouti and Kenya, said James Jonah, the United Nations' top relief official, in a monthly report on the Horn released October 11.

In a pledging conference last month, only $ 110 million was raised for relief, food and health assistance for the region -- 25% less than what the United Nations says is required until December. 

"The effects of civil war, recurring drought and severe social and economic deterioration have been catastrophic for tens of millions of people in the Horn of Africa," said Jonah. "In addition to the incalculable cost in terms of human life, unprecedented numbers of people have become either internally displaced or live as refugees in neighboring countries."

Civil war in Ethiopia and Somalia has pushed tens of thousands of refugees into neighboring Sudan, Djibouti and Kenya. All five Horn countries are wracked by recurring drought.

But despite the shortfall in donor pledges and "enormous logistical and political obstacles," Jonah said there was progress in providing relief to the Horn in September:

* In Sudan, 800 metric tons of food were airdropped and delivered by barge to feed returning Sudanese refugees. However, 8.5 million Sudanese continue to require emergency and rehabilitation assistance.

* In Ethiopia, 10,000 metric tons of blood were flown in, but 8.7 million people still require emergency assistance, including an estimated 250 Eritrean refugees returning daily from Sudan. The World Food Program is scaling down its airdrops as the post-war crisis eases. More cost-efficient trucking operations are being expanded and the target of delivering 20,000 metric tons of food has been met.

* In Somalia, 4.5 million people need emergency assistance despite a resumption of activities in the north between the United Nations and non-governmental organizations. Those activities include providing food aid, reactivating health services and restoring water sites.

* In Kenya, approximately 10,000 Somali refugees in two northern camps were relocated where vital services are being provided.

* In Djibouti, most Ethiopian refugees have returned to Ethiopia, but there are an estimated 15,000 remaining in addition to some 80,000 Somali refugees who require assistance.


LOAD-DATE: October 18, 1991


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1991 AllAfrica, Inc.


114 of 211 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


OCTOBER 21, 1991


D-DAY NEARS IN UN RACE


LENGTH: 1122 words


United Nations -- With the selection of a new United Nations secretary general expected within the next few weeks, African countries are stepping up their campaign to have an African at the helm of the world body.

The continent is the only major region never to have had one of its own in the UN's top post. Formal deliberation to choose a successor to Javier Perez de Cuellar, who retires at the end of the year, began in the Security Council about two weeks ago. But the talks are secret and no front runner has emerged. 

The African candidate with the best chance to get the job may be Boutros Boutros Ghali, the deputy prime minister of Egypt. Of the six candidates submitted by the 51-member Organization of African Unity (OAU), Ghali probably is the one most likely to be able to get the vital endorsement of the United States.

"We strongly believe that the next secretary general should be an African," Nigerian President Ibrahim Babangida, the current OAU chairman, reiterated earlier this month in an address to the UN General Assembly. Babangida said Africa's case is based on both "competence and justice," reminding the UN of the "distinguished" names presented by the OAU. The list includes Zimbabwean Finance Minister Bernard Chidzero, former Nigerian head-of-state Olusegun Obasanjo, Ghana's Kenneth Dadzie, who is secretary general of the UN Conference on Trade and Development (Unctad), Sierra Leone's James Jonah, the UN undersecretary general for political affairs, and Francois Owono-Nguema, a former minister of culture from Gabon.

"I remain optimistic that a spirit of equity and fairness will prevail and that an African will be chosen," says Vivian Lowery Derryck, president of the New York-based African-American Institute. "Africa has an abundance of superb candidates who can serve the UN in its entirety," says Derryck, who is monitoring the race from her office across the street from UN headquarters.

But many observers believe big power considerations may dictate the selection of a prominent figure from another area of the word. Other potential candidates whose names have gained ground during the discussions include Prince Sadruddin Aga Khan, a veteran international civil servant and current chief of UN humanitarian operations in the Persian Gulf; Norwegian Prime Minister Gro Harlem Brundtland and Canadian Prime Minister Brian Mulroney.

The winner not only must get the vote of a majority of the 15-nation Security Council but also must avoid a veto by any of the five permanent members -- Britain, China, France, the U.S. and the USSR. Two new OAU members -- Cape Verde and Morocco -- took rotating seats on the council last week, replacing Cote d'Ivoire and Zaire. But Africa has only three votes -- the continent's third seat is held by Zimbabwe -- and must get support from other council members to elect one of its candidates.

Ten days ago, France formally signalled that it will veto any prospect who is not French-speaking. "France will never agree to the future secretary general of the United Nations not being a Francophone," a French foreign ministry official said, according to the Reuters news agency. Two of Africa's leading prospects, Boutros Ghali and Chidzero, studied in France, but Nigeria's Obasanjo is not known to speak French with any fluency.

According to the London daily, the Independent, Chidzero has the backing of the British government. But the decision, which was not formally announced, was made primarily to "ensure an easy ride" for British Prime Minister John Major at this month's Commonwealth meeting in the Zimbabwean capital, Harare, the paper suggested. Britain, which previously has rejected the idea that this is Africa's turn to fill the post, could switch to another candidate when the final voting comes, the newspaper said.

Thus far, there has been no indication of an American favorite and no hint of focus on the race by President Bush, who once served as U.S. ambassador here. But many observers believe Bush will eventually take a personal interest in the selection and that his preference will likely prevail. "In the 'new world order,' the Americans can usually get what they want around here," one senior African diplomat says.

For this reason, Boutros Ghali may enjoy an edge, since his leading backer, Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak, has a close relationship with the American president and might be able to appeal directly to the man most able to influence the final outcome. During a visit to Washington last month to campaign for the position, Boutros Ghali met with Bush, although U.S. officials say the president made no commitments to support him.

Some objections have been raised to having an Arab secretary general at a time when Arab-Israeli negotiations are a prime international concern. But Israel and its supporters apparently are not actively opposing Boutros Ghali, who has a history of involvement in the peace-making process. In 1977, he accompanied Egyptian President Anwar Sadat on his historic visit to Jerusalem, and in 1978 Boutros Ghali took part in the Camp David talks between Sadat and Israeli Prime Minister Menachem Begin.

The New York Times, in an editorial on October 4, argued that Boutros Ghali is the "one compelling choice in a generally excellent field." His selection makes sense, the paper said, because "he speaks sensibly for a third-world constituency fearful of being marginalized by the end of the cold war."

AAI President Derryck, who worked closely with Ghali during the biennial African-American Conference in Cairo early this year, says the Egyptian would be an excellent choice. "He has a keen intellect and is an experienced diplomat with wide contacts," she says.

But Ghali's selection might not satisfy completely the concerns of sub-Saharan Africans to be recognized as world players. Although he appears on Africa's list, the fast rise of his candidacy has not helped smooth ruffled relations between Egypt and Nigeria, which began when Mubarak failed to turn up for the OAU summit in May, which was hosted by Babangida in Abuja, the Nigerian federal capital. Boutros Ghali led the Egyptian delegation after Mubarak cancelled at the last minute.

A further setback came last month, when Babangida visited Egypt to formally open the annual All-Africa Games. He was not publicly recognized or allowed to speak at the opening ceremony, sparking a furor in the always-lively Nigerian press. If Boutros Ghali is chosen, Derryck believes, sub-Saharan Africa should still have a turn the next time around. "There are enough highly qualified Africans that they need to be considered and Africa should be given an equal chance," she says.


LOAD-DATE: October 18, 1991


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1991 AllAfrica, Inc.


115 of 211 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


OCTOBER 21, 1991


SAVIMBI PLEDGES IMPROVEMENTS


LENGTH: 822 words


Unita leader Jonas Savimbi says the Angolan government's policies have wrecked the country's economy and created such poor conditions that investors have been driven away. "No one will invest in a country where he cannot make a phone call, where he cannot have a fax sent," Savimbi said during his recent U.S. visit. Unita's detailed economic program for reviving the war-wrecked Angolan economy was presented to several meetings of business leaders by Fatima Roque, Unita secretary for economic affairs.

Here are excerpts from her presentation, which was illustrated with slides:

The adoption of the central-planned controlled economy destroyed the market economy that we had during the colonial period, destroyed human and physical capital of the country, destroyed the emerging Angolan entrepreneurial class, and disrupted totally the circuits of distribution. If we add those main economic consequences with the political interference in the economic management of the country, the poor economic management and inconsistent decision-making, with the ill-conceived and incoherent investment decisions and appallingly low productivity in most sectors controlled by the government, we will have the right recipe for severe macroeconomic distortions. 

Putting all this together we find in our country the following consequences: the almost total collapse of production outside the oil sector, a very high import dependency, rising balance of payments problems and foreign debt. Just to give you an idea, in 1990 the total foreign debt of our country is conservatively estimated to be $ 7.3 billion, very much above the GDP of the country -- it's about 128% of the country's GDP in that year...

We in Unita are committed to dismantling the centrally planned, controlled economy. We are committed to implementing a comprehensive program to restructure and restore the economic vitality of our country. The goal is to establish a private-enterprise driven, socially oriented market economy...

Unita has therefore identified four major economic policy objectives. The first is related to the distribution pattern of income. The second one is the creation of an enabling environment for sustainable development and the reintegration of the Angolan economy into the world economy.

The third one is the definition of our philosophy itself and the relationship with development of the Angolan entrepreneurial class. The fourth one is the supply side of our economy that has been totally federalized since the adoption of the MPLA economic system. The fifth one is related to domestic demand, and the last one to better allocation of resources...

Unita has identified priority sectors as far as foreign investment is concerned. The sectors presenting major investment opportunities are: the rehabilitation of infrastructures, commercial agriculture and agro-business, fishing, mining, petroleum and petro-chemicals, energy, transportation, telecommunications, manufacturing, light and heavy industry, banking and finance and wholesale and retail trade.

As for our foreign investment guidelines:

Is the project viable in economic terms? Does the project contribute to regional development and linkages? Does it create jobs and train the Angolan people? Does the project provide managerial skill and transfer technology to Angola? Is the technology transferred appropriate?

Does the project generate foreign exchange or save foreign exchange, whether we are talking about projects that will promote exports or projects that will substitute imports? ... And is the potential investor prepared to reinvest the profits that are made in the country? ...

Besides that, the foreign investor should have a technical capability and strong financial standing and a good knowledge of local conditions; an ability to make positive contribution to development, to invest in our priority sectors, and to integrate into the Angolan society, willingness to transfer technology, know-know, and managerial skills, to train the local labor force, and to provide vocational training and access to foreign markets.

What is Unita and Angola prepared to offer the foreign investors? We are prepared to offer equal treatment. That is to say, all opportunities, all sectors in principle open to domestic investors are open to foreign investors. We are prepared to offer security of title, access to foreign exchange, the right to repatriate profits and dividends, and the right to international arbitration of investment disputes.

But more important than that, we are offering you people an enabling environment for business that we don't have in our country at the moment. We are prepared to offer an honest and efficient public administration; reasonable, clear and consistently applied corporate and labor legislation; reasonable levels of taxation and double-taxation treaties; and realistic exchange rates.


LOAD-DATE: October 18, 1991


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1991 AllAfrica, Inc.


116 of 211 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


OCTOBER 21, 1991


DOS SANTOS CALLS FOR U.S. INVESTMENT


LENGTH: 725 words


Angolan President dos Santos's most extensive postulation of his government's economic policies were presented in a speech to the American Chamber of Commerce in Washington, D.C. on September 17. Here are excerpts:

We began our independence determined to create a new and more just society, and for most of us that meant adopting socialism, since our previous experience with colonial capitalism was synonymous with exploitation, corruption, and gross inequalities. In focusing on socialism or the just distribution of wealth and material benefits, we put too much emphasis on equitable redistribution. Unfortunately, we learned the hard way that the state was incapable on its own to produce and distribute sufficient goods and products.

We also underestimated the entrepreneurial spirit of the Angolan people. In the short time since we started to take the reins of the state off the economy, our people have demonstrated a remarkable entrepreneurial capacity. Restaurants, clothing shops, businesses of almost every type, especially in services, are springing up. And this has brought an improvement to the daily life of our people. 

The restructuring of the economy already has begun to pay dividends. Exports have increased steadily. In 1989, Angola became a member of both the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank. We regard this as an important vote of confidence by the international financial community, as well as a valuable opportunity to gain access to technical assistance in the areas of budget, tax and fiscal policy, and general economic management.

The technical assistance provided by the IMF has already measurably improved our budgeting procedures, and the new $ 23 million technical assistanceloan from the World Bank to facilitate the transition to a market economy will provide us with the expertise we need to continue our progress toward this goal.

Although the restructuring is making steady progress, there is need to accelerate its pace. To do so means rapidly enhancing our decisionmaking and policy analysis capability. It also means limiting the consumption of important imported goods and expanding investments in human resources, primary materials for factories, and capital equipment such as tractors, transport and telecommunications.

Our commitment to privatization was shown recently, when we privatized 30 coffee plantations that had been nationalized in the 1970s. Further privatization will come of agricultural properties, manufacturing companies, and services. Unfortunately, not all can be done at once. And, frankly, there are some types of activities that may require greater preparation for privatization than we have the capability now to act upon. But the direction is clear and commitment is clear...

Our capital, Luanda, today is full of business people of many nationalities. I regret to say there are fewer Americans than I would like to see. One of my messages today is to call on American businesspeople to come to Angola to invest and to participate in our economic future. It is a bright one, and I believe your participation can be helpful -- vital, in fact. We need capital. We need technology. We need training. We want American companies to be part of our future...

Although the US is Angola's largest trading partner, regrettably there are some barriers to the normal flow of commerce between Angola and the United States. These barriers are a remnant of the past. Hopefully, the US government will see fit to remove them. In fact, they clearly punish American companies more than they hurt the Angolan economy.

They also make US companies less competitive than companies from all other countries. And they have not responded to the changed political circumstances, either the Angolan ones or the international ones... I wonder how many of you are aware of the magnitude of lost business that US companies have needlessly suffered in Angola because of the punitive legislation passed in Washington. I wonder how many of you are aware of the magnitude of lost business with Angola that US companies have suffered because of these trade and investment restrictions...

I cannot end these barriers, but I call on you to do so. It is in your interests. There is much room to expand the friendship between our two countries and peoples.


LOAD-DATE: October 18, 1991


LANGUAGE: English

117 of 211 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


OCTOBER 21, 1991


RUNNING FOR PRESIDENT -- IN WASHINGTON


SECTION: DIPLOMACY: ANGOLA


LENGTH: 1027 words


Washington, D.C. -- The American presidential campaign may be slow getting started this year, but Angola's two main presidential contenders have wasted no time putting in appearances at all the right places in this political town.

In an indication of the importance of the U.S. role in their country, President Jose Eduardo dos Santos and his principal rival, Jonas Savimbi, have in recent weeks paid separate calls on President George Bush at the White House and on key Congressional leaders. Both also made partisan pitches at think tanks and other influential Washington institutions and met with important business figures.

Their visits took place against the backdrop of the end to a devastating civil war, which began at the time of Angolan independence from Portugal sixteen years ago and ended in May, when a peace accord was signed. Now the long-standing contest between dos Santos' ruling Popular Movement for the Liberation of Angola (MPLA) and Savimbi's National Union for the Total Independence of Angola (Unita) is moving from the battlefield to the polling both, with elections scheduled for late next year. 

For Savimbi, whose forces have been armed and supplied by the U.S. throughout much of the conflict, this month's trip to Washington, New York and Houston was a familiar stint. As he has done on a half dozen previous visits, the Unita leader asked for American backing and spoke of his commitment to a democratic future for his country.

This time, however, he said he did not come in search of money, although the Bush administration has pledged a continuation of covert U.S. assistance to ease Unita's transition from a guerrilla force to a political party. Rather, Savimbi said, he was seeking to ensure continued American attention to the peace process.

Without outside pressure, particularly from the U.S., Savimbi told reporters at a breakfast meeting in New York, "we will not have elections before 1993 or 1994."

But dos Santos, who was making his first Washington pilgrimage, gave assurances at every stop that elections will take place as scheduled. "We are determined to proceed along the course we have charted for ourselves," he said in several of his appearances. A specific date for the voting will be set after consultations with all the political parties, now numbering about 30, as called for in the peace accord, he said.

The controversy over an election date, reflecting the deep distrust which divides the two principal parties, is an outgrowth of a disagreement which delayed settlement for many months. The government originally sought a 36-month timetable, during which a census would be held, voters' rolls prepared, and campaigning would take place. But the compromise accord worked out with Portuguese mediation and the active involvement of the U.S. and USSR, states that the vote will take place between September and November of 1992.

Savimbi made clear his belief that he has been promised a September election, and he pressed his case against any later date. Speaking of his MPLA rivals, the Unita leader told reporters that "they want to delay to improve their image" prior to the election to improve their standing with voters. Savimbi, who said dos Santos fears an election loss, predicted that "if we have a free and fair election, Unita will win."

Both leaders made a point of appealing for American investment and trade. Addressing the U.S. Chamber of Commerce, dos Santos said Angola needs capital and technology and wants "American companies to be part of our future." At a time of "tremendous world change," Angola is changing as well, he said, an indirect reference to the close ties and extensive support the MPLA has received from both the Soviet Union and Cuba. "I do not hide the fact that I have been head of a socialist government," he said, "but we are a Marxist government no longer."

Savimbi sought to sow doubts about the MPLA's ideological conversion and argued that a Unita-led government would be far more hospitable to foreign investors than the present regime. Speaking to a business luncheon at the Overseas Private Investment Corporation here, he promised "privatization of all the land and enterprises confiscated by the government" and "a new law which will guarantee those investments."

On the future U.S. role in Angola, dos Santos said he had been assured by Bush of American neutrality in the election period. But in answer to questions at several stops, he admitted to some skepticism. The fact that the Congressional aid authorization for Angola includes a continuing covert component suggests, he said, "that we may be confronted by two conflicting American faces."

The leaders struck several similar notes. Both sought to rebut notions that their parties are regionally or ethnically based. And each emphasized that there is no possibility for a return to the state of war that their country has known for three decades, including the 15-year independence campaign that preceded independence.

Both trips were professionally managed by people knowledgeable about the way Washington works. The Angolan government, which previously has used a variety of public relations and lobbying agents -- often without coordination among them -- this time hired the respected Washington firm Hill and Knowlton to put together a busy four days of meetings. Arrangements for Savimbi were handled by Black, Manafort, Stone, and Kelly, the political consulting group that has represented Unita in Washington for a decade.

Meanwhile, the U.S. government has announced a new allocation of $ 6 million in emergency assistance for Angola. On October 1, at the beginning of the new fiscal year for the U.S., Assistant Secretary of State Herman Cohen re-issued a disaster declaration for Angola for the fourth year in succession. According to a situation report issued last week by the Office of U.S. Foreign Disaster Assistance at the State Department, the funds will be used to provide food supplies and to pay for an airlift of food and other needed supplies to 12 "severely stressed" centers, where Unita soldiers are being demobilized.


LOAD-DATE: October 18, 1991


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1991 AllAfrica, Inc.
