Africa News


OCTOBER 21, 1991


A HOME FOR HOMELY ART


LENGTH: 606 words


home'ly, a.; (ME. homli.)

1. originally, (a) of the home; domestic; (b) familiar; intimate; (c) fond of home.

2. characteristic of or suitable for home or home life; simple; plain; everyday; as, homely virtues. -- Webster's New Universal Unabridged Dictionary 

They've been sat on; they've been slept on; they've been carried." That, says curator Roslyn Walker, is part of the mystique of the pieces in the new permanent collection at the National Museum of African Art.

The collection, called "The Art of the Personal Object," is the third permanent exhibit to be installed since the museum opened four years ago in Washington, D.C. as part of the Smithsonian Institution. A fourth permanent collection -- "Purpose and Perfection: Pottery as a Women's Art in Central Africa" -- will open on January 15. The personal objects exhibit that opened September 25 has over 100 pieces used in everyday life, primarily from eastern and southern Africa. It is, says curator Walker, "the rest of the story" of traditional art. It is immediately obvious to the viewer, she says, that these objects,although very beautiful, are "art for domestic purposes rather than for ritual," in contrast to exhibits dominated by sacred pieces or emblems of office such as masks, staffs and anthropomorphic sculpture.

Philip L. Ravenhill, the African Art museum's chief curator, says that the pieces in the exhibit are "singular examples of both individual creativity and the creativity of African cultures." And he says that the origins of the objects makes the museum's collection more representative of the continent. East and southern Africa, he says, "have usually been underrepresented in both private and public collections of African art."

The bulk of the new exhibit was purchased in 1989 from colonial collections assembled in Great Britain.

There has been increasing interest among artists and art historians in what Ravenhill calls " the integration of aesthetics and daily life in Africa."

The Henry Ford Museum in Dearborn, Michigan has just opened an exhibit called "African-American Family Life and Culture" which features a gourd collection belonging to Duke University historian Peter Wood. Wood says West Africans brought gourds to the American south, where their use flourished in the 18th and 19th centuries. His collection includes two beaded shekeres, West African percussion instruments. Banjos -- originally an African instrument -- as well as drums and certain fiddles were all once made with gourds.

Durable and replaceable, gourds were "the plastic of the pre-modern world," Wood says. The ways they were decorated, he says, is yet another example of how frequently Africans made ornaments out of objects of daily use.

The African art museum's new collection vividly illustrates that phenomenon with a group of snuff containers from Zimbabwe, South Africa and Mozambique made from hard fruit shells trimmed with wire. The theme will be developed more fully in a 32-page booklet the Museum of African Art is publishing on the "personal objects" collection later this year and a booklet that will accompany the women's pottery exhibit.

So far this year, over 300,000 people have visited the museum. n

The Museum of African Art is trying to expand an appreciation for the diversity and sophistication of African artistic expression through a series of lectures, discussions, family programs and workshops for teachers. For information on the latter contact: Teacher Workshop, National Museum of African Art, 950 Independence Avenue, S.W., Washington, DC 20560, or phone (202) 357-4860.


LOAD-DATE: October 18, 1991


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1991 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


NOVEMBER 4, 1991


LITTLE BY LITTLE


LENGTH: 193 words


Another session of peace talks aimed at ending Liberia's 22-month long conflict has produced a long-awaited timetable for disarming and encamping all the warring parties. The agreement calls for elections to be held in six months. 

After a two-day summit in Yamoussoukro, the capital of Cote d'Ivoire, 12 of the 16 members of the Economic Community of West African States (Ecowas) endorsed an accord which will give control of all of Liberian territory to the West African peace-keeping forces known as Ecomog within 60 days.

Ecomog, which now polices only the capital Monrovia, will take charge of all border posts, sea and air ports, and checkpoints throughout the country. Rebel leader Charles Taylor, whose forces now hold most of the territory, agreed to accept the expansion of Ecomog's role during late-night bargaining and heavy pressure on Taylor from several west African heads of state who have supported him in the past.

A communique detailing the disarmament process is being prepared for release this week, Ivorian foreign ministry officials said. Once the disarmament has taken place, election preparations will intensify.


LOAD-DATE: November 4, 1991


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1991 AllAfrica, Inc.


120 of 211 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


NOVEMBER 4, 1991


TWO STEPS BACK?


LENGTH: 472 words


Tunisia appears to have taken a step towards human rights as it struggles to enter Africa's expanding democratic fold, but critics say its government has reneged on earlier commit-ments.

After seizing power from an aging and ailing Habib Bourguiba in 1987, President Zine al-Abidine Ben Ali freed thousands of political prisoners, most of them Islamic militants, who had been detained under Bourguiba's rule.

Ben Ali vowed to put the North African country on the road to democracy, and by 1989 he had legalized political pluralism and liberalized press freedom. He has also announced new measures of support for Tunisia's six legal opposition parties, including about $ 60,000 in financial assistance a year. 

However, Ben Ali has kept a tight control on the growth of Islamic fundamentalism and refuses to legalize the main Islamic opposition party, an-Nahda.

It is that issue which has some Tunisians saying Ben Ali's path to democracy is paved with good intentions but marred with abuse.

The human rights group Amnesty International has expressed its concern to the government over what it says is a deteriorating human rights situation in Tunisia in the past year. The group urged Tunis to investigate numerous allegations of torture of political detainees, mostly members or suspected members of an-Nahda.

In June 1991, Tunisian courts sentenced to death five an-Nahda members accused of attacking the ruling party headquarters in February this year. Eighteen others were sentenced to life or long prison terms.

On October 11, Amnesty said it "deeply regrets" the hangings and regreted that Ben Ali had rejected appeals for clemency despite his stated opposition to the death penalty. Former president Bourguiba advocated capital punishment, and Ben Ali used his own rejection of such measures as one of his justifications for seizing power. The first execution since 1987 was carried out last year, Amnesty said.

The Islamic issue is no longer solely a domestic concern. Tunisia last month said it was recalling its ambassador from Khartoum to protest what it said was Sudan's support of a coup attempt. Members of an-Nahda now face trial in Tunisia for the alleged plot to kill the president and members of his cabinet.

Tunisia, historically the most open of the Arab countries, is an unlikely place for Islamic fervor, and an-Nahda has shown signs of weakness. It split during the Gulf War; one group opposed to Iraq's Saddam Hussein sought to establish a new Islamic party which eschews religious absolutes and violence.

Some of an-Nahda's members left the group following the attack on the ruling party's offices, and Ben Ali immediately opened a dialogue with them. But whether he will follow in Algeria's steps and give Islamic fundamentalists a legal voice remains to be seen.


LOAD-DATE: November 4, 1991


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1991 AllAfrica, Inc.


121 of 211 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


NOVEMBER 4, 1991


SENDING A SIGNAL


SECTION: BITS AND PIECES


LENGTH: 312 words


Five members of the House Foreign Relations Committee have asked President George Bush to act immediately to "avoid unrest of tragic proportions" in Zaire by calling for the departure of President Mobutu Sese Seko. "We are troubled by the absence of any vigorous diplomatic effort by the United States to promote a peaceful and orderly transition process in Zaire," the five said in a letter to Bush last Wednesday. 

The letter was signed by Donald Payne (D-NJ), Dan Burton (R-IN), Amo Houghton (R-NY), Stephen Solarz (D-NY), and Howard Wolpe (D-MI), all members of the Foreign Relations Africa subcommittee. Mervyn Dymally (D-CA), the subcommittee chairman, did not join in the appeal. Payne also introduced a resolution supporting democratic change in Zaire and calling upon the administration to "use its influence to persuade President Mobutu to respect the wishes of the democratic forces in Zaire."

The lawmakers say it is "essential" to avoid a repetition of two earlier African crises, Liberia and Somalia, "where a hands-off American policy, combined with a refusal to insist on the departure of formerly U.S.-backed dictators Samuel Doe and Mohammed Siad Barre, contributed to the unraveling of the political fabric and ultimately to bloody fratricidal strife." And they called for a coordinated effort with Zaire's two other major backers, France and Belgium. On Friday, the last French paratroopers left Zaire, and Belgium promised a quick pullout of its remaining forces after it oversees the evacuation of the last of more than 20,000 foreigners fleeing the country.

Opposition leaders pleaded for foreign troops to stay to prevent massive bloodshed.

The legislators' letter asks Bush to back peace-keeping efforts and to urge the French and Belgians to remain "until an appropriate international peace-keeping force" can be organized.


LOAD-DATE: November 4, 1991


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1991 AllAfrica, Inc.


122 of 211 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


NOVEMBER 4, 1991


MADAGASCAR: COMPROMISE BREAKS DEADLOCK


LENGTH: 1030 words


Madagascar's government and opposition have agreed to form an 18-month transitional administration. Last week's accord came just days after the military hinted that it might take matters into its own hands unless a five-month political stalemate was unblocked.

The island nation has suffered a series of sector-specific strikes since early June to pressure President Didier Ratsiraka to resign and to win reform. Defense Minister Philippe Ramakavelo called the deadlock "collective suicide." 

In the deal, which apparently leaves Ratsiraka in power, Prime Minister Guy Razanamasy and the opposition's shadow government promised a referendum on a new constitution before the end of the year.

The referendum would include changes to electoral laws and would be followed by presidential elections, the two sides said in a statement broadcast on state radio.

Ratsiraka -- who had ruled Madagascar for 14 years before he was re-elected in a 1989 vote the opposition claims was rigged -- had agreed to talks on electoral and constitutional reforms, but he has refused to step down.

On October 24, about 50,000 people thronged the center of Antananarivo, the capital, for a religious service to mark the end of prolonged strikes that economists say has left some industries bankrupt.

The return to work represents "a new form of struggle," not weakness, an opposition spokesman told Radio France Internationale, and reflects a desire to "make our government effective." But, he said the opposition would continue to stage peaceful mass rallies in Antananarivo which has seen demonstrations attracting hundreds of thousands of people.

At least two people were killed and about a dozen others wounded October 24 in the northern town of Antsiranana when demonstrators clashed with security forces near the residence of the provincial governor, Amnesty International said last week.

That violence was the worst since August 10 when troops guarding the presidential palace opened fire on thousands of demonstrators. At least 31 people were killed.

The 16-party opposition coalition, known as Forces Vives, has already effectively seized a large degree of autonomy from the government, declaring five of the country's six regions "federated states." In August it named a shadow government to lead the island's 10 million people.

The military, which has maintained political neutrality in the conflict, had been growing increasingly frustrated with the protracted deadlock.

On October 26, the armed forces warned that they would step in if an agreement on forming a government capable of restoring confidence was not reached soon.

"The armed forces solemnly declare they will take their responsibilities to preserve public order and defend the nation's vital interests," Reuters news agency quoted a broadcast statement by General Ramakavelo as saying.

His comments appeared to signal the growing possibility of a military takeover to end the political deadlock between Ratsiraka's regime and the Forces Vives.

International aid donors and creditors, who want to see Madagascar back on what they judged a largely successful track of economic reform, had also expressed their frustration over Madagascar's political crisis. "Ratsiraka's government is under no illusion that donors and creditors will not come into the picture" if economic reform continues to slacken, an International Monetary Fund (IMF) official, speaking on condition of anonymity, said last week.

Donors and creditors communicated this sentiment to Malagasy government representatives at the recent annual World Bank and IMF meetings in Bangkok, the official said. That pressure provided further incentive for Ratsiraka to move to break the political impasse.

"The international community expects the process of democratization to accelerate before resuming financial and economic assistance," says the IMF official. Opposition parties were legalized in the former French colony last year.

In the view of donors, the Indian Ocean nation was just beginning to show real signs of growth stemming from Ratsiraka's economic reform program when the unrest erupted. A flood of economic aid poured in after the formerly Socialist leader sold off some state firms, lifted state controls on domestic and foreign trade and liberalized laws on private banking and investment. In 1989 and 1990, some $ 18.2 million were invested in Madagascar, according to theLondon-based newsletter, Africa Confidential.

But the recent strife has made investors wary, economists say. The Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries (OPEC) has put on hold a plan to send a team of potentitial investors to meetings in Bangkok warning that the country was bankrupt. He said state wages -- $ 20 million for the government staff and the military -- could not be paid because the crisis had completely emptied government coffers. The average per capita income already is one of the world's lowest, about $ 225 a year.

"How far short they are of the economic targets we established -- no one can know," the IMF official says. National output will likely be "a lot less," he adds.

But he downplayed reports of severe damage to the island's economy.

"The damage to economic infrastructure is minimal because there hasn't been large-scale violence in this political turmoil," he said. "It hasn't taken that much of a beating. Nobody has burned buildings, or factories. People haven't gone crazy on property, so far."

About 85% of the population works in agriculture, and tourism is an important industry.

Some government workers went back to their jobs at the end of October. But the IMF official says that is "nothing to get excited about" because fluctuations in attendance are normal during such periods of unrest.

But if there are no paychecks, the situation could deteriorate, says the political analyst. "You know, if you don't pay the workers -- that's what happened in Zaire." Zairian soldiers went on a looting rampage in September after not receiving their pay, sparking a showdown between the government and pro-democracy forces that has left the country in turmoil. n


LOAD-DATE: November 4, 1991


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1991 AllAfrica, Inc.


123 of 211 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


NOVEMBER 4, 1991


ZAIRE FIDDLING WHILE ZAIRE CRUMBLES


SECTION: AROUND THE CONTINENT


LENGTH: 926 words


Brussels -- President Mobutu Sese Seko of Zaire defies everybody.

Twenty thousand foreigners have fled the turmoil in his country; Belgium and France, who have backed him for 25 years, are now pressing him to compromise with his opponents; the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund have cut off their loans; and his own people are determined that he will leave.

But Mobutu has thumbed his nose at them all. He has dismissed Etienne Tshisekedi wa Malumba, the popular prime minister he was forced to appoint last month by pro-democracy demonstrators. In Tshisekedi's place, Mobutu appointed another former political rival, Mungul Diaka. The new Zaire cabinet, intended by government opponents to be part of a transition towards democratic rule, leaves several key ministries -- defense, foreign affairs and mines and planning -- firmly in Mobutu's grip. As a result, he still has authority to ask the bank to give him money, to nominate ambassadors from among those still loyal to him, and to control any remaining foreign assistance. 

Meanwhile, the country is in shambles. A national conference, finally held during the summer at the insistence of Mobutu's opponents, attempted both to design future institutions for Zaire and to fix responsibilities for past problems. There were high hopes among the diverse political and civic groups which demanded the meeting that Mobutu's political career was finished.

This proved to be a serious miscalculation: Mobutu apparently is uninterested in going into exile at one of his luxury mansions in Morocco, France or Switzerland. He still considers himself the father, the "Guide," of Zaire and intends to cling to power as long as he can. His skillful manipulation of the conference showed his intentions.

Of the more than 4,000 delegates who assembled in the Palace of the People in Kinshasa, Zaire's capital, the majority were fake opponents, representatives of fake citizen organizations or open Mobutu followers. Mobutu's agents openly "bought" consciences by distributing huge sums of money to delegates. That wasn't a difficult feat -- the government had money printed in Zurich and flown to Zaire. The rate of inflation rose to 3,000 percent for the year, further eroding salaries and wages of soldiers and civil servants.

Orchestrated by Mobutu and badly organized, the national conference collapsed. The Union Sacree, a grouping of the main opposition parties, pulled out of the meetings.

How has Mobutu again eluded what had seemed to be an opposition stranglehold?

The man is a gambler. This time he gambled with the army. In early September, a mutiny in Kinshasa saw soldiers looting warehouses, shops and houses of foreigners, prompting France and Belgium to send troops to protect their nationals. There is evidence that the soldiers wages had been witheld intentionally by the government, in the expectation that foreign intervention would stabilize the regime, as has happened so often in the past.

But it is possible that this time it is Mobutu himself who has miscalculated. Perhaps he had not expected the revolt to spread so quickly throughout the country nor the pressures against him to be so strong. Instead of backing him as they did during an intervention 12 years ago, France and Belgium insisted that Mobutu deal with Tshisekedi.

The compromise that resulted in the naming of Tshisekedi as prime minister, after long and painful negotiations, lasted only two days. Mobutu's claim that he was dismissing his rival for not respecting the constitution is believed by nobody.

The real story is this: two days after Tshisekedi's appointment, Mobutu asked the national bank of Zaire for his usual disbursement of a million dollars. But this time the governor of the bank asked the approval of the finance minister, who refused.

Because money is the lifeblood of the Mobutu system of governing, the president cannot survive in power without free access to the bank. The riots and lootings that followed Tshisekedi's dismissal have spread, and most foreign nationals have now been evacuated, leaving the Zaire people to suffer the consequences.

At this stage, the Zaire army is playing no political role. It is like a wild dog out of control, looting and threatening civilians, destroying infrastructure and factories. Soldiers are stealing, generals participate in the looting, and nobody seems able to monitor or temper their actions. Mobutu himself, protected by his well-armed presidential guard, holds onto power.

Was it really possible for Zairians to oust Mobutu? Belgians and French were expecting him to leave, but an OK from the U.S. was not forthcoming. Washington decision-makers still believe, against all evidence, that Mobutu is in charge, that he is a guarantor of stability. Behind this odd view may be the 30-year friendship between Mobutu and the Central Intelligence Agency, whose projects he has supported in such places as Angola and Chad.

U.S. officials have kept a remarkably low profile during the latest Zaire crisis. While Melissa Wells, the ambassador in Kinshasa, was very active during the summer, pressuring for human rights, she has been silent this autumn.

Many Zaire watchers fear that the U.S., preoccupied by the Middle East and other issues, will delay action on Zaire until it becomes too late to influence events. Mobutu may still be there, but he will sit atop a smashed opposition and a destroyed country.

-- Colette Braeckman reports on Africa for the Belgian newspaper Le Soir.


LOAD-DATE: November 4, 1991


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1991 AllAfrica, Inc.


124 of 211 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


NOVEMBER 4, 1991


ERITREA: AHEADINESS OF PEACE


SECTION: CONFLICT


LENGTH: 2661 words


The fall of the Ethiopian government in Addis Ababa at the end of May brought three decades of war to an end for the people of Eritrea, who stubbornly resisted incorporation by two successive Ethiopian regimes.

Now formally autonomous -- until a referendum to decide the future is held in two years -- Eritrea is establishing its own administration. The scheduled vote will allow Eritreans to choose between independence and becoming part of Ethiopia.

As a former Italian colony, Eritrea was entrusted to Ethiopian government control by the United Nations at the end of World War II. It was formally annexed in 1962 by Ethiopian Emperor Haile Selassie, sparking an independence campaign led by guerrillas of the Eritrean People's Liberation Front (EPLF). 

The military rulers who ousted Selassie in 1974 continued the war to stamp out the independence movement. Fighting continued until five months ago, when the forces of Ethiopian President Mengistu Haile Mariam collapsed before the combined advance of the EPLF and an anti-government coalition of Ethiopian groups which now administers a transitional administration in Addis Ababa, the Ethiopian capital.

The process of creating a functioning state in Eritrea is fraught with difficulties, not the least of which is the problem of economic viability in a territory the size of England with a third the number of people as London.

Some actions of the new administration have come under criticism. There have been reports that Eritrean authorities refused to allow Addis Ababa-based diplomats to visit the territory and that relief workers from the International Committee of the Red Cross and other groups have been forced to leave, because they served in the capital, Asmara, when it was still held by the Ethiopian army.

Press accounts of the weeks following the EPLF takeover told of Ethiopian families who lived in Asmara being forced to flee, leaving all their possessions behind. There were also stories that the surrendering Ethiopian soldiers from the Asmara garrison were force-marched back to Ethiopian lines without food or water.

The following eyewitness account of early nation-building efforts presents another view. It was written by Karen Hauser, development and outreach director of the New York-based Eritrean Relief Committee, which has been working with the EPLF to provide assistance to the territory since 1976. Hauser was one of a handful of foreigners in Eritrea from mid-July to mid-August, visiting towns, farms and health facilities, as well as water, reforestation and food distribution projects.

I arrived in Eritrea just six weeks after the end of the war and of Ethiopian rule -- an extraordinary, jubilant moment in Eritrea's history.

The feeling of new freedom is palpable on the streets, in shops, and in homes. To a visitor it seems as if 3.5 million persons held hostage for a generation have suddenly been set free. There is an atmosphere of celebration: relief resonates in the air, joy lights every face. "We are so happy now," are the first syllables of every greeting.

Ethiopian administrators "told us they would burn the city and leave only ashes behind," one Asmara woman said. "We knew our children would come to free us, but sometimes we didn't know if we would survive until they got here." Living became like waiting to die.

And still there is a sense of disbelief that their 30-year ordeal is over and that, in Asmara, (the Eritrean capital) the end came without bloodshed. "Pinch me so I'll know I'm not dreaming," is a common refrain.

On several occasions I witnessed truckloads of EPLF fighters arriving in Asmara from other areas. People spilled out of stores and homes to greet them with cheers. One afternoon I watched a convoy of trucks pass by from the fourth-floor balcony of a downtown hotel, and could see women, men and children jogging through the streets from blocks all around to join the welcome. The hotel housekeeper cried with joy as she leaned out the window.

The outpouring was spontaneous, intimate, genuine. I was reminded of World War II film clips showing allied forces rolling into Nazi-occupied Europe.

Eritrea is bouncing back to life like a garden blossoming in spring. Within 48 hours of assuming control, the EPLF provisional government restored electricity throughout the city and began work to rehabilitate the municipal water system and intra-Eritrea long distance telephone service.

The government lifted the curfew and restrictions on travel. It released all political prisoners. It is establishing a system for returning private property that the Mengistu government had nationalized. Within a week, factories had resumed operations.

Perhaps most importantly, there are no longer trigger-happy Ethiopian soldiers standing at every corner and at the lookout posts built above every sidewalk. There is no longer need to fear for one's basic safety.

The high energy of freedom translates into a bustle of activity. People are on the move everywhere. Mothers, fathers, children, and grandparents are taking pure delight in being able to go where they want, when they want, how they want, with whom they want. Every evening in Asmara, folks stroll down the boulevards with arms linked, stopping for coffee or fruit juice in the cafes that helped make the city famous, chatting in a way that cements the society on its most human level.

Cars, bicycles, donkeys, horses drawing carts and carriages, and castor-wheeled dollies called cuchinetas vie for space on the Asmara streets. They compete with the pedestrians who still feel safer walking on the streets because the lovely patterned-tile sidewalks were frequently off limits -- in order to "secure" buildings with military sensitivity or any neighborhood where a ranking officer might have been visiting.

Besides, people still aren't too used to vehicles, as there had been no fuel for the previous year and a half. And bicycles -- because they could be used for 'subversive' activities -- were sometimes outlawed, and always ridden legally by no one but the owner, who had to carry the bicycle registration along with his identity card.

Commercial activity had slowed considerably in the Ethiopian-controlled enclave over the past year and a half due to limited or unavailable electricity, fuel and raw materials.

With constraints lifted, urban markets that had been empty are now stocked with tomatoes, potatoes, peppers, onions, and fruits, among other foodstuffs, which farmers bring in fresh from the rural areas every morning.

In both urban and rural Eritrea, most people are deeply impoverished.

'Our country is free but she has been left naked,' one man said. Outward signs of poverty are everywhere. In general people look haggard, even gaunt. It is common knowledge that some people do not eat every day. Many wear frayed and torn clothing. Beggars, including children, dot the streets. Too many people are crowded into small living spaces. In the market, old women and children scour the ground picking up fallen grains.

The poverty is striking to Eritreans returning home after many years abroad. They remember Asmara as a gleaming city whose residents strolled in bright white clothes, whose buildings were painted yearly by mandate of a municipal ordinance, whose sidewalk tiles were replaced the day they cracked, whose hardworking people were always working.

But the severity of the recent droughts is clear. Four fifths of the entire Eritrean populace is now surviving on external food aid.

The Eritrean Relief Association (ERA) -- the only private voluntary organization that operated in EPLF-controlled areas during the war -- is overseeing relief activities from its new Asmara headquarters. According to ERA's acting relief coordinator, the ERA to date has received 121,000 metric tons of food aid. This is only one third of the request for aid made before the end of the war for part of the population. The World Food Program and the European Economic Community have pledged help but there remains a serious deficit.

The ERA is maintaining no stockpiles of food aid; food is transported to distribution centers as soon as it arrives. "There are many empty distribution centers," one ERA logistics coordinator lamented.

ERA offices around the country are reporting to headquarters that their beneficiaries are running out of food. "They are asking for more," said the acting relief coordinator, "but we just don't have any more to send them."

Meanwhile, the ERA is trying to phase out its use of port facilities in neighboring Sudan so as to rely exclusively on Massawa, the Eritrean port city, as quickly as possible.

All facilities at Massawa are in urgent need of repair. Most warehouses at the port were damaged in the fighting. The cranes need spare parts and the generators must be replaced. The deepwater frontage and docks need rehabilitation and associated roadways need resurfacing.

The provisional government's economic development plans flow from those previously laid out by the EPLF. The new government clearly intends to cultivate a mixture of public and private ownership of economic resources. But it has inherited an infrastructure in which the previous government controlled all sectors -- including, for instance, the distribution and showing of entertainment films -- and planning for selective privatization will be a gigantic venture.

Government planners have defined agriculture as the nation's highest development priority. Eighty percent of the Eritrean population lives directly off the land as farmers and herders. Helping them recover their self-reliance and improve their capacity for production are key to Eritrea's stability and to developing food security. The agricultural development policy is broad and will focus on rehabilitating damaged lands as well as providing seeds, tools and livestock.

Already, agricultural activities are in full swing, despite the setback caused by late rain. I found a powerful determination to cultivate wherever possible, whatever possible, however possible. If there was any chance that cereal or legume crops would grow, farm families were plowing and planting. Sometimes this meant taking the brave step of sacrificing food for seeds.

Livestock health appears to be poor. Most of the oxen I observed are quite thin; some are nearly skeletal. The grasses that sprouted with the recent rainfall have come just in time, and herd owners are working to bring back animals that seem on the brink of death. Many of the oxen I saw plowing were very weak for the job, and in one case the pair could barely keep moving.

Landmines are a major problem. Sadly, war casualties are continuing even after the end of the war. Every day people trip some of the hundreds of thousands -- if not millions -- of landmines that the Ethiopian army left across Eritrea. Twenty to 25 persons with landmine injuries arrive at the Adi Caieh hospital each month. Most of them are children who were herding the family's animals.

Health facilities throughout Eritrea are in poor shape. Visiting the Central Hospital in Asmara as an out-patient, I had to walk clear across the hospital grounds to find a usable lavatory. Ethiopian soldiers had filled the toilets with pebbles and stones to block the plumbing. The antiquated pharmacy had fewer supplies than any corner drug store in the U.S., and is in no way adequate to serve a modern urban population center.

The physical reminders of conflict are ever-present. A drive along any of Eritrea's highways is an eery lesson in war's destructive power. Hulks of burned and destroyed tanks, armored personnel carriers, jeeps, and lorries litter the roads and adjoining fields.

Shell casings and heavy demolition bomb fins are also scattered across the land. In areas near recent battles -- more precisely, at Ethiopian army positions -- there are sometimes piles of heavy gauge bullets and even hand grenades. One can also follow the trail of the Ethiopian army by the hills of empty ration tins it left behind -- which I saw in the south, in the west, and in the east, some rusted, some glinting in the sun.

Highway scenes also include damaged and destroyed buildings -- pockmarked shops, churches and mosques, homes with just a wall or two standing.

A huge percentage of the buildings in Massawa are damaged or destroyed. One cannot walk for two minutes without seeing bombed structures. Having no other option, residents still live and work in the damaged buildings. We ate in a small restaurant that also once included a bar. The waitress who delivered the hot spaghetti with spicy sauce passed through what used to be the game room on her way to the kitchen, walking past twisted metal supports jutting from the door-sized hole in the wall, under a ceiling fan swinging low from torn plaster, past rubble topping the billiard table.

At the Asmara airport, unused bomb casings are still piled against the sides of small concrete bunkers, ready for loading. The Ethiopian army left this war like a cook walking out with dinner simmering on the stove.

There is a strong nationalist element in the rejoicing over the end of Ethiopian rule. There is a clear sense of Ethiopia as "the other." There is also a clear sense of Ethiopia as "the enemy," an agent of unspeakable suffering. An important question, it seems to me, is whether this energy can be channeled into something positive. Can the concept of "the enemy" be transferred to underdevelopment, to poverty, to injustice, to illiteracy?

The EPLF/provisional government of Eritrea has treated Ethiopian civilians living in Eritrea and ex-soldiers with restraint and provided for them as well as possible given the resources available at the time.

Upon returning from Eritrea, I was shocked and saddened to read press accusations of the provisional government "expelling" Ethiopians and mistreating the ex-soldiers it held as POWs.

While the situation with the Ethiopian ex-soldiers was far from ideal, I feel strongly that the international community needs to judge the EPLF according to full and contextually comprehensive information.

Of the 140,000 or more Ethiopian soldiers stationed in Eritrea, about 80,000 surrendered to the EPLF and the rest withdrew from Eritrea. Contrary to accusations, the EPLF provided transportation to every Ethiopian asked to leave Eritrea, civilian or military. No one was forced to walk.

The commanding officers of the Ethiopian Army made no logistical arrangements for the retreat from Eritrea. While some officers rode in vehicles, the enlisted men embarked on a treacherous foot journey to the Sudan -- many days walk through semi-desert with no food or water. Hundreds of thousands of ex-soldiers perished. Although the EPLF and local communities had been burying the corpses, many still remained when I traveled along the road from Sudan. In places there were one or two bodies resting under the shade of almost every tree.

Eritreans with whom I was traveling felt a mixture of rage and pity toward these dead soldiers. Looking at their uniforms one had to remember atrocities that the Ethiopian army committed in Eritrea -- the bombings, the bayonettings, the bestiality. But, as individuals, the dead evoked a deep sadness -- many were young conscripts, peasant boys whose lives were badly twisted into violence and who were ultimately betrayed by their leaders.

Many Eritreans feel enmity towards the specific instruments of Ethiopian power in Eritrea. But there is also a sense of empathy with other Ethiopians, who also suffered under years of repressive governments. Most importantly, I found a great hope that the "new Ethiopia" will behave differently toward Eritrea, and that conditions would now allow for Eritreans and Ethiopians to get along and to trade with one another as good neighbors.

n


LOAD-DATE: November 4, 1991


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


NOVEMBER 4, 1991


GOT A FEVER IN FLORIDA? COULD IT BE MALARIA?


LENGTH: 370 words


It's going much too far, scientists say, to pack malaria prophalaxis for a Florida or California vacation. Almost all the 1,100 malaria cases in the United States that were reported to the Centers for Disease Control last year were contracted abroad.

Still, there are occasional incidents of malaria transmission to people who have not traveled overseas nor had blood transfusions. In San Diego, the county health department has conducted investigations into local transmission in each of the last three years, including an outbreak that struck 30 people in 1988. Many of those cases are attributed to poverty and lack of health care among temporary residents from malarious areas. But last year, a teenage boy living in a San Diego suburb and a woman in southern Florida were diagnosed with malaria, and researchers have been unable to trace the origins of either illness. 

For some time, doctors have been concerned that the current spread of malaria to areas where it has never been seen before is a harbinger of its return to areas where it had been eradicated. In a global culture, no country can isolate itself completely from international health problems.

The National Academy of Science's Institute of Medicine cites the summer of 1989, when five Swiss citizens were diagnosed with malaria over a two-week period. All five lived within a mile of the Geneva International Airport and medical investigations suggested that the "mini-epidemic" was caused by stowaway mosquitoes on planes landing at the airport.

In the United States, the relative freedom from malaria is a newer phenomenon than many Americans realize. As recently as the early 1900s, there were 500,000 reported cases, mostly in the south, although earlier cases were widespread. Boston, for example, had a particularly severe epidemic in the 17th century.

However, malaria was virtually eradicated from the U.S. in a five-year campaign ending in 1952 -- and for all practical purposes, that situation is likely to continue. While American travelers are increasingly at risk, the Centers for Disease Control's Dr. Hans Lobel predicts that cases transmitted within the U.S. will remain "more a curiosity than a threat."

n


LOAD-DATE: November 4, 1991


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1991 AllAfrica, Inc.


126 of 211 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


NOVEMBER 4, 1991


MALARIA MAKES A DEADLY COMEBACK


SECTION: HEALTH


LENGTH: 1435 words


 

Malaria has made a dramatic worldwide resurgence in recent years, causing illness and death at almost unprecedented levels, especially in sub-Saharan Africa, according to scientists studying the disease.

The nearly 300 million people now infected with malaria is double the number of cases of a decade ago and the World Health Organization (WHO) says that more than half the world's population is facing a malaria threat.

International efforts to eradicate the disease have waned, drugs no longer kill some species of the parasite and insecticides are increasingly ineffective on malaria-bearing mosquitoes.

The outlook for controlling malaria "is grim," says the National Academy of Sciences in a report released last month. "Unless practical, cost-effective strategies can be developed and successfully implemented, malaria will continue to exact a heavy toll on human life and health around the world," the academy's Institute of Medicine says in "Malaria: Obstacles and Opportunities." 

For Africa, this is particularly bad news. More than 85% of malaria deaths worldwide occur in Africa, says Dr. Richard Stecketee, the chief of malaria, epidemiology and control activity at the Centers for Disease Control's (CDC) malaria branch.

The disease also threatens to bring Africa's children closer to Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndrome (AIDS), says Robert Desowitz in his new book, "The Malaria Capers." Blood for transfusions used to treat severe anemia caused by acute childhood malaria is often tainted with the virus that causes AIDS, says Desowitz, professor of tropical medicine and medical microbiology at the University of Hawaii.

Last month, WHO called for renewed global action to fight malaria, and health experts from around the world met in Brazzaville, Congo, for the first of three regional conferences to begin discussing a strategy to combat the disease.

Next October, government ministers from malaria-affected countries will meet in Amsterdam to discuss the regional recommendations and develop an international strategy to combat malaria's rise.

Dr. Carlos C. Campbell, the chief of the malaria branch at CDC, returned from the Brussels conference last week. He says that while there were no surprising initiatives during the five-day meeting, there were important discussions about how to fit malaria control efforts into the complex set of programs and priorities for Africa's future. Among the main topics of debate was the need for new treatment guidelines resulting from the spread of malaria strains resistant to chloroquine, currently the most widely used drug for both prevention and treatment. "We can now show very clearly," Campbell says, "that in many places we shouldn't be using chloroquine as a first-line therapy."

Malaria infects some 270 million people annually -- more than the entire population of the United States. Over two billion people are at risk of the disease in 120 countries, including 250 million in Africa alone, says Dr. Hans Lobel, the chief of malaria surveillance for the CDC.

Malaria kills about 1.5 million people each year. Most are children and many have been infected with malaria several times before their first birthday, Lobel says. Survivors can build up a partial immunity to the disease.

Malaria -- from the Italian mal aria, or bad air -- may have surfaced as long as a million years ago, some experts estimate. Romans associated fevers with stagnant water holes, where mosquitoes breed, and pioneered swamp drainage. In modern times, malaria was considered "the American disease," until the 1940s, according to Desowitz. Now the bane of the developing world, malaria is "the most important disease of humans" in terms of sheer numbers, he says.

Malaria is caused by a parasite that enters the blood through a mosquito bite and lodges in the liver. The parasite then attacks and bursts red blood cells, releasing more parasites and causing fever, chills, vomiting, diarrhea and sometimes death.

In 1957, WHO endorsed an extensive effort to wipe out the disease, including blanketing mosquito-infested areas with the insecticide DDT. It was during that decade that chloroquine was developed for widespread use as a prophylactic to prevent the disease and as a treatment to cure it.

The availability of both a new drug and a potent insecticide fostered a widespread perception that malaria could be reduced as other tropical diseases such as yellow fever and typhoid had been. Infection dropped dramatically in less temperate zones and isolated island nations.

But by 1961, after the world had spent $ 100 million dollars in eradication efforts the previous year alone. Health experts considered the magnitude of Africa's malaria problem and the lack of technological capability needed to carry out the effort insurmountable.

"Nobody ever has proposed to eradicate malaria from Africa," says Lobel.

Africans are particularly vulnerable to malaria because the most dangerous of the four species of human malaria parasites, Plasmodium falciparum, thrives in tropical areas of the continent. Falciparum can lead to cerebral malaria that can develop rapidly and accelerate to convulsions, coma and death. Africa is also home to the virulent Anopheles gambiae mosquito that is becoming increasingly resistant to DDT.

"It's all over the place" in Africa, Lobel says of this mosquito. It needs little space to breed and can make a water-filled hoofprint or footprint its home.

Scientists and doctors agree that eradication is not the answer to fighting malaria today.

"It can be done, but it is resource intensive," says Stecketee. "In Africa, we're dealing with many places that are resource poor."

More energy needs to be spent on research and controlling the disease, doctors say.

The Institute of Medicine suggests a range of actions: educating affected populations about treatment to prevent severe illness and death; promoting personal protection measures such as insecticide-treated bednets; encouraging community-wide mosquito control such as draining small bodies of water where mosquitoes breed; and considering higher cost measures such as large-scale insecticide spraying.

In Gambia, one recent experiment, with bednets impregnated with insecticide, reported in the British medical journal Lancet earlier this year, reduced child deaths from the disease by 70%. But, to be effective, the nets must be used properly and widely within communities. If not, unprotected people will be more likely to contract malaria because mosquitoes will be diverted to them, says WHO.

Malawi is one of the first countries experimenting with new measures to treat the disease. Instead of using chloroquine, it will administer sulfadoxine pyrimethamine. The program is funded by the U.S. Agency for International Development (AID) and is being implemented by the Malawi Health Ministry, says Stecketee. The new drug -- at 13 cents a dose compared to nine cents a dose for chloroquine -- nevertheless is inexpensive relative to other medicine available to treat malaria.

Among other experiments underway, WHO and U.S. Army doctors have refined a drug that Chinese healers have used for 2,000 years -- an extract known as arteether from the quinghao plant -- to treat malaria. Tests are scheduled to begin in the Netherlands, but the remedy may not be ready for widespread use for another 10 years, WHO says.

Meanwhile, scientists continue to pressure research on a malaria vaccine. Some steps have been made, but Lobel says: "I think the picture is not very rosy, that's for sure."

Dr. Stephen Hoffman, director of the malaria program at the Naval Medical Research Institute, is slightly more hopeful. "We're making slow, steady progress and feel we will succeed," he says. "The question of 'when' would be stupid to answer at this point."

Charles Carpenter, the Institute of Medicine's malaria committee chairman, says because drugs and insecticides offer no permanent panacea, vaccines are particularly attractive. "We're down to our last drugs," he says in the report. "Fewer institutions are working in drug development, and research funding for that purpose is also dropping. The problem is only getting worse."

Human test vaccines have protected only half of those immunized, according to a report in the May issue of Science News. And although a test vaccine completely protected a group of mice from infections, a human vaccine is far off, says Hoffman. "It's a long jump from there to human vaccines, but it was a long jump just to get to mice," he says.


LOAD-DATE: November 4, 1991


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1991 AllAfrica, Inc.


127 of 211 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


NOVEMBER 4, 1991


COTE D'IVOIRE AID AIMED AT EASING HARD TIMES


LENGTH: 1828 words


Abidjan -- School enrollment in Toumanguie, a small village of 950 people about 80 miles from this West African metropolis, has dropped in each of the past two years. "It has been very difficult for parents," says Jeanne Kamara Donontio, a nurse from the village who works in Abidjan but spends many weekends promoting develop-

ment projects among Toumanguie's women. "The farmers have not been able to send their children to school because they lack the funds for school fees, uniforms and notebooks."

Toumanguie's problems are a sign of the times in Cote d'Ivoire, a former French colony usually called 'the Ivory Coast' in English. Despite the fact that it has one of Africa's most developed economies, the country now finds itself in the grip of the serious recession that afflicts the entire continent. 

But there are indications that the painful economic reforms implemented by the government are winning some of the outside assistance needed to mitigate the crisis. A $ 113 million stand-by credit has been approved by theInternational Monetary Fund (IMF), and two major World Bank loans are expected to be finalized this month.

Over the past decade, living standards in almost all of Africa have plummeted as a result of deteriorating trade terms, falling commodity prices and failed economic policies, many of them urged on African governments by a variety of foreign advisors. From 1980 to 1990, average real incomes in Africa dropped by more than 25%.

The resulting increase in human suffering has given new impetus to demands for an end to totalitarian rule in most of the continent's 54 countries and has spurred political changes in Africa on an unprecedented scale. Already this year, pro-democracy campaigns have forced at least 20 formerly autocratic regimes to hold elections, share power, or leave office. More than 30 countries are implementing some form of economic reform program supervised by the IMF and World Bank.

The impact of economic decline is evident in this seaside city of tall skyscrapers and wide boulevards. Although the modernity is striking in contrast to almost everywhere in Africa, signs of widespread deprivation are readily apparent. Unemployment is mounting, and living standards are falling for all sectors of the society. Average income is about $ 790, down from nearly $1,000 adecade ago.

Immigrants and itinerant workers from throughout the region, who make up at least a quarter of the country's population of 12 million, have been especially hard hit by the slowdown, as has the large peasant population.

The sizeable middle class has felt the pinch as well. No longer able to afford many of the consumer goods that were once considered standard many now struggle to meet daily needs.

"Ivory Coast has been so prosperous, Ivorians have been so rich compared to all of our neighbors, they feel our conditions of living should be high no matter what happens," says Prime Minister Alassane Ouattara, a former International Monetary Fund official and central banker who was placed in the job a year ago by President Felix Houphouet-Boigny to rescue the country from its crisis state.

Houphouet-Boigny, who has governed since independence in 1960 and is Africa's longest-serving head of state, last year became one of the continent's first entrenched leaders to yield to pro-democracy demands when he legalized opposition parties and newspapers after several months of unprecedented strikes and demonstrations, just in time for constitutionally mandated elections in October and November.

After the president and his party won handily at the polls, the unrest died down. But the downward slide of the economy continued, as the prices of coffee and cocoa, Cote d'Ivoire's leading export earners, remained at record lows on the world market. Street protests resumed in May.

Ouattara's efforts to restore the country's economic health have come up against some tough realities. It is difficult to implement the painful austerity measures required to win the support of international donors without fueling domestic dissatisfaction and alienating government supporters.

Ouattara says he has tried to secure popular approval for economic reforms by sending "all kinds of signals" that the government is shouldering its share of the hardship. The number of ministries has been reduced, limits have been placed on spending by government ministers and on the number of cars at their disposal. The civil service is being trimmed.

"We have tried to help our people understand that we have become poor because of the decline in raw materials prices, the decline in export receipts, and the decline in economic growth," the prime minister said in a lengthy interview reviewing his first year in office. "We have to live within our means, but after being prosperous for 25 years, this is very difficult to achieve," he said.

The recent breakthrough with the IMF has given Ouattara some much-needed operating space. Getting Fund support for the government's financial program was not easy, since Cote d'Ivoire has been unable to keep up its end of two other recent IMF agreements. But IMF approval was the necessary precursor to attracting assistance from other financial institutions and donor governments.

Just days after the IMF arrangement was announced, the U.S. government gave the go-ahead for a new $ 23 million economic aid package for Cote d'Ivoire,primarily for a five-year health and family planning program. "We know that Ouattara is an efficient technician and manager," says one senior U.S. policymaker, interviewed by telephone in Washington, D.C. "Whether the government will really tighten up and push ahead with what needs to be done remains to be seen."

One of the new World Bank loans will provide $ 200 million over two years for the government's financial program, while the other will finance human resource development and improved economic competitiveness. Half of the financial sector loan will come from a special World Bank fund, the International Development Association (IDA), which makes loans at below-market concessional rates for developing countries. Until this year, Cote d'Ivoire was not eligible for IDA lending, but Ouattara, during a visit to Washington in June, negotiated a reclassification based on the country's current economic difficulties.

To qualify for the IMF stand-by credit, the government has implemented a series of reforms, including a 25% reduction in government spending, privatization of the water and electricity companies, and cuts in customs duties and fees which have been seen as obstacles to trade and investment.

Cutbacks affecting the civil service are particularly sensitive, because of the presence of a large government bureaucracy inherited from the French.

The fact that the "multi-party timebomb exploded first" in a relatively well-off country like Cote d'Ivoire, a recent Economist Intelligence Unit study suggests, could be attributable to the fact that economic downturn "is felt more sharply" by the middle class than by "people in poorer African countries who are barely integrated within the money economy." A member of "virtually every family" in the Ivorian middle class is employed in the public sector, the study says.

"Since Ouattara became prime minister, the economic situation has grown worse, not better," says Paul Arnaud, editor of the new Abidjan daily, Le Soir and the weekly Nouvel Horizon, which support the Ivorian Popular Front, the largest opposition party. "The government is not competent to solve the problems our society faces," he says.

With over 40 officially recognized political parties in the country and at least that many newspapers, government policies have become the leading target for commentators and cartoonists alike.

Criticism of the reforms has not been limited to the opposition. Ouattara has also met with resistance from within the ruling party's old guard, which was more comfortable with the way things worked when the opposition was outlawed and the country's coffers were full. "The government can no longer do just anything it wants," says one senior bureaucrat sympathetic to the reform efforts. "Not everyone has been able to adjust very well."

In May, after a violent raid by police and army troops on a university dormitory, street demonstrations became an almost daily occurrence again, and strikes shut down schools and the national university. Pressure mounted within the ruling party for a crackdown on government opponents. Ouattara surprised many Ivorians with nationally televised speech that took a hardline position, outlawing the university student union and threatening striking teachers with dismissal.

Despite angry opposition responses, President Houphouet-Boigny used the political skills he has often successfully employed through his long public career to persuade teachers and students to return to classes. The provisional truce lowered the political temperature and allowed final exams to take place.

The influx of new outside support and a reduction in domestic turmoil offer only a temporary respite from the problems Cote d'Ivoire faces. The national debt, accumulated during the late 1970s when cocoa and coffee prices were high, and inflated by U.S. dollar's climb in the 1980s, now exceeds $ 15 billion. The economy remains tied to the still-sagging fortunes of coffee and cocoa. And the cost of doing business here is so high that many investors take their money elsewhere, despite the attractive amenities and services available. A gallon of gasoline, for example, costs over $ 4.60, and fees for using the port of Abidjan are among the highest on the continent.

"We have to diversify, and we have to improve our competitiveness," Ouattara says. "We have a program to reduce all processing and production costs," he says, including water, electricity, customs duties and domestic taxes.

But with debt servicing assuming over 40% of export earnings and nearly 30% of the Gross Domestic Product -- and many of the country's obligations still unmet -- there is little left to finance recovery. The country has suffered a 40% drop in the terms of trade since 1986. Export earnings have fallen from $ 3.4 billion to about $2.8 billion.

"The reality is that we cannot pay the debt if we want the economy to survive," says Dr. Joseph Yao Yao, director of the center for economic research at the University of Abidjan. "I think it is time to acknowledge that the debt burdens of countries like Cote d'Ivoire are too great and some relief must be found."

For commodity-growing villages like Toumanguie, relief is nowhere in sight. The cocoa and coffee farmers are sitting on unsalable stocks, and the empty desks in the small school are a mute testimony to the problems. Still, Kamara says her friends and family there refuse to give up. "We think the future will be better," she says.


LOAD-DATE: November 4, 1991


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1991 AllAfrica, Inc.


128 of 211 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 2, 1991


STRIKE TWO


LENGTH: 248 words


The leader of Madagascar's opposition coalition has called for a general strike following Prime Minister Guy Razanamasy's announcement of a transitional government for the Indian Ocean island nation. Forces Vives leader Albert Zafy last Thursday told a rally of 20,000 people in the city center of Antananarivo that he disagreed with proposals announced at the end of October, when he was abroad, to end five months of political unrest. 

A series of sector-specific strikes which began in June eased somewhat at the end of October. At that time the opposition called for a general strike but then backed down.

The October 31 agreement between the government of President Didier Ratsiraka and the Forces Vives provided for a broad transitional government of national unity which was to be in power for up to 18 months. Zafy was named to head the temporary administration, but he has refused because Ratsiraka would remain armed forces commander under the agreement.

Ratsiraka, who has ruled Madagascar for 16 years, refused to step down last summer despite daily demonstrations calling for his ouster by hundreds of thousands of people in the streets.

A referendum on a new constitution is to be held before the end of the year. It would include changes to electoral laws and would be followed by presidential elections.

The new team announced by Razanamasy last Wednesday mixes 24 politicians, including some opposition figures, with technocrats and military men.


LOAD-DATE: November 20, 1991


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1991 AllAfrica, Inc.


129 of 211 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 2, 1991


BAD TO WORSE


LENGTH: 386 words


Almost a year after Somalian rebels overthrew their aging dictator, Mohamed Siad Barre, the capital Mogadishu has become both a battlefield and a graveyard for rival factions fighting for power.

Between 70 and 100 people die from gunshot wounds in Mogadishu daily, doctors say, and every street is punctuated with scores of hastily-dug graves. No national army exists and personal safety has become a matter of self-protection; even hospital patients are said to keep guns close at hand. 

The United Nations says the entire country is in ruins. More than half of the nation's 7.1 million people are hungry and destitute, says a recent report. Water supplies have been "severely disrupted, destroyed and looted" and most of the health system is in need of "reconstruction."

The International Committee of the Red Cross has suspended relief supplies to southern and central Somalia, which are plagued by armed bandits and unrest. The Food and Agriculture Organization (FAO) said it is impossible to distribute food aid in the country for similar reasons.

In contrast, the breakaway northern region that calls itself the Republic of Somaliland appears to be faring better and relief and rehabilitation work is well under way, the United Nations says.

But the region's foreign minister, Yusuf Ali Sheikh Madar, appealed for foreign assistance and recognition for the northern territory during a recent visit to Washington.

"Our unilateral declaration of the sovereign state of Somaliland is irreversible," he said. "The Republic of Somaliland is not against negotiating with or talking to our southern brothers in Mogadishu, but given the continued factional fighting there is no credible representative leadership to talk to."

In July, six Somali rebel groups met in neighboring Djibouti to decide Somalia's fate. They hastily agreed to a mutual cease-fire and to joint efforts to defeat remnants of Siad's army which is inching towards the capital. Siad, who ruled the country for 21 years, is reportedly holed up in southern Somalia.

The new government, led by Ali Mahdi Mohamed of the United Somali Congress (USC), has promised to halt the violence. But it is beset by internal rivalries and challenged by four other clan-based rebel groups, so it has no authority beyond Mogadishu.


LOAD-DATE: November 20, 1991


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1991 AllAfrica, Inc.


130 of 211 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 2, 1991


COURTING DISASTER?


SECTION: BITS AND PIECES


LENGTH: 421 words


Amid growing fears that widespread violence might overtake Zaire, the Bush administration has come under increasing pressure to cut remaining ties with President Mobutu Sese Seko. "It has become nearly impossible to justify our continued implicit support for the corrupt, repressive, and incompetent regime," David Boren (D-OK), chairman of the Senate Intelligence Committee, said in a letter to National Security Advisor Brent Scowcroft at the White House. Last Thursday, Scowcroft heard a similar appeal in an unannounced meeting with two long-time Zaire hands, Dr. William Close, Mobutu's former personal physician and Joe Gatt, a New Jersey businessman with investments in the central African nation. 

In Senate Foreign Relations Committee hearings on November 6, Assistant Secretary of State Herman Cohen said the U.S. believes Mobutu still has an important political role, even though the president "has lost the legitimacy to govern." Cohen called for a transitional administration drawn from "the ranks of the opposition" and said the new government must "guarantee the president's personal safety and his right to participate in the democratic process."

But critics of the current policy call it a formula for disaster. Testifying the same day, Nancy Warlick, a Presbyterian missionary who has served in Zaire for 16 of the past 26 years, called for the U.S. to "publicly break its ties" with Mobutu. "Each day that he remains in power moves the country closer to anarchy," she said.

The hearing was chaired by Illinois Democrat Paul Simon and was attended by Republicans Nancy Kassebaum of Kansas and Richard Lugar of Indiana -- all three of whom have asked for a firmer U.S. stance.

Fears of spreading trouble were heightened by several incidents last week, most notably an attack on the home of Roman Catholic Archbishop Monsengwo Pasinya, who has been tapped as a possible mediator in the current stalement between Mobutu and the opposition. Monsengwo was thought to be the most likely choice to chair the national conference, which has been stalled by procedural disagreements and charges that Mobutu was trying to stack the meeting in his favor.

Meanwhile, two key West African countries have sought to mediate the dispute. Nigerian Foreign Minister Ike Nwachukwu visited Zaire ten days ago, and last week Senegal's minister of state, Abdoulaye Wade, was in Kinshasa, the Zaire capital. Wade is a leading Senegalese opposition figure who joined Senegal's cabinet earlier this year.

LANGUAGE: English

BULLETIN BOARD


LENGTH: 346 words


The Sixth International Conference on AIDS in Africa will be held in Dakar, Senegal from December 16-19. The conference and exhibitions will be held at the CICES International Congress Center. Pre- and post-conference workshops will also take place. Abstracts on a variety of topics are still being accepted. Please contact the Commissariat General, MCI - BP/PO Box 4000, Dakar, Senegal. Telephone: (221)25-55-55/24-24-00. Fax: (221)25-55-56/24-04-63. Telex:202139 F RCINF Attn:MNMS 10. In the U.S., contact Rebecca Kohler, Family Health International, AIDSTECH, Box 13950, Research Triangle Park, NC 27709, or call (919)544-7040.

Telephone (202)293-1051 for more information. Reservations must be received by mail by November 18. Send to: World Affairs Council, 1726 M Street, NW, Suite 800, Washington, DC 20036.

The Middle East Research & Information Project (MERIP) is celebrating its 20th anniversary on November 23. MERIP's staff, editors and board of directors will be hosting an evening featuring Middle Eastern cuisine, music and poetry. LOAD-DATE: November 20, 1991


LANGUAGE: English
