132 of 211 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 2, 1991


WAR TOUCHES GORILLAS


LENGTH: 494 words


The Rwandan war is threatening the safety of the country's rare mountain gorillas. But conservationists say that rudimentary snares set in the rainforest by Rwandan villagers are proving more of a danger than the stray bullets of rebels and soldiers.

Faced with growing food shortages because of the fighting, villagers near the Volcanoes National Park along the Ugandan border have set up snares to trap antelope. 

"There's been an enormous increase in poaching in the rainforest," says Pam O'Malley, resource assistant for the Digit Fund, a Colorado-based non-profit group carrying on the research of zoologist Dian Fossey.

Fossey, who was mysteriously slain in Rwanda at the Karisoke research center in 1984, founded the organization in the name of one of her favorite gorillas, Digit, who himself was killed by a poacher.

O'Malley says that none of the 310 mountain gorillas -- the last of their kind in the world besides a small group believed to live deep in Uganda's Bwindi Forest -- were shot, but one gorilla group has become "more agitated" because of the noise of the weapons and is no longer as welcoming to researchers.

Snares are a bigger threat. Early this year, conservationists cut down 150 of the wire traps in one week in the area inhabited by the gorillas; normally about a dozen snares a week are found.

At least four gorillas have been caught in snares this year, compared to none in 1990, says the Digit Fund. All have recovered with the help of veterinarians, but one male lost his hand.

A group of gorillas which disappeared in January turned up later in Zaire, says O'Malley. The animals usually wander throughout the rainforest, located in a chain of seven extinct volcanoes called the Virunga Mountains in Rwanda, Uganda and Zaire. But the fighting appears to have made the gorillas even more mobile, says O'Malley.

Craig Sholley, former director of the Mountain Gorilla Project, says Rwandan rebels invaded Volcanoes Park in January. Fortunately, he says, only 25 mountain gorillas live in the park.

"Everybody still is extremely concerned" because fighting is ongoing at the Rwanda-Uganda border, says Sholley, who left Rwanda in February. The Mountain Gorilla Project was turned over to the Rwandan government last year.

Tourist visits to the gorillas ceased when the fighting began in October, he says, but infrequent trips to one group resumed in September. Such visits are essential to the Rwandan economy, which has already taken a beating from the costs of war, says Sholley.

He says Volcanoes Park brought in over $ 1 million in 1989, and tourism associated with the gorillas that year was between $ 6 million and $10 million -- second only to coffee and tea exports in earning foreign currency.

"Rwanda is a very, very natural resource deficient country," says Sholley. "Tourists who come to Rwanda come for one reason: gorillas. If they can't see gorillas, they don't come." n


LOAD-DATE: November 20, 1991


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1991 AllAfrica, Inc.


133 of 211 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 2, 1991


NEW FIGHTING FLARES ON BORDER


SECTION: CONFLICT: RWANDA


LENGTH: 1232 words


Heavy fighting this month between rebels and government soldiers in Rwanda indicates that the country's year-long conflict is far from a resolution, despite attempts to move towards democracy and to solve a growing refugee problem.

The rebel Rwandan Patriotic Front (RPF) said it had advanced 32 miles inside Rwanda from Uganda on November 3 and killed more than 40 soldiers. The Rwandan government said its troops killed more than 100 RPF rebels November 10 after repulsing a third attack in less than two weeks. State-owned Radio Rwanda said the insurgents had been driven back into Uganda "and will never capture even an inch of Rwandan territory." 

"Apparently this was a very serious battle -- both sides admit," says one U.S. analyst, speaking on condition of anonymity. She says November's fighting was the worst in several months.

Over a year ago, thousands of armed refugees invaded Rwanda from Uganda in an effort to push their way back home and force President Juvenal Habyarimana out of office. The fighting spurred troops from Belgium and France to rush to the government's rescue temporarily, but by February the struggle had subsided and a cease-fire was agreed to in March.

It is unclear just how bad the fighting is today because both sides in the conflict have a reputation for using the media for propaganda and intimidation. But what is clear, ironically, is that the war that began over the refugee problem continues to push Rwandans living near the Ugandan border out of their homes, according to Amnesty International. The human rights group says 100,000 people have been displaced because of fighting mainly in the mountainous northern region.

And while international attention on the tiny overcrowded country that once promoted itself as the "Switzerland of Africa" has diminished, Rwanda is still reeling politically and economically from the October invasion.

The RPF rebels, who are mainly former Ugandan army soldiers of Rwandan Tutsi descent, accuse Habyarimana, a Hutu, of undemocratic and corrupt practices and say his regime reserves most educational and vocational opportunities for a small clique from the north, the president's home region.

Habyarimana legalized multiparty politics in Rwanda in June and says elections are to be held by late next year, but he refuses to hold a national conference similar to those that a half-dozen other African countries have used to make the transition to democracy.

However, a prime minister designated in October is working on forming an "all-party transitional government," the analyst said. Rwanda now has six new parties.

Much of the political conflict can be attributed to long-standing ethnic tension between the Tutsi minority that had oppressed the Hutu majority for 500 years. German and Belgian colonizers concentrated power and wealth in Tutsi hands and introduced a segregated education system that blocked Hutu mobility and advancement. In the early 1960s, thousands of Tutsis fled to Uganda after the Hutus seized power in Kigali, the capital.

It was the refugee problem that sparked the October 1990 uprising. Rwanda produces Africa's seventh largest number of refugees, just behind war-ravaged Angola, which is almost 10 times its size, according to the U.N. World Refugee Survey. An estimated 323,900 Rwandans now live in neighboring countries.

Habyarimana has contended that his country cannot absorb all the Rwandans who are in Uganda, Tanzania, Zaire, Kenya and Burundi. He has asked leaders to accept some of the exiles as immigrants. Uganda, where an estimated 207,000 of them live, has refused.

The recent conflict has also heightened tension between the Rwanda and Uganda governments. Rwanda has accused Ugandan President Yoweri Museveni of backing the RPF. Most of the RPF's leaders are former exiles who served in Museveni's guerrilla force which seized power in 1986. These leaders were serving in Uganda's army until the time of the invasion. Museveni has denied Rwanda's charges and has called for more troops to join an Organization of African Unity (OAU) observer force along the border.

Regional leaders, including Organization of African Unity chairman Ibrahim Babangida and Zairean President Mobutu Sese Seko, have tried to bring peace to Rwanda, but to little avail. The leader of the Rwandan Association for Defense of Human Rights, Nkubito Alphonse Marie, says government and RPF leaders have begun holding meetings but the sessions have proved fruitless so far.

Marie was demoted from his job as a magistrate in the capital to a provincial judicial post for refusing to keep a group of suspected RPF sympathizers in jail, saying there was no evidence against them. Marie, who says he is apolitical, believes a national conference is the only way to solve Rwanda's problems. "All the vital forces of the country, as a matter of principle, should say what they think about the future of the country, including the Patriotic Front," he says.

Marie notes that the RPF is no longer the only opposition group and its conduct will be weighed against other government opponents.

On a recent visit to the United States to seek support for his organization, to learn about the U.S. judicial system and to talk with human rights groups, Marie emphasized that Rwanda's problem is regional because so many Rwandan refugees are living in neighboring countries. The United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR) appears to agree. It is conducting surveys of Rwandan refugees, asking them if they want to return to Rwanda, to retain a passport and just be allowed to visit, or to remain where they are and become nationalized, the U.S. analyst said. UNHCR is to present its results to a donor conference next year.

The analyst said the Rwandan government is working on plans to locate sites within Rwanda to bring at least some of the refugees home. About 18,000 Rwandan refugees have returned from Tanzania since March 1990.

The World Bank and International Monetary Fund (IMF) recently have sent missions to Rwanda to assess the country's economic damage from the war. Officials do not yet know how much the economy has suffered, but they say structural damage has been limited because fighting has been isolated in northern plains and mountains.

But the World Bank's annual report for 1991 says Rwanda experienced negative growth last year. "In Rwanda, the recent civil hostilities resulted in extensive damage to the infrastructure and increased defense expenditures," the report says. In addition, the price of coffee -- which accounts for about 90% of Rwanda's exports -- hit an all-time low in 1990. The country's gross domestic product declined by almost three percent.

On the other hand, the World Bank says Rwanda's neighbors, Uganda and Burundi, seem to be having more success, despite their own problems with a rebel insurgency and ethnic tension respectively.

Uganda, fighting back a rebel incursion from the north, has remained a strong, consistent economic reformer since 1987, and its growth performance continues to be impressive, according to the report.

Burundi, whose governing Tutsi slaughtered an estimated 60,000 Hutu in 1988, has also been successfully pursuing a long-standing adjustment program, the World Bank says. Its growth rate was been over 4.5 percent during 1980-89.


LOAD-DATE: November 20, 1991


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1991 AllAfrica, Inc.


134 of 211 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 2, 1991


"WE'LL BE STRONGER PEOPLE," SAWYER SAYS


LENGTH: 1977 words


A year after he was sworn in as president of the interim government in Liberia, Amos Sawyer remains hopeful that he will see the end of the "nightmare" that his country has experienced. Sawyer was tapped to head the transition team during a meeting of a broad range of Liberian organizations convened in neighboring Gambia by west African governments in August 1990. Ecowas, the Economic Community of West African States, has been working on a settlement of the two-year Liberian conflict and has placed a peacekeeping force, known as Ecomog, inside Liberia.

Sawyer, a university professor forced into exile in the United States in the mid-1980s by President Samuel K. Doe, had expected his tenure in office to be over by now. The peace plan drawn up at the Gambian meeting called for a one-year transition to elections and precludes the interim president from being a candidate. Sawyer says he never aspired to be president but is willing to remain in office until the transition to democracy has been made.

When Sawyer was selected, Doe was still in power and rebel forces headed by Charles Taylor were closing in on the capital, Monrovia. After Ecomog took charge in Monrovia -- and Doe was killed by rival revel leader Prince Johnson -- Sawyer and his government assumed the administration of a devastated nation. 

However, Taylor refused to recognize or cooperate with Sawyer, whose control was limited to the capital and surrounding areas.

With a revised peace plan now in place, placing Ecomog in command of border posts, checkpoints, and air and sea ports throughout the country, the prospects for an end to the year-long stalemate have risen.

But Sawyer is facing another challenge: the continued refusal of a new rebel army -- the United Liberation Movement (Ulimo) made up of former Doe supporters opposed to Taylor -- to surrender their arms. Ulimo has been attacking Taylor's forces inside Liberia from bases in neighboring Sierra Leone, and Taylor has threatened to scuttle the new peace plan unless the attacks stop. Senegalese Foreign Minister Djibo Ka pledged last week that all factions, including Ulimo, will be disarmed -- either "voluntarily or by Ecomog."

Last month, during a visit to the United States Amos Sawyer discussed his views of the current situation with Africa News. Here are excerpts from the conversation.

AN: As you know, many Liberian refugees have been deeply disappointed by the difficulty of getting visas to come to the United States. Is this something that concerns you?

Sawyer: Well, we were hoping that there would be more sympathetic consideration on the part of United States officials regarding the entry of Liberians. You know, it's rather difficult psychologically for Liberians, because Liberians see New York or Washington, DC, in the same way that the Francophones see Paris or the Anglophones see London. And, what Liberian can you find that does not have a relative or a friend who has either studied here or been here? One would hope that in a time of distress, the United States would be more accommodating.

I can understand what the American immigration people have outlined as the problem. But we hope that for those refugees who cannot come here, the United States government will support UNHCR (the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees) so that better care can be taken of our people where they are.

AN: In general, what role would you like to see the United States be playing in the Liberian crisis now?

Sawyer: I think there are three things the United States needs to do to help the process on.

One is a little bit more substantial support for the peacekeeping effort. They've already provided $ 3.7 million and we welcome that. But we'd like a little bit more because it is an expensive proposition, especially for countries (providing the peacekeeping forces) like The Gambia, Sierra Leone and Ghana.

Secondly, we would like United States support for the elections process. We have agreed on elections, we look forward to setting up the appropriate machinery for elections, and we look forward to international supervision. This can be expensive. We would like the United States to play a role in supporting this process.

Thirdly, there's a repatriation program. About a third of our people are outside of the country now. We'd like to have them come back home. We are told by UNHCR that, prior to elections, there is a need for some $ 62 or $65 million for this repatriation package. That money has to come from somewhere. We'd like some support on that.

I'm saying to the United States government, "We think you're headed in the right direction now, but, in addition, we'd like you to look down the road. There is the problem of reconstruction that we're going to have to face as soon as elections are over. We'd like you to be ready to help us at that point."

So this is the package, this is the message, we try to bring along.

AN: Do you think it is realistic to believe that the hundreds of thousands of Liberians who have fled the country will return before they can be guaranteed a secure future for themselves and their families? How will you persuade them to come back before elections take place?

Sawyer: I think that there are serious fears and reluctance. The propaganda against Ecomog (the West African peacekeeping force), has taken its toll, and many people have been nervous about Ecomog.

I think now we find that the truth is coming out, and there is wider acceptance of Ecomog, even in the interior of Liberia. We believe that once there is an indication that Ecomog has taken control of security, border posts, ports of entry, normal security, checkpoints, all of these, there will be a greater inflow of people. True there may not be a stampede, but we think there will be a most substantial inflow, sufficiently so that one could have valid elections.

AN: Liberians spend a lot of time talking about the "special relationship" with the United States, and you touched on that when you mentioned the family ties. Aside from that, is there a special relationship between our two countries, and, if so, how do you define it?

Sawyer: There is a special relationship; whether it has an emotive quality to it or not is a different matter. But the historical ties and linkages are there, and there is nothing we can do to erase those.

Now whether they mean anything at this point is where we have a problem, because Liberians have had high expectations, because of the special relationship. Because of the special relationship, Liberians expected that the United States would come to the rescue in this crisis, at the early stages. When the Marines arrived offshore, there was this anticipation that, well, this nightmare is over. And it wasn't.

Now we have seen that the special relationship has been defined in a new sense, which is to play a supportive role to Liberia, as Liberia is now seen in the context of the West African sub-region. So, what of the new bilateral relationship that will emerge between the United States and Liberia? It may be a second-order relationship to Liberia's relationship within the West African sub-region.

In a way, this is a big thing for us Liberians, because we have come to grips with ourselves within the context of our own geographical and socio-economic milieu. And I think we will be a stronger people for that, a more self-reliant people for that, and will develop concentric circles of relationships in which the West African ones would form our priorities, and then, perhaps, after those, would come the larger relationships.

AN: There are those who say that after what Liberia has gone through, there's really very little hope for the country for a long time to come. Would you disagree with that?

Sawyer: Well, I do disagree. I think Liberians are doing some serious assessments of ourselves and of our relationships one to the other. We're doing a serious assessment of inter-ethnic relationships. We all have been glad to admit, for once, there's hardly any economic or class difference. Everybody is impoverished.

I think we are also beginning to do an assessment of our possibilities, and we're becoming more modest people. We will become more appreciative of our own resources, individual as well as the social resources in this society. We will set our sights more modestly, and, perhaps -- I hope -- we will work more conscientiously.

We probably had an inflated perception of ourselves on the West coast. You know, we have this thing -- even now when we're down! -- that this is supposed to have been the New York of West Africa. We expected people to come running in and enjoy themselves in Monrovia. We had more things in our shops than they had in Freetown, and we were supposed to be the super-sophisticates in the region; we were in tune with Western culture, and all that.

Now we realize that there is much more to being, and to becoming, than just being Western in values and taste. I think we'll be better off for this realization.

AN: In contrast to that image of Monrovia and Liberia, the picture that's been coming across since the war began, in our media -- especially the few television reports -- have been very graphic in their presentation of a barbaric society where people go about cannibalizing each other, torturing each other, cutting off each other's body parts. How does that square with the Liberia you know?

Sawyer: Well, that is the shocker, and that is where we have now seen another side of ourselves. We are shocked that we have it in us to go to this extent of brutality one to the other.

So I think that is going to force us into a more modest estimation of ourselves, and perhaps, a real assessment of those institutions and values that we thought we had. I still cannot put my finger on it, except, perhaps, we've done too much with the superficial, and assumed that our own aspirations of a sophisticated society were not being based on firm foundations. (We thought) our educational system, our religious values, were perpetrating messages of brotherhood and sisterhood that were coming across.

Now we have to face facts about the big ethnic divide that had, for so many years, taken the better part of our politics and power relations. The slogans of inclusion were, in fact, being translated into reality, but not fast enough. So we have the bare facts now; we have to build.

AN: Given all this, what you've just gone through, how can the country pull together now and have an election in a few months?

Sawyer: Yeah, that's a tall order. But you see, we have to find a way. And I think, first, we have a way because the country is war-weary. Nobody wants to fight anymore. Two, there's a realization that behind all of this conflict, there's this struggle for power, and a prolongation of it is not necessarily the way to find a solution.

I think there is a view that if we can correct the problems as they've developed, not over the centuries, but just as of 1985, that might give us a good start. And, therefore, if we can have free and fair elections this time, we're not going to solve the age-old problem, but we have a lesson before us that a new regime would know to be more careful in its construction of the military, that the bar association has been burned by the crisis, and should therefore know that it ought to strive to be more assertive, that the press should be more watchful.

At the institutional levels, we might begin with the empowerment of these institutions through the electoral process, and through the attitudes of the new regime. That will be the first order of business.

Then, over time, we can attack the more serious underpinnings of attitudes and values that have not gone right over the years.

n


LOAD-DATE: November 20, 1991


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1991 AllAfrica, Inc.


135 of 211 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 2, 1991


PLAN FOR ELECTIONS IN SIX MONTHS


LENGTH: 816 words


Last Friday, West African peacekeepers began implementing a new agreement designed to end the conflict in Liberia. The plan calls for an expansion of the West African peacekeeping force to all areas of the country and the holding of elections in the middle of next year.

The agreement was worked out late last month in the latest of a long series of regional summits aimed at bringing peace to Liberia. The meeting, hosted by President Felix Houphouet-Boigny in the Cote d'Ivoire capital Yamoussoukro, set a six-month timetable for election preparations to begin on November 15, which the agreement calls "D-Day." In attendance at Yamoussoukro were the presidents of Burkina Faso, Guinea Bissau, and Senegal, the prime minister of Togo, and senior ministers from Nigeria, Sierre Leone, the Gambia, Ghana, and Guinea. All are members of the 16-nation Economic Community of West African States (Ecowas). 

The agreement was signed by the participating governments as well as by the president of the interim government of Liberia, Amos Sawyer, and Charles Taylor, leader of the rebel movement known as the National Patriotic Front of Liberia (NPFL).

For the first time, the leaders got Taylor to agree to disarm his forces, which control about 90 percent of the territory. Within 60 days of D-Day, all armed factions are to turn in their weapons and report to camps that are being established by the west African peacekeeping force, Ecomog.

Taylor has always resisted any cooperation with Ecomog, which has been dominated by Nigerian troops and which Taylor has seen as hostile to his aspirations to be president of Liberia. To win Taylor's cooperation, the West African leaders have added two new nations to the previously six-nation force. About 450 soldiers from Senegal were ferried to Liberia just before the summit opened and the rest of the 1,500-member contingent are slated for arrival before the year's end. The troops are being transported in U.S. military planes and are receiving American logistical assistance. Guinea-Bissau has also agreed to send soldiers to join Ecomog.

The details of the Yamoussoukro accord have been spelled out in the following "program of implementation."

The Ecomog Mission is to cover the whole of Liberia and to supervise the encampment and disarmament of all warring factions.

Preliminary Accepted Conditions:

* Ecomog shall enjoy freedom of movement throughout Liberia.

* All warring factions will willingly abandon their fighting positions and move into designated camps

* During the period of encampment and disarmament, eminent persons of the International Negotiating Network (headed by former U.S. President Jimmy Carter) will visit Liberia in order to reinforce the confidence of the parties.

* All parties concerned will recognize the absolute neutrality of Ecomogand demonstrate their trust and confidence in it.

* Some weapons would be inadvertently be lost and would therefore need to be located and recovered.

* There would be some obstacles and possible minefields that would need to be neutralized.

* All entry points into Liberia would be monitored by Ecomog groups.

Tasks:

* Eliminate external threat to allow the encampment and disarmament program to be smoothly and effectively carried out.

* Monitoring of all possible avenues of approach into Liberia by patrols and static guards.

* Search, in conjunction with administrative authorities, to recover hidden or lost weapons.

* Strategic installations will need static guards.

* Security will be provided to all VIPs and where freedom of movement isestablished such security will not be necessary for local dignitaries.

Timetable:

D-Day (November 15)

* Issue Orders

D-Day+7

* Confirmatory reconnaissance completed of all encampment areas areas and all forward patrol bases.

* Border guards in place including buffer zones along Sierra Leone/Liberia border.

* Road blocks and check points removed in collaboration with administrative authorities.

* Reception centers for encampment open.

* Ecomog patrols commence.

* National Patriotic Front of Liberia (Charles Taylor's troops) encampment and documentation.

* Receiving, crating and storage of weapons at designated points completed.

* Resettlement program commences.

* Robertsfield International Airport reactivated.

* Consolidation of border areas in collaboration with the administrativeauthorities.

* Appropriate light Air Detachments deployed in Liberia (including helicopters).

* Routine patrols continue

* Permanent presence and monitoring of all airports and seaports.

* International flights into Robertsfield commence.

* No movement of heavy weapons belonging to Ecomog where not necessary.

D-Day+60

* Assignment completed. (By January 14, 1992, all factions are to be disarmed and encamped.)


LOAD-DATE: November 20, 1991


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1991 AllAfrica, Inc.


136 of 211 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 2, 1991


YU-JAY'S STORY


LENGTH: 698 words


By the age of 14, Yu-Jay Harris had survived a war that chased him from his home in Monrovia, separated him from his mother, and deposited him with his 12-year-old brother Jared in an unfamiliar rural environment. The sight of dead bodies became commonplace, but staring into the barrels of guns, some wielded by children their own age, remained terrifying. His experiences, Yu-Jay says, have given him a confidence in his ability to cope and a new compassion for the people around him.

Both brothers project an innocent sweetness that belies the horrors they have seen. Jared's shy smile masks a thoughtful seriousness that emerges under patient questioning. Yu-Jay, more voluble, is a ready spokesman for the two, fielding inquiries with a disarming wit and a penetrating intelligence. When he gets excited, his precise articulation slides towards "Liberian English," a colorful, expressive dialect that challenges unfamiliar listeners with its dropped consonants and slap-dash speed. 

Here, in his own words, are some of Yu-Jay's experiences.

On fleeing from his house:

One of the frightening things was when the army of President Doe came and broke the house and put everyone of us inside. They ransacked our house, took all the things we had and decided they were going kill us. But, as God had it, the forces (of rebel leader Charles Taylor) were starting to shoot. So my mother started begging them to let us go before we got caught in a crossfire. They hurried to take all the things they can and then they let us go.

On being a city kid in the Liberian countryside:

I thank God (for helping me grow up) because I felt I was like a baby at home -- someone to wash my clothes, clean the house, even though I used to do a little work. And I was so used to my Ma, I couldn't let her go far from me -- like one little baby! But I just feel like this experience makes boys like us, who will have to be dependent on ourselves one day, know how to depend on ourselves. When I came, no one could help me wash my clothes, I had to take care of myself.

Just imagine me taking a cutlass -- about three boys trying to brush an acre or two to make a cassava farm to have something to eat. We used to walk five, six, seven hours. I never thought!

Sometimes we had to go and take some cassava stakes from another farm -- that's about an hour walk -- put it on our head, and then we will bring it back to our farm. We had to pass through swamp water. I was so afraid. I said, "What? Leeches and things will be in the water, they will stick on me and I will get injured badly. "But there were guys who were used to it because they live in it. And they just passed through and I had to pass through or fall in the water, stakes and all. I was so weak until they were vexed, telling me, "You're too lazy."

I said, "My man, you know, I'm not used to this kind of thing." I said they shouldn't tell me that I'm lazy, because I have the strength to do the thing. But the thing is that I never tried it before, it's my first time getting to it.

On plans and prayers:

When I see sick people I feel like being a doctor. I didn't plan on being a doctor, but I feel like being a doctor, because to see your fellow man suffering...I felt that if I kept on seeing such a thing I would be a doctor or do something that other people would benefit from. I would help or be able to take care of my fellow human beings.

I hope that the war will finish and our country will rebuild and there will be peace and stability. Many people, they think they can pray to get out. But you shouldn't pray you can leave the country and forget about the other people, because some people don't have the way to leave. Those people far in the villages, good, good people, they can't go. And people who have PhD's, they are making farm for a living, they can't get out.

The best thing is just continue to pray that the war will finish, that school may resume and things will become normal, because if you keep on praying, "Hey, God, please get me out of this war," then how about the other people? I don't think that's a fair prayer. So I just wish that the war will finish. n


LOAD-DATE: November 20, 1991


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1991 AllAfrica, Inc.


137 of 211 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 2, 1991


U.S. HAS ABANDONED US, SAY LIBERIANS


SECTION: REFUGEES: LIBERIA


LENGTH: 2361 words


Abidjan -- U.S. consular officer Steve Voien grimaced as Liberian refugee Rosetta Goweh started to cry. "Ah, please," he said, through the speaker in the security glass that separated them. "Please don't do that to me."

Voien and his colleagues at embassies in West Africa have been facing a refugee crisis they feel has been largely ignored by U.S. policy makers. "Being out here on the front line," Voien says, "we wish that there was something in the law that would at least allow us to reunite families."

Since a rebel army invaded Liberia on Christmas eve of 1989, over two million Liberians -- more than half the country's population -- have fled their homes. Over 300,000 crossed the border to Cote d'Ivoire. The embassy here, like those in Sierra Leone and Guinea, Liberia's other neighbors, has been besieged by refugees seeking American visas. Most of them are turned down. 

The result is a profound bitterness towards the United States that spans the traditional class and political divisions among Liberians. In travels around Cote d'Ivoire, the frontier area where refugees are concentrated, to villages scattered throughout the country, it is impossible to meet a Liberian without being asked why the United States has betrayed Liberia.

That attitude is rooted in historical reality, as well as in resentment over present policies. Founded by freed American slaves in 1822, Liberia often appeared to be an outpost of Americana in Africa. Many Liberians have family in the U.S., and the elite has always sent its children to be educated in American schools. U.S.-made products filled the stores, U.S. tunes dominated the music scene, the red, white and blue -- with 11 stripes and a lone star -- hung from flagpoles, and U.S. dollars were legal tender. Even Liberians who had no personal ties to the United States tended to think of it as "the motherland."

"Liberians have always looked to the U.S.," says Joyce Mends-Cole, a Liberian attorney who is a consultant to the United Nations Development Fund for Women. "But now we find," she says, "that the 'special relationship' has been special only to Liberians."

For the years of the Cold War, though, Liberia was a friend the U.S. could count on. The U.S. military had rights to use the country's international airport. The Voice of America built one of its biggest transmitters near Monrovia. In return, in the decade from 1975 to 1985, Liberia garnered the largest per capita amount of U.S. aid in sub-Saharan Africa and hosted the largest Peace Corps contingent on the continent.

Last year, when fighting among rival factions began to tear the country apart after the overthrow of the regime of President Samuel Doe, Liberians expected the U.S. to step in to stop the conflict. The fact that the U.S. limited its intervention to the evacuation of its nationals has been an additional element in Liberian resentment over U.S. policy. In September 1990, the West African peacekeeping force Ecomog secured the capital, Monrovia, but the country remains divided into armed camps.

Kenneth Brown, the U.S. ambassador to Cote d'Ivoire, says that the United States continues to recognize a special historic and cultural relationship with Liberia, but says Congress has not extended that specialness to immigration policy. "What we have to keep in mind," he says, "is that the consular officer works within a law legislated by Congress."

Under current law, visa applicants must satisfy the embassy that they will return to their own countries when their visitors' visas expire. "Unfortunately, the applicant is guilty until proven innocent," Brown says. "If you've fled a country where a war is going on, it becomes difficult to convince somebody that you will go back to that country."

Last February, after intense pressure from human rights groups like the New York-based Africa Watch, then-Attorney General Richard Thornburgh announced that the Immigration and Naturalization Service would issue temporary visa extensions to nationals of Liberia who were already in the U.S., as well as to citizens of Kuwait and Lebanon. While welcoming the action, Africa Watch argued that it did nothing to relieve the plight of most Liberians, including those who have arrived more recently.

Nor can many Liberians expect to enter the U.S. as refugees. Each year, the administration proposes and Congress approves a cap on refugee admissions by region, and Africa is low on the list. Although the continent accounts for a third of the world's 15 million refugees, less than 5% of those admitted to the U.S. in a typical year are African. The largest number of refugees by far come from the Soviet Union and Asia, at about 50,000 each. This year's ceiling for Africa is 4,900 -- a limit that refugee organizations are protesting.

"I think race plays a very serious role," says Beverlee Bruce, a former Peace Corps director in Liberia, who visited West Africa in April and May as part of a fact-finding team from the New York-based Women's Commission for Refugee Women and Children. "I think the official American community thinks Liberians would just be additional black people who would exacerbate an already difficult situation in America's urban ghettos."

Ambassador Princeton Lyman, the State Department's director of refugee programs, says that the administration is responding to criticism that the Africa ceiling is discriminatory. "In fact," he says, "our numbers have gone from 3,000 just a few years ago to over 4,000 now, and we are projecting even more for the coming year."

Hiram Ruiz, of the U.S. Committee for Refugees in Washington, says that actual admissions don't always reach the ceiling levels. In 1986, for example, the ceiling was 3,500, but only 1,315 Africans were admitted.

But even if as many Africans as the law allows are admitted this year, the increase is small comfort to consular officers who deal with the Liberian caseload. The job is an emotional ordeal, they say, because the applicants are so desperate and their numbers overwhelm the embassy's capacity to interview and process them. Every refugee tells stories of terror and death, and the majority are still trying to locate missing family and friends.

Rosetta Goweh's case differs from others only in its particulars. She fled Monrovia with her two sons and other family members, after soldiers ransacked her house and prepared to shoot all the inhabitants. In a reprieve that Goweh attributes to the miracle of answered prayer, rival forces chose that moment to invade the neighborhood. Crawling to avoid the crossfire, the family escaped to the home of friends in another town, although Goweh was hampered by a severely injured leg.

Concerned with Goweh's worsening condition, friends and family pooled their resources to pay for an airplane ticket to the U.S. and to bribe rebels to take her across the border into Cote d'Ivoire. As a clerk at the U.S. embassy in Monrovia, Goweh had visited the U.S. and already had a visa. "Leaving my boys was the hardest thing I ever did," she says, "but I thought that if I died I would not be able to help them anyway."

With the financial assistance of a church group in Charlotte, North Carolina, Goweh had extensive surgery that left a temporary pin in her leg, and she began trying to get her boys out of Liberia. But by then chaos had spread to every part of the country, and all she learned from the efficient refugee communication network was that her friends' town was decimated and its residents scattered. The Charlotte group bought her a roundtrip ticket to travel to Cote d'Ivoire to look for her children, aged 12 and 14. "I prayed that they were alive," she says, "but I feared they were dead."

When she arrived at the embassy in Abidjan three weeks later with sons Jared and Yu-jay in tow, Goweh couldn't stop smiling -- until she met with Steve Voien. She had to have surgery to remove the pin from her leg, she told him, and she couldn't and wouldn't leave the boys again. She said friends in Charlotte would support the family until they could return to Liberia. The longer Goweh cried the more pained Voien looked, but the response remained the same: no visas for the boys.

"It's real human drama," says Ambassador Brown. "No one with any feeling wants to turn away people who have gone through what the Liberian refugees have gone through. And that's particularly true when they are from a country that we have a special affinity for. But if there is to be greater flexibility, then we need greater guidance from Washington."

Mary Anne Schwalbe, staff director of the Women's Commission, says such flexibility would be a good investment for future U.S. relations with Liberia. The Commission recommends more visa approvals, increased humanitarian assistance to refugees in West Africa, and greater U.S. help in tracing the large number of separated families. "In most refugee situations, people flee with their families," she says. "In Liberia, the situation was so fluid that people could be in different parts of town when fighting started and never see each other again."

The United States has provided $ 130 million in aid to Liberian refugees. But Schalwbe says that without additional assistance, conditions will continue to deteriorate. Already, malnutrition, disease and prostitution are spreading.

Despite the difficult physical conditions, Schwalbe says, she has been struck by Liberians' pleas for printed materials and textbooks. "They are starving intellectually," she says. "Unlike many refugee populations who want lots of other things first, most of the people we've spoken to here want schooling for their children and books to read."

Claude Regnier, who coordinates refugee programs for the Ivorian government, says more help is needed urgently. When the first flood of refugees poured across the border, he says, African hospitality ensured a sympathetic welcome. "But when there are more than 300,000," he says, "they are too numerous for Ivorian resources."

Regnier says that even with United Nations and other international aid, there is not sufficient housing, food, water or medical care for the Liberians. The growing pressure on the land is becoming a source of tension between local and refugee communities. "In certain host areas, Ivorians don't have enough land for themselves," he says. "That's the problem." Some border villages have swollen to ten times their previous size, with nine Liberians to every Ivorian.

Regnier estimates that Cote d'Ivoire can continue to accommodate only 20% of its current population of refugees without facing serious social repercussions of its own.

Education for refugee children remains a serious problem. Ivorian schooling is in French, a language foreign to Liberians. And the establishment of English-language schools has become a delicate political issue. In one border town, a school run by refugee teachers was closed because of community resentment over the shortage of local schools for Ivorians. "We have studied the problem," says Regnier. "But it is difficult and there is a certain danger for the future. The only solution is to reopen Liberian schools inside Liberia."

In the last month, that possibility seems more promising, as a West African peace initiative backed by the Carter Center in Atlanta appears to be gaining ground. The plan calls for holding internationally-supervised elections six months from now (see page 10).

Joyce Mends-Cole says that the United States has an obligation to ensure Liberia's future by strong and immediate support for the peace process. She articulates a grievance that is encountered among Liberians across West Africa. "Here we go with the tiring figures again," she says. "But we musn't forget that $ 500 million, more than was given in 135 years to Liberia, was given to support the Doe administration. If we're talking about U.S. policy, clearly there is a lot of fault to be placed at the doorstep of the United States."

U.S. Deputy Assistant of State for Africa Leonard Robinson says that view is too simplistic. "We can't rewrite history," he says. "The Doe regime was the consequence of 100 years of most Liberians being left out of the system," due to the dominance of descendents of the Americo-Liberians who founded the country.

Now, Robinson says, "Liberians should take the responsibility for solving their own problems. We have got to move away from this paternalism that we wear in the West, that our system is best."

Mends-Cole dismisses that argument. "The Liberian people marched in Liberia and asked Doe to step down," she says. "They marched to the U.S. embassy and asked the U.S. to intervene, placing themselves at severe risk. Where were Doe's arms coming from? Most of the huge military arsenal came from the U.S. or was bought with U.S. aid."

Robinson and Mends-Cole agree, though that the U.S. can play a constructive role by supporting the current peace effort and pressing any reluctant parties to cooperate.

The success of that effort can't come too soon for Liberian refugees. Exhausted by the difficulties of exile, many are talking of return. An estimated 70,000 have already gone to Monrovia, swelling the city to several times its normal size and straining its ability to function.

But most refugees say they won't return until the situation becomes more stable and the countryside safer. For their children's sake, many say, they dare not risk it.

Rosetta Goweh turned out to be one of the lucky ones. Despairing of getting visas for her sons while she remained in Abidjan, she decided on a bold move. She returned to the U.S. and applied from there, taking advantage of an immigration service directive that the immediate families of Liberians already in the United States would be allowed to join them. When the papers arrived in Abidjan, the boys' visas were issued.

Interviewed by phone from her temporary home in Charlotte after her children arrived, Goweh said she still is praying for peace. Meanwhile, she says, the family is safe, together -- and the boys are doing well in school.

n


LOAD-DATE: November 20, 1991


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1991 AllAfrica, Inc.


138 of 211 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 2, 1991


EXCERPTS FROM THE FEDERAL INDICTMENT INVOLVING ARMS EMBARGO VIOLATIONS


LENGTH: 1317 words


The Gamma Business Among the munitions and other commodities shipped by the ISC to defendent ARMSCOR through Gamma were:

a. components for use in air to air, ground to air, and ground to ground missiles including gyros, infrared detectors, cryostats, magnetrons, xenon bulbs, high voltage power supplies and laser rods;

b. components for night vision devices including micro-channel plates, image intensifier tubes and fiber optics; and

c. components for inertial navigation systems including two axis gyros, rate gyroscopes, linear accelerometers and pendulums.

The Gamma smuggling was accomplished by portraying this ISC front compny known as a domestic customer and misrepresenting the nature of the product and end-user to United States Customs. In or about September, 1987, subsequent to a seizure of Gamma business records by law enforcement authorities, the ISC defendants dismantled Gamma and established another front company known as Triangle Engineering to disguise ISC shipments of munitions and electronic components to defendent ARMSCOR.

The Military Systems Sales

Between in or about 1981 through in or about 1989, the defendants would and did engage in the sale of in excess of $ 10,000,000 of military systems to defendant ARMSCOR which were purchased from United States vendors and shipped without the proper licenses to RSA. These systems included:

a. technology for the inertial and land navigation systems and gyroscopes for aircraft, missiles, vehicles and helicopters;

b. film reader tracking systems for military test ranges; and 

c. telemetry antennas designed to support a tracking system for a military test range.

These miltary system sales to defendant ARMSCOR were accomplished by the defendants through a series of false and fraudulent statements on export declarations and other shipping documents in order to disguise the true nature and value of the systems as well as their intended use and end-user, because the defendants knew or had reason to know that RSA and defendant ARMSCOR were subject to an arms embargo.

The 40mm Grenade

In or about 1981, ISC would and did develop drawings and a technical data package for production of a 40 millimeter ("mm") grenade. This grenade was derived from the United States army's 40mm grenade.

Between in or about May, 1981 and December, 1981, the defendants would and did transfer this grenade technology and technical data to defendant ARMSCOR without a license or approval by the Department of State.

In or about 1983, in order to facilitate ISC's marketing efforts for the 40 mm grenade, the defendants would and did export to and re-import from RSA a cutaway display model of the grenade.

In or about June, 1987, defendant ARMSCOR engineers encountered problems with the fuse mechanism for the RSA's copy of the United States Army's 40mm grenade. In order to assist defedant ARMSCOR in solving these problems, the defendants would and did provide United States technical data and technical assistance to ARMSCOR engineers at ISC without a license or approval from the Department of State.

The Striker Problem

Begining in or about 1980, the defendants would and did assist defendants ARMSCOR and KENTRON in the development of anti-armor, antitank missiles.

In or about 1984, ISC would and did enter into an agreement with KENTRON to market the RSA missile internationally, and ISC began negotiations with the Peoples Republic of china for hte sale of $ 300,000,000 of missiles andmissile production tecnology. ISC was to recieve approximately one-third of ARMSCOR's profits from this sale. This program became known as the "Striker".

At various times in or about 1986, in order to resolve development problems with the Striker, the defendants would and did illegally import from the RSA a Striker model, missile bodies, and launch tubes into the United States, and would and did attempt to import Stiker rocket motors by routing trans-shipment of such munitions through Italy or Belgium and by misrepresenting to the Department of Treasury on Imports Permits that the country of origin and manufacture was either Italy or Belgium, when in truth and fact the country of origin and manufacture was the RSA

In or about 1987, in order to conduct testing and resolve the operational problems with the Stiker for the Chinese contract, the defendants would and did illegally transfer technology and technical data concerning wind tunnel tests to RSA engineers.

The PF-1 Program

Beginning in or about 1982, ISC developed a proximity fuze for international sale. A proximity fuze is a detonation devise desinged to enable an explosive warhead to detonate above the target in order to maximize the kill ratio.

In or about 1986,.ISC entered into a contract with the Peoples Republic of China for the sale of fuzes and technology to provide fuze production capability. During the testing stage of this contract, ISC began to experience problems with premature detonation of the fuzes. In an effort to avoid contract penalties, in or about February, 1987, ISC contracted with defendant FUCHS to provide ISC with technical assistance to resolve the fuze problem.

In order to solve the fuze detonation problems, in or about March, 1987, the defendants would and did misrepresent the fuzes as metal parts, and shipped 5,500 fuze casings to Darion Pty., LTD.("Darlon") n the RSA acting for defendant FUCHS. These fuze casings were smuggled to the RSA for intergration of South African electrical systems

After 50 fuzes were fitted with the South African electrical systems, the defendants would and did cause the fuzes to be imported back into the United States for testing, again misrepresenting the nature of the product and country of origin.

In or about 1987, the defendants would and did arrange for South African engineers from defendant FUCHS to visit ISC to work on the fuze detonation problem. During this visit, the defendants would and did cause the transfer of fuze technical data without proper notification to and approvals by the Department of State.

In or about 1987, based on technical assistance provided by the South African engineers, ISC corrected the fuze detonation problems, and thereafter would and did re-import the 5,450 fuze casing which had been illegally shipped to Darlon. n

When Africa News reported in 1976 that a meeting had taken place two years earlier between a senior South African defense offical and two American companies, one of them International Signal and Control (ISC), there was no way to predict what the collaboration was to yield (see story).

We later learned that ISC had been seeking a multi-million dollar contract to study and construct a sophisticated ocean surveillance system for South Africa and was trying to obtain a license for the project from the U.S. government. ISC's silent partner in the deal was the New Hampshire-based Sanders Associates. A large-scale behind-the-scenes lobbying effort, in which Sanders played a central role, resulted in approval for the license just before the 1976 New Hampshire primary, where President Gerald Ford was facing stiff opposition.

The lobbying also produced a letter to Ford from a powerful group of U.S. senators, calling on the administration to lift the arms embargo against South Africa. An internal Sanders document obtained by Africa News said that the South African project "was established following significant dialog (sic) at very high levels in both governments" (see AN, April 13, 1981).

In 1978, following imposition of the mandatory United Nations embargo against South Africa and a reinforcement of U.S. restrictions by the Carter administration, the ISC/Sanders license was revoked. It was at that time, according to the indictments issued in Philadelphia last month, that the illegal arms shipments began.


LOAD-DATE: November 20, 1991


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1991 AllAfrica, Inc.


139 of 211 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 2, 1991


FEDS CHARGE BIG-TIME ARMS PLOT


SECTION: U.S.-AFRICA: SOUTH AFRICA


LENGTH: 1056 words


A massive decade-long conspiracy to violate the U.S. arms embargo against South Africa has been unmasked by federal prosecutors in Philadelphia. Indictments were returned by a federal grand jury on October 31 against the South African government-owned Armaments Corporation (Armscor), two affiliated companies, and 10 American and seven South African nationals. The accused are charged with illegal munitions sales valued at more than $ 10 million.

The U.S. government imposed a ban on arms sales to South Africa in 1963 and added stronger provisions in 1977 when a mandatory United Nations embargo was adopted. Additional restrictions were enacted by Congress in 1985. 

According to prosecutors, the chief alleged American conspirators are James H. Guerin and his former associates at International Signal and Control Company (ISC) in Lancaster, Pennsylvania. Some of the sophisticated weaponry and parts sold to South Africa by ISC are said to have been re-exported to Iraq. In addition to the arms export offenses, Guerin -- who founded ISC in 1971 -- is accused of inflating the value of his company when it was sold four years ago to a major British defense firm, Ferranti International. Guerin has denied any impropriety.

In a related development, the Johannesburg Weekly Mail on November 8 reported that at least 38 foreign companies broke the United Nations embargo against South Africa. The Mail says companies in the United States, Japan, Britain, Switzerland, Italy, Germany, Austria, France, the Netherlands, Australia, Spain and Brazil took part in major transactions. More than 60 South African companies imported and exported thousands of tons of arms on Armscor's behalf during the 1980's, the newspaper said.

The Philadelphia indictments suggest that ISC made a crucial contribution to Armscor's efforts to breech the international embargo and keep the South African military well supplied. Throughout the past decade, the South African government pursued an aggressive regional military posture -- fighting a major insurgency in neighboring Namibia, intervening in Angola and other near-by states, and repelling armed attacks from guerillas of the then-outlawed African National Congress.

At the time, Armscor was also actively promoting sales of military hardware around the world. As a result of the alleged wrongdoing, the U.S. government has recently imposed two-year sanctions against the arms manufacturer that will remain in force until September of 1993, even if the U.S. arms embargo is lifted. The sanctions prohibit exports to Armscor of all military-related items, bar U.S. government contracts with Armscor, and forbid imports to the U.S. of any Armscor-made products.

The following account of the federal charges is drawn from reporting by Tim Mekeel and Ernest Schreiber of the Lancaster New Era, which because of the importance of ISC to the Lancaster community, has followed the story closely for several years and has published earlier investigative pieces on the company's South African ties. The material is used with the New Era's permission.

In two indictments, containing 75 charges against 17 people, the Justice Department portrays Guerin as the architect of the intertwining fraud and export schemes. Although the federal government has been investigating ISC for three years and Guerin and other ISC principals have been named in previous court proceedings, they were never formally charged before.

According to the 51-page fraud indictment, ISC executives created $ 1 billion worth of fake business to pump up the value of ISC. The phony deals boosted the value of the company's stock when it went public in London in 1982 and helped lure Ferranti into buying ISC in 1987, prosecutors charge.

In the 129-page export indictment, prosecutors say ISC used an intricate web of front companies and money laundering to put U.S. military technology in South African hands. ISC exported missile parts, navigational aids, night vision devices, grenades, antennas and missile-tracking film readers to South Africa, all in violation of U.S. and United Nations embargoes, the indictment says.

ISC also illegally sold to South Africa $ 4.4 million worth of parts for proximity fuses Q devices that trigger artillery shells. South Africa in turn sold these parts to Iraq, where the armies of Saddam Hussein used them against U.S. troops during the Gulf war, prosecutors say. Federal agents displayed one of the dud Iraqi artillery rounds containing the ISC part during a press conference in Philadelphia where the indictments were announced.

According to prosecutors, the arms smuggling scheme was conducted in cooperation with Armscor, Kentron, an Armscor missile subsidiary, and Fuchs Electronics, a private South African defense firm which makes bombs for Armscor.

"It was the plan of the conspiracy that the ISC and South African defendants would and did for money aid the defendant Armscor in evading the United Nations embargo by selling and smuggling U.S.-made arms, munitions, weapons technology, as well as other restricted commodities to Armscor," the indictment states. Armscor used the illegally obtained weaponry "to enhance its inventory" and to "market weapons systems to third world countries," the document says.

The charges provide precise details about both the export scheme and the alleged fraud. They state that ISC executives changed the description and price of the munitions to hide the transactions, then shipped the goods to South Africa through a New York-based front company, Gamma Systems.

In the contract fraud, the indictments say ISC used nearly 50 front companies circulating more than $ 700 million to create the illusion of substantial arms-related contract business.

After Guerin established ISC in Lancaster, the firm grew into a large defense electronics conglomerate, eventually employing 1,800 people. Its workforce today is about 800, but that is expected to drop to 500 in the next couple of years.

Some of the first detailed allegations surfaced in civil suits filed last year by Ferranti, in which the British firm said ISC had been exporting camera and film-reader equipment to evaluate performance of missile systems, navigational systems, and night-vision equipment and heat-seeking missile parts.


LOAD-DATE: November 20, 1991


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1991 AllAfrica, Inc.


140 of 211 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 2, 1991


AN EYEWITNESS COMMENDS THE VOTING


LENGTH: 949 words


One of the unique features of the Zambian election process was the significant role played by both national and international monitors. On the basis of Zambia's experience, independent election monitoring may come to be seen as a necessary component of transitions from single-party rule to multiparty democracies in Africa. Elections without independent observers, such as those in Gabon and Cote d'Ivoire last year, have been followed by persistent disputes about the legitimacy of the subsequent governments.

The Zambian election, in contrast, produced a clear and accepted result, despite the lack of any formal arrangements between the government and the opposition on electoral procedures. 

After the decision in December 1990 to amend the constitution to legalize opposition parties, the government of Kenneth Kaunda retained all the characteristics of a single-party state. The ruling party monopolized public resources, controlled the media and kept complete command of the military and police forces. Although the electoral bureaucracy was semi-autonomous, it was materially dependent on the government.

Nevertheless, 10 months later the opposition Movement for Multiparty Democracy (MMD) was able to wrest power from the ruling United National Independence Party (UNIP). Among the factors on the MMD's side were the depth of the economic crisis, the opposition's broad political base, the increasing assertiveness of Zambia's judiciary as well as its electoral commission, and the vigilence of the monitoring teams.

When Kaunda rejected the opposition's demand for international observers, a group of Zambians led by a prominent lawyer, Rodger Chongwe, proposed creating a Zambian Independent Monitoring Team (ZIMT). President Kaunda relented, as he often did on critical issues, and invited several eminent individuals and organizations to observe the October 31 elections. Former U.S. President Jimmy Carter was invited, and a joint monitoring effort was launched by the Carter Center and the National Democratic Institute for International Affairs, entitled Z-Vote (Zambia Voting Observation Team).

Several other observer missions went to Zambia, including delegations from the Commonwealth and the Organization of African Unity (OAU). But it was mainly Z-Vote that sought changes in the electoral process to improve chances for a free and fair vote. ZIMT lended a hand as did the Zambia Elections Monitoring Coordinating Committee (ZEMCC), which was formed in September. ZEMCC is a coalition of several civic organizations including the Christian Churches, the Law Association of Zambia, the Press Association of Zambia, the Student Union of the University of Zambia, a women's lobby and a council of non-governmental organizations.

Unlike other African countries where national conferences have led to transitional governments charged with organizing new elections, election monitoring teams assumed this mediating role in Zambia. They were criticized repeatedly, especially by the former ruling party's campaign headquarters. Less than a week before the election, a particularly harsh advertisement appeared in the Times of Zambia, accusing the monitoring teams of being part of "an imperialist plot" aimed at destabilizing the country. President Kaunda, to his credit, disassociated himself from this attack and called on Zambians to support the work of the monitors.

On election day, Zambian voters throughout the country showered praise on the monitors, seeing them as the chief guarantors of a free and fair election. The frequent irregularities caused by inadequate voter records and administrative errors failed to dampen their enthusiasm.

Zambia appears to have reaped certain benefits from agreeing to such a comprehensive election monitoring effort:

* Heated conflicts over electoral procedures were minimized by the presence of neutral bodies, which sought compromises to disputes through communication between government and election officials.

* Visiting foreign missions of election experts provided technical assistance.

* The presence of over 3,000 Zambian monitors and several teams of international observers during the voting and counting enhanced confidence in the elections.

* Zambian civic associations were given the chance to play an active role in the process and to lay the basis for their continued involvement during the consolidation phase of the new system.

* Foreign observers from major donor countries reflected the international community's commitment to help the new government meet the challenges of political and economic restructuring.

* The media's fair coverage of the election and the just implementation of election procedures have set a high standard for subsequent governments to follow.

When Kaunda finally relented and decided to invite international observers, he commented, "Let them come. We have nothing to hide." As it turned out, not only was there little that could be concealed on election day, but Zambia was able to display the impressive civic virtue and democratic commitment of its people. Seasoned public servants from other countries went away deeply moved by what they had seen and shared as election monitors. They left with indelible memories of how precious a free election was to people who had been denied that right for many years.

In time, Zambians will conduct national elections without needing such an extensive exercise involving international monitors. Nevertheless, civic vigilance is the hallmark of democratic society. So Zambians may continue to insist that independent monitoring be an integral part of the voting process in any election.


LOAD-DATE: November 20, 1991


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1991 AllAfrica, Inc.


141 of 211 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 2, 1991


AFRICAN DEMOCRACY MARCHES ON


LENGTH: 379 words


It hasn't been a good year for incumbents in Africa. The four presidents who have faced election opponents have been defeated by wide margins.

Five other leaders have been ousted by extra-constitutional means, and most of the rest are under pressure to give up all vestiges of the strong-arm methods once so dominant across the continent. 

Zambian President Kenneth Kaunda's defeat in the most recent African election has sent the strongest signal yet that no leader can take his position for granted. Kaunda was the only president Zambia has known since independence in 1976. He has enjoyed a worldwide reputation as a voice for justice and peace, particularly in southern Africa. But he was defeated soundly by Frederick Chiluba, a trade union leader once imprisoned by Kaunda's government.

When pressure began building last year for an end to Zambia's one-party system, Kaunda initially resisted. His first concession was to call a referendum on multiparty rule. But as events in Zambia and the rest of Africa gained momentum, Kaunda cancelled the scheduled referendum and agreed to hold the country's first contested presidential vote in two decades.

Despite numerous problems that arose during the period leading up to the election, in the end, voting went relatively smoothly. When the results became clear, Kaunda congratulated the winner and quickly stepped aside.

"Whatever mistakes Kaunda has made, by accepting the election results and handing over power so gracefully, he has left Zambia and Africa a very important legacy," says Makau wa Mutua, a Kenyan lawyer who is project director of the human rights program at the Harvard University Law School. "History will remember Kaunda for this." Mutua credits the election observers, both from within the country and from outside, with helping to ensure a creditable outcome.

Richard Joseph helped design and administer the international monitoring process on behalf of former President Jimmy Carter, leader of the U.S. observer team.

A professor of political science at Emory University, Joseph also directs the African Governance program of the Atlanta-based Carter Center. He wrote the following analysis of the election process from his perspective as a participant observer.


LOAD-DATE: November 20, 1991


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


December 9, 1991


SOMALIA CONFLICT


LENGTH: 112 words


Somalia's capital, Mogadishu, has plunged into chaos, with more than 3,000 people dying in the past three weeks as warring clans fighting for power wage gunbattles in the streets. 

International aid agencies are working with Somali doctors to treat the wounded, but they say food and medical supplies are in desperately short supply.

The International Committee of the Red Cross Monday appealed to all parties to allow a boat carrying about 800 tons of food, medical supplies and fuel to unload in Mogadishu. The boat has been unable to dock for more than two weeks because the port, under control of one of the armed factions, has been heavily shelled.

LANGUAGE: English
