143 of 211 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 9, 1991


LETTER FROM MOZAMBIQUE


LENGTH: 808 words


Another round of peace talks are scheduled to begin this week in Rome between the government of Mozambique and the Renamo guerrilla movement. Progress in previous sessions, sponsored jointly by Mozambique's Catholic Church and the Italian government, has been slowed by procedural wrangling. However the eighth round, which ended on November 13, resulted in a protocol dealing with legal registration procedures and the obligations of political parties. The Mozambique government which has made numerous concessions in the talks, has appealed to the world community to pressure Renamo to cooperate, amid growing fears that the group has no real agenda other than banditry. The government of South Africa, which supported Renamo in the past, says it no longer provides any aid. Several reports in recent years have linked Renamo to a network of right-wing extremist groups in Europe and the United States, as well as in South Africa.

Ruth Minter has seen more of Mozambique's history up close than almost any other American. During the war against Portuguese colonial rule, she taught at a secondary school run by Frelimo, the Mozambique independence movement, which is now the governing party. For the last year, sponsored by the United Church Board for World Ministries and the Christian Church (Disciples of Christ), she has taught at a seminary outside Maputo, the Mozambique capital. In this letter, she shares her personal perspective on what the continuing war means for some individual Mozambicans. 

Peace does not feel any closer here in Mozambique.

Wednesday when I arrived at the seminary, I found that about two-thirds of the faculty and students had gone to visit Mr. Panguana, a grandfather, probably in his sixties, who works at the school. Every Wednesday he does all the measuring of dry items -- peanuts, flour, salt, sugar, beans -- at the campus "store," which is really a consumer cooperative.

But on Tuesday night he was kidnapped by Renamo from his home. The night was in the 50-degree range, and he was taken without having adequate clothing. He soon began to cough. (His captors) told him to stop coughing or they'd kill him. He couldn't. They punched him in the chest with rifle butts. He got worse and became short of breath.

Finally the commander took pity on him -- told him to go home, which he did. We are grateful that he is alive, even though his chest is very bad and it will take time for him to recover.

A week earlier we had begun second semester. Telvina, the wife of one of our fourth-year students, returned with her children from visiting family in Gaza Province. She was also very much in shock and relieved to be back safely. The night before she left to return here, her family's house was in the middle of an attack in which Renamo burned 60 houses all around theirs. People died but she did not stay to learn details. She says it was an area people thought was safe, so they had everything at home and lost all -- food, clothes, furniture, dishes... In "insecure" areas, people often bury or hide many of their things and sleep outside their homes in trenches or under bushes, knowing attacks usually come at night.

The last peace talks finally began to talk about item one of an agenda with a couple of dozen items. The government here has been very eager to find a way to end the war and has proceeded with many changes that "the world" would think Renamo must have wanted: a multiparty system with elections, a "free and open" economy, a chance for Renamo's people to participate as full citizens despite all the years of atrocities. But Renamo never had a political program or structure. It was created to help military intelligence in white-ruled Rhodesia before it became independent Zimbabwe. It was handed off to South African military intelligence in 1980. They found it in their interest to destabilize Mozambique.

Renamo only had its first political congress -- presumably to work out its identity and goals -- after the peace talks began. Their conservative friends around the world must have told them that they should learn to negotiate and talk politics. But they balk at every step and I cannot imagine that they feel ready to compete as a political party of free, responsible citizens. That is not what they were trained for.

On the ground, I still have never heard anyone who has experienced an attack who could give a story of Renamo trying to win hearts and minds or organize politically. They tell only of terror, death, mutilation, atrocities.

Meanwhile, Sofala province has had the worst drought in 40 years, causing major shortage of food. Every attack in the war means more dislocated people needing support until resettlement and self-support is again possible.

How long, o Lord, before your Mozambican people will have peace?


LOAD-DATE: December 18, 1991


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1991 AllAfrica, Inc.


144 of 211 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 9, 1991


TOGO: REFORM GOVERNMENT SURVIVES ANOTHER COUP ATTEMPT


LENGTH: 643 words


Togolese Prime Minister Joseph Kokou Koffigoh has proven his staying power once again, fending off the army's third attempt to topple him during Togo's fitful transition to democracy.

Since the latest attempted coup began late last month, Koffigoh and President Gnassingbe Eyadema -- who has been stripped of almost all but his ceremonial powers -- have been negotiating to form an interim government.

They are seeking to establish a ruling body that would satisfy both democracy advocates and the army's Eyadema loyalists, and therefore have a chance to last until elections scheduled for June. 

At least 17 people, mostly soldiers, died when pro-Eyadema troops backed by tanks stormed the prime minister's office and briefly arrested him December 3. Twenty-six civilians died the previous week in clashes between troops and pro-Koffigoh demonstrators.

France sent some 300 troops to neighboring Benin in response to appeals by Koffigoh, but only 10 soldiers entered Togo, to guard the French Embassy. French Foreign Minister Roland Dumas said France had no plans to send an expeditionary force to Togo because "it has no business telling people what should be done."

Koffigoh, a human rights lawyer, was named prime minister in August by a national conference which left Eyadema virtually powerless following widespread protests and strikes.

Since the latest unrest, borders and the international airport have reopened, but the country remains "unstable," says one U.S. official.

Thousands of people fled to neighboring Benin and Ghana after the border crossings reopened. Some of the estimated 15,000 refugees arriving in Benin said they feared for their lives because they had criticized Eyadema, an autocratic soldier who staged independent sub-Saharan Africa's first coup in 1963.

Koffigoh ordered a return to work late last week, but unions are urging an indefinite general strike beginning December 11. A recent call for a general work stoppage was largely unsuccessful.

Eyadema ordered troops back to their barracks last week. Although they have stayed there, they have been gritting their teeth as Koffigoh remains in office, analysts say.

"They are saying, 'If it doesn't go the way we like it, expect us to rise again,'" says the official, who spoke on condition of anonymity.

Diplomats say there is evidence of a purge of pro-Koffigoh soldiers within the army, which is dominated by Eyadema's Kabye ethnic group, and fears are growing among Togolese that the danger of ethnic rivalry will increase. The Eyadema government heavily favored the army's Kabyes, who are from Eyadema's region in the north, while southern Ewes felt increasingly isolated.

Although the president has called for the punishment of mutinous soldiers, opposition leaders charge that he has instigated the unrest and is sabotaging the transition to democracy.

There appears to be good reason for fears that the soldiers will act again. Last week's attack was their fourth attempt to keep Eyadema in control. But there also are signs that their efforts might be backfiring. Koffigoh's sheer resilience is winning him widespread respect in Togo; cheering crowds greet him wherever he appears.

Eyadema loyalists are calling for the dissolution of the High Council of the Republic -- the transitional legislature which sparked the recent crisis by banning Eyadema's former ruling party. The president's backers also have demanded that Koffigoh form a broad-based government that includes Eyadema supporters.

Koffigoh has said he refuses to buckle to demands of any particular group. "I know the people are with me and it is the people whom I serve, not any special interests," he told reporters last week after the coup attempt.

Both Koffigoh and Eyadema are barred by the transition plan from contesting June's polls.


LOAD-DATE: December 18, 1991


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1991 AllAfrica, Inc.


145 of 211 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 9, 1991


GABON: OIL REVENUES TO SPUR DIVERSIFICATION


LENGTH: 1022 words


Gabon, which last year became one of the first single-party states in Africa to adopt a multiparty structure, is seeking a return to the oil-fed good times of the 1970s.

"For some time they were the Kuwait of Africa, but it didn't work," says one World Bank economist, because the bottom fell out of the oil market and people lost money. Now, Gabon wants to break its dependence on oil, expand its exports and attract investment as it strives to become Africa's version of Hong Kong.

The prospects for achieving these goals are relatively good, according to a recent analysis produced by the London-based Economist Intelligence Unit (EIU). Already, the economy has received a boost by the addition of a new oil field, Rabi-Kounga, which increased the country's petroleum output by 25% last year. 

But the ambitious diversification and expansion plan will work, the Economist report forecasts, only if "the recently introduced experiment with political pluralism proves a success" and President Omar Bongo "refrains from excessive interference in the affairs of government," leaving the prime minister free to direct the year-old administration. At the same time, the EIU says that a comfortable win for Bongo in the multiparty presidential election scheduled for 1993 would help secure the present stability

Bongo's agreement last year to legalize opposition parties and newspapers came amid political strife and strikes in which hundreds of Gabonese took to the streets demanding wage hikes and an end to one-party rule. The protests followed government payroll cuts prompted by depressed oil prices and excessive government spending .

The EIU's scenario stipulates that a return of domestic unrest could scuttle any prospects for economic recovery and growth.

Like many developing countries, Gabon has relied on its chief resource -- in this case oil -- for income, and the country has suffered as world prices waxed and waned. Now Gabon wants to export more timber, manganese, uranium and other natural resources to help revitalize its economy, which suffered a downturn during last year's political turmoil.

For investors, one of Gabon's advantages is its membership in the "franc zone," which guarantees a stable exchange rate and continuity of fiscal and monetary policy, says the EIU study, authored by Patricia de Mowbray, a British economic consultant.

U.S. direct investment in Gabon last year more than tripled -- from $ 139 million in 1989 to $463 million -- largely due to the $300-million purchase of the government's stake in Rabi-Kounga oilfield by Amarada Hess.

Gabon, a member of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries (OPEC), is sub-Saharan Africa's third largest oil producer, after Nigeria and Angola. Eighty percent of its exports were petroleum-related last year and petroleum activity generated 42% of the gross domestic product.

Despite all oil revenues, Gabon has serious fiscal problems. In 1980, the country's annual per capita income reached $ 4,000, but falling oil prices pulled it below $ 2,800 in 1987, according to the World Bank. Growth in the non-oil sector is not expected this year and only modest advancement is anticipated next year, says Prosper Youm, an economist with the International Monetary Fund (IMF).

Still, one State Department official notes, "There are a lot of other countries that would love to have Gabon's problems."

With a population of only 1.2 million, Gabon's civil servants are among the highest paid in Africa, earning the equivalent of those in Senegal which has 7.2 million people, Youm says. World Bank figures show Gabon's per capita gross national product last year as the highest in sub-Saharan Africa at $ 2,960 -- almost three times that of neighboring Cameroon which follows Gabon in African oil production.

Gabon's wealthy elite flaunt ostentatious villas and flashy imported cars, but the vast majority of Gabonese are poor and the gap between the classes is growing wider, analysts say. Civil servants, students and teachers, who are caught in the middle between the two extremes, led last year's protests, accusing Bongo of causing unemployment and wage cuts by corruption, nepotism and economic mismanagement.

Bongo, who assumed power in 1967, eventually yielded to pressure to grant pay raises. "It was essentially a give-away by the president" to quell the unrest, says the World Bank official.

In May, the National Assembly approved a new constitution providing for a multiparty system and legislative elections. In October, the IMF approved a stand-by credit for Gabon, authorizing drawings up to the equivalent of about $ 38 million to support its new economic reform program.

"Gabon's dependency on oil revenues, inadequate diversification of its economy, and a heavy debt burden have given rise to large financial imbalances," the IMF said in a statement. "The emergence of a broadly based non-oil sector is fundamental to restoring steady and sustainable economic growth."

The EIU study says oil itself might help Gabon make the transition to a broader-based economy. Following the opening of the Rabi-Kounga oilfield, additional production increases "are now in prospect and higher revenues should open the way to diversification of the economy away from oil," says the report, "Gabon to 1995: Will Oil Secure Economic Transformation?"

After the Gulf War, investors became more wary of the risks attached to the presence of large military arsenals in key oil-producing areas, the report adds. "In West Africa the arsenals are far too small to provoke international conflict." As a result, potential investors may find countries like Gabon more attractive.

"It has much better chances than some of its neighbors, but it has a long way to go," says the World Bank economist. However, if Gabon can solve its economic problems as efficiently as it seems to have quieted political discontent, analysts say it could become one of the international business community's new favorite sons in Africa, replacing unstable regimes that have resisted calls for democracy and reform.


LOAD-DATE: December 18, 1991


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1991 AllAfrica, Inc.


146 of 211 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 9, 1991


DEMOCRACY MOVEMENTS WIN ROUND ONE


SECTION: AROUND THE CONTINENT: KENYA


LENGTH: 1171 words


Kenyan President Daniel arap Moi has yielded to demands from the country's pro-democracy movement that he allow opposition political parties to operate in the East African nation.

The move came one week after international donors, meeting in Paris, decided to suspend aid to Moi's scandal-ridden government. But the president's opponents caution against viewing the action as a sign that he is ready to loosen his 13-year grip on power.

Moi has frequently called advocates of pluralist politics names like "rats" and "anarchists." A month ago he predicted that competing parties would not operate in Kenya until the year 2000. Last month, under mounting internal and external pressure, he revised the timetable for multipartyism to "two to three years," and two weeks ago he promised to legalize the opposition "soon." 

"How can we take him seriously?" asks Makau wa Mutua, a Kenyan who is projects director of Harvard Law School's human rights program.

Democracy advocates in Kenya say the president needs to take further steps to prove his commitment to political reform. They are demanding a national conference, the release of political prisoners and amnesty for exiles.

Mutua is skeptical that Moi will agree. He says the president "knows that a national conference would bury him alive" as it has other African strongmen. Since a pro-democracy wave began sweeping the continent two years ago, national conferences called by democracy campaigners have stripped power from several long-time African leaders.

Donor pressure seems to have forced the pace of reform in Kenya, following disclosures of corruption and abuses by high-level government officials and violent crackdowns on pro-democracy demonstrators.

Kenya has long been regarded in the West as one of Africa's most stable nations, and over the years it has been attractive to foreign investors. U.S. direct investment to Kenya last year was $ 115 million. But the latest statistics from the International Monetary Fund (IMF) rank Kenya fourth on the continent -- behind Liberia, Nigeria and South Africa -- in the loss of assets to capital flight. High levels of capital flight usually indicate either large-scale corruption or lack of confidence in a country's economy, or both. The report says that Kenya had over $ 2.6 billion in overseas accounts as of theend of 1990.

Kenya's economy is heavily dependent on foreign aid. It received about $ 900 million in aid this year and hoped to win even more for 1992.

The United States had been prepared to pledge $ 47 million in economic assistance to Kenya for next year, an increase of $ 8 million over 1991, said one U.S. official. Instead, Washington has agreed to release only a previously agreed-upon $ 19 million for family planning, agricultural research and assistance to private humanitarian agencies, all programs that have little connection with the government.

Moi first showed signs of bending to the pressures for political reforms last month when he fired one of his closest political allies -- former cabinet minister Nicholas Biwott, who had long been accused of corruption by reformists.

Biwott also has been named by witnesses as a prime suspect in the murder last year of foreign minister Robert Ouko, a vocal opponent of official corruption.

With Biwott increasingly seen publically as an obstacle to cleaning up graft in Kenya, Moi apparently began to sense that he had become too great a liability to the government. The president ordered Biwott's arrest while Kenya's 12 major aid donors were meeting in Paris to decide the fate of the country's economic aid package.

Complaints that Kenya is guilty of human rights abuses have also assumed new prominence, as the democracy movement has become more widespread. Last month, riot police used tear gas and clubs to disperse hundreds of opposition supporters who tried to attend a rally, and shot dead one demonstrator.

Some opposition leaders fear Moi is offering only the appearance of reform in an effort to get back into the good graces of international donors, and that he has no real intention of expanding Kenya's political life.

"Let them (opposition parties) go and get the mandate from the people -- they will get zero," Moi said last week at a special conference in Nairobi of the ruling Kenya African National Union (Kanu). "I will not run away into exile. I will remain here. I want Kanu to remain here for another 100 years," he said.

Party delegates, responding to Moi's December 2 announcement that Kenya will allow political pluralism, voted to scrap the 1982 constitutional amendment, Section 2A, that had made Kanu the nation's sole legal political party. The amendment enshrined what was already a reality; other Kenyan parties had been banned since 1969.

Parliament is expected to follow Kanu's lead and enact legislation legalizing opposition by the end of the year.

The next battle between the president and his critics is likely to be over the timing of elections. Under current law, the government must call elections at least every five years. The last ballot in 1988 was widely viewed as rigged and prompted the surfacing of the opposition movement.

Harvard's Mutua says that donors "should not be fooled" if Moi announces elections for next year -- a political move Mutua says would be a "recipe for disaster" for the opposition.

"If they rush headlong into elections without a national conference, Moi will manipulate the electoral process and win the election," says Mutua. He says the opposition needs to demand a conference to "unmask (Moi's) deception," as well as to win a mandate from the Kenyan people.

Moi's opponents also must overcome ethnic, personality and age differences, which until recently have been submerged in the common drive for political change. A split emerged in the opposition's umbrella group, the Forum for the Restoration of Democracy (Ford), shortly after Moi announced his proposals for reform.

The gap continued to widen this week. On Sunday, three of Ford's six founding members said they would try to register their faction as a party under the Ford name. Martin Shikuku, speaking for the three, said they were upset that former president Oginga Odinga had welcomed "outsiders as Ford members."

Among the Odinga group are several former political detainees, former cabinet members and dissident lawyers, including Kenya Law Society head Paul Muite.

Moi has long warned that a pluralist system would lead to conflict among Kenya's dozens of ethnic groups and result in domination by one group or in anarchy. He says the wrangling in Ford's ranks is proof of his fears. "I told you that with multiparty, tribalism will come," he told the Daily Nation newspaper on the weekend.

Opponents disagree, pointing out that both sides in the Ford dispute represent a diversity of ethnic groups. "The disenchantment against the government is universal," Mutua says. "The distaste crosses ethnic boundaries."


LOAD-DATE: December 18, 1991


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1991 AllAfrica, Inc.


147 of 211 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 9, 1991


TAYLOR GETS A JUMP ON CAMPAIGNING


SECTION: CONFLICT: LIBERIA


LENGTH: 2170 words


Gbarnga, Liberia -- Charles Taylor, the 42-year old rebel leader who launched the uprising that engulfed Liberia in a devastating civil war, is mounting an aggressive campaign to become his country's president.

After months of fighting and a year of uneasy truce, hopes for a return to normalcy have been raised by a new peace plan. An accord sponsored by regional leaders mandates an internationally supervised election by the middle of next year, after disarmament of all armies and militias.

Although implementation of the new agreement is moving slowly, the American-educated Taylor has no wasted no time in launching his presidential drive, using techniques that have proven effective for political candidates in the U.S. While his potential opponents bicker over who should run against him, Taylor is blanketing the country with campaign messages on radio and television. He is also traversing the countryside, trying to convince war-weary Liberians that the man who started the conflict is the right person to lead them to peace. 

"We think the majority of people understand our position and support us," Taylor said in an interview at his headquarters. "We expect to win."

When Taylor led a small group of armed insurgents across the border from Cote d'Ivoire into Liberia on Christmas Eve two years ago, he expected to quickly cover the 200 miles to the capital Monrovia and seize power from President Samuel K. Doe.

That plan was thwarted by unexpectedly fierce resistance from Doe's U.S.-equipped army and by splits within rebel ranks. The bitter battles left thousands dead and caused half the country's 2.6 million people to flee their homes, many into exile.

As atrocities by all sides mounted, West African governments stepped in to stop the carnage. With few resources and no prior experience in mediation, the West African Economic Community managed to end the civil war and oversee negotiations, something no regional grouping anywhere in the world has accomplished before.

"The Europeans haven't been able to do it in Yugoslavia," said Ambassador Joseph Iroha, a former Nigerian envoy to Brussels who has served as the Ecowas representative in Liberia throughout the peace process. Ecowas stepped in last year at the height of the fratricidal killing because "we couldn't allow this sort of thing to continue," Iroha says.

But the intervention has left Taylor bitter. "After the American revolution, your general of the army George Washington was given the opportunity to lead the country," Taylor says. "We took up arms, got rid of Doe, and took more than 95 percent of the country," he said. "But we were denied what was our right -- not by other Liberians but by the so-called West African peacekeepers," he says.

The interview was conducted -- with armed commandoes posted outside the door and inside the room -- in a large hilltop mansion which serves as the headquarters for the provisional government Taylor has established in Gbarnga (pronounced BONG'-GAH), a pre-war provincial capital, 125 miles from Monrovia. Used as a guest house by former Liberian presidents, the building is ringed by command posts and anti-aircraft artillery. Inside the mansion, Taylor is heavily guarded and all visitors are subjected to thorough searches.

For the past year, the country has been divided into two distinct camps. Monrovia, where some 8,000 West African troops maintain control, is administered by an interim government protected by the West African peacekeeping force, known as Ecomog. The rest of the country lies behind lines controlled by Taylor's National Patriotic Front of Liberia (NPFL).

The first steps in the peace process are to expand operations by the multinational force into Taylor territory, to open roads to unfettered travel, and to disarm and encamp the NPFL forces, along with those of other warring parties. Ecomog is slated to take control of checkpoints, borders posts, seaports and airports throughout the country during a 60-day period that began on November 15.

One thing the accord doesn't cover is control of the mass media. Except for the upsurge of small newspapers in Monrovia, Taylor appears to hold all the cards.

In the Monrovia area on FM 88.9 and throughout the rest of the country on the medium-wave band, Taylor's modulated voice is heard hour after hour, intermixed with the latest pop music from the United States. Residents of Gbarnga and the Atlantic Ocean port of Buchanan, can see Taylor's television as well.

By contrast, an interim government-run radio station broadcasts a few hours daily on a small shortwave transmitter provided by Ecomog. But most Liberians don't have access to shortwave or to the half-dozen Monrovia newspapers.

So at the moment, for information and entertainment, most Liberians have only Taylor's stations, featuring his recorded prayer for peace, repeated excerpts of his speech attacking "selfish, power-hungry" politicians in Monrovia, and his occasional "exclusive" interviews.

"I am using the radio to promote peace," Taylor says. "That is better than preaching hate, lies, and deception."

Amos Sawyer, a university professor who is serving as president of the interim government in Monrovia, concedes that the peace accord doesn't cover all factors that will influence the election process. "It is not an ideal plan," he says. "We do expect some obstacles along the way. But it should be possible to have free and fair elections."

Sawyer's administration, made up of representatives of most of the country's political parties, armed factions, and civic, professional and religious organizations, was installed in Monrovia last November.

"We had expected to expand the authority of the interim government across the length and breadth of the country," Sawyer said. But Taylor resisted, charging that the mediation effort was a Nigerian-led plot to bar him from power.

Sawyer, who was teaching political science at the University of Indiana when he was tapped for the job, says he still is committed to the provision in the original peace plan that bars the interim president from running for office.

Sawyer rejects Taylor's assertion that the NPFL is the legitimate authority in the country. About a third of Liberia's people are in Monrovia and about an equal number in exile, he says, with the rest in areas that fall behind checkpoints controlled by Taylor's bands of armed youth. "There are no doubts in the minds of the people as to where the civil authority rests," Sawyer says, predicting that those in areas under Taylor's control are "geared up with their bundles ready to come this way once the roads open."

Although the assertion is difficult to confirm, long lines of people with their possessions in tow gather daily in Kakata, site of the NPFL checkpoint closest to Monrovia, seeking passes from the commander of Taylor's forces to permit them to travel to the capital.

The latest agreement on opening the roads and holding elections, worked out at a late October West African summit chaired by President Felix Houphouet-Boigny of Cote d'Ivoire, appears to have a better chance at success than previous plans.

Ecowas's Iroha says he is confident that momentum towards disarmament, encampment, and elections is well-established and will not be sidetracked by the numerous technicalities still under discussion.

To mitigate Taylor's unease over Nigerian and Ghanaian dominance of Ecomog, 1500 troops from French-speaking Senegal are being added to the peacekeeping force. Some 700 Senegalese soldiers -- many of them veterans of Senegal's participation in the Gulf War -- have been airlifted to Monrovia in a U.S. Air Force C-130 transport and outfitted with surplus American gear. The rest are due to arrive this month, along with a small contingent from Guinea-Bissau.

Nevertheless, Taylor continues to raise objections. "We have a government here," he says. "This government is not going to be dissolved, and this army will not be dissolved." While agreeing that the NPFL's disarmament and encampment will be "supervised" by Ecomog, Taylor says "Liberian sovereignty" must be respected. Taylor, whose personal guards reportedly include crack soldiers from next-door Burkina Faso and dissidents from the Gambia and other nearby nations, says he will not give up armed protection by his own men during the election campaign.

He also threatens to retaliate against the armed group based in neighboring Sierra Leone, which has attacked NPFL positions near the Sierra Leone border. The group, known as Ulimo (United Liberation Movement of Liberia), is made up mostly of former Doe soldiers. Ulimo was formed to repulse last March's invasion of Sierra Leone by NPFL troops commanded by a Sierra Leone dissident -- an apparent attempt to overthrow President Joseph Momoh. Ulimo has announced its acceptance of the peace terms, and Taylor says his forces now control the entire border area.

On Monday, Sierra Leone claimed that two of its soldiers and a driver were killed over the weekend in fighting with Taylor's soldiers, despite Taylor's pledge to withdraw from Sierra Leone.

Major General Ishaya Bakut of Nigeria, the Ecomog commander, admits that implementation of the peace plan is taking longer than he had hoped. But he says his troops are getting cooperation from all the parties. "No one wants to be seen to be standing in the way of elections," he says.

Travel from the outskirts of the Ecomog-controlled zone to Kakata, a 25-mile stretch, is made slow and cumbersome by the presence of some 20 NPFL roadblocks, each with a congregation of young men, many appearing to be under 15 years old, with some type of automatic rifle slung across their shoulders. Beyond Kakata, the armed youth are still in evidence, but the roadblocks almost disappear.

Bishop Arthur Kulah, leader of Liberia's United Methodist Church, who has made six trips into the interior from Monrovia, says he has seen a great reduction in tensions during the five weeks since the peace accord was signed in Cote d'Ivoire. "The roads have not officially opened and the checkpoints have not been dismantled, but the attitude has changed quite a lot," he says.

Despite the problems and the continuing reservations Taylor says he has about Ecomog, the rebel leader expresses a firm commitment to the election process outlined in the peace plan. Replying to a question, he says his support includes a willingness "to accept the results of the process if we are defeated."

But he doesn't plan to lose. And he attaches great weight to the fact that former President Jimmy Carter's International Negotiation Network has been asked by the West African states to observe the elections.

Taylor implicitly acknowledges that many Liberians hold him responsible for the widespread killing and looting carried out by his forces. "War is never good; people die in war and properties are destroyed," he said. "But we think between now and the election we will have explained some of these irregularities."

While access to most of the country remains blocked for the Monrovia-based politicians who may oppose him, Taylor is travelling widely to get his message across. Last month, he visited Maryland County in the southeast and the eastern region of Grand Geddah, Doe's home area, where hostility to Taylor is said to be the greatest because his troops massacred large numbers of Doe's Krahn ethnic group. Taylor said the reception he has received on these tours suggests that "ethnic tensions have eased" and that war wounds are healing.

Taylor's critics accuse him of drawing out the peace process in order to enrich himself and his top aides by selling off the country's natural resources. A former government procurement officer in Doe's government, Taylor was accused of embezzling nearly a million dollars in the early 1980s. Since the incursion, exports of timber, rubber, iron ore and diamonds have gone from Taylor-held areas to the outside world through Cote d'Ivoire as well as via the Liberian port of Buchanan.

Taylor says the money has gone to support his war effort and is now being used for hospitals and schools. He denied profiting personally from the revenues and says he has no secret bank accounts oversees.

Responding to concerns that his troops are now a law unto themselves, with unrealistic expectations of big payoffs, Taylor says he commands the loyalty of all his commanders and troops. Some diplomats say they fear that elements of Taylor's forces may resist disarming, since their weapons give them authority and access to privileges. Neither soldiers nor officials in Taylor's civilian administration receive regular pay. Instead, they are given extra rations of rice and other items to sell or trade.

"We expect some dissatisfaction," Taylor said, likening the potential discontent to the feelings many U.S. Vietnam veterans had on their return from war.

"But mutiny -- no!" he says.


LOAD-DATE: December 18, 1991


LANGUAGE: English

148 of 211 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 9, 1991


NEW THEORY ON HOW AIDS SPREAD TO HUMANS


LENGTH: 270 words


Dr. Charles Gilks, of John Radcliffe Hospital in Oxford, England, believes that AIDS may have been introduced to humans during research on preventing malaria.

In an article in the November 28 issue of the British journal Nature, Gilks writes that during experiments begun in the 1920s, researchers in Europe and the United States injected chimpanzee and monkey blood into human subjects in the hope of inducing resistance to the malaria parasites that were in the blood. 

"All these recipients of primate blood must be considered at risk of developing retroviral infections," Gilks said, if the blood contained simian immunodeficiency virus, which is considered by many researchers to be a likely source of what became, in humans, the human immunodeficiency virus or HIV.

Gilks, who is currently a visiting scientist at the Kenya Medical Research Institute in Nairobi, told the BBC that he hopes his theory may lift some of the burden of blame off Africa. He said Africa has been unfairly credited with "starting" the AIDS epidemic, and that Africans have been accused in popular literature of perverted sex practices with monkeys.

"My theory is testable," Gilkes says in the Nature article. He urges researchers to trace previous experiments, including those involving prisoners in the United States, to see if blood samples can still be found. If so, and if they test positive for retroviruses, he says, his idea about the appearance of HIV in humans is plausible. Gilkes says he hopes that testing such hypotheses will encourage the debate about the origins of AIDS to "become more scientific."


LOAD-DATE: December 18, 1991


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1991 AllAfrica, Inc.


149 of 211 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 9, 1991


COTE D'IVOIRE: IVORIANS BRACE TO BATTLE AIDS EPIDEMIC


LENGTH: 1122 words


Abidjan -- Although AIDS was only diagnosed in Cote d'Ivoire's major city in 1985, the disease has rapidly overtaken other causes of death among adults, prompting fears of a looming public health crisis. And because Abidjan is a crossroads of West Africa, the spread of the disease here is an indication of what may be happening in countries throughout the region.

The three-year-old Project RETRO-CI, a collaboration between the Atlanta-based Centers for Disease Control and the Ivorian health ministry is trying to determine the magnitude of the problem. Project director Kevin De Cock says he doesn't think the enormity of the challenge Africa faces is fully appreciated. While he cautions against "doomsday predictions," which he says are not useful, De Cock says there is an urgent need for "accurate, sober assessment of what is a real catastrophe." 

According to a study De Cock authored for the journal Science last year, the rate of death from AIDS is higher here than in New York City, where the malady has been prevalent for a longer time. Rates of infection with HIV, the virus that causes AIDS, are higher still.

But even those figures probably mask the true incidence of the disease, De Cock says. The medical team stuck to a tight case definition of AIDS in calculating the causes of death. But the third leading cause of death among those studied was tuberculosis -- a disease commonly linked to AIDS -- and of those, 50% were HIV positive. "So there are people dying of HIV-related disease who don't fit the AIDS definition," De Cock says. In addition, those studied accounted for less than half the deaths in Abidjan during the 105 days of the survey, while the city's entire two-million population was used as a denominator for calculating rates of death and infection.

De Cock and his colleagues made their determinations from blood samples of bodies in Abidjan's two largest morgues. Results showed that 41% of males and 32% of females were HIV infected. The study also found that AIDS is the cause of death in 15% of men and 13% of women.

Other recent studies in Abidjan have shown a 12% HIV infection rate among pregnant women in some parts of town and 15% among new blood donors. In comparison, the Zaire capital of Kinshasa has rates of about six to eight percent for pregnant women and 10-12% among blood donors. British journalist Mark Huband has reported that at least 60% of patients receiving treatment at the Center for Infectious Diseases at Abidjan's University Hospital are HIV positive, according to the center's director, Dr. Justine Agness.

For women, the AIDS epidemic comes on top of a high maternal mortality rate of 15%, which is the leading cause of death among adult women. "What's striking," says Kevin De Cock, "is that if you add the two together, it means that over a quarter -- between a quarter and a third -- of female death is due to sexually transmitted disease or maternal mortality, just emphasizing the importance of reproductive health."

The RETRO-CI researchers worry that Abidjan has become a more efficient transmission point than most African cities that are plagued with AIDS. One Ivorian study found rates of infection in the countryside only slightly below that of Abidjan, in contrast to Zaire where many rural areas apparently remain relatively free of the disease. Scientists theorize that the well-developed roads and transportation systems in Cote d'Ivoire have facilitated the spread of AIDS.

Another concern is the travel routes that radiate from Abidjan throughout West Africa. The country's booming economy over much of the past two decades attracted so many foreign workers that, today, as much as a quarter of the population is from other countries. A survey of some 1,500 hospital admissions in Abidjan found patients representing 22 nationalities.

A high percentage of the foreigners are young men away from their families, and patronizing prostitutes is common among that group. With some Ivorian doctors estimating at least a 50% HIV infection rate among the city's prostitutes, transmission of the virus may be escalating.

Against that background, the rapid rise in the sale of condoms is encouraging, says Steve Chapman of Population Services International, a group founded two decades ago to promote family planning. He says that in the first five months of this year, nearly twice as many condoms were sold in Cote d'Ivoire as in all of 1990.

Chapman credits the Ivorian government with dismantling legal and economic barriers to condom distribution, by repealing a law that limited condom sales to pharmacies and removing tariffs that increased condom prices to consumers. Now condoms are available in numerous shops and roadside stands at a fraction of their former cost.

Nevertheless, health workers say, limiting the spread of AIDS is still a formidable task. People who work with prostitutes say the women complain that if they ask their customers to use condoms, the men take their business elsewhere. Since most prostitutes are working for survival money, the threat of infection is less immediate than money for the next meal.

Chapman concedes that AIDS incidence rates are not falling and that there has been no dramatic change in sexual behavior. But he argues that the foundations for change are being laid. "Now is the time to roll up our sleeves," he says.

Kevin De Cock says agencies like RETRO-CI have an important role to play in that process. "Research projects will have to focus more on intervention," he says. "There is a need to evaluate attempts to reduce infections, (whether they be) educational campaigns or medical interventions or, in the future, vaccine interventions."

At the same time, De Cock cautions that prevention should not be the only concern. It is also important, he says, to address problems in the care and treatment of those who are already ill. The lack of resources for medical treatment is worsened when a patient's employment is threatened. In Abidjan, there have been instances of domestic servants or food handlers losing their jobs after testing HIV positive, as has happened in other cities around the world -- a reaction De Cock says is uninformed. "You couldn't go out to eat in Abidjan without someone who is HIV positive somewhere along the line dealing with your food," he says. "And the same is true of New York and San Francisco."

De Cock says the difficulties caused by HIV infection and AIDS are the same all over the world. "They occur in different cultural contexts," he says, "but the actual issues are exactly the same. And it seems that each society has to go through the painful learning process of dealing with this problem."


LOAD-DATE: December 18, 1991


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1991 AllAfrica, Inc.


150 of 211 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 9, 1991


AIDS PREVENTION PROGRAMS STRESS EDUCATION


SECTION: HEALTH: AFRICA


LENGTH: 1648 words


In Africa, truck drivers discuss it, young people perform plays in the streets about it and presidents lecture on it. The subject is condoms and AIDS experts say the West can learn a lesson from Africa's candid approach to dealing with the deadly disease.

AIDS has become so entrenched on the continent that virtually no community can afford to be prudish about discussing sex -- the main mode of transmission of the human immuno-deficiency virus (HIV) which causes AIDS -- and condoms, which have proved effective in curbing the spread of the disease.

"It seems that we are now breaking through the stigmatic phase" of AIDS in Africa, says Dr. Eric van Praag of the World Health Organization (WHO). "Communities are opening up and accepting AIDS as part and parcel of their societies." 

They have no choice. About one in every 40 adults in sub-Saharan Africa is infected with HIV, and of the approximately 200 people who contract the virus every hour, more than half are African.

WHO estimates that some seven million people in sub-Saharan Africa have been infected since the pandemic began in the early 1980s. A total of 121,000 cases of AIDS, among 418,000 worldwide, have been reported across Africa, but experts say the actual figure is much higher.

"Looking at the world as a whole, the toll in human suffering, health care costs and social disruption already seems unbearable, but there is far worse to come, especially in the developing world," says Dr. Michael Merson, director of the WHO Global Program on AIDS.

WHO predicts that by the year 2000 the cumulative number of adults and children infected with HIV will triple or quadruple, rising from the current 9-11 million to 30-40 million. At that time, developing countries will hold close to 90% of the world total of AIDS cases and Asia and Latin America are expected to outpace Africa's infection rate. Acquired immune deficiency syndrome (AIDS), which destroys the body's immune system, takes as long as 10 years to develop.

East Africa has been the hardest hit by AIDS, with 21,719 cases reported in Uganda, followed by Tanzania with 21,208 cases and Zaire with 14,762. But the pandemic is not confined to the east; in the West African city of Abidjan, AIDS is the number one cause of death in men.

Behind these grim statistics, however, is a creative effort among Africans to fight AIDS as it selectively strikes young and middle-aged adults who are the mainstay of young children and elderly relatives.

At the bar in the Good Luck Guest House in Chalinze, Tanzania, customers, many of them truck drivers, often receive free condoms with their drinks. In Cameroon, a group of female prostitutes have toured cities performing "Marriage to the Condom," a play about AIDS and the importance of using the prophylactics to avoid contracting HIV and other sexually transmitted diseases.

But sex workers and their prospective customers are not the only ones talking about AIDS and Prudence -- the name of a brand of condoms widely used in Africa.

"There are a lot of heads of state who are talking about condoms and talking about AIDS as part of society," says Dr. Van Praag, who recently returned from Zambia where he headed an AIDS education team for three years. Former Zambian president Kenneth Kaunda was one of the first leaders to speak candidly about AIDS -- one of his sons died of the disease in 1986. Other presidents, including Ugandan President Yoweri Museveni and Tanzanian President Ali Hassan Mwinyi, have taken to the airwaves to caution against unsafe sex.

Ugandan First Lady Janet Museveni has been a strong advocate of community-based programs to promote public health and the welfare of children, including efforts to stem the spread of HIV infection.

"We use radio, we use TV, we use drummer groups, we use religious leaders in their places of worship, we use teachers in teaching institutions," says Museveni, who last month attended the 1991 AIDS Prevention Conference in Washington. "So many times, the only way that you can get information to the people is by word of mouth, so we have to travel around the country to talk from place to place to give this information to our people," she says, noting that illiteracy is widespread across the continent.

In Uganda and Tanzania, governments have adopted a multi-sectorial approach to fighting AIDS, expanding their anti-AIDS programs beyond the health ministries and into the education, social welfare and other government sectors, says Dr. Van Praag.

In Malawi -- where officials strictly enforce laws requiring women to wear long skirts and men to wear short hair -- the government subsidizes the sale of eight million condoms annually. In addition, a government AIDS Band sings cautionary songs about the disease. By age 10, children in government schools are taught about the sexual transmission of AIDS, and at 12, they learn about condoms.

This contrasts with the United States where the distribution of condoms in New York City high schools made national news, and where television networks only recently decided to accept advertising for the prophylactics.

"I think that we can learn a lot from the African response to AIDS," says Dr. Van Praag.

One of the most successful education and condom-promotion programs in Africa has been in Zaire, where the word Prudence is synonymous with safe sex.

Condom sales in Kinshasa alone quadrupled from one million to four million between 1988 and 1989, according to Steve Chapman, projects officer for Population Services International, a private group which provides technical assistance for health and family planning programs in developing countries.

"I was very impressed to see how widely (the Zaire programs) had managed to spread information about AIDS in so short a time," says WHO's Dr. Merson. He says condom sales across the country rose from less than one million to over 15 million within three years. "This gives us hope that it is indeed possible to make people aware of the risk of infection and to change sexual behavior in a very short time," he says.

The U.S. Census Bureau has reported that if condom use were increased by 25% in urban areas in Africa, then HIV prevalence actually would drop in the next 25 years.

But success stories in Africa should not divert attention from the magnitude of the AIDS problem, experts say. The disease will continue to kill scores across the continent, leave thousands of children orphaned and further strap an already burdened healthcare system.

WHO says that health care costs "are set to skyrocket" across the continent. Already, up to 80% of the adults hospitalized on medical wards in some African cities have HIV-related diseases. Data from studies in the Americas and in Africa show that up to half of the total national expenditure for health would be spent on AIDS care if the needs of AIDS patients were fully met.

"The hospitals are under tremendous pressure to cope with this AIDS load," says Dr. Van Praag. If patients do not find care, they may "give up and die at home" without adequate medication and attention.

More work needs to be done, officials say, and the safe sex message needs to be even stronger.

"We don't have a Magic Johnson in Africa," says Dr. Van Praag, referring to the U.S. basketball star Earvin "Magic" Johnson who recently disclosed that he was infected with HIV through heterosexual intercourse and has been asked to participate in the work of the National Commission on AIDS.

Chapman says a role model who would be "living proof" of the AIDS message is needed to promote condom use to Africans. "We need someone ... to look them in the eye and say, 'Use it. We're not kidding. It needs to be done.'"

Even successful beginnings do not guarantee results. Zaire is having problems keeping its safe-sex campaign going as its political crisis -- sparked by government resistance to pro-democracy campaigns -- continues to worsen. Project SIDA (AIDS in French) recently suspended a plan to start a major trial on an AIDS vaccine in Zaire.

Dr. Merson says that today there are about 12 experimental vaccines being tested in the United States and in Europe on small groups of people. He says WHO is setting up sites in Uganda, Rwanda, Brazil and Thailand to test vaccines that look safe and immunogenic.

"I don't think we can count on having a vaccine for worldwide use either for prevention or for treatment of HIV infection to prevent AIDS before the end of this decade," says Dr. Merson. "Each day, 5,000 new persons are infected with HIV, and so right now, we have to focus our efforts on education while we hope that a vaccine will come in the future."

For many of Africa's children, even tomorrow is too late. Some 10-15 million uninfected children, mostly in sub-Saharan Africa, will lose their mothers to AIDS by the turn of the century, according to WHO.

"We have of late been having more and more orphans because of AIDS, and our work has become more and more difficult, because we have to support children all-around -- the way they're going to live, the way they can be educated, the way they will be fed," says Janet Museveni.

Originally, children without families to care for them were being housed in orphanages, but their numbers became too overwhelming due to the war in Uganda as well as to AIDS.

"We encourage relatives now to take care of their children, but that means that most of the relatives are grandparents, and they are not able to support the children, because they can't work anymore," she says.

As time goes on, the children themselves become high risk for HIV infection, says Dr. Van Praag.

Children who lose their support at an early age, he says, are victims to poor education and they "easily become street kids" whose only chance for survival is prostitution.


LOAD-DATE: December 18, 1991


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1991 AllAfrica, Inc.


151 of 211 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 9, 1991


U.S. BUSINESSES TAKE A NEW LOOK AT AFRICA


LENGTH: 1116 words


 

Dakar, Senegal -- After a decade of declining involvement in Africa, American firms are showing new interest in the continent, drawn by widespread moves towards democracy and economic reforms.

One sign of that trend was the arrival here of a delegation of American business leaders who toured West Africa last month.

"There is a definite change of attitude on the part of American business," said Percy Wilson, an executive of Coca-Cola Africa, a subsidiary of the Atlanta-based beverage company. Wilson, whose headquarters in London, joined representatives of other American companies at the end of their four-nation tour for a meeting with top business leaders from two dozen African countries. 

With the demise of apartheid in South Africa and the end of authoritarian rule in many other countries, companies that once left Africa or never were attracted there are now paying attention.

"The political changes taking place in many African countries are making them a lot more attractive to American companies," said Kevin Callwood, vice president of the U.S. government-run Overseas Private Investment Corporation (OPIC), which along with the U.S. Agency for International Development sponsored the visit, with stops in Gambia, Cote d'Ivoire and Ghana as well as Senegal. The corporation, which promotes foreign investment by U.S. firms and insures investors against politically caused loss, has organized similar tours to other parts of the world. But Callwood said this trip, with over 40 companies taking part, is "the largest investment mission OPIC has ever put together."

Companies represented on the trip are involved in mining, marketing, construction, agribusiness, and finance. Several are minority-owned companies eager to expand in Africa. Two of the largest participants are telecommunications firms, Comsat and Bell Atlantic, looking for opportunities created by the privatization of many African telephone companies and by the growing demand for voice, data and cellular services.

"We were impressed by the improving climate for private investment everywhere we went," said Eugene Elrod, a Washington attorney who represents the Houston-based Tarpon Resources, which is planning to invest in gold mining ventures in Ghana and several other countries. "There are lots of opportunities, and competition is not nearly so intense as in more developed areas of the world," he said.

Although political change has swept Africa at a remarkable pace this year, news of the changes has been overshadowed by events in Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union. But Daniel Montana, a California investment banker with extensive experience in the former Communist bloc, said Africa offers more immediate prospects for profitable investments. "Everything is in place -- a legal system, basic transportation and communication," said Montana, chief executive of VTN Corporation of Los Angeles. This infrastructure will not be ready in most of Eastern Europe or the Soviet Union for five to 10 years, he estimated.

The 1980s was a period of severe economic downturn in Africa caused by deteriorating trade terms, falling commodity prices, and failed economic policies. As a result, U.S. investment in all African countries dropped to $ 4.7billion last year, after a peak of $ 6.8 billion in 1982.

"Companies lost interest in Africa," said Robert Tubman, general manager for Africa at Federal Express, a participant in the OPIC/AID investment mission. "Lack of accountability on the part of the politicians and arbitrary actions to stifle business by governments meant it just wasn't profitable to operate here," he said. But democratization is bringing the companies back. Responding to the demands of its American corporate clientele, Federal Express expanded its operations to 25 countries earlier this year and is adding 23 more by January 1, Tubman said.

The political changes have been accompanied by sweeping economic reforms, instituted by over 30 governments in conjunction with the International Monetary Fund and World Bank. The new measures, in which the private sector is given a greatly expanded role, are designed to promote the recovery of African economies and restore the confidence of outside investors and donor governments and agencies.

"We are spreading the word that the Africa you once knew is not Africa now," said Evelyn K. Mungai, a Kenyan business woman and member of the African Business Roundtable, a continent-wide group of 60 top business leaders which convened here last week to meet with the OPIC mission. With the elimination of much "cumbersome bureaucracy" and of corruption in many countries, Mungai said, "we are finding a lot of Americans are interested in coming back -- or coming here for the first time."

The increased American attention is heartily welcomed by Babacar Ndiaye, president of the African Development Bank and a leading African economic spokesman, who founded the business roundtable in 1987, based on the belief that the private sector is the best way to sustain development in Africa. Along with official aid, foreign investment is "absolutely crucial for consolidating democracy," Ndiaye said in an interview. "As in Eastern Europe, if these experiments are not to fail, it is necessary to inject sufficient resources into places where change is taking place," he said.

During a visit to the U.S. last month, Ndiaye made the case for investing in Africa in meetings with top American business leaders and in addresses at the New York Stock Exchange and the Council on Foreign Relations. "Wide-ranging business opportunities exist all across the continent," Ndiaye told a well-attended luncheon at the stock exchange.

Although the atmosphere for doing business in Africa has improved greatly, problems remain. Elrod, a partner in the Washington law firm Sidney and Austin, said high start-up costs remain a deterrent to investors, particularly when lingering bureaucratic obstacles create delays and uncertainties.

As an example of such difficulties, Federal Express cites its efforts to get landing rights for its planes, which have been blocked by protectionist rules designed to aid African-owned airlines. As a result, Africa is the only continent where the company does not make deliveries in its own aircraft and where -- as a result -- service is somewhat slower than in other parts of the world.

Despite the problems, Africa is "catching on" with many American investors, said Alison Rosenberg, deputy assistant secretary of State for Africa. "Even though it is very far away and relatively unknown, the news is spreading that you can do business in Africa," she said.


LOAD-DATE: December 18, 1991


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1991 AllAfrica, Inc.


152 of 211 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 23, 1991 / January 6, 1992


ETHIOPIA AND ERITREA PURSUE AMICABLY DIVERBENT PATHS TO DEMOCRACY


SECTION: HORN OF AFRICA


LENGTH: 1269 words


Addis Ababa -- It was neither free elections nor a free market that finally toppled the 17-year old dictatorship of Mengistu Haile Mariam in Ethiopia last May. Instead, it was the superiority of popular guerrilla movements over what was Africa's largest, but most fragile army.

Just days after Mengistu's flight to exile in Harare, Zimbabwe, the Ethiopian Peoples Revolutionary Democratic Front (EPRDF) and the Eritrean Peoples Liberation Front (EPLF) marched into their respective capitals at Addis Ababa in Ethiopia and Asmara in the territory of Eritrea, which has been fighting for independence from the Ethiopian government. Thus began two differing experiments in what, given current trends, falls under the rubric of "democratizations." 

At talks brokered by the U.S. government in London last May, the EPRDF committed itself to a national conference to form a transitional government. In July, some 25 political and professional organizations gathered in Addis Ababa and endorsed the country's new National Charter. The document, a sort of road map for the two-year transitional period, establishes a Cabinet and Council of Representatives, endorsed the UN Declaration of Human Rights and set forth a commitment to national and regional elections within a specific timeframe.

The Charter also decrees what might be considered the ultimate expression of democracy, specifically, that all "nations and nationalities" in Ethiopia should be granted the right to self-determination, up to and including independence. The resolution has had the greatest immediate impact upon the Red Sea territory of Eritrea. With the 30-year war now officially ended, Eritrea is governed by a provisional government of the EPLF which operates independent of the Transitional Government in Ethiopia. According to the Charter, an internationally-supervised referendum -- offering Eritrea's four million people a vote on independence -- will be held within two years; in the interim, Assab -- on the Eritrean coast -- is a free port for Ethiopia, which has no other access to the sea.

The Charter's resolution on self-determination also means -- in theory -- the end of domination of one nationality by another, a significant departure from Ethiopia's history. In practice, the resolution is already having significant impact: the internal borders of the country are being re-drawn; for the first time people are speaking their mother tongues in public; and many people are exhibiting pride in identities that have been suppressed for decades.

Bringing Ethiopia's national contradictions out of the closet also poses some serious threats to the country, however, as old animosities die slowly and some -- predominantly the urban Amhara elite -- appear disinclined to give up the reigns of power. At the same time, Ethiopia's ever-growing number of national movements represent varying degrees of political development; in much of the north, for example, alternative social and political structures were in place by the time the center collapsed last spring. Many movements in the south, however, have not yet completed the process of "liberation" and are thus vying, militarily, for territory. Most significantly, given the strength of national sentiment, the unity of Ethiopia (excluding Eritrea) will depend upon the ability of the Transitional Government to reflect the aspirations of all Ethiopia's peoples and thus forge a new national identity.

A few years ago, the profound changes sweeping Ethiopia and Eritrea would have been referred to as "the cessations of hostilities," or perhaps, "the end of the war." Now they're referred to as "the emergence of democracy" and the "beginnings of good governance."

In the cases of Ethiopia and Eritrea, such terminology begs several questions, among them what "democracy" means to societies that have been systematically controlled ever since "Ethiopia" came into being. To donor governments, many of whom now maintain special funds for democracy and good governance, democracy means free elections, multiparty political systems, respect for human rights, a free press and economic liberalization. To varying degrees, each of these is in the cards for Ethiopia and for Eritrea.

But democracy here is a much broader concept, as it has meant confronting head-on the problems that have been traditionally suppressed by force. The outcome involves a radical transformation that goes far beyond recognition of individual political rights to include the redefinition of the country itself and the purposes of nationhood.

At the same time, "economic democracy" is also on the agenda, particularly in the eyes of the new government in Addis Ababa. Brought to power largely through the support of Ethiopia's poor peasant majority, the Transitional Government gives equity high priority. Traditional economic reform programs, however, often run counter to economic egalitarianism and foster the emergence of distinct economic classes.

While the World Bank and other major donors to Ethiopia are offering what is, in relative terms, a flexible package of assistance involving a $ 500 million "Economic Reconstruction and Rehabilitation Program," there is an emphasis on free markets and privatization. For its part, the Transitional Government favors a decentralization of power and the development of distribution and marketing systems that offer incentives to the peasant majority. At the same time, however, there is concern -- in a country characterized by a long-term dependency on international relief -- that structural adjustment may have adverse effects upon the poor, while favoring a class which has, in the past, enjoyed top status.

Although democratization is widely perceived in almost all quarters as a positive move for Ethiopia, it is not a panacea and it also, in some cases, is posing problems of its own. Balancing the diverse political views in the Council means that national policy-making requires weeks -- and sometimes months -- of deliberation, despite the fact that the economy is in need of swift and decisive action and other decisions are equally urgent.

While the Transitional Government has cut military spending by well over 60%, it has seen few budgetary gains and must contend with the needs of over 25,000 de-mobilized soldiers. It has yet to receive the $ 150 million pledged by donors to rehabilitate the former troops. Security conditions in the south of the country remain poor.

As elsewhere in Africa, everyone is using the same language, but not everyone is talking about the same thing. Democracy in Ethiopia has meant the emergence of well over 40 political movements. By contrast, the Eritreans are emphasizing the upcoming independence referendum as a primary manifestation of democracy, and are not likely to encourage the emergence of a multiparty system until after the national vote in 1993.

The Addis Ababa government argues that political success in Ethiopia requires the immediate granting of full political rights and freedoms throughout the country. The Provisional Government in Eritrea, on the other hand, operates from a belief that in a country without any experience of freedom, democracy must be guided in order to prevent its abuses.

The challenge to the international community is to recognize that both governments may be pursuing paths to greater popular participation. For if democratization is to bring real change to Africa's poorest region, it must be democratically defined -- that is, as the saying goes, be by and for the people.

--Gayle Smith


LOAD-DATE: January 14, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1991 AllAfrica, Inc.


153 of 211 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 23, 1991 / January 6, 1992


MOBUTU NAMED IN NEW YORK MONEY SCHEME


LENGTH: 936 words


New York -- President Mobutu Sese Seko of Zaire is a figure in criminal conspiracies to launder millions of illicit U.S. dollars, according to a tape recording the FBI made secretly during an undercover sting operation in New York City.

The allegations come at a time when the U.S. government is under increasing pressure to cut ties with Mobutu and support the forces pressing for democratic change in Zaire.

The FBI investigation that led to Mobutu began in July 1986, when Federal agents received information that a United Nations ambassador, Lloydstone Jacobs of Antigua, along with several associates, was involved in a wide variety of criminal activities, ranging from money-laundering to bank fraud, advance fee schemes, and the sale of counterfeit or stolen checks, stocks and bonds, according to sworn testimony by Special Agent Jack F. Camanella in the U.S. District Court in Manhattan.

Allegations that President Mobutu was involved in money laundering activities were found in an examination of thousands of pages of testimony, legal papers and government exhibits filed in the Federal money-laundering case against New York State Senator Andrew Jenkins. In the Jenkins case, the government charged the then-senator with conspiring to launder money through Zaire. 

This is the first known instance of an allegation of this type against Mobutu. The president is assumed to have accumulated his huge fortune by siphoning revenues from the sales of his country's extensive natural resources, by demanding kickbacks from people doing business in Zaire, and by diverting foreign aid funds to his own accounts.

Based on information supplied by an informant as well as victims of the ambassador's alleged criminal activities, the FBI initiated an undercover investigation of the diplomat and his associates. They dubbed the case Operation Short Sell, in a humorous reference to the Wall Street trading practice known as selling short -- which means, in essence, to sell securities that the seller doesn't own, based on the expectation that the stock price will drop, yielding a profit on the difference.

As part of the FBI's investigation, Special Agent David Manicus assumed the guise of "Dan Garth," a criminal who needed millions of dollars of tainted money cleaned up. Agent Manicus made contact with the ambassador's associates, and once he gained their confidence, gently pressed to meet as many people involved in the group's criminal activities as possible.

One of the people Manicus was introduced to, according to court records, was a criminal named Louie Moore -- a fast talker who claimed to be a Hollywood producer with numerous celebrity contacts. Snared by the FBI sting, Moore pled guilty to two charges of conspiring to sell stolen travelers checks and counterfeit treasury checks. In May 1987, facing a potentially long jail term, Moore also agreed to become an informer.

He introduced Manicus to more than a dozen of his criminal colleagues, including Senator Andrew Jenkins, the testimony says. Moore identified the senator as a man who could launder big money.

Jenkins was a man who apparently had everything going for him. Tall, handsome, with an athletic build, he was a respected elected official. As a liberal Democrat, he had championed minority rights as well as the interests of the constituents in his St. Albans district in the Queens section of New York City.

On June 5, 1987, Moore introduced the FBI's undercover agent to Senator Jenkins. In the first meeting, the agent, posing again as Dan Garth, told the senator that he had money he needed laundered. Jenkins mentioned several ways the money could be cleaned up. One of the ways, Jenkins said, would be through his bank, the Afro-American Development Bank in Kinshasa, Zaire.

In a later discussion with Moore about the illegal nature of the funds Jenkins agreed to launder, the senator was taped as saying: "As long as it looks like business, I don't have any obligation to see where the money is coming from."

He also explained to Manicus, the undercover agent, that he smuggles money in and out of Zaire by diplomatic pouch, according to transcripts of the conversations filed in the senator's court case.

Agent Manicus agreed to pay Jenkins $ 150,000 in cash to get the operation going. Speaking into the agent's hidden microphone, the senator was recorded as saying that part of the money would go towards bribing high-level Zairean officials: "The secretary of state gets $ 59,000. My partner gets $ 40,000. The secretary of state is the brother-in-law of the president of the country."

Jenkins indicated that for the money-laundering to proceed, both the secretary of state and the president of Zaire would need to be paid off. Firms with legitimate interests in Zaire have confirmed that the president routinely requires a cut of any major business or fiscal operation. Similar charges against Panamanian dictator Manuel Noriega resulted in a U.S. indictment, after he was deposed by U.S. forces in Panama.

Jenkins lost his senate seat in 1990 when he was convicted on two of the government's charges against him -- accepting a deposit without being registered as a U.S. bank and the use of a telephone in furtherance of a crime. His conviction was upheld on appeal, and the former senator, who maintains his innocence, has said through his attorney that he will appeal to the Supreme Court.

Zaire officials have not commented on the testimony that Mobutu and his top aides were cooperating with international criminal activities.

-- Michael D. McNickle


LOAD-DATE: January 14, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1991 AllAfrica, Inc.


154 of 211 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 23, 1991 / January 6, 1992


WAITING FOR MOBUTU


SECTION: ZAIRE


LENGTH: 1194 words


Washington, DC -- When President Mobutu Sese Seko's term in office formally expired on December 4th, Zaire watchers were braced for trouble. With opposition to his 26-year rule escalating, the U.S. government prepared a contingency response.

After unpaid army troops mutinied in late September and joined civilians in a looting spree, fears of bloody civil strife in Zaire grew. At least 250 people are estimated to have died in the September rioting, with shortages of food and medicine threatening its 35 million people. 

In November, CIA analysts warned the administration that the likelihood of renewed violence increases as remaining stocks of essential goods are exhausted.

Correctly anticipating that the Zaire leader would cling to power after his presidential term expired, the State Department had prepared press guidance for possible issuance in Washington and Kinshasa, the Zaire capital, noting that "many Zaireans are questioning the constitutional legality" of Mobutu extending his tenure. "While we are aware of the various arguments, it is the Zaireans themselves who must render judgment on the matter," the guidance states.

A tougher statement, declaring U.S. non-recognition of the term extension, was drafted but never cleared for release, according to two administration sources who asked not to be identified. The sources say private messages have been sent, urging Mobutu to allow an opposition-led government to assume control over all aspects of the country's administration.

On December 5th, with military forces on alert, Mobutu made his announcement that he would remain in office, pending an election in which he plans to be a candidate.

The fact that Zaire has remained relatively calm, despite fears to the contrary, has given the U.S. more time to decide how to respond. "If there had been a lot of killing," one official said, "we would have had to react."

The Belgian and French governments, who after evacuating their citizens from the country have withdrawn and refused further dealings with Mobutu, have pressed for a firmer U.S. stance, diplomats say. In an interview published on October 28 in the Paris daily Liberation, Mobutu responded to a question about pressure from the U.S., Belgium and France, following a meeting of the three governments in Brussels, by claiming "it was France and Belgium that were expressing that desire." The U.S. representative "tapped his fingers on the table" and "was not in agreement with the other two," Mobutu said.

Mobutu's perception of an enduring American lifeline is contributing to his refusal to relinquish power, in the view of critics of administration policy. "Why does our government continue to support a man who pathologically clings to power for the benefit of his entourage and himself and to the detriment of his long-suffering people," says Dr. William Close, an American physician who served for 16 years as Mobutu's personal doctor. "The longer Mobutu remains, the more brutality and repression and human misery will spread," he says.

The Zaire leader has a long record of support for American policies, including providing a base for covert interventions in Angola and other African countries and strongly supporting the Gulf War. He has visited the White House on numerous occasions and has known President George Bush since 1972.

But with the end of the Cold War and the sweep of democracy across Africa, the administration is facing new demands to cut the old ties. "It is precisely because the U.S. has funded and tolerated this regime in the past that we now have an obligation, in my view, to stanch the chaos and internecine bloodshed," David Boren, the Oklahoma Democrat who chairs the Senate Select Committee on Intelligence, said in a letter last month to Brent Scowcroft, the national security adviser at the White House.

Three Republican Senators -- Nancy Landon Kassebaum (R-KS), Richard Lugar (R-IN), and Alan K. Simpson (R-WY) -- sent a similar appeal to Scowcroft, asking for a "more active and more visible U.S. role," and Kassebaum has pressed senior officials make a break with Mobutu.

Paul Simon, an Illinois Democrat and chairman of the Senate Africa subcommittee, convened hearings, held consultations with top administration officials, and sent a letter to President George Bush decrying "the apparent lack of a strong diplomatic effort to promote democracy" in Zaire.

The House of Representatives in a November resolution urged administration action and called on Mobutu "to step down and permit the transitional government to return the country to democratic rule."

Since the army mutiny in September, William Close has been peppering officials in Washington with phone calls and letters, urging swift action to avoid greater suffering and civil war. He has had a letter to the editor published in the Washington Post and an op-ed piece in the New York Times, both making the case that the administration needs to cut ties with Mobutu.
