Nancy Warlick, who spent 16 of the last 26 years in Zaire as a Presbyterian missionary, is devoting most of her time and energy to lobbying for a change in U.S. policy. After being evacuated with her husband, son, and about 3,000 other Americans in September, she testified before Senator Simon's subcommittee, organized a petition from other missionaries and a letter from her denomination, and called Congressional and administration offices pressing for action.

Warlick and Close reject administration assertions that Mobutu's potential successors might not be up to the task of running the strategically placed nation, which is rich in natural resources. "In the first place, I don't think that is true," Warlick said. "But what business is it of ours -- it's up to the Zaire people to choose their leader."

Close says the opposition coalition known as Union Sacre (Sacred Union) has behaved responsibly during the current crisis. The day after Mobutu announced his intention to remain in office, Union Sacre called a stay-home strike, rather than sending people into the streets where clashes with Mobutu's well-armed troops could have resulted in a massacre. "I am afraid that the upper levels of our government are not going to react until some terrible crisis erupts," Close says.

Nancy Warlick says she was commissioned by the people she left behind in Zaire to plead their case. "So many friends said to me as we left, Tyou go back and tell the people in Washington to let us proceed with the democratic process,'" she says. "So that's why I'm here."

Days before the expiration of Mobutu's term, Warlick heard from White House staffers that what she understood was to be a tough statement on Mobutu would be issued. "They said it would be the one I had been asking for -- cutting ties with Mobutu publicly and immediately," she says.

When the White State failed to make any pronouncement at all, Warlick renewed her lobbying campaign. "Let's make the statement that we have disassociated ourselves from Mobutu," she wrote in a December 17 appeal to Secretary of State James Baker III. "God help the people of Zaire if we do not.

n


LOAD-DATE: January 14, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1991 AllAfrica, Inc.


155 of 211 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 23, 1991 / January 6, 1992


ZIMBABWE


LENGTH: 99 words


The ruling Zimbabwe African National Union announced last June that it had abandoned its Marxist-Leninist ideology. However, President Robert Mugabe has renewed his pledge to create a one-party state, saying that a multiparty system will lead to "national destruction."

In elections last year, three opposition parties contested the polls and won three seats in the parliament.

The House of Assembly has abolished sections of the Bill of Rights, which among other things guaranteed freedom of political association.

Cindy Shiner was the chief contributor to this report.


LOAD-DATE: January 14, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1991 AllAfrica, Inc.


156 of 211 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 23, 1991 / January 6, 1992


ZAMBIA


LENGTH: 74 words


Frederick Chiluba ousted president Kenneth Kaunda in multiparty elections in October. Kaunda had been Zambia's only president since independence in 1976.

Pressure began building last year for an end to the one-party system. Kaunda initially resisted, but later called a referendum on multiparty rule. He then cancelled plans for the referendum and agreed to hold the country's first contested presidential vote in two decades.


LOAD-DATE: January 14, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1991 AllAfrica, Inc.


157 of 211 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 23, 1991 / January 6, 1992


ZAIRE


LENGTH: 247 words


One of Africa's most corrupt and durable dictators maneuvered to stay in power during 1991, as he saw his control slipping. President Mobutu Sese Seko's third seven-year presidential term ended December 4, but he refused to step down, despite widespread unrest and the opposition's move to form a rival government. 

Mobutu, who came to power with CIA backing in 1965, has said he will remain in office until elections can be scheduled, but has given no date for the polls.

Democracy protests led to a national conference in August, but it collapsed amid opposition claims that Mobutu had rigged the proceedings to ensure his survival. In September, disgruntled army units revolted and looted cities, leaving 250 people dead.

The following month, Mobutu reluctantly installed Etienne Tshisekedi, the opposition coalition's choice -- but sacked him 48 hours later in a clash over who would wield the real power, including control over finance and the military.

Mobutu then named Nguza Karl-I-Bond as prime minister, over opposition objections.

Nguza, a former Mobutu aide who once was on death row for treason -- before being pardoned by the president -- has been trying to win sufficient domestic and international backing to form a credible government. Meanwhile, the national conference resumed deliberations and on December 12 chose as its president Roman Catholic Archbishop Monsengwo Pasinya, who won 65% of the votes in defeating Mobutu's candidate.


LOAD-DATE: January 14, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1991 AllAfrica, Inc.


158 of 211 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 23, 1991 / January 6, 1992


WESTERN SAHARA


LENGTH: 156 words


On September 6, 1991, the Polisario Front independence movement and the government of Morocco began observing a United Nations-sponsored cease-fire in the former Spanish colony. Polisario launched its fight against Spain in 1972, but found itself battling Morocco's attempt to annex the territory when Spain pulled out the following year. 

The peace plan projected internationally-supervised elections in January, but disagreements over procedures have stalled the process. Morocco remains in control of the territory and strictly limits access to it. Although a limited number of UN personnel arrived in the territory before the year's end, none of the parties to the agreement would speculate on when the next steps towards elections might be taken.

A British newspaper, the Independent, reported in November that Morocco has moved tens of thousands of people into the territory, in violation of the peace agreement.


LOAD-DATE: January 14, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1991 AllAfrica, Inc.


159 of 211 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 23, 1991 / January 6, 1992


UGANDA


LENGTH: 106 words


President Yoweri Museveni promised after he came to power in 1986 to restore civilian rule by January 1990. But Parliament in 1989 extended his tenure by another five years, until 1995.

Museveni honored his promise to hold free general elections within four years of coming to power, but political parties were prohibited from actively campaigning on party platforms.

In October, a member of Parliament called for a referendum to decide whether the country should turn to political pluralism immediately, a proposal widely covered in the press. In November, the government proposed a law to control the mass media.


LOAD-DATE: January 14, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1991 AllAfrica, Inc.


160 of 211 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 23, 1991 / January 6, 1992


TUNISIA


LENGTH: 84 words


President Zine al-Abidine Ben Ali has vowed to put the country on the road to democracy, and in 1989 he legalized political pluralism and liberalized press freedom. After seizing power from an aging strongman in 1987, he freed thousands of political prisoners, most of them Islamic militants who had been detained under the former government.

However, Ben Ali has kept a tight control on the growth of Islamic fundamentalism and refuses to legalize the main Islamic opposition party, an-Nahda.


LOAD-DATE: January 14, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1991 AllAfrica, Inc.


161 of 211 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 23, 1991 / January 6, 1992


TOGO


LENGTH: 154 words


After a year of unprecedented turmoil, ongoing instability has raised suspicions that President Gnassingbe Eyadema, who staged post-independence Africa's first coup in 1964, may be trying a new approach to power grabbing.

In early December, troops loyal to the president made their third effort in three months to unseat Prime Minister Joseph Koffigoh. Since the attack, during which Koffigoh was briefly abducted, the prime minister has been trying to broker a deal between Eyadema and opposition trade unions and political groups that will enable a transitional government to rule until elections planned for next June.

Koffigoh was selected in August by a national conference that removed most of Eyadema's authority. The conference resulted from months of pro-democracy protests led by a coalition of human rights and political groups demanding an end to the president's 24-year authoritarian rule.


LOAD-DATE: January 14, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1991 AllAfrica, Inc.


162 of 211 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 23, 1991 / January 6, 1992


TANZANIA


LENGTH: 173 words


Following an endorsement of multiple poltical parties by former President Julius Nyerere last month, Tanzania may be moving ahead with legislative changes ending one-party rule. Nyerere, who stepped down voluntarily in 1985 from the presidency and last year from the chairmanship of the ruling Chama cha Mapinduzi party, said in a November interview with Radio Tanzania that additional parties should be allowed, although not as many as 30 as has happened in other African countries. 

President Ali Hassan Mwinyi, who succeeded Nyerere and won relection last year in an uncontested poll, has allowed discussion on multiparty democracy and appointed a presidential commission to solicit public opinion on pluralism. He is expected to legalize the formation of new parties when the commission completes it work in early 1992.

Two opposition parties have already been announced, but a rally called by opposition groups in late-November to celebrate the election of Zambian President Frederick Chiluba was barred by police.


LOAD-DATE: January 14, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1991 AllAfrica, Inc.


163 of 211 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 23, 1991 / January 6, 1992


SWAZILAND


LENGTH: 66 words


Political parties and political meetings have been banned in Swaziland since 1973, when King Sobhuza suspended the constitution on grounds that it was unsuited to the Swazi way of life.

In August, three political activists were charged with holding an illegal political meeting.

King Mswati III, in power since 1986, said in April he had no plans to return to a multiparty system.


LOAD-DATE: January 14, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1991 AllAfrica, Inc.


164 of 211 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 23, 1991 / January 6, 1992


SUDAN


LENGTH: 86 words


President Omar Hassan Ahmad Al-Bashir, who seized power in a 1989 coup, has banned political parties, saying multiparty politics breed ethnic conflict. 

Once he seized power, he suspended the constitution, dissolved parliament, prohibited political parties and trade unions and imposed an indefinite overnight curfew. Opposition groups remain in exile.

In November, Al-Bashir's Islamic fundamentalist regime ordered women in the civil service and in schools and universities to wear Islamic dress.


LOAD-DATE: January 14, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1991 AllAfrica, Inc.


165 of 211 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 23, 1991 / January 6, 1992


SOUTH AFRICA


LENGTH: 93 words


Long-anticipated negotiations opened December 20 between the white government of President Frederik de Klerk and black opponents on a constitution that is to grant equal voting rights to the country's black majority. 

The talks are aimed at fashioning a multiracial democracy to end centuries of conflict. Earlier this year Parliament abolished apartheid laws.

This month, the first 120 exiles of an estimated 24,000 expected to return to South Africa under the auspices of the U.N. High Commissioner for Refugees arrived in South Africa.


LOAD-DATE: January 14, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1991 AllAfrica, Inc.


166 of 211 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 23, 1991 / January 6, 1992


SOMALIA


LENGTH: 113 words


Somali National Movement (SNM) guerrillas took control in northern Somalia in January 1991, ousting the forces of former dictator Mohamed Siad Barre after a decade of war. 

In May, northern Somalia, which calls itself Somaliland, seceded, reverting to pre-1960 colonial borders and achieving relative peace.

But the capital, Mogadishu, has been devastated by rival factions fighting for power and tens of thousands of people have been killed. President Ali Mahdi Mohamed and General Mohamed Aidid Farrah, chairman of the ruling United Somali Congress, remained locked in a power struggle throughout the year.

Siad Barre is believed to be holed up in the south.


LOAD-DATE: January 14, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1991 AllAfrica, Inc.


167 of 211 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 23, 1991 / January 6, 1992


SIERRA LEONE


LENGTH: 76 words


In December, the opposition called for a coalition government of national unity to run the country, in the face of a nine-month-old invasion by rebels based in neighboring Liberia.

Voters overwhelmingly approved a return to political pluralism in a referendum last August.

Two months later, President Joseph Saidu Momoh, who came to power in 1986, legalized opposition parties, ending the 13-year monopoly by the ruling All-People's Congress.


LOAD-DATE: January 14, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1991 AllAfrica, Inc.


168 of 211 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 23, 1991 / January 6, 1992


SEYCHELLES


LENGTH: 131 words


Buckling to persistent demands for a pluralist system, President Albert Rene said this month that the Indian Ocean island nation would adopt a multiparty system.

Meanwhile, Sir James Mancham, who was ousted from power in a 1977 coup that ushered Albert Rene into the presidency, said he planned to return to the Seychelles and run for president in future elections. 

Rene has given no date for the polls, but he said the one-party constitution would be modified to allow registration of political parties.

In June, Rene had promised to step down if voters chose a multiparty system in a proposed referendum on the nation's political future. In October, he said exiles could return to the Seychelles, which had been a multiparty democracy at independence in 1976.


LOAD-DATE: January 14, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1991 AllAfrica, Inc.


169 of 211 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 23, 1991 / January 6, 1992


SENEGAL


LENGTH: 182 words


Although Senegal has had a multiparty system since its independence from France in 1960, critics of President Abdou Diouf, who came to power 10 years ago, accuse him of heading a one-party state with a permanent opposition.

The opposition accused Diouf of winning the 1988 elections through fraud. Since then, the president has promised a reformed voter registration plan, proportional representation in the legislature and free access to the media.

In May, Diouf named to the newly recreated post of prime minister Habib Thiam, who held the job in the early 1980s. The president also brought several opposition figures into his Cabinet, most importantly Abdoulaye Wade, leader of the Senegalese Democratic Party (PDS), who has served time in prison for his political activities. Several of the smaller opposition groups are considering a merger to strengthen their position prior to the 1993 elections.

A peace agreement was signed this year with a secessionist movement in southern Casamance, a province separated from the nest of Senegal by the small nation of Gambia.


LOAD-DATE: January 14, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1991 AllAfrica, Inc.


170 of 211 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 23, 1991 / January 6, 1992


SAO TOME AND PRINCIPE


LENGTH: 40 words


The government of President Miguel Trovoada came to power in April after elections in March, completing the country's formal transition to democracy.

The island nation held its first multiparty legislative elections in January.


LOAD-DATE: January 14, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1991 AllAfrica, Inc.


171 of 211 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 23, 1991 / January 6, 1992


RWANDA


LENGTH: 182 words


The first opposition demonstration took place in Rwanda in November, called by three opposition parties which are pressing for a national conference.

The government of President Juvenal Habyarimana changed its constitution in June to introduce a multiparty system. A prime minister, designated in October, is working on forming an all-party transitional government.

Habyarimana, who seized power in a 1973 coup, says elections are to be held by late next year, but he has refused to hold a national conference.

Besides the potential political threat of opposition parties, Habyarimana's government has to contend with armed Rwandan refugees from Uganda who have been fighting for over a year to return home and seize power. A long-standing ethnic conflict between the majority Hutu and minority Tutsi peoples is at the root of the fighting. Thousands of Tutsis fled to Uganda and other neighboring countries in the early 1960s after the Hutus ended the Tutsi's 500-year grip on power.

Habyarimana has contended that his country cannot absorb all the Rwandan refugees.


LOAD-DATE: January 14, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1991 AllAfrica, Inc.


172 of 211 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 23, 1991 / January 6, 1992


NIGERIA


LENGTH: 218 words


Nigeria, Africa's most populous nation, voted in gubernatorial and legislative elections in 30 states on December 15 as part of the military government's planned transition to civilian rule.

The slightly right-of-center National Republican Convention won 16 governships to the 13 won by the moderately left-leaning Social Democratic Party. 

The vote in the 1991 contests was much larger than in the December 1989 local elections, when many Nigerians stayed home. One part of the preparation process was a national census in November, the first for Africa's most populous nation since 1973.The vote comes after two months of controversial primaries which saw both parties engage in widespread electoral fraud. Nigeria has known only two brief periods of civilian rule since independence from Britain 30 years ago.

President Ibrahim Babangida, who came to power in 1985, has said he wants to be Nigeria's last military ruler. The country is trying to implement a two-party system -- both parties were created by the government -- and presidential elections are to be held in late 1992. Babangida lifted the five-year ban on political activity in May 1989. After the gubernatorial elections, the government removed the prohibition against participation in elections by former politicians.


LOAD-DATE: January 14, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1991 AllAfrica, Inc.


173 of 211 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 23, 1991 / January 6, 1992


NIGER


LENGTH: 112 words


Widespread protests forced President Ali Sa bou to meet opponents in March to chart the country's transition to multiparty rule. At the same time the army withdrew from the ruling party as a prelude to the adoption of pluralist politics.

A national conference, first announced by President Ali Sa bou in 1990, finally took place in August to chart a path towards multiparty government after 17 years of military-led rule. Steady public protests, including unprecedented street marches by Muslim women, forced the government's hand. The conference removed all but ceremonial powers from Sa bou and set presidential and parliamentary elections for next year.


LOAD-DATE: January 14, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1991 AllAfrica, Inc.


174 of 211 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 23, 1991 / January 6, 1992


NAMIBIA


LENGTH: 166 words


Namibia, in its second year of independence from South Africa, is making plans for its first one-person, one-vote election for regional-level government next year.

The country's internationally supervised elections in October 1989 brought to power President Sam Nujoma, leader of the independence movement, Swapo (South West African People's Organization), which took office at independence in March 1990. 

Since then, the government has struggled to overcome the divisions produced by years of white rule and a major rich-poor gap that largely parallels racial lines. The Democratic Turnhalle Alliance, which won 21 seats in the 72-member national assembly, has accused Swapo of mismanaging the economy.

A Swapo party congress, the first full-fledged meeting the organization has held since its formation in exile in 1960, selected an enlarged central committee and drafted policy statements on a range of key issues during five days of lengthy deliberations in December.


LOAD-DATE: January 14, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1991 AllAfrica, Inc.


175 of 211 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 23, 1991 / January 6, 1992


MOZAMBIQUE


LENGTH: 149 words


The government of President Joaquim Chissano and the rebel movement known as Renamo signed an accord in October providing for the rebels to lay down their arms once a cease-fire ending their 16-year war is reached. The government said it would not introduce any new legislation or enforce existing laws that would contradict a final peace pact. A ninth round of talks convened in Rome in mid-December to try to reach final agreement on a cease-fire.

The ruling party has dropped its designation as Marxist and it announced in November 1990 that it would introduce a multiparty system.

Renamo wants elections postponed for at least two years after an accord on a cease-fire has been reached and new electoral laws are complete. The Mozambique government wants to schedule elections for next year. Meanwhile, Renamo has continued its savage attacks on civilian communities.


LOAD-DATE: January 14, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1991 AllAfrica, Inc.


176 of 211 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 23, 1991 / January 6, 1992


MOROCCO


LENGTH: 130 words


Africa's longest-reigning monarch, King Hassan II, has escaped assassination attempts, popular uprisings, attempted coups and economic riots. And he has managed to avoid a strong challenge from the Islamic fundamentalist movements that plague neighboring governments.

After coming to power in 1961, the king introduced a constitution that was ratified by popular referendum. It guaranteed freedom of speech, press and religion and created an elected, two-chamber legislature.

Morocco has vocal but ineffectual opposition parties. In addition, there have been sporadic anti-government riots, trade union demonstrations and protests against human rights abuses, including the torture of political prisoners.

However, all real power remains in Hassan's hands.


LOAD-DATE: January 14, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1991 AllAfrica, Inc.


177 of 211 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 23, 1991 / January 6, 1992


MAURITIUS


LENGTH: 92 words


Prime Minister Sir Aneerood Jugnauth announced in October that Queen Elizabeth will cease to be the country's head of state when the island becomes a republic in March 1992 -- the 24th anniversary of its independence from Britain. 

Last August, Jugnauth dissolved Parliament and announced that new elections would be held in September. The opposition Mauritius Labour Party said the polls were rigged and called for a new vote.

Mauritius has been an independent and sovereign state within the British Commonwealth since March 1968.


LOAD-DATE: January 14, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1991 AllAfrica, Inc.


178 of 211 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 23, 1991 / January 6, 1992


MAURITANIA


LENGTH: 98 words


The government suddenly announced last March that it would free all political prisoners in the country. President Maawiy Ould Sid'Ahmed Taya made the move following opposition unrest and strikes calling for his ouster.

After a referendum in July, the government legalized political opposition, guaranteed freedom of the press and committed itself to installing multiparty democracy by the end of the year.

However, elections are not expected to take place until sometime next year, and there are persistent charges that slavery remains a practice in several communities.


LOAD-DATE: January 14, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1991 AllAfrica, Inc.


179 of 211 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 23, 1991 / January 6, 1992


MALI


LENGTH: 112 words


Military president Moussa Traore was overthrown last March by military officers, ending his 22-year rule. A transitional civilian-military government took over. Amadou Toumani Toure formed a government with Soumana Sacko, a University of Pittsburgh-trained economist, who is prime minister.

The coup was prompted by strikes, protests and a violent military suppression of demonstrators in March which left up to 200 people dead. A national conference held in August adopted plans for presidential polls in February 1992, with a second round in March. A constitutional referendum was scheduled for January, along with municipal and legislative elections.


LOAD-DATE: January 14, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1991 AllAfrica, Inc.


180 of 211 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 23, 1991 / January 6, 1992


MALAWI


LENGTH: 109 words


In early December, "President for Life" Kamuzu Banda told parliament to make a final decision on one-party rule. The Malawi Congress Party, the country's sole legal party, voted unanimously in September to maintain its current monopoly on power.

Opposition is scattered and weak, but exiled opposition leaders recently formed an alliance and began stepping up calls for the introduction of a multiparty system.

Banda, who is believed to be between 92 and 100 years old, has ruled the country since independence 27 years ago.

In a rare sign of the government's softening, almost 100 political prisoners have been released this year.


LOAD-DATE: January 14, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1991 AllAfrica, Inc.


181 of 211 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 23, 1991 / January 6, 1992


MADAGASCAR


LENGTH: 139 words


A High State Authority has been installed to oversee a provisional government appointed in November by Prime Minister Guy Razanamasy. The authority, which has replaced the national assembly and supreme revolutionary council, will serve for 18 months while a constitution is drawn up for a referendum. The opposition coalition known as "Force Vives," or Active Forces, will hold about half the seats in Razanamasy's new transitional cabinet.

Since last June, there have been repeated nationwide general strikes and demands for the resignation of President Didier Ratsiraka. Hundreds of thousands of people took to the streets on numerous occasions.

Ratsiraka, who has ruled the country for 16 years, has refused to step down. He says he remains in office as the symbol of national unity and head of the armed forces.


LOAD-DATE: January 14, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1991 AllAfrica, Inc.


182 of 211 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 23, 1991 / January 6, 1992


LIBYA


LENGTH: 106 words


Libyan leader Muammar Qaddafi, shaken by anti-government riots in neighboring Algeria that forced political reforms, has begun to relax Libya's economic and political policies. 

In late 1990 and early this year there were outbreaks of fundamentalist-inspired unrest at Tripoli's Al Fatah University. There also have been increasingly outspoken political discussions at mosques during Friday prayer sessions, and slogans denouncing Qaddafi have appeared periodically on campus walls.

So far, however, there has been little demonstration of discontent by fundamentalists against Qaddafi, who seized power in a 1969 coup.


LOAD-DATE: January 14, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1991 AllAfrica, Inc.


183 of 211 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 23, 1991 / January 6, 1992


LIBERIA


LENGTH: 85 words


Rebel factions and an interim government led by university professor Amos Sawyer have signed an agreement to end two years of civil war and hold free national elections.

An invasion headed by rebel leader Charles Taylor in December 1989 led to the death by torture of President Samuel Doe, a coup leader accused of stealing 1985 multiparty elections.

The October accord, brokered by the 16-member Economic Community of West African States, calls for presidential elections to be held in mid-1992.


LOAD-DATE: January 14, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1991 AllAfrica, Inc.


184 of 211 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 23, 1991 / January 6, 1992


LESOTHO


LENGTH: 122 words


The leaders of this kingdom's ruling Military Council have promised to establish a democratic government next year and have appointed a constituent assembly to draft a new constitution. 

In February 1990, Major General Justin Lekhanya suspended King Moshoeshoe's executive and legislative powers following a disagreement over the Military Council's role. The following month, the king fled the country; his son, King Letsi III, was sworn in to replace him.

Lekhanya had promised that there would be a return to civilian rule by June 1992, and a program of privatization was introduced. In May of this year, Lekhanya was ousted in a bloodless coup led by Colonel Elias Ramaema, who established the military council.


LOAD-DATE: January 14, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1991 AllAfrica, Inc.


185 of 211 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 23, 1991 / January 6, 1992


KENYA


LENGTH: 150 words


President Daniel arap Moi yielded in December to demands from the country's pro-democracy movement that he allow opposition political parties to operate. Moi, who has been in power for 13 years, made the move one week after international donors decided to suspend aid to his scandal-ridden government. 

Parliament is expected to follow the ruling party's lead and enact legislation legalizing opposition parties, which have been banned since 1969.

Moi first showed signs of bending to internal and external pressures for political reforms in November when he fired one of his closest political allies - former cabinet minister Nicholas Biwott, who had long been accused of corruption by reformists. Biwott also had been named by witnesses as a prime suspect in the murder last year of foreign minister Robert Ouko. However, Biwott was released in December without being charged.


LOAD-DATE: January 14, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1991 AllAfrica, Inc.


186 of 211 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 23, 1991 / January 6, 1992


GUINEA-BISSAU


LENGTH: 75 words


The government of President Joao Bernardo Vieira implemented a series of new laws in November that allow press and trade union freedoms. The first opposition party was legalized the same month. At least two other opposition groups plan to contest the country's first free elections, expected in 1992.

Vieira, who came to power after a 1980 coup, is the last leader of Africa's former Portuguese colonies to move towards democracy.


LOAD-DATE: January 14, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1991 AllAfrica, Inc.


187 of 211 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 23, 1991 / January 6, 1992


GUINEA


LENGTH: 111 words


President Lansana Conte in October promised that legislative elections will be held next December and presidential elections in early 1993. A new constitution, approved by a referendum a year ago, adopted a multiparty system for the country. There was criticism of the drafting process, since the new document was written by a commission and released only two weeks before the referendum.

Until a new government is chosen, a civilian-dominated transitional committee is ruling the country, led by Conte, who came to power in a bloodless military coup in 1984. The official start-up date for opposition parties to begin operations is April 3, 1992.


LOAD-DATE: January 14, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1991 AllAfrica, Inc.


188 of 211 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 23, 1991 / January 6, 1992


GHANA


LENGTH: 126 words


A decade after the ouster of the last civilian government, Ghana is making preparations for parliamentary and presidential elections in 1992. A draft constitution, prepared by a committee of legal experts, has been under consideration by a consultative assembly which opened in August with representatives from civic organizations and regional assemblies. A constitutional referendum may precede elections next year.

Ghana's leader, Flt. Lt. Jerry Rawlings, who seized power in 1981, has been under pressure to return the country to elected government. His administration granted amnesty to exiled critics in July, but Amnesty International this month accused the government of using arbitrary detention to silence critics and opponents.


LOAD-DATE: January 14, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1991 AllAfrica, Inc.


189 of 211 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 23, 1991 / January 6, 1992


THE GAMBIA


LENGTH: 124 words


President Dawda Jawara, who made a surprise announcement in early December saying he would not be a candidate for reelection when his term expires next April, has reversed his decision to retire after 26 years at the helm. The 67-year-old leader became prime minister at independence in 1965 and president when Gambia became a republic five years later. He announced his decision to run in mid-December, after the central committee of the ruling People's Progressive Party unanimously re-nominated him for the post.

Gambia has always had a multiparty system, but the opposition has been largely ineffectual. Two Gambian opposition parties have petitioned for an independent electoral commission to run next year's elections.


LOAD-DATE: January 14, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1991 AllAfrica, Inc.


190 of 211 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 23, 1991 / January 6, 1992


GABON


LENGTH: 84 words


The government of President Omar Bongo held the country's first multiparty legislative elections in 22 years in October 1990. 

(The government had annulled the initial round of Gabon's multiparty elections, held in September 1990, after allegations of widespread fraud.)

The voting followed public protests and a national conference in March last year. Bongo, who came to power in 1987, agreed in April to end the one-party political system.

Presidential elections are slated for 1993.


LOAD-DATE: January 14, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1991 AllAfrica, Inc.


191 of 211 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 23, 1991 / January 6, 1992


ETHIOPIA


LENGTH: 121 words


Three decades of civil war came to an end in May, when rebels ousted president Mengistu Haile Mariam, who headed the military regime that had ruled the country since ousting Emperor Haile Selassie in 1974. 

An interim government came to power through a national conference in July. It is headed by Meles Zenawi, from the Tigre People's Liberation Front, which joined in a coalition with two other groups to oust Mengistu. Free elections are scheduled to be held in two years.

In the territory of Eritrea, the Eritrean People's Liberation Front set up a separate provisional government after the May takeover. The group has deferred a formal independence declaration until a referendum is held in two years.


LOAD-DATE: January 14, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1991 AllAfrica, Inc.


192 of 211 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 23, 1991 / January 6, 1992


EQUATORIAL GUINEA


LENGTH: 101 words


Voters went to the polls last month and approved a referendum on a new constitution that would allow multiparty elections for the first time in the former Spanish territory. In May, President Obiang Nguema Mbasogo's ruling Democratic Party voted to end 12 years of one-party rule. No timetable for the change was set.

The new constitution calls for a separation of powers between the presidency and government with Mbasogo giving up his position as head of government to a prime minister. In addition, it also grants amnesty to Mbasogo for actions before, during and after his presidency.


LOAD-DATE: January 14, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1991 AllAfrica, Inc.


193 of 211 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 23, 1991 / January 6, 1992


EGYPT


LENGTH: 127 words


President Hosni Mubarak has moved towards a more open society by permitting greater press freedom and political activism. But he has also said democracy will be administered in what he terms "doses." He said in August that he would allow the free formation of political parties once the economic situation had stabilized.

Last year, for the first time, judges were ordered to oversee election procedures and election rules were changed to permit independents to run. Nevertheless, the three main opposition parties boycotted the November 1990 general elections, called after a referendum approved the dissolution of parliament. The referendum followed a Supreme Court ruling that the legislative body had been elected unconstitutionally in 1987.


LOAD-DATE: January 14, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1991 AllAfrica, Inc.


194 of 211 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 23, 1991 / January 6, 1992


DJIBOUTI


LENGTH: 145 words


Members of the Afar ethnic group in northern Djibouti took up arms against the central government in November, claiming President Hassan Gouled Aptidon's rival Issa ethnic group was gradually taking over the country.

The rebels, called the Front for the Restoration of Unity and Democracy, are calling for a national conference. Opposition parties are officially outlawed, but the country maintains the tradition of prolific opposition parties which it began before independence.

Aptidon has ruled Djibouti since its independence from France in 1977. Shortly thereafter he imposed a one-party state. He has maintained power through elections which draw candidates only from a list approved by the governing party. The last elections were held in April 1987.

Djibouti maintains a tradition of prolific opposition parties, but they remain outlawed.


LOAD-DATE: January 14, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1991 AllAfrica, Inc.


195 of 211 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 23, 1991 / January 6, 1992


COTE D'IVOIRE


LENGTH: 123 words


Multiparty parliamentary elections in November 1990 ended 30 years of one-party rule. 

Last October, President Felix Houphouet-Boigny was reelected in the first contested presidential race since he came to power at independence from France in 1960.

The government had been forced to accept a multiparty system in May 1990, following a series of strikes and mass demonstrations.

More than 40 political parties and several dozen opposition newspapers now function in the country. The president's ruling Democratic Party of Cote d'Ivoire (PDCI) maintains firm control of the government, but there is uncertainty about the strength and cohesion of the party when Houphouet-Boigny, who is 86 years old, leaves the scene.


LOAD-DATE: January 14, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1991 AllAfrica, Inc.


196 of 211 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 23, 1991 / January 6, 1992


CONGO


LENGTH: 125 words


A three-month national conference ended in June, naming a transitional government and setting dates for elections. Amid often fractuous debate, conference delegates effectively stripped President Denis Sassou-Nguesso of most of his powers and named Andre Milongo, a former World Bank official, as prime minister. The move ended 30 years of one-party rule.

Protests in 1990 had forced Sassou-Nguesso, who took power in 1979, to drop Congo's official Marxist ideology. In January he named a new prime minister to head what he called a national unity government. Opposition parties became legal the same month.

Multiparty municipal elections are set for January 1991, national assembly polls for April and presidential elections June.


LOAD-DATE: January 14, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1991 AllAfrica, Inc.


197 of 211 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 23, 1991 / January 6, 1992


COMOROS


LENGTH: 81 words


A coup last August failed to unseat President Said Mohamed Djohar, who became president in March 1990 after the country's first elections since independence from France in 1975.

However, an opposition leader on Moheli, one of the islands forming the archipelago nation, said in November that his island might break away from the state if the central government did not hold a national conference.

Opposition leaders have claimed the 1990 presidential vote was rigged.


LOAD-DATE: January 14, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1991 AllAfrica, Inc.


198 of 211 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 23, 1991 / January 6, 1992


CHAD


LENGTH: 64 words


President Idriss Deby has promised to install a democratic government by September 1992. Last October he ratified a charter on political parties, banning those based on ethnic group or religion.

About a dozen informal parties have sprung up since Deby made the promise after ousting Hissene Habre -- who strongly resisted calls for democracy -- in a December 1990 coup.


LOAD-DATE: January 14, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1991 AllAfrica, Inc.


199 of 211 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 23, 1991 / January 6, 1992


CENTRAL AFRICAN REPUBLIC


LENGTH: 49 words


President Andre Kolingba lifted a ban on multiparty politics in April. Opposition parties met publicly for the first time in October.

Kolingba, who outlawed multi-partyism when he seized power in a 1981 coup, has promised that a national conference will be held early next year.


LOAD-DATE: January 14, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1991 AllAfrica, Inc.


200 of 211 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 23, 1991 / January 6, 1992


CAPE VERDE


LENGTH: 96 words


The African Party for the Independence of Cape Verde (PAICV) lost its 15-year grip on power when it suffered a crushing defeat in parliamentary and presidential elections in January and February of 1991, the first free elections in the archipelago.

The vote was also the first multiparty poll among Portugal's five former colonies, all of which had been ruled by leftist parties since independence in 1975.

The Movement for Democracy, which came to power in the early 1991 votes, also triumphed in mid-December local elections, winning in 10 of 14 municipalities.


LOAD-DATE: January 14, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1991 AllAfrica, Inc.


201 of 211 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 23, 1991 / January 6, 1992


CANARY ISLANDS


LENGTH: 107 words


The Canary archipelago, 60 miles off the coast of Western Sahara, has been ruled by Spain since the 15th century. The activities of an independence movement, which mounted dozens of terrorist bombings, peaked in the late 1970s. Efforts by the Organization of African Unity to support decolonization have also waned, in recognition of an apparent desire among islanders for greater autonomy under Spanish central control. Although many Canarians see Spain as the best hope for economic development on the overpopulated volcanic chain, there has continued to be widespread resentment over the continuing poverty of the islands.


LOAD-DATE: January 14, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1991 AllAfrica, Inc.


202 of 211 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 23, 1991 / January 6, 1992


CAMEROON


LENGTH: 183 words


The National Assembly approved a constitutional amendment providing for the formation of political parties in December of 1990, but public pressure for representative government continued to swell.

Beginning in May 1991, this former colony of both France and Britain was paralyzed by a pro-democracy strategy called "Operation Ghost Town" -- a nationwide campaign of strikes that closed most businesses. In November, the government and opposition agreed to entrust constitutional reforms to a 10-member committee. The opposition agreed to end the strikes and the government said it would lift its ban on public meetings.

President Paul Biya also has granted amnesty to political prisoners and revived the post of prime minister, but he continues to reject calls for a national conference.

Biya, who came to power in 1982, has moved legislative elections up from 1993 to February 1992. He has promised to appoint the prime minister from the majority group in the National Assembly following elections, and he says the new official will be in charge of forming a government.


LOAD-DATE: January 14, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1991 AllAfrica, Inc.


203 of 211 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 23, 1991 / January 6, 1992


BURUNDI


LENGTH: 106 words


President Pierre Buyoya has approached democratization slowly, but steadily.

In August 1990, Buyoya, who seized power in a bloodless coup in 1987, announced amnesty for political prisoners. A new National Unity Charter aimed at restoring democracy and ending the domination of one ethnic group over another was adopted last February after being approved in a referendum.

Late November clashes between security forces and insurgents, reflecting traditional ethnic tensions in the country, left an estimated 300 people dead. Although 80 percent of the population is of Hutu origin, the government is dominated by Tutsis.


LOAD-DATE: January 14, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1991 AllAfrica, Inc.


204 of 211 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 23, 1991 / January 6, 1992


BURKINA FASO


LENGTH: 146 words


President Blaise Compaore has promised a return to democracy for one of the world's poorest countries, but has resisted calls for a national conference.

Compaore, who seized power in a 1987 coup in which former president Thomas Sankara was killed, won elections held December 1 because he was the sole candidate and three-quarters of the population boycotted the polls. The opposition had planned to field six candidates.

Ten days after the vote, in separate still-unexplained attacks, a prominent opposition leader, Oumarou Clement Ouedraogo, a former top aide to Compaore, was killed by a grenade thrown at his car and another opposition leader was critically wounded by gunfire.

Legislative elections are scheduled for January 12. A new constitution, approved in a referendum in December 1990, sets a seven-year presidential term with a two-term limit.


LOAD-DATE: January 14, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1991 AllAfrica, Inc.


205 of 211 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 23, 1991 / January 6, 1992


BOTSWANA


LENGTH: 96 words


South Africa's northern neighbor has earned international applause as one of a handful of democracies on the continent. Multiparty elections have been held every five years since independence from Britain in 1966.

The ruling Botswana Democratic Party, which has held power throughout the period, won a landslide victory in the October 1989 elections, although some of the results were disputed.

Despite the country's relative stability, the government last November fired 150,000 government and public sector workers who had been on strike for higher wages.


LOAD-DATE: January 14, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1991 AllAfrica, Inc.


206 of 211 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 23, 1991 / January 6, 1992


BENIN


LENGTH: 101 words


The people of Benin were pioneers of Africa's pro-democracy movement, with widespread pro-democracy protests that forced then-president Mathieu Kerekou to end his one-party rule.

A national conference in 1989 stripped him of most of his authority after conference delegates appointed a caretaker government headed by Nicephore Soglo, a former World Bank official, as prime minister.

Kerekou, who seized power in a military coup in 1972, lost elections in April 1990 to Soglo, who became the first presidential candidate on the African mainland to defeat an incumbent in democratic elections.


LOAD-DATE: January 14, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1991 AllAfrica, Inc.


207 of 211 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 23, 1991 / January 6, 1992


ANGOLA


LENGTH: 109 words


After 16 years of civil war, the National Union for the Total Independence of Angola (Unita) and the government of President Jose Eduardo dos Santos signed a peace treaty in May 1991, opening the way to a multiparty system. 

Before the accord was signed, the government abandoned Marxist dogma, embraced free market reforms, committed itself to ending one-party rule and recognized the opposition. In September, Unita leader Jonas Savimbi, whose guerrilla war against the government was backed by South Africa and the United States, returned to Luanda, the capital.

Presidential elections are tentatively scheduled for next September.


LOAD-DATE: January 14, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1991 AllAfrica, Inc.


208 of 211 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 23, 1991 / January 6, 1992


ALGERIA


SECTION: THE CHANGING FACE OF AFRICA


LENGTH: 152 words


Algerians are preparing for their first free general elections since the country became a one-party state after independence from France in 1962.

Some 50 parties are expected to participate in the parliamentary vote, which was postponed in June after clashes between Moslem fundamentalists and security forces. President Chadli Bendjedid, in power since 1979, pledged to call presidential elections after the parliamentary polls, December 26 and January 16. Less than two weeks prior to the first round, the Islamic Salvation Front, the country's main opposition group, which had threatened a boycott, announced plans to take part in the contest.

Street riots in 1988 marked the beginning of open pressure for political reforms. A new constitution was approved by referendum in February 1989, guaranteeing freedom of expression and assembly, and the right to strike and form political parties.


LOAD-DATE: January 14, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1991 AllAfrica, Inc.


209 of 211 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 23, 1991 / January 6, 1992


DEMOCRACY, VARIOUSLY DEFINED, IS THE WORD OF THE DECADE


LENGTH: 542 words


"An election doesn't automatically create a democracy," said one African activist when asked about the status of reforms in his country. "There are elected leaders without accountability. And true democracy is not just political. It is also economic." 

Any attempt to classify countries as democratic or undemocratic, free or not free is tricky, although the exercise can be useful. The African Governance Program at the Carter Center of Emory University divides countries into democratic and authoritarian camps. It further designates some countries as "regimes in transition" with a strong, weak or ambiguous commitment to democracy and others as practicing "directed democracy" or exhibiting "contested sovereignty."

In a recent issue of the program's newsletter, editor Richard Joseph replied to a letter from political scientist Catherine Scott, who criticized the categories as simplistic for "equating elections with democracy in a formalistic way" and for ignoring the common exclusion of "women, the poor and other disenfranchised groups" from political life.

"We recognize the need to reflect deeper, and often contradictory, dynamics," said Joseph, promising to present a more complex methodology as it is developed.

The following brief look at Africa's 54 nations does not attempt to classify countries according to their systems of governance. Nor does it probe the definitions of democracy. It is, rather, a news round-up, meant to convey the variety and the pervasiveness of on-going political changes throughout the continent and its off-shore islands.

But as an arrangement of ink on paper, this summary cannot convey the drama of the African democracy movement. Behind every national conference, every new prime minister appointed, every election, there are real people who have flooded the streets in demonstrations too numerous to mention -- or stayed at home, leaving the streets empty, in observance of pro-democracy strikes.

Some of the leaders that have been deposed or had their power curtailed called themselves Marxist. Others embraced free enterprise. In the ways that were important to their citizens, however, most were indistinguishable. They shared a tendency towards authoritarian rule that enriched a small elite at the expense of the majority.

In their response to pressures for change, however, their paths have diverged. P. Anyang' Nyong'o, who heads the Nairobi-based African Association of Political Science, observes that among the most reluctant to democratize have been former British colonies, while "Afro-Marxist" regimes, including former Portuguese and French colonies, have shown more readiness to respond to popular demands.

The future of African countries is as uncertain as that of the former Soviet republics or the fledgling democracies of eastern Europe. Radical transformations sow the seeds of possible disaster as well as of progress. And Africa begins its climb towards political inclusiveness from the bottom rung of the economic ladder.

But the nations profiled here share a vast potential wealth and an infectious energy that is seeping across borders, however well guarded. No leader, anywhere on the continent, can expect to be exempt from the results.


LOAD-DATE: January 14, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1991 AllAfrica, Inc.


210 of 211 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 23, 1991 / January 6, 1992


ECONOMIC DEMOCRACY TOPS AFRICAN AGENDA AS POLITICAL REFORMS TAKE HOLD


SECTION: ECONOMY: AFRICA


LENGTH: 1647 words


Washington D.C. -- Africa's rapid moves towards democratization could be undermined by a continuing shortage of financial resources, according to leading experts on the continent's economy.

"People who are denouncing dictators and crying out for democratic rule, often at considerable risk, expect to see a change in their own living conditions in a reasonable period," says Babacar Ndiaye, president of the African Development Bank and a prominent economic spokesman. "As in Eastern Europe," Ndiaye says, "if these experiments in democracy are not to fail, it is necessary to inject sufficient resources into places where change is taking place." The bank president visited Washington and New York in November to raise awareness of Africa's needs.

President Nicephore Soglo of Benin, one of the first of the new generation of African leaders, agrees. "It is essential to support the democratization process if it is to become really rooted in our countries," he said during a conference on democracy, sponsored by the African-American Institute (AAI) in New York last month. 

Africa, with about a tenth of the world's population, receives about 30 percent of the development assistance dispensed by the wealthy industrial nations and the high-income oil-producing countries. But it remains the poorest continent by far, and its leaders are pressing their case for outside help to help surmount long-standing impediments to recovery and growth.

"We have two months arrears in salaries," says Congolese Prime Minister Andre Milongo, who visited Washington in early December seeking assistance for the transitional administration he has headed since July. Milongo says economic constraints threaten the country's progress towards full democracy. "We lack the resources to conduct our elections," he says.

"Africa faces the most difficult economic challenge in the world right now," says Edward V. K. Jaycox, vice president for Africa at the World Bank. "That is why Africa is at the top of our agenda."

The bank estimates that sub-Saharan Africa needs $ 19 billion in aid, loans and investment annually for the rest of this decade in order to reverse the decline in living standards that took place across the continent over the past decade. Average growth rates of five percent are the minimum needed to initiate significant increases in per capita income, according to Bank estimates. In addition, the bank says that $ 9 billion in debt relief will be required to offset the impact of the continent's crippling indebtedness. Even taking into account years of repayments and a number of recent debt forgiveness packages by creditors, high interest rates and loan reschedulings mean that Africa still owes more to donors than the amounts it has borrowed.

After a decade of declining living standards, the first glimmers of a turnaround appeared this year with the news that per capita incomes rose by about one percent in 1990, according to the African Development Bank. But the World Bank's annual report on the world debt situation, issued in December, says the progress many African countries have been making economically could be threatened "unless extraordinary action is taken to reduce the debt burden."

"The main challenge facing Africa is to make democratic institutions more sound and durable," says Ugandan Vice President Paul Ssemogerere, who also spoke at the AAI democracy conference. Although the "primary responsibility" for ensuring the success of the changes rests with Africans themselves, he said, "support for these democracies in their efforts to improve the well-being of their people is critical."

Before Africa can expect or truly benefit from outside aid, says the African Development Bank's Ndiaye, African governments must launch the first difficult steps -- and many already have done so. Paralleling the political transformations, most countries are engaged in painful economic reforms designed to reverse their economic downturn. These "structural adjustment programs," as they are known -- usually adopted under the auspices of the International Monetary Fund and World Bank with the objective of reducing mismanagement and waste and restoring international confidence -- generally entail massive budget cuts that reduce the provision of social services to the populations.

The reforms are harsh, Ndiaye concedes. "With structural adjustment, it is difficult for everyone right now, especially for those in the lowest incomes brackets," he says. "But these are necessary steps to take, and most people now recognize it."

The World Bank says the 20 "core countries" engaged in economic reform programs over the past several years experienced growth rates of four percent on average between 1988 and 1990, up from one percent from 1980 - 84 and twice that of "non-reforming countries."

Critics argue that structural adjustment programs, as currently designed, are worsening -- not bettering -- Africa's economic position. "There has yet to be one instance where these measures have improved the quality of life for local populations," the Development Group for Alternative Policies, a Washington, D.C.-based non-profit organization, argues in a recent analysis of structural adjustment in West Africa.

A position paper issued by a coalition of African non-government organizations earlier this year concludes: "The emphasis on export-led growth strategies, rationalization of public expenditures, and liberalization of prices and markets as prescribed by these programs have brought Africa closer to the brink of non-viability and chaos. As aid flows and other forms of external resource transfers dry up or come with heightened conditionality, Africa is sure to face an even greater crisis of resources in the upcoming decade."

Ndiaye concedes that despite the "first positive signs" of recovery in 1990 and the recent good harvests in many parts of the continent, the economic picture will probably not show an improvement this year. "There has been such a preoccupation with political change that economic activities have slowed in many places," he says. But he argues that after these changes are in place, "the prospects for vigorous growth will be there."

During contacts with American and European business leaders, Ndiaye has been soliciting private investment for Africa. He believes that better government economic policies will attract foreign capital and encourage local citizens "to bring their savings from the countryside into the banking system and to return the money that is now hiding in foreign bank accounts."

While it has been argued that democracies will have a harder time introducing the tough measures needed to eliminate waste and overspending, most experts see accountable government as a necessary precursor to economic growth. "It is evident from the history of the past thirty years that authoritarianism has stifled development," said P. Anyang' Nyong'o, secretary general of the African Association of Political Science, in a study of the democratization process in Africa.

"The existence of popular-based institutions is essential for sustaining democracy and for sustaining development," says Adebayo Adedeji, former executive secretary of the Economic Commission for Africa and the architect of the African alternative to structural adjustment, which advocates a more "humanized" approach to economic reforms.

After years of working closely with African governments -- including notoriously corrupt regimes and ruthless dictatorships -- the World Bank is being nudged by public demands within Africa, as well as growing international pressure, to give the issue of governance more weight in its decision making. Last month's meeting of donors to Kenya, chaired by the World Bank -- which ended with a decision to withhold new commitments of assistance pending implementation of political reforms and a crackdown on corruption -- was an example of how political pressures for change are now intertwined with economic assistance decisions.

The Bank also has adopted a newly fortified position on debt relief. "The debt relief policies in place are not adequate," says Ishrat Husain, chief economist of the African region at the Bank. The most far-ranging proposals adopted by the major donor nations are the "Trinidad Terms," proposed by British Prime Minister John Major in late 1990, when he was Chancellor of the Exchequer, calling for a write-off of about two-thirds of developing nations' debts.

Africa's indebtedness rose above $ 270 billion in 1990, including $174 billion for sub-Saharan Africa. The combined debt of the region's countries exceeds the annual Gross National Product by $ 18 billion. In contrast, Latin American external debt is equivalent to about 40% of its GNP.

If fully implemented, the "Trinidad terms" would provide sub-Saharan African countries with a maximum of $ 4 billion in reduced debt burden annually for the next several years. However, the U.S. has resisted some aspects of the relief proposal, which in any case falls short of Africa's urgent requirements.

Without $ 9 billion in debt relief, the World Bank says, Africa's recovery could suffer serious setbacks. The delay in resolving the debt crisis is diverting the energies of African policymakers "from the urgent task of reviving economic growth" and is discouraging domestic and foreign investors, Husain said in a press briefing this month.

Africa's entire debt needs to be forgiven, for the sake of children, James P. Grant, executive director of the United Nations Children's Fund (Unicef) said in releasing the Unicef annual State of the World's Children report for 1992.

Africa is spending more money on the small portion of interest its manages to pay, which is about one-third of what is due, than on health and education, he said. n


LOAD-DATE: January 14, 1992


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1991 AllAfrica, Inc.


211 of 211 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 23, 1991 / January 6, 1992


PEOPLE POWER: "UNSTOPPABLE"


LENGTH: 792 words


The breathtaking pace of political change in Africa has surpassed any predictions or expectations. Namibia's independence in March 1990 marked the explosion of a continent-wide democracy movement that is spreading -- in the words of former Nigerian head of state Olesegun Obasanjo -- "with a virulence that will be unstoppable." Almost every country has experienced some form of citizens' pressure for broader public participation in political and economic decision-making. Nearly two dozen authoritarian leaders have been overthrown or forced to share power.

Africa is experiencing a revolution as profound as the wave of independence that began to sweep the continent three decades ago. And the revolution is a mass popular event, enacted in the streets and fueled by years of frustration at the unfulfilled promises of nationhood. 

Scholars have begun to write about the protest movement as a quest for a "second independence," where African aspirations can be pursued with renewed vigor. Georges Nzongola-Ntalaja of Zaire, a Howard University political scientist, says that the people have been ahead of the pundits. "The concept of Tsecond independence' was developed, not by social scientists," he says, "but by ordinary people." For them, he says, "independence was meaningless without a better standard of living, greater civil liberties, and the promise of a better life for their children." Discontent over the corruption and violence of post-colonial rulers, Nzongola says, has inspired movements to achieve "a new and genuine independence."

The extent to which news from Africa is ignored by the U.S. press corps is as stunning as the events themselves. There has been scant attention or no mention at all in the major media of such dramatic developments as the daily pro-democracy demonstrations in Madagascar that brought hundreds of thousands of people into the streets; the arrival of a United Nations peacekeeping force in Western Sahara to supervise elections ending 16 years of war; or the military rebellion in Mali, where troops revolted against the killing of over 200 demonstrators and threw out the dictator who had ordered the crackdown.

In Belgium, press reports about a Zaire government massacre of dissident university students in 1990 forced the Belgian government to cut aid to its former colony. The Bush administration, on the other hand, faces little public pressure to adapt its policies to the changing African scene. Although the U.S. has pressed for democratic reforms in a number of African countries, it has failed to satisfy critics that it has done enough to encourage authoritarian rulers with longstanding U.S. ties to step aside.

U.S. officials argue that the American government is doing as much as is appropriate. "We have got to move away from this paternalism that we wear in the West that our system is best," says Deputy Assistant Secretary of State for Africa Leonard Robinson, when questioned about the U.S. role in Liberia, a country founded by freed American slaves that has been devastated by civil war. "Liberians," he says, "should take the responsibility for solving their own problems."

The problem with that stance, say the critics, is that the U.S. is widely seen as blocking change, when it fails to give the nudge to despots it has kept in power. In countries like Zaire or Morocco or Liberia, the critics say, the U.S. has lost much of the esteem it once enjoyed. "The Liberian people marched in Liberia and asked (former president Samuel) Doe to step down, placing themselves at severe risk," says Joyce Mends-Cole, a Liberian who works on women's issues for the United Nations. "Where were Doe's arms coming from? Most of the huge military arsenal came from the U.S. or was bought with U.S. aid."

Some Africans say the price of aid is too high and have pulled back from the process of seeking international support. The Six S Association, a rural peasant group based in Burkina Faso, is one of the fastest-growing organizations on the continent. With over 5,000 affiliate groups in Burkina Faso alone -- 60% of them headed by women -- Six S has spread to five nearby countries, taking along its message of self-reliance and grassroots democracy.

Whatever their approach, Africans face daunting challenges. Togolese lawyer Diyanama Ywassa welcomes the democratic changes in her country, but worries that public expectations have outpaced possibilities. "I fear that many people think democracy is a magic word, that with democracy everything is going to change," she says. "The long march to democracy is punctuated with difficulties."

Few would disagree. But whatever the pitfalls along the road, there is no doubt that the journey is underway. n


LOAD-DATE: January 14, 1992


LANGUAGE: English
